articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s judgment: blocking Andy Burnham would be a mistake | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Excluding a popular mayor would fracture Labour’s coalition and make Downing Street look fearful rather than authoritative
articles.summary: Labour risks fracturing its coalition and appearing fearful by blocking Manchester mayor Andy Burnham from running in a parliamentary by-election after Andrew Gwynne’s resignation. Sir Keir Starmer’s allies and the NEC are using procedural hurdles—costs, by-election fears, gender-balance rules—to bar a popular figure with rising favourability. Excluding Burnham undercuts Labour’s progressive credentials, weakens internal pluralism, and could drive him to run as an independent, weaponising his personal appeal. This move misreads voter mood amid stagnating wages, growth woes and the rise of the far right.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Syria’s crisis: Islamic State fighters are not the only concern  | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: As a lightning government offensive leaves the Kurdish-dominated SDF reeling, the political horizon needs attention as well as security
articles.summary: In just two weeks, President Ahmed al-Sharaa’s offensive has erased over a decade of Kurdish self-rule in northeast Syria, compelling the SDF to agree to dissolution in principle but not practice, and imperiling a fragile truce. Frustrated by integration delays, the US has shifted support from the SDF to Damascus, abandoning its former Kurdish partners. Meanwhile, tens of thousands of suspected IS members and families languish in dilapidated camps or are moved to Iraq, while Europe’s refusal to repatriate foreign nationals—and plans to return Syrian refugees—deepens the crisis. The Guardian urges inclusive politics, transitional justice and elections to secure a lasting peace.

articles.title: As the world finally punches back, was this the week Donald Trump went too far? | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: The US president took his bullying doctrine to Davos and hit a wall of opposition. If this creates a new western alliance against him, all to the good, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: At Davos Trump stunned allies by threatening to seize Greenland, belittling NATO troops and unveiling a self-styled “board of peace” that excludes traditional partners, exposing US unreliability. Europe’s united resistance forced his retreat, underscoring Steve Bannon’s “maximalist” strategy: push until stopped. Jonathan Freedland argues this rupture demands a new Western alliance – led by the EU, UK and Canada – with increased defence spending to reduce dependency on US protection, reshape UK-EU ties and forge a “third path” of institutions and rules beyond Trump’s whims. Its aim would be to defend Ukraine and Europe independently, in a decade-long shift away from US hegemony.

articles.title: The ‘good life’ in Australia is about access to the beach. This week’s shark attacks feel like the natural world is striking back | Brigid Delaney
articles.trailText: Four shark attacks in a matter of days is a sudden shock to humans, whose relationship with nature has long been out of balance
articles.summary: In four shark attacks over 48 hours in NSW this January, Sydney’s iconic beach culture is shaken as water lovers weigh familiar leisure against rare but rising shark bite incidents (averaging 27 annual bites, three fatal). The spate follows extreme natural events and underscores humans’ fragile balance with nature. While swim fatalities remain lower than kangaroo kills, fear runs high near sparkling waves once taken for granted. Writer Brigid Delaney, who cites personal near-misses, proposes real-time shark-risk alerts akin to weather or fire warnings. For many Sydneysiders, unrestricted ocean access defines the ‘good life’—but this summer it feels like Russian roulette.

articles.title: It’s Andy Burnham, the man who could be king. Will he, won’t he – are we really still watching this movie? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Many yearn and yearn for the Greater Manchester mayor to claim his Westminster crown. They should be careful what they wish for – as should he, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde argues that whispers of Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham’s return to Westminster mirror Johnny Depp’s shift from scarce icon to overexposed flop. Labour’s NEC must greenlight his resignation and bid to replace Keir Starmer; if approved he risks losing a safe seat to Reform or Greens, rattling bond markets and squandering his ‘scarcity’ appeal. His emerging 'Manchesterism' platform won’t resolve the UK’s deeper woes, so Hyde warns he’s better off staying metro mayor than staging a star-crossed leadership challenge.

articles.title: Donald Trump doesn’t want us to believe our own eyes | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: Renee Nicole Good’s killing is the latest example of the president’s outrageous – and blatant – assaults on the truth
articles.summary: After one year in office, Trump routinely rejects visible truths—from ICE’s killing of 37-year-old Renee Nicole Good (falsely depicting her as a violent ‘Radical Left’ attacker) to twin inflation (2.7% annual CPI, 3.1% food jump), $2.80-plus gasoline, and absurd claims of 500–3,000% prescription-drug cuts. He’s also lied about Ukraine’s war, January 6, ISIS and Portland riots. By enlisting Kristi Noem and VP J.D. Vance to spread “big lies,” he erodes fact vs fiction—echoing Arendt’s warnings—“owns the libs,” stifles accountability and emboldens official impunity.

articles.title: Trump’s Greenland U-turn was spectacular. The lesson for Europe: strongmen understand only strength | Nathalie Tocci
articles.trailText: With conflict over Greenland averted for now, European leaders will be tempted to retreat to their comfort zone of cowardice. But the next crisis will soon be here, says Guardian Europe columnist Nathalie Tocci
articles.summary: Following Trump’s dramatic threat to annex Greenland, his unexpected U-turn—citing a vague deal with NATO’s secretary-general and market concerns—safeguarded Greenland’s place within Denmark. Nathalie Tocci warns Europe’s year of appeasement—gold-plated invitations, trade concessions, defense-spending pledges—failed to secure US support on Ukraine or trade guarantees. Only unified firmness, from joint military exercises to suspending EU-US trade ratification and outlining €100 billion in counter-tariffs via an anti-coercion tool, rattled markets and forced Trump’s retreat. Tocci urges Europe to sustain this assertiveness, since strongmen respect strength alone, not genuflection.

articles.title: Democrats are campaigning as if the 2026 election will be fair. That’s a mistake | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: Trump’s remarks and Project 2025’s proposals have made the plan clear. Democrats must focus on stopping it
articles.summary: Trump’s remarks and Project 2025 outline a clear plan to undermine the 2026 midterms: seizing voting machines, shifting DOJ oversight to criminalize voting, defunding CISA, weaponizing federal power, harvesting voter data and pressuring states to comply. Historians warn Trump will not accept defeat and is more prepared and ruthless than in 2020; parallels to Orbán’s gerrymandering and “voter tourism” underscore the threat. Democrats, by assuming a fair contest and focusing solely on turnout, risk undercutting democracy—they must pivot to blocking subversion tactics now.

articles.title: Mary Berry, and now Prue Leith. Retiring in your 80s is the new 60s | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: As long as you feel able to work and have wisdom to offer, you should continue to do so. Although some outstay their welcome, even on the world stage, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins celebrates Prue Leith’s decision to step down from The Great British Bake Off at 86 (and Mary Berry’s earlier exit at 81) as emblematic of a shift: age 60 no longer signals decline. Since the 2010 Equality Act and pension age rise, employment of over-65s has surged, harnessing mature workers’ experience, judgment, and resilience. Jenkins warns against disguised or unjust forced retirements, advocating clear standards for demanding professions. He contrasts Britain’s pragmatic embrace of aged talent with US politics, noting Donald Trump’s contested fitness and the daunting 25th Amendment process to remove an unfit president.

articles.title: The greatest threat facing Britain may soon be the US – but the establishment won’t recognise it | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: Since the end of the second world war, all eyes have been on Russia. Yet Trump’s increasingly hostile presidency is shattering old assumptions, asks Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Andy Beckett argues Britain’s Cold War security mindset—fixated on Russia—now fails to recognise a greater danger: an increasingly erratic US under Trump. Despite deep defence and intelligence ties, transatlantic rifts over Greenland, trade, free speech, climate and tech regulation have shifted public sentiment: 32% of Britons now view America as a threat. Yet Westminster’s recent strategic defence review barely mentions US hostility, clinging to the ‘special relationship.’ Beckett warns UK elites must abandon this outdated orthodoxy and develop fresh policies that reflect the new reality of American unpredictability.

articles.title: Doomscrolling won’t bring order to the chaos. It’s OK to put the phone down and take a break | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: Keep Calm and Carry On: that’s not how people felt just before the second world war. But maybe, as Trump stalks, that old slogan is finally making sense, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: The Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff compares life under Donald Trump’s erratic threats—like potential force against Greenland or trade tariffs—with the “war of nerves” Britain faced between Munich 1938 and the Blitz, as described by historian Julie Gottlieb. She argues that ordinary people should adopt a Scandinavian-style resilience—sisu—balancing preparedness for disruptions such as power or wifi outages, strong social bonds, and work–life balance. In an age of 24/7 doomscrolling, she advises imposing normal routines, switching off the news, and seeking small everyday pleasures to manage collective anxiety without normalising a transgressive presidency.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s Board of Peace: an international body in service to one man’s ego | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: It was supposed to give Gaza a future, but the US president is using it to attack the UN, international law and multilateralism
articles.summary: Editorial critiques Trump’s self-styled ‘Board of Peace,’ launched at Davos under UN Security Council authority intended for Gaza reconstruction, as a veiled ego project that sidelines multilateralism and Palestinians. Trump names himself perpetual chair, picks members, sets agenda and can dismiss even billion-dollar donors, overriding UN and international law. The charter omits Gaza, relegating Palestinians to a fourth-tier committee alongside indicted leaders like Netanyahu. While proposed 100-day aid and infrastructure plans offer some hope, this unilateral power play risks peace and justice and demands defence of international law.

articles.title: The Guardian view on toddlers and screens: more reasons to be fearful of big tech | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Growing concerns about the impact of smartphones on the youngest children must be addressed
articles.summary: The Guardian warns that the first UK government guidance on under-toddlers’ screen use, due in April, is urgently needed. New data shows 98% of two-year-olds exceed two hours of daily screen time, correlating with smaller vocabularies and doubled emotional or behavioral concerns. A Kindred Squared survey found 37% of four-year-olds lack key life skills on starting school, with screens cited alongside poverty and service cuts. WHO advises no screens under two. Amid broader debates over AI nudification and a proposed age-16 social media limit, the editorial calls for clearer public health messaging and stricter tech oversight.

articles.title: Trump has defused a bomb of his own making. For now | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: After a bombastic speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Trump backed away from his threat to impose tariffs on European countries
articles.summary: Donald Trump threatened 25% tariffs on Europe unless Denmark sold Greenland to the US, even hinting at military force, then retracted at Davos after claiming a “framework” for a deal with NATO. His second term has been marked by coercive, ego-driven foreign policy, dismantling oversight (firing inspectors general, securing absolute immunity), and exploiting the presidency for at least $1.4 bn in personal profit through licensing, real estate and crypto ventures. The Greenland gambit exemplifies his transactional, “might makes right” approach, risking NATO unity and global stability.

articles.title: If the assisted dying bill is killed off by the Lords, let that be the end for this unelected chamber | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: With filibustering slowing the pace to a crawl, there is no chance the legislation will get through – unless the government shows some backbone, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee warns the UK’s private member’s Assisted Dying Bill is being filibustered in the unelected House of Lords by an alliance of Conservative peers and religious opponents, blocking a vote through time-wasting amendments. Despite decades of public and Commons support, the bill—allowing terminally ill adults (six-month prognosis) to self-administer a lethal prescription under strict safeguards—faces defeat by mid-May. Toynbee urges Keir Starmer to use the Parliament Act or promote the bill as government legislation, predicting this episode will fuel demands to reform or abolish the Lords.

articles.title: The revolutionary women of Rojava are in grave danger. That has consequences for us all | Natasha Walter
articles.trailText: For a decade, the autonomous territory in Syria has been a bastion of gender equality. It holds important lessons for the fight against authoritarianism, says author Natasha Walter
articles.summary: Rojava in north-east Syria has for over a decade operated under an autonomous administration (DAANES) committed to gender equality and power-sharing. Women in the Kurdish-led SDF and YPJ helped defeat ISIS and built direct democracy with restorative justice. Now, Damascus under Ahmed al-Sharaa, allied with jihadist factions, is reclaiming territory, threatening minorities and women’s gains. Rojava’s unique blend of Kurdish tradition, socialist ideals and feminism attracts global solidarity. As government forces advance, activists warn the world must pressure for rights protection, defend decentralised governance, and sustain a collective counterweight to rising authoritarianism.

articles.title: Vertigo has turned my world upside down. But knowing there are famous people suffering steadies me | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: How can a Normal understand what it feels like to turn my head and suddenly feel like the floor has smashed violently into my face?
articles.summary: Rebecca Shaw recounts her struggle with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo—when tiny inner-ear crystals shift, triggering violent spinning, nausea and vomiting. She likens her episodes to drunken or theme-park sensations, details failed Epley manoeuvres and public collapses, and finds solace learning that figures like cricketer Steve Smith and actor Bill Hader endure similar ailments. This shared experience, Shaw argues, doesn’t cure vertigo but reduces isolation, offering emotional steadiness until the next dizzying turn.

articles.title: Wake up, Westminster:after May, the Scottish and Welsh parliaments will likely be for independence | Will Hayward
articles.trailText: With Plaid Cymru and the SNP leading polls in their respective nations, can the United Kingdom continue in this – or any – form, asks Guardian columnist Will Hayward
articles.summary: By May elections the SNP is forecast to win the most Scottish seats, Plaid Cymru and the Welsh Greens could secure a pro-independence majority in the Senedd, and Sinn Féin leads in Northern Ireland, signalling a union at risk. Labour views Welsh nationalist gains as anti-establishment rather than separatist zeal, yet this surge underscores widespread frustration with an over-centralised UK. An independent commission’s ten recommendations—including stronger devolution safeguards, Welsh budget autonomy and policing powers—highlight the need for federal reform. Absent radical restructuring of Westminster’s arcane, England-dominated system, the UK risks unravelling.

articles.title: I went back to school for a day – and discovered some very unsettling facts about learning | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: I thought my articles and radio shows made an impact on people. A notice in the staffroom suggested otherwise, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles spent a ‘Deep Learning Day’ at a Birmingham secondary school, noting a staffroom poster on retention: learners recall just 10% of what they read, 20% of what they hear, 30% of what they see, 50% of both, 70% of what they discuss, 80% from personal experience and 90% of what they teach. He reflects on the limited lasting impact of his writing and radio work versus TV, and warns how high recall from discussion and lived experience fuels echo chambers and personal truths. He admires teachers’ stamina and concludes every day is a school day.

articles.title: The Trump administration has a Nazi problem | Mehdi Hasan
articles.trailText: Think I’m exaggerating? Consider the copious amounts of evidence
articles.summary: Mehdi Hasan exposes how the Trump administration is normalizing Nazi ideology, revealing official DHS and White House posts echoing neo-Nazi memes, slogans and imagery. Agencies like DHS and Labor used “Which way, American man?” and “One Homeland. One People. One Heritage” recalling Hitler’s slogans, while staffers praised Hitler or rallied with Holocaust deniers. Senior aides like Stephen Miller quote Goebbels, ICE prosecutors returned praising “America is a white nation,” and other officials admitted a “Nazi streak.” Hasan warns this deliberate embrace of fascist aesthetics and hires shows the US government under Trump has a Nazi problem.

articles.title: 'Manchesterism' is building a better politics and a strong economy. The whole country should be inspired | Andy Burnham
articles.trailText: We are the fastest-growing city-region economy in the UK, proof that it is possible to use public funds effectively while reducing crisis spending, says Andy Burnham, mayor of Greater Manchester
articles.summary: In this Guardian commentary, Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham coins “Manchesterism” as a blueprint for national renewal: devolution-powered collaborative politics and public-sector-led growth. He pins Britain’s crises—cost of living, housing shortage, low growth—on Thatcher-era deindustrialisation, privatisation, austerity and Brexit, and critiques Reform UK’s adoption of “Thatcherite” rhetoric. Highlighting Manchester’s achievements—bus re-nationalisation, new council housing, five global industry clusters, diverse training paths and double-UK-average growth—he calls for electoral reform to forge consensus on public investment and long-term economic resilience. He insists replicating Manchesterism nationwide can reduce crisis spending, empower communities, and restore market confidence.

articles.title: David and Victoria Beckham learned the hard way – modern kids go ‘no contact’ with no guilt or stigma at all | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: No one is suggesting the sort of decision Brooklyn made is taken lightly, but support networks and the language of therapy seem to lessen the sting, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: In Emma Brockes’s Guardian column, the Beckham family’s recent rift highlights Gen Z’s normalized ‘no contact’ (NC) and ‘very low contact’ (VLC) frameworks drawn from online estrangement communities. A simple ‘like’ by Victoria Beckham on Brooklyn’s roast chicken video triggered his blocking and NC escalation. Brockes contextualizes this trend, noting 20–27% of families face estrangement, aided by therapeutic language and acronyms that legitimize parental alienation. Critics decry its perceived frivolity, while half-measures like ‘grey rocking’ offer emotional detachment without full cutoff. Echoing the Beckhams, new support networks (e.g., Doormat Mom) enable parents to share grievances and cope with adult children’s rejection.

articles.title: What happens when the taps run dry? England is about to find out | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: It’s not just Tunbridge Wells – a country famous around the world for its rain is in danger of self-imposed drought, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty warns Britain is on the brink of self-imposed drought after repeated days-long outages in Tunbridge Wells and other affluent towns expose “resilience issues” in ageing, under-invested water infrastructure. Privatised firms, laden with debt and focused on shareholder returns, have neglected critical treatment works—Thames Water’s primary plant is reportedly “on its last legs.” Climate change and housing sprawl exacerbate supply risks, with experts forecasting wider shortages. Chakrabortty calls for renationalisation and progressive billing to raise billions for urgent system upgrades.

articles.title: Europe must heed Mark Carney – and embrace a painful emancipation from the US | Paul Taylor
articles.trailText: Trump’s tariff retreat should lull nobody into dropping their guard. The EU must join forces with Canada, Japan and other like-minded countries, says Paul Taylor of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: At Davos Mark Carney warned that the era of a Western-led rules-based order is over: rising “predatory” powers demand coalitions of liberal democracies rather than bilateral appeasement. He urged Europe to diversify trade and supply chains, form alliances with Canada, Japan, Australia, India and Brazil, and deploy its “trade bazooka” anti-coercion tool. Faced with Trump’s Greenland gambit and tariff threats, EU leaders must retaliate—€93bn in counter-tariffs, an emergency summit, and probe US coercion—ending nostalgic Atlanticism with a firm, united stance and a painful emancipation from US hegemony.

articles.title: After the Bondi terror attack people keep calling me a hero. But I am not a hero. I’m a mum who was at a Hanukah event | Jessica Rozen
articles.trailText: My phone zoom helped me see better. One man was on the footbridge. He was holding a gun. It was pointed towards me
articles.summary: Economist and mother Jessica Rozen was at a secure, unadvertised Hanukkah celebration near Bondi Beach when two gunmen opened fire. Searching for her son, she sheltered with a stranger’s toddler, filmed a shooter on a footbridge, and witnessed fatalities and shrapnel wounds. Bleeding but composed, she rescued and reunited the child with her father, then found her own family safe. Treated at hospital for cuts, bruises and embedded shrapnel, Rozen credits her husband, security volunteers, paramedics and police, rejects the “hero” label, and urges a world built on gentleness, kindness and listening.

articles.title: Minneapolis leaders call the ICE surge a ‘siege’. My reporting from there concurs
articles.trailText: After covering Trump’s immigration policies from Chicago and LA, the Twin Cities operation feels like a marked escalation
articles.summary: Local leaders and residents describe Operation Metro Surge, which deploys 3,000 ICE agents—five times the size of Minneapolis police—as a 'siege' on Twin Cities immigrant communities. Officers have conducted warrantless show-of-force raids at schools, homes, churches and mosques, stopping people at gunpoint, including US citizens and visa holders. Aggressive tactics, backed by a recent Supreme Court ruling, have driven immigrant-run businesses to close, overwhelmed 911, and sparked volunteer legal observers and mutual aid efforts as fear keeps residents inside.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Keir Starmer and Donald Trump: quiet diplomacy has reached its limit | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The prime minister has a duty to be candid with the British public about the scale of the global realignment caused by a volatile US president
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s trade and territorial threats—from annexing Canada to probing Greenland—are eroding the postwar rules-based order. Speaking at Davos, Canadian PM Mark Carney urged middle powers to forge new coalitions, boost security and diversify economies. Britain, uniquely tied to both the US and the EU, has pursued “mid-Atlantic equidistance” under Keir Starmer—quiet diplomacy meant to safeguard Ukraine and manage tariffs. But Trump’s public rebukes over the Chagos Islands and Greenland show this approach is untenable. The PM must frame a strategic vision, “name reality” and secure public consent for navigating an emerging era of great-power rivalry.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the City & Guilds privatisation: big bonuses cast a shadow over this deal | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Questions about the breakup of a venerable education charity, and who has benefited from it, need answers
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial criticises the sale of City & Guilds’ 148-year-old qualifications arm to Greek-owned PeopleCert, spotlighting £1.7m and £1.2m bonuses paid to CEO Kirstie Donnelly and CFO Abid Ismail without parliamentary debate. The deal, now under Charity Commission, PeopleCert and Ofqual inquiries, enables offshoring of UK roles, potential fee hikes and the pruning of less profitable courses. Trustees’ chair Dame Ann Limb’s involvement and academic claims face questions. With the original charity left holding up to £200m, editors demand transparent stewardship of public-benefit assets.

articles.title: Trump’s tariff threat leaves Europe with a choice: fight back or cease to matter | Georg Riekeles
articles.trailText: Appeasing Trump has only emboldened him. But European leaders are not as helpless as the US president believes, says Georg Riekeles, the associate director of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: In Davos Trump threatened to impose tariffs on Greenland and Denmark to force US demands, marking direct economic coercion. Georg Riekeles argues Europe must abandon appeasement, reclaim escalation dominance by rejecting the Turnberry trade deal, reinstating €93bn in suspended tariffs from 7 February, and fast-tracking the EU’s anti-coercion “trade bazooka.” He urges an extraordinary European Council directive, NATO’s Article 4 for Greenland defense planning or a willing coalition, plus NATO operational command reforms. Only a united, determined EU counter-offensive—political, diplomatic, military and economic—can defend its member states and preserve geopolitical relevance.

articles.title: The ‘rules-based order’ Davos craves has bigger problems than Trump: it represents a world that no longer exists
articles.trailText: The global economic system doesn’t even benefit its US and European creators any more, says Guardian columnist Larry Elliott
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Larry Elliott argues that the Davos-crafted liberal rules-based order—a US-led postwar arrangement enforced via NATO, IMF, World Bank and Western-dominated trade deals—has collapsed. Trump’s protectionism and disdain for multilateralism underscore Davos’s irrelevance. Emerging powers (China, India, Brazil) reject institutions reflecting 1940s power balances. Europe lags on growth and defense; inequality erodes liberal legitimacy. Elliott calls for new global governance: inclusive growth, public infrastructure, climate aid, equitable IMF/World Bank reform, stronger UN/WTO, and fairer defense burden-sharing, warning the old order won’t return.

articles.title: I risked my life to cross the Channel because I believed in British justice. But Britain is abandoning me | Anonymous
articles.trailText: The government has been trying to send me back to France under the “one in, one out” policy. The threats to my life there don’t seem to matter
articles.summary: An anonymous former oilfield manager says he fled corruption and death threats from a powerful figure at home, received more threats in France, then risked his life crossing the Channel believing British justice would secure his asylum. Instead, he was whisked into inadequate interviews, detained in violent, drug-fueled centers, denied legal support and had his evidence dismissed over translation technicalities. His removal under the “one in, one out” return deal with France – backed by £800m – has sent back under 250 of 16,000 arrivals. He calls for safe, legal routes, fair processing and targeting smugglers, not vulnerable asylum seekers.

articles.title: I had an eye-opening experience in the queue for a pub toilet | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: There was the struggle to make chitchat, a whiff of humiliation – and a sobering recognition of what women have to put up with
articles.summary: In a busy pub/restaurant reunion with old friends before Christmas, Adrian Chiles found himself queued for the men’s restroom—while the women’s facilities were empty. Facing unfamiliar embarrassment and awkward silence, he experienced the mundane injustice women routinely endure. Men in line lacked the chitchat women master, limiting conversation to occasional eye-rolls. A lone woman exiting silently underscored male entitlement. Chiles reflects on ‘wee waiting times’ as a gauge of societal gender parity, plans research on restroom queues, and gains fresh insight into everyday structural inequalities women navigate without sympathy from men.

articles.title: Here’s how to fix America’s immigration system. Trump’s path is not the solution | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: A grand bargain on immigration could address problems with both the old approach and Trump’s new approach
articles.summary: Kenneth Roth argues that America’s immigration system is failing both historically and under Trump. He cites an overwhelmed asylum system—where migrants wait years for hearings—and policies that force claimants to Mexico or deny asylum outright. Trump’s workplace and neighborhood raids uproot long-settled immigrants who pose no security threat, due to no statute of limitations on immigration violations. Roth proposes a bipartisan ‘grand bargain’: beef up border enforcement and hire more immigration judges to clear backlogs, while enacting a five-year statute of limitations so undocumented residents with no serious crimes can stay if they’ve lived in the U.S. over five years.

articles.title: The IMF’s banal language is sane-washing an economic crisis created by the egomaniacal Donald Trump
articles.trailText: Their latest report makes no mention of Greenland, Venezuela, or even Trump. This is just a pretence that normality continues
articles.summary: Greg Jericho slams the IMF's latest World Economic Outlook update, titled "Global Economy: Steady amid Divergent Forces," for using bland, "sane-washing" language to mask the crisis triggered by Donald Trump's erratic policies. Despite Trump's threats of 10–25% tariffs on European exports unless Greenland is ceded, and his picture-map provocations, the IMF downplays "flare-ups" in trade tensions and omits any mention of Trump, Greenland or Venezuela. It acknowledges tariffs have surged sixfold, touts AI investment as a growth driver but warns of potential market crashes and recessions, and urges energy and labor policies to cushion impacts—pretending normality endures amid turmoil.

articles.title: Why are British people so obsessed with bins? | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Our nation’s fascination with rubbish knows no bounds – as was proved by one recent online debate, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Freelancer Polly Hudson uses the legendary Mumsnet—Britain’s “cultural thermometer” and birthplace of memes like the penis beaker—to expose a national fixation on bins. A user’s account of slipping Christmas overflow into an empty neighbour’s bin at 6.45 am ignited an “am I being unreasonable?” debate over morality, etiquette and confusing collection schedules, birthing the “binfluencer” sticker craze. Even James Corden’s row over paving his front garden for smoother bin-rollout underscores how waste rituals now unite social classes and fuel online chatter.

articles.title: World leaders in Davos must stand up to Trump. This is their chance | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The world needs global leaders to clearly and firmly denounce the havoc Trump is wreaking on the US and international order
articles.summary: At Davos, over 60 heads of state and global CEOs, including Jamie Dimon, must denounce Trump’s dismantling of NATO, withdrawal from climate agreements, tariff threats, and bid to annex Greenland. Trump’s lawsuit threat against JPMorgan aims to intimidate Dimon from criticizing his assault on international norms, but Reich argues that world leaders’ unified repudiation could spark a tipping point. With Trump bringing his largest-ever US delegation to Davos, Reich calls on attendees to seize their duty and speak out now to defend democracy and the rules-based world order.

articles.title: Enough appeasement: Britain needs its own ‘trade bazooka’ to take on Donald Trump | Ed Davey
articles.trailText: It’s time to stand up for ourselves. With targeted action and tariffs, we can help push back the bully-in-chief, says Liberal Democrat leader Ed Davey
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s recent threats to Greenland and NATO allies cross a line, Ed Davey says, calling on Britain to abandon Keir Starmer’s appeasement. He proposes a “trade bazooka” with the EU to enforce targeted retaliatory tariffs and punitive measures—scrap the £3 bn NHS–US drug deal, impose import duties on Tesla, and exclude US firms like Palantir from government contracts—to inflict economic pain on Trump ahead of midterms. Davey argues this show of strength, rather than diplomatic niceties, is the only way to protect UK industries, jobs, and living standards and to revive the “special relationship.”

articles.title: So a cow can use a stick to scratch its backside. When will we learn that humans are really not that special? | Helen Pilcher
articles.trailText: Veronika’s improvised grooming device has caused great surprise – but that tells us more about humans than cows, says science writer Helen Pilcher
articles.summary: In a Current Biology study, Austrian researchers document for the first time a cow, Veronika, using a broom as a multi-purpose grooming tool—twisting it with her tongue to scratch belly and back spots she couldn’t reach. This joins known examples of tool use in chimps, otters, crows and more, challenging the view that such behavior is uniquely human. Science writer Helen Pilcher argues that our surprise reveals an anthropocentric bias and urges us to acknowledge animals’ complex minds.

articles.title: Donald Trump is not forgetting America’s old alliances – his goal is to destroy them | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: European leaders who know their continent’s history must now see that the US president is siding with the forces of tyranny, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rafael Behr argues that in his second term Donald Trump deliberately targets Europe’s alliances rather than preserving them. Contrasting Angela Merkel’s 2018 Davos appeal to twentieth-century lessons, Trump’s self-serving actions—from eyeing Greenland’s real estate to lashing out at the UK and Denmark—undermine NATO, multilateral trade and the rules-based order. He glorifies might over law, aligns with tyrants and erodes democratic norms. European leaders must abandon flattery and push for US regime change to salvage transatlantic security.

articles.title: As I navigated the hazy days of early parenting, voice messages from friends kept me afloat | Samantha Allemann
articles.trailText: A phone call feels impossible amid the busyness of motherhood, but a quick voice note? That I can manage
articles.summary: Samantha Allemann recounts how brief voice notes from friends anchored her through the haze of early parenting in lockdown-scarred Melbourne. With nap schedules and swirl of TOG ratings, breast-pump rhythms and infant wails, traditional calls felt intrusive but voice messages offered timely support—Bella’s calming tones soothed her baby, Sevil’s detailed advice on top-up feeds arrived after midnight, and Emily’s Yorkshire lilt over pump noise even confused her partner. These unedited audio snippets—complete with household clatter, children’s chatter and tonal nuances of fatigue, relief and joy—fostered deep connection when texts fell flat and live calls proved impossible.

articles.title: My friends in Italy are using AI therapists. But is that so bad, when a stigma surrounds mental health? | Viola Di Grado
articles.trailText: State provision for psychological health services is lamentable. Until things improve, let’s not judge those who turn to an app for help, says Italian author Viola Di Grado
articles.summary: Viola Di Grado explores a burgeoning trend in Italy: millions turning to free AI–therapy apps amid chronic underfunding and cultural stigma around mental illness. Surveys show 81% of Italians treat mental health as weakness and 57% cite cost barriers, while Italy invests least in Europe on mental-health services. Traditional care is understaffed, prompting tech adoption: users name their chatbots, find them always available, unjudging, and anonymous—especially valuable for LGBTQ+ or low-income patients. Though ethical concerns linger, AI therapy offers a cost-free, private ‘setting’ until public provision and destigmatisation improve.

articles.title: Tech bros have made us lonely. I’m fighting back by getting off social media and talking to strangers | Jess Harwood
articles.trailText: Connections can be found anywhere: the local cafe, the dog park and community events
articles.summary: Australian comic artist and tour guide Jess Harwood criticises how social media, controlled by tech billionaires, has deepened loneliness and even inspired AI companions. Citing new guidelines that link isolation’s health risks to smoking, she shares how she regained genuine connection by putting away her phone and chatting with strangers—from an ultrasound clinic waiting room to cafes, dog parks and an eight-hour cricket match. Her experience leading women’s history walking tours in Sydney illustrates how spontaneous public encounters can restore community. Harwood urges readers, when they have the capacity, to seize any chance for offline conversation as a small rebellion against tech-bro–fostered isolation.

articles.title: The transatlantic order is crumbling. Greenland is a moment of great rupture | Christopher S Chivvis
articles.trailText: Trump’s demand for Greenland is a throwback to the 1884 Berlin conference: a transaction of land and people driven by a might makes right worldview
articles.summary: On January 17 the US threatened 10–25% tariffs on key European allies unless they back Washington’s “complete and total purchase” of Greenland, marking a shift from security partner to imperial rent-seeker. Comparing this coercion to the 1884 Berlin Conference, Chivvis warns it spells the end of the post-1945 transatlantic order, exposing EU fault-lines. He argues Europe must abandon its wait-and-see reflex, activate the Anti-Coercion Instrument sparingly, and urgently pursue defence integration, economic liberalism and industrial policy to achieve genuine sovereignty.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the French far right: mainstream parties are running out of time | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A Paris appeals court will decide if Marine Le Pen can stand in next year’s presidential election. But legal troubles have not damaged the fortunes of her party
articles.summary: Ahead of the 2027 election, Marine Le Pen’s appeal against a conviction for misusing EU funds will decide if she can run again or be succeeded by Jordan Bardella, who is broadening the National Rally’s appeal to both blue-collar voters and business elites. Despite legal woes, polls show over 40% believe the party could improve security, industry, services and living costs, with growing support for “national preference.” As far-right ideas erode the traditional “republican barrier” and actors like Steve Bannon eye a French victory to weaken the EU, mainstream parties have under 500 days to regroup.

articles.title: The Guardian view on food security: Britain can no longer trust markets alone | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: As climate and geopolitics shocks bite, countries are rebuilding food buffers. The UK clings to neoliberal ideas while households pay the price
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns Britain’s market‐only food strategy leaves it exposed to climate and geopolitical shocks, unlike EU states and emerging economies rebuilding strategic grain reserves. Relying on liberalised trade and household stockpiling neglects how staples’ demand and supply don’t flex quickly with price shifts, while exporter concentration and speculation fuel volatility. Public buffers—buying when prices are low, releasing when scarce—serve as shock absorbers to stabilise inflation. Recent price dips belie that food remains 25% costlier than pre‐pandemic. Britain should emulate India’s capped‐reserve model, rather than China’s open‐ended stockpiling, to pair market efficiency with resilience.

articles.title: In the face of Trump’s threats, Britain’s best path is clearer than ever: hurry back to Europe | Stella Creasy
articles.trailText: Labour must urgently seek new roles and alliances, while also enhancing the UK’s own military capabilities, says Stella Creasy, MP and chair of the Labour Movement for Europe
articles.summary: Stella Creasy warns that Donald Trump’s anti-European stance and the US pivot to Asia expose the UK’s vulnerability if it remains estranged from Europe. Rejecting Green calls to evict US bases or ditch Trident, she stresses Britain’s nuclear deterrent is vital. Labour must spearhead rebuilding ties—reviving EU defence projects like Safe, bolstering the European pillar of NATO, enhancing UK military capabilities and pursuing deeper Swiss-style single-market integration to align security and trade.

articles.title: Is it ever a good idea to give someone a nickname? | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: A five-year-old girl has convinced her parents to legally change her real name to the nickname she prefers. But giving someone an unexpected epithet can come fraught with problems, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson outlines the potent social dynamics of nicknames, sparked by a viral story of a five-year-old in Michigan legally adopting the nickname she’s always preferred over “Margaret.” Nicknames can foster intimacy—think Spice Girls—but tread a fine line: mis-timed or unwelcome epithets can feel controlling or disrespectful. Research shows managers’ nicknaming lowers employees’ perceived power and safety, and courts have penalized workplace nicknames as harassment under equality laws. Hudson advises caution—reserve nicknames for close, consenting relationships to avoid unintended offense.

articles.title: Greenland’s tragedy: the dream of independence now looks like a trap laid by Donald Trump | Rune Lykkeberg
articles.trailText: Denmark and its former colony have a complex relationship, but for now they must speak with one voice against US colonial ambitions, says Rune Lykkeberg, editor-in-chief of the Danish newspaper Information
articles.summary: Rune Lykkeberg examines Greenland’s two competing origin stories—Denmark’s portrayal of 1953–79 ‘hidden colonisation’ evolving into progressive decolonisation under the Danish crown, and Greenlanders’ narrative of ongoing racism, forced IUD insertions and child relocations—amid a quest for full independence. He argues that Trump’s public proposal to ‘buy’ Greenland exploits these divisions by courting anti-colonial sentiment, placing Greenland in a dilemma: leverage US interest to pressure Denmark, or remain within the Danish kingdom to safeguard welfare, dependence on Denmark’s €600m annual grant, legal rights and avoid new imperial domination.

articles.title: Gut check: are at-home microbiome tests a way to ‘hack your health’ or simply a waste? | Antiviral
articles.trailText: Spruiked by online influencers as a way of gaining insight into our health, experts say at-home tests oversimplify complex factors and can cause unnecessary distress
articles.summary: For a few hundred dollars at-home gut microbiome tests promise AI-generated insights on food sensitivities, metabolism and pathogens but experts warn they oversimplify complex ecosystems. Professor Rupert Leong says lab methods vary, results are hard to interpret and useful only when ordered and analysed by specialists. Most consumers get no actionable benefit, risk false alarms and distress. Cultural influencers pitch them as ‘health hacks,’ shifting responsibility onto individuals while ignoring social, environmental and clinical factors. Instead, clinicians recommend high-fiber diverse diets, qualified dietitian or GP advice and evidence-based screenings.

articles.title: I am in Iran watching the protests and desperate for change. But I don’t believe the regime will fall | Anonymous
articles.trailText: I wish I were wrong, but all I see is a paranoid state digging in, says our anonymous author
articles.summary: Iran endures another wave of civil unrest amid an internet blackout and brutal repression, echoing 2009’s post-election uprisings. Citizens leverage protests, social media, universities and limited elections to demand meaningful change, yet face a paranoid regime fortified by US sanctions under Trump. Main opposition figure Reza Pahlavi is widely rejected. Fear of violent foreign intervention and state retaliation has deepened public pessimism. With the Islamic Republic entrenched, Tehran braces for recurring cycles of dissent crushed by force, dashing hopes of democratic reform.

articles.title: Is this Labour party for rich investors or hard-working leaseholders?  We must make that clear today | Angela Rayner
articles.trailText: A titanic battle is raging to prevent us capping crippling ground rents that families have to pay, often to faceless companies. We must fight and win it, says MP and former deputy PM Angela Rayner
articles.summary: Labour MP Angela Rayner warns that wealthy investors are fiercely lobbying government to weaken Labour’s manifesto pledge to cap crippling, unregulated ground rents that trap millions of leaseholders—often young families—paying hundreds or thousands annually for nothing. She recalls Labour’s landmark Employment Rights and Renters’ Rights Acts, and calls on ministers to introduce a draft leasehold and commonhold reform bill with an annual cash ground rent cap. Rayner argues pension funds would barely feel the loss, and urges channeling capital into growth sectors. This fight symbolizes whose side the party is on: wealthy landlords or hard-working homeowners.

articles.title: Why are saunas suddenly everywhere? I think it’s to do with booze | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: People are serious about wanting to see each other without getting drunk – and they could be on to something, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams explores the sudden boom in urban sauna culture as a sober social space. Once seen as medical or Nordic novelty, saunas have become trendy meetup spots where alcohol is banned by heat, forcing participants into quiet, reflective gatherings. Williams argues this shift follows dry-curious drinking patterns from zero-alcohol beer to coffee dates and walks, culminating in communal heat sessions that promise zen vibes rather than weight loss or inflammation relief. The trend reframes self-care as presence and connection, not self-improvement or tipsy conversation.

articles.title: It’s a Brooklyn v Beckham Inc disaster: what happens when the elephant in the room goes rogue | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Sir David and Victoria cornered the market in selling their family’s privacy for money – but there was a price to pay, and Brooklyn Peltz Beckham has just sent them the bill, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde dissects Brooklyn Peltz Beckham’s explosive Instagram rebuke of David and Victoria Beckham, accusing them of prioritising ‘Brand Beckham’ and social-media endorsements over genuine family bonds. She traces how the couple commodified his life—from selling pregnancy shots and nursery tours to monetising their Netflix doc—as part of a vast empire built on curated publicity. Hyde warns this obsession with public image mirrors broader social-media pitfalls, eroding privacy and mental wellbeing, and even suggests stricter limits on parents posting children’s lives online. As Brooklyn demands accountability, the Beckhams confront a real-world crisis beyond any PR play.

articles.title: Triumphant Tories might miss Robert Jenrick more than they think – they need the voters he represents | Henry Hill
articles.trailText: Kemi Badenoch may look like a stronger leader now, but Jenrick is a dangerous rival – he knows where the Conservatives have been going wrong, says Henry Hill, deputy editor of ConservativeHome
articles.summary: Henry Hill argues that Robert Jenrick’s exit from the Tory party, far from marginal, exposes its failure to grapple with policy and ideological divisions that cost it the 2024 election. Kemi Badenoch’s deft handling of his defection has bolstered her leadership, but she now faces the task of engaging the Conservative grassroots Jenrick embodied—voters concerned about immigration, taxation and law-and-order—while countering the urge among insiders to settle for vague competence narratives. With Reform UK under Nigel Farage topping polls, triumphalism risks handing extremists the initiative. Badenoch must prove her party can deliver real change, not just rhetorical shifts.

articles.title: As Trump menaces Greenland, this much is clear: the free world needs a new plan – and inspired leadership | Gordon Brown
articles.trailText: The idea that the liberal rules-based order can survive his presidency now seems complacent. This is a historic moment – and a time to act, says former UK prime minister Gordon Brown
articles.summary: Former UK PM Gordon Brown warns Donald Trump’s plan to take Greenland by force marks a decisive break with the postwar liberal, rules-based order. With the US abandoning multilateralism, human rights and environmental stewardship, Brown urges Europe and southern democracies to draft a new global charter affirming self-determination, outlawing aggression, upholding law, civil rights and cooperation on food, security, climate, gender equality and pandemic prevention. Rejecting spheres of influence, this multipolar framework should reflect interdependence and shared values. Europe must seize its moment as the US retreats, reviving Roosevelt’s four freedoms and remaking leadership for the 21st century.

articles.title: Australians must demand that their cultural custodians uphold freedom of speech | Margaret Simons
articles.trailText: As we have seen after Adelaide writers’ week, defending the right of people to speak, even when we deeply disagree with them, is very, very difficult
articles.summary: After the abrupt cancellation of the 2026 Adelaide Writers’ Week and other cultural flashpoints, Margaret Simons argues Australians must insist that cultural custodians — festival boards, editors and curators — defend free speech, even when ideas offend. Drawing on a Myanmar festival and contrasting political remarks on “bigotry” and “agitation,” she defines free speech as a right to speak, not to be platformed or respected. Custodians require intellectual rigor, moral muscle and courage to host uncomfortable or dissenting voices. Governments must appoint capable, independent boards to preserve democratic debate and national cultural health.

articles.title: The 2016 trend on social media is giving me absolute chills. But could it be the cure for this new-year funk? | Eleanor Burnard
articles.trailText: Millennial pink hair. Thigh-high boots styled with T-shirt dresses. Dare we even mention the Harambe of it all?
articles.summary: In her comment piece Eleanor Burnard dissects the resurgence of 2016 nostalgia sweeping social media – grainy purple sunsets, flower crowns, millennial pink hair and thigh-high boots – popularised by influencers and Kylie Jenner’s throwbacks. She reminds readers that 2016 also ushered in Brexit, Trump’s rise, Harambe mania, major celebrity deaths and the pre-#MeToo era, arguing that while wistful reminiscing offers comfort amid 2026’s fresh crises (Bondi massacre fallout, global unrest), it’s vital to acknowledge past turmoil, draw resilience from it and shape a more just future.

articles.title: The Guardian view on protecting NHS staff: ministers must take a lead in reducing attacks on the health workforce | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Rising violence in hospitals is part of a disturbing pattern that must be addressed with actions as well as words
articles.summary: Focusing on England’s NHS, the Guardian describes an emergency in rising violence against staff—285 reported attacks daily in 2024-25, including weapon threats, sexual assaults and racist incidents tied to anti-migrant sentiment. Ministers must back words with action: reinforce employer duties under the Employment Rights Act, empower managers to set boundaries, involve police in prosecutions and uphold an NHS sexual safety charter. Without strong leadership, morale, patient satisfaction and international recruitment will keep falling, further eroding the NHS’s vital social contract.

articles.title: Donald Trump needs helpers for his appalling neocolonialist project. What else is this ‘board of peace’? | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: Blair, Putin, Erdoğan, Orbán: the names of those invited to serve say it all. And it’s about so much more than Gaza, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Owen Jones condemns Donald Trumps proposed board of peace for Gaza as a neocolonialist power grab, chaired by Trump personally. With invites to Blair, Putin, Erdoğan, Orbán and property tycoons—but no Palestinians—the board aims to control Gazas reconstruction and finances, echoing plans of ethnic cleansing and luxury development. Presented as an alternative to the UN, it exemplifies US moral bankruptcy and blunt financial-military dominance. Gaza serves as a trial run for Trumps global hegemony blueprint, revealing the decline of Western moral authority.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Poems on the Underground at 40: public art to be proud of | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: This simple idea has travelled around the world, bringing hope and inspiration to millions
articles.summary: Poems on the Underground marks its 40th anniversary this month, bringing free poetry to London Tube commuters since Judith Chernaik launched the initiative in 1986. Edited today by Chernaik alongside Imtiaz Dharker and George Szirtes, it rotates six poems each term—from 18th-century haiku by Kobayashi Issa to contemporary British voices Rachel Boast and Blake Morrison. The project weathered controversies over bawdy historic verses and profanity, expanded worldwide to New York, Dublin, Paris and beyond, and earned a Cambridge archive. Backed by TfL, the Arts Council and British Council, it underscores art’s role in boosting wellbeing underground.

articles.title: Robert Jenrick boasts that Reform is for the workers, but it’s a class war trap – and Labour shouldn’t fall for it | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Though Labour's voters are more likely to be the educated middle-classes, its focus must be fighting inequality. We know Farage’s party will only enrich the wealthy, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee argues that Reform UK, branded by Robert Jenrick as the “workers’ party” against Tory elites, is a populist trap serving wealthy founders rather than low-paid voters. Despite Reform’s anti-elite rhetoric, its tax-and-spend plans benefit the richest. Education level now predicts voting: less-educated voters back Reform or Conservatives, graduates back Labour or liberal left. Toynbee urges Labour to reclaim class politics by fighting inequality through early years and FE funding, leveraging its core of young professionals to narrow Britain’s widening wealth gap.

articles.title: Why can’t women enjoy Heated Rivalry without being treated with contempt? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The TV hit has cracked open a rich seam of misogyny: romance is written off as a weird thing that women like, and the audience is dismissed as ‘wine moms’, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams critiques the sexist backlash against women enjoying the hit drama Heated Rivalry, whose intense slow-burn romance between two professional ice-hockey players—Shane Hollander and Ilya Rozanov—has been dismissed as frivolous “wine-mom” entertainment. Critics mock romance as lightweight, even likening it to porn without sex, while ignoring its faithful adaptation of genre conventions and its deeper challenge to homophobia and patriarchal oppression. By foregrounding real-world barriers—from sports sponsorship to Russia’s anti-LGBT laws—the show uses romance’s formulaic structure to highlight systemic injustice. Williams argues that romance, far from being unserious, offers a radical, happy-ending critique of sexist norms and deserves respect for its narrative and social impact.

articles.title: My partner died in 2020, but grief made it impossible to complete this final step | Nova Weetman
articles.trailText: Scattering the ashes of someone we love can feel like an overwhelming responsibility at a time when getting out of bed is hard enough
articles.summary: Nova Weetman recounts why she still hasn’t collected her partner’s ashes more than three years after his pandemic-era death: the endless paperwork, absence of scattering instructions and the overwhelming weight of grief. Comparing her struggle to scattering her mother’s ashes at Williamstown beach and her daughter’s frank university explorations of death rituals, she describes cancelled appointments with the funeral home and persistent guilt. Only after her father’s ashes joined her in her home office does she find the resolve to gather her partner’s urn, placing both men she loved side by side.

articles.title: From Trump’s rejected treaties to our daily lives, we’re building walls around ourselves | Anand Pandian
articles.trailText: Martin Luther King Jr knew that ‘whatever affects one directly affects all indirectly’. But we Americans are denying that reality
articles.summary: Anand Pandian argues the US under Trump is rejecting international cooperation—66 treaties on climate, migration, cultural heritage, clean water, renewable energy—building walls of indifference that mirror domestic isolation: fortified homes, SUVs, media echo chambers. These everyday walls hinder recognition of global interdependence, undermining responses to shared crises like climate change, migration, inequality. Pandian’s anthropological research highlights how communal initiatives—e.g., Newburgh water defenders embedding watershed awareness and mutual solidarity—reveal paths to collective well-being, echoing MLK’s ‘inescapable network of mutuality’ and urging a shift from isolation to communal responsibility.

articles.title: MLK Day reminds us to harness ‘urgency of now’ as the US grapples with crisis | Kelly Carter Jackson
articles.trailText: People across the US are moving on from the empty platitudes MLK Day often evokes – and embodying King’s words
articles.summary: On MLK Day 2026, Kelly Carter Jackson urges Americans to heed Martin Luther King Jr’s ‘urgency of now’ amid nationwide protests against militarized federal policing, ICE abuses and state violence in Minneapolis and beyond. She contrasts today’s expansive federal force under Trump with past civil rights repression, recalling King’s 1967 ‘Beyond Vietnam’ call for universal love and solidarity against racism, poverty and militarism. Jackson highlights modern activists embodying King’s revolutionary spirit in resistance to government crackdowns on immigrants and advocates renewing commitment to true justice, equality and brotherhood rather than empty platitudes. She emphasizes that King’s dream demands sacrifice and collective action today.

articles.title: The 75 hard challenge has come roaring back - but I have my own self-improvement regime | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: As punishing wellness challenges proliferate online, I’ve decided the only sensible response is to invent a kinder – and more lucrative – alternative, says Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington, intrigued by punishing social-media regimens, revisits the 75 Hard challenge—75 days of strict hydration, workouts, clean eating and reading—popularized by podcaster Andy Frisella and recently touted by Paddy McGuinness. Rather than endure its harsh routine, she sketches three playful alternatives: an “intellectual 75 Hard” of dense philosophy and language drills; “75 housetrained,” a daily domestic reboot of chores like recycling and dish loading; and her own “75 gentle,” a winter-cheer programme of animal stroking, nostalgic treats, naps, memes, hot drinks and daffodil buys—backed, she jokes, by sales of her branded pre-nap biscuits.

articles.title: Did God fix a football match? Welcome to the great divine intervention debate | Ravi Holy
articles.trailText: Vicars and others devout – and some who are desperate – do a lot of praying for things but it's complicated. There are definitely dos and don'ts, says vicar Ravi Holy
articles.summary: In a playful yet theologically nuanced essay, vicar Ravi Holy examines claims that God or even the Pope intervened to secure Wolverhampton Wanderers’ first win of the season—a surprising 3-0 victory over West Ham after a dismal run. He questions the logic of treating prayer like a “slot-machine” for trivial needs (from parking spaces to match results) while global crises go unaddressed. Citing Bruce Almighty’s chaos, Anne Lamott’s warning about idols we shape in our own image and Rowan Williams’s view that prayer can tilt outcomes, Holy explores tensions between free will, divine micromanagement and personal desire. Reflecting on his own prayer for a desired church posting, he acknowledges unexpected blessings but ultimately won’t petition God to save West Ham from relegation.

articles.title: The Trump-Kennedy Center is another front in the battle for the soul of America | Charlotte Higgins
articles.trailText: Under Trump, the world-class centre for performing arts is one of many US cultural institutions changing beyond recognition. Will others buckle, asks the Guardian’s chief culture writer, Charlotte Higgins
articles.summary: After taking the helm of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts upon his inauguration, Donald Trump ousted its experienced leadership and installed loyalist Richard Grenell, prompting mass artist departures and audience boycotts. Productions like Hamilton were canceled, ticket sales plunged, and the Washington National Opera formally severed ties, planning independent performances offsite. The center was rebranded “The Donald J Trump and John F Kennedy Center,” amid legal dispute. Upcoming concerts and events continue to be axed, leaving the National Symphony Orchestra isolated. Similar political pressures saw the Smithsonian edit Trump’s portrait label. Cultural institutions face a high-stakes fight over America’s identity.

articles.title: What ICE is doing on US streets looks terrifying, but don’t forget: it could happen anywhere | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: This shocking moment is the outcome of a political, institutional and media environment that is not far off Britain’s, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Nesrine Malik argues the fatal shooting of Renee Good and ICE’s growing paramilitary street raids reflect a creeping authoritarianism born of post-9/11 fusion of immigration and security, expanded under Obama and turbocharged by Trump’s massive budgets and "existential threat" mandate. Fueled by right-wing media scaremongering, institutional racism and military-style policing, ICE operations erode due process and civil rights, creating a climate of constant vulnerability. Malik warns Britain shows early signs—political nativism, hostile media, expanded police and border powers, tougher protest restrictions and glamorized raids—suggesting a similar slide toward unchecked state coercion even without US-style firearms.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump and Greenland: get real! Bullying is not strength | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Tariff threats over the Arctic island expose the limits of coercive diplomacy. Europe’s united response and pushback shows fear is fading
articles.summary: Trump’s threat to impose sweeping tariffs on Europe unless it agrees to US purchase of Greenland has laid bare the limits of coercive diplomacy. European leaders from Macron to Meloni and Denmark have rebuffed intimidation, pausing EU-US trade deal ratification and warning of a dangerous spiral. Allies like the UK and Canada are diversifying from erratic US policy, forging rules-based ties. With domestic support waning, Trump’s tariff ultimatums lack credibility. Real power, the editorial argues, rests on trust, predictability and mutual benefit, not bullying—a lesson increasingly learned. The US should bolster Greenland’s defenses and forge genuine commercial partnerships.

articles.title: The Guardian view on microplastics research: questioning results is good for science, but has political consequences | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Errors in measuring microplastic pollution can be corrected. Public trust in science also needs to be shored up
articles.summary: The Guardian's editorial warns that recent critiques of 20 studies measuring micro- and nanoplastics in humans—chiefly flawed pyrolysis-GC-MS methods—suggest up to half of high-impact papers suffer systemic methodological gaps in this young field. While electron microscopy and FTIR confirm plastics in organs, reported quantities may be exaggerated. Many papers led by medical researchers lacked chemistry rigour. Given science’s messy self-correction and a hostile political climate—from climate denial to Trump’s “Gold Standard Science” order—such disputes risk eroding public trust and being weaponized by industry lobbyists. The piece urges agreed standards, broader peer review and media caution.

articles.title: If it wasn’t clear before, it is now: Britain needs an escape plan from the Trump world order | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: The US president’s trade war for Greenland tells us that the time for fence-sitting or wishful thinking is over, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff argues that Trump’s Greenland trade gambit marks the end of Europe’s fence-sitting toward its unpredictable US ally. Despite Keir Starmer’s efforts to balance transatlantic ties, Trump’s all-or-nothing posture has shown the old western alliance is effectively dead. Europe must pursue short-term deals to buy breathing room—protecting jobs and Ukraine’s security—but urgently draw up a long-term “escape plan”: building new political, military and trade frameworks with neighbours (likely short of full EU membership), boosting defence spending, and diversifying security dependencies, while keeping a wary link to the US until Trump’s tenure ends.

articles.title: No amount of defections will change the fact that Reform and the Tories are singing the same tunes | John Harris
articles.trailText: The battle for political domination on the British right is a family feud – the result will be a Conservative restoration, not revolution, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris argues that defections from the Conservatives to Reform UK are less a revolution than a turf war among right-wing kin, sharing the same Brexit, Thatcherite, anti-immigration and culture-war agenda. Using a UB40 split as metaphor, he traces Robert Jenrick’s sacking and move to Reform alongside Nigel Farage’s and Richard Tice’s deeply Tory roots. Despite personal animosities, both camps hawk identical laissez-faire economics and nativist rhetoric. Harris warns this feud may end not in ideological rupture but in a right-wing reunion under a reformed Conservatism.

articles.title: Abolishing ICE isn’t enough – it’s time to center people’s humanity | Heba Gowayed and Victor Ray
articles.trailText: It’s far from radical to reject a system predicated on violence – despite what thinktanks might claim
articles.summary: On 7 January 2026, ICE agent Jonathan Ross fatally shot Renee Good and mocked her, prompting nationwide protests. A Wall Street Journal review documents multiple instances of ICE firing on civilians since July 2025. ICE’s poor detention conditions saw 32 deaths in 2025 alone. Born in the post-9/11 security surge and rooted in racialized immigration policy dating to 1790, ICE’s mandate fuels violence, impunity, and racial profiling. Training or funding increases won’t stop killings: abolition is needed. Authors call to dismantle ICE, guarantee legal counsel, expand immigration pathways, and replace coercive security logic with respect for people’s humanity.

articles.title: The pitfalls of perfectionism – and why ‘good enough’ should be your goal | Gill Straker and Jacqui Winship
articles.trailText: Healthy striving – a flexible wish to improve – accepts limits and understands that error is integral to mastery
articles.summary: New year’s resolutions can feed perfectionism, turning goals into self-worth tests where one misstep triggers shame, anxiety and burnout. Perfectionism masks as diligence but stems from fear of failure, causing procrastination, avoidance and chronic dissatisfaction. Therapy differentiates it from healthy striving—a flexible, self-focused wish to improve that tolerates mistakes. Case study: Julie, an overworked academic, learned to accept “good enough,” reducing anxiety and enhancing connections. Reclaiming healthy striving—setting modest goals, embracing errors as part of learning—fosters innovation, self-compassion and sustainable growth.

articles.title: Why am I a vegan? I do it for my mental health | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Vegan restaurants are closing, RFK Jr is sounding the drum for carnivores, and the protein cult is bigger than ever. But eschewing animal products helps me ward off a sense of impotence – and despair, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington reflects on a perceived backlash against veganism: closures of plant-based eateries, declining meat substitute sales and high-profile reversals like Eleven Madison Park. She attributes waning vegan interest to a "meat revival" spurred by RFK Jr's pro-steak dietary guidelines, wellness trends around protein and skepticism over ultra-processed plant foods. Beddington counters that her veganism, far from altruism alone, sustains her mental health amid climate despair—small acts of choice ward off impotence, however modest, and she urges perseverance as "fibremaxxing" gains traction.

articles.title: Weight-loss drugs do nothing to address the troubled relationships we have with our bodies | Susie Orbach
articles.trailText: The food, beauty and pharmaceutical industries poison our self-image. GLP-1 drugs will only make them richer – and strengthen the hold they have over us, says psychotherapist Susie Orbach
articles.summary: Psychotherapist Susie Orbach argues that GLP-1 weight-loss drugs, hyped by pharma, beauty and food industries, merely suppress appetite temporarily, enrich corporations and overlook our deep-seated body anxieties. While these drugs offer short-term relief, they fail to re-educate appetites, cause side-effects like “GLP-1 face” and muscle loss, and fuel new discrimination. Orbach warns the same ultra-processed food and cosmetic industries will adapt to profit from diminished hunger. She calls for a holistic, lifespan-wide approach to nurture healthy, unconflicted relationships with food and bodies from infancy onward.

articles.title: Iran cannot be bombed into democracy. But it can be helped to find its way there | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: Independent media, civil society, the rule of law – these are the things that Iranians truly need. And there are ways for the west to help secure them, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Tisdall warns that bombing Iran will not usher in democracy but instead advocates sustained nonviolent Western support for independent media, civil society and the rule of law. He dismisses Trump’s threats as short-sighted, underscoring military strikes’ inability to deliver lasting change. Tisdall proposes targeted sanctions, cyber operations to disrupt regime revenues and communications, and suspension of diplomatic ties. He urges backing of Iran’s fragmented opposition, expansion of Persian language broadcasts and digital tools to circumvent censorship. Ultimately, he argues that genuine reform—scrapping the supreme leader, enforcing human rights and free elections—must emerge from within, with Western practical assistance.

articles.title: Does my obsession with old trinkets make me a hoarder or a sentimental maximalist? | Eleanor Burnard
articles.trailText: Nostalgic knick-knacks will always have a place on my shelf – and in my heart. There’s something magical about being able to access the past in tangible, physical ways
articles.summary: Author embraces ‘sentimental maximalism’, filling her home with birthday cards, faded toys and handmade gifts—each a tangible link to personal history. Though some might call her a hoarder, she argues that these trinkets provide comfort and continuity amid adult responsibilities and economic uncertainty. Even objects that evoke embarrassment or loss—like a music-merch T-shirt or a farewell card—form a mosaic of identity and memory. In rejecting minimalism, she and her peers treat keepsakes as emotional lifelines, tethering them to moments and people who shaped their lives.

articles.title: Racial quotas for immigration are back | Heba Gowayed
articles.trailText: The Trump administration’s immigration policies hearken back to the racist 1924 Immigration Act, meant to whiten the US
articles.summary: On 14 January the Trump administration halted immigrant visas for applicants from 75 countries in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean plus 10 eastern European states, citing false “public charge” claims despite immigrants’ net tax contributions and lower benefit use. This mirrors the 1924 Johnson–Reed Act’s eugenicist racial quotas that privileged white Europeans, barred Asians and limited African and Levant immigration, and introduced illegal‐alien and literacy tests. Trump’s rhetoric and policy—English interviews, health screenings—echoes century‐old white supremacism. The ban serves to whiten the US, reviving racist quotas, and underscores enduring resistance needs akin to the civil‐rights coalition’s multiracial struggle.

articles.title: The Republicans’ latest Clinton stunt will not work | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Focusing on the ex-president won’t distract Americans from the Trump administration’s foot-dragging on the Epstein files
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi criticizes the Trump administration's tactic of targeting Bill and Hillary Clinton to distract from its own failure to release Jeffrey Epstein records. While Clinton admits visiting Epstein before his 2005 conviction but denies wrongdoing, Republicans have released photos and issued subpoenas threatening contempt. Mahdawi cites Trump's other stunts—from planting a Greenland annexation idea to floating a plot to kidnap Venezuela's president—yet an autoworker still heckled him as a 'pedophile protector' for Epstein-file delays. Even Jon Stewart urges full compliance only if DOJ also releases the files. She argues attacking the Clintons lacks the cultish fervor around Trump and will ultimately backfire, exposing the administration's contempt for the public.

articles.title: My picture was used in child abuse images. AI is putting others through my nightmare | Mara Wilson
articles.trailText: I was a child actor, exploited by strangers on the internet. Now millions of children face the same danger
articles.summary: Mara Wilson, a former child actor, describes her experience of having images from her youth manipulated into CSAM and warns that generative AI supercharges deepfake abuse of minors. She cites instances of AI tools like X’s Grok generating underage sexualized images and a Stanford study finding CSAM in training datasets. Open-source models risk removing safeguards entirely. Current industry filters and laws in Europe and parts of the US are insufficient. Wilson urges robust data curation, legal liability for platforms, technological detection tools, and public pressure to demand accountability and protect children online.

articles.title: Americans disapprove of Trump’s foreign policy. His escapades are likely to cost him | Sid Blumenthal
articles.trailText: History tells us what happens when American presidents focus on foreign policy and neglect domestic economic policy
articles.summary: President Donald Trump’s aggressive foreign policy—from his Venezuelan “Donroe Doctrine” capture of Nicolás Maduro to schemes to annex Greenland—has alienated majorities of Americans, who disapprove of military interventions, oil-grab plans and disregard for democratic norms. His theatrical “strongman” posturing, vanity projects and coercive diplomacy echo anachronistic imperialism while sidelining Congress, widening the affordability crisis at home. Polls record record-low approval for his foreign and economic leadership, risking midterm losses for Republicans. By attacking the Fed, empowering ICE violence and flaunting a Nietzschean “will to power,” Trump courts spectacle but erodes public trust and party credibility.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Stag and hen dos should be fun, not bankrupting endurance tests | Liam Pape
articles.trailText: Multi-day benders that deplete your mates’ annual leave and wallets are a no-no. Keep it cheeky, cheap and – crucially – enjoyable, says writer and live comedy producer Liam Pape
articles.summary: Liam Pape argues that modern stag and hen dos have become gruelling, multi-day and costly endurance tests—UK guests now spend £779 on average (£1,208 abroad)—fueled by US-style excess.
