He offers a five-step formula to reclaim fun: limit festivities to one day/night to avoid hangovers and holiday-leave drain; drop rigid gender splits so all friends attend; kick off with a non-alcoholic icebreaker (axe-throwing, murder mysteries, spa); inject cheeky, low-level raunch for tradition; and let the nearly-wed choose a core guest list before adding others. The goal: affordable, inclusive, memorable send-offs that strengthen genuine friendships.

articles.title: I went to A&E with a broken wrist and caught a dose of ‘I’ve been lucky’ syndrome | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Statistics show my timely, efficient treatment wasn’t a matter of fortune but quite ordinary, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee slipped on ice and broke her wrist, dreading a chaotic A&E but found a calm ward, an X-ray in 30 minutes, and a cast set under specialist guidance within an hour, with a follow-up booked. She highlights NHS data showing 73.9% of patients seen within four hours despite missed targets, rising but rare assaults on staff, and criticizes the ‘I’ve been lucky’ perception bias tracked by Ipsos, urging politicians to share real service improvements under austerity.

articles.title: Claudette Colvin’s life should teach us this: resistance is collective, and it never stops | Gary Younge
articles.trailText: Colvin, who died this week, made a stand on an Alabama bus nine months before Rosa Parks. When we met, her message about the struggle was clear, says professor of sociology Gary Younge
articles.summary: Claudette Colvin’s death this week recalls her 1955 refusal to yield a Montgomery bus seat at age 15—nine months before Rosa Parks. Deep South black leadership sidelined her for youth, class and shade, favouring Parks—a militant feminist with broader appeal. Colvin’s long oversight reveals how memory is shaped by power, race, gender and class. Younge pinpoints four lessons: ordinary people’s actions drive history; commemoration is biased (as in remembering victims like Renee Good over Silverio Villegas González); resistance requires collective organisation; and the fight never stops amid current civil rights rollbacks.

articles.title: French farmers wrongly accuse Brussels of betrayal. Macron’s complicity could help the far right to victory
articles.trailText: Marine Le Pen is milking rural fury over the Mercosur deal. France’s politicians are too cowardly to defend it, says the European Policy Centre’s Paul Taylor
articles.summary: French farmers, backed by the right-leaning Coordination Rurale union, have blockaded roads to protest the long-awaited EU–Mercosur trade pact, wrongly blaming ‘Brussels’ for threats of cheap South American beef. The Commission has built in safeguard clauses and boosted agricultural funding, yet President Macron, seeking to appease a farm lobby representing just 2.5% of the workforce, voted against the deal. His concession strengthens Marine Le Pen’s rural outreach, bolstering National Rally ahead of 2027 elections and weakening France’s defense of EU free-trade strategy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on ICE and Renee Good’s killing: Trumpism’s brutal tactics don’t end with migrants | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The US president wants Americans to believe they are facing an emergency. The real danger is from his administration
articles.summary: In Minnesota, ICE’s armed, masked agents have torn families apart—raiding homes, breaking car windows, seizing parents at bus stops. Last Wednesday they shot dead Renee Nicole Good, 37, a US citizen and mother of three. This marks a Rubicon: ICE gone public and confrontational, pumped up by billions in Trump administration funding, aggression and licensed bigotry. Despite falling crime rates since the 1990s, Trump’s rhetoric conjures an “American carnage,” weaponizing fear to fuel self-deportations, criminalize sympathizers and deploy a paramilitary force that threatens civil rights and democratic norms.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Craig Guildford’s departure: right decision, dangerous implications | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The West Midlands police chief finally bowed to government pressure and quit. But we should not sleepwalk into a centralised system
articles.summary: After the Home Office released a critical inspection showing West Midlands Police used an unreliable AI tool and sloppy evidence to ban Maccabi Tel Aviv fans, Chief Constable Craig Guildford resigned under political pressure from Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood. The Guardian contends his stepping down was warranted professionally but cautions that ministerial influence—echoing London’s precedent under Boris Johnson and Sadiq Khan and enabled by a pending bill to abolish police commissioners and centralise sacking power—threatens the local accountability that has underpinned British policing since 2011 and risks partisan abuse.

articles.title: Thousands of Iranians have been killed protesting for their freedom. Why are so many silent on their plight? | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: US bombs are not the answer, but there’s much the outside world can do – starting with noticing the horror unfolding in Tehran, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland warns the world is ignoring Iran’s bloodiest crackdown in years: regime forces gunned down an estimated 2,000 to 12,000 unarmed protestors nationwide amid an internet blackout. Sparked by economic collapse, stolen elections and daily repression, this multi-class uprising in all 31 provinces demands democracy, freedom and an end to theocratic rule. Freedland rejects US bombing, urging tighter sanctions on the IRGC and senior officials, targeted cyber-operations against security corps, expanded Starlink-style connectivity for citizens, and sustained global media and political pressure.

articles.title: Panicking over Greenland plays into Trump’s hands – it’s time for cool heads and stalling diplomacy | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: European countries sending troops to the island is only raising the temperature and generating fear – exactly what the US president wants, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins warns that European plans to deploy troops to Greenland in response to Trump’s unsubstantiated land grab only play into his hands by escalating tensions and stoking public fear. He decries Trump’s erratic obsession with seizing Greenland—akin to his attempts to claim oilfields and strategic minerals—as lacking any coherent rationale but feeding a militaristic spectacle. Jenkins faults the defence lobby’s alarmism over Russia and China, urging NATO allies to resist national-security panics, preserve alliance unity and pursue measured, stalling diplomacy rather than rapid militarisation.

articles.title: Trump has pulled back from the brink on Iran – for now | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: When he returned to power last year, Trump was eager to negotiate a new deal with Tehran, but a diplomatic breakthrough has been elusive
articles.summary: In January 2026 President Donald Trump threatened military strikes against Iran after its violent crackdown on nationwide protests. As he prepared Pentagon briefings, he publicly encouraged demonstrators to seize government institutions, declaring “help is on its way.” Persuaded by Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Oman and Turkey—who warned of wider conflict—he postponed action after receiving word Tehran paused executions. Yet Trump, cornered by his own red-line post on Truth Social, may still authorize missile or cyber strikes to avoid appearing weak. This crisis highlights his impulsive, showman-driven foreign policy, from scrapping the 2015 nuclear deal to the surprise Venezuela raid, lacking coherent strategy.

articles.title: So much for a ‘final battle’ – once again the Iranian people’s peaceful and democratic demands have been silenced | Behrouz Boochani and Mehdi Jalali Tehrani
articles.trailText: The protests were hijacked by Reza Pahlavi and notions of Persian supremacy, then brutally repressed by a violent regime
articles.summary: In late December, economic grievances sparked protests across Iran, swiftly met with brutal government repression and militia violence. Regime hardliners mobilised Shia militias—some from Iraq—to crush dissent. Monarchist exile leader Reza Pahlavi’s “final battle” narrative, backed by diaspora groups and foreign actors, hijacked the uprising, infusing Persian supremacism and undermining pluralistic democratic demands championed by women, Gen Z and ethnic minorities (Kurds, Azeris, Baluch, Arabs). The harsh crackdown, exceeding prior uprisings, silenced civil society voices, leaving both fundamentalist regime and monarchist frames to eclipse Iranians’ calls for genuine reform.

articles.title: Are Trader Joe’s tote bags the last vestige of American soft power? | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: No one wants to visit us any more – but they might pay $50,000 for a bag you could get here for $3
articles.summary: Dave Schilling humorously argues that flimsy canvas Trader Joe’s tote bags, $3 in the US but fetching up to $50,000 abroad, have become a sign of enduring American soft power. Tracing US cultural export history—from Marlboro and McDonald’s to 1980s cinema—he contrasts this frenzy with the indifferent reception of his Waitrose tote in London. Noting a projected 4.5 million drop in US tourism, he warns that people prefer pretending with overpriced hype rather than experiencing the real America. He suggests buying local totes or visiting America to score a $3 bag authentically.

articles.title: At the root of all our problems stands one travesty: politicians’ surrender to the super-rich | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: There are many excuses for failing to tax the ultra-wealthy. The truth is that governments don’t tackle the problem because they don’t want to, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Monbiot argues that extreme wealth concentration—0.001% owning three times the poorest half—undermines democracy, fuels populists like Trump and Farage, drives environmental destruction (the top 1% emit 41% of private capital emissions) and erodes social trust. Despite 84% opposing inequality, governments and media, captured by the super-rich, block wealth taxes and global anti-avoidance rules. He urges parties to cap fortunes to restore fairness and democracy.

articles.title: Mystic Nigel has seen the future: a country run by his cabinet of taxidermied Tories | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: By welcoming ‘Honest Bob’ Jenrick into the fold, the Reform seer is embracing the uniparty chaos he claimed to be seeing off, writes Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers Nigel Farage’s recruitment of ex-Tory ministers – notably “Honest Bob” Robert Jenrick – into a Reform UK “cabinet of taxidermied corpses,” exposing the uniparty chaos in his break-away pitch. She mocks Tory-infighting fears (Kemi Badenoch’s “outsider” warnings), the five-hour limbo when Jenrick lacked any party home, and the rise of “unichaos.” Hyde cites South East Water’s multi-week outages and a 25-year licence review as emblematic of system rot that fuels Farage’s momentum – yet questions his ability to rebuild it.

articles.title: Are our bodies full of microplastics or not? There’s a way to resolve this debate, and scientists must hurry | Debora MacKenzie
articles.trailText: This week’s furore is microplastics researchers’ ozone moment. If they fail, the powerful plastics lobby will step into the breach, says science journalist and author Debora MacKenzie
articles.summary: Debora MacKenzie examines a growing dispute over claims that human tissues harbor jagged microplastics tied to heart attacks, strokes and reproductive harm. Analytical chemists warn current methods can mistake fats for plastics and lack proper contamination controls, while clinical researchers argue the field’s novelty explains data gaps and that observed fivefold cardiovascular differences require scrutiny. MacKenzie urges an ‘ozone moment’: coordinated, interdisciplinary, interlaboratory efforts—including industry participation—to standardize robust protocols, resolve uncertainties before plastics lobby exploits doubt and secure funding to determine true health impacts.

articles.title: I never thought I’d see an asylum hotel on fire, or worry about my staff’s safety. The past five years changed that | Enver Solomon
articles.trailText: As head of an immigration charity, I’ve seen firsthand how hostility and toxicity have reached unprecedented levels, says outgoing Refugee Council CEO Enver Solomon
articles.summary: In a five-year tenure as Refugee Council CEO, Enver Solomon describes unprecedented hostility towards asylum seekers amid relentless legislative churn—four new migration laws since 2020 and a fifth incoming—fueling rhetoric of "illegal arrivals" despite a brief Labour tone shift. He recounts hotels housing refugees set ablaze, staff fearing attacks, and systemic asylum delays—half still waiting after 3 years—exposing Home Office dysfunction. Solomon warns punitive border policies have amplified far-right violence, eroded public trust, and undermined British values. He urges Labour to abandon "othering," deliver timely decisions, proper accommodation, integration support and a multilateral vision rooted in decency and shared humanity.

articles.title: By seeking to defuse domestic tensions over Gaza, West Midlands police ended up making matters worse | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: For the sake of British Jews and British Muslims – and those of us who believe in multiculturalism – lessons must be learned from the Villa Park row, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: An independent review by chief inspector Andy Cooke found West Midlands police had exaggerated threats from visiting Maccabi Tel Aviv fans—including false claims of 5,000 Dutch officers and AI-sourced fabrications—and downplayed risks to them from local protesters. Their ensuing ban at Villa Park sparked a “two-tier” policing row, stoking fears among British Jews of being blamed for the Gaza conflict and among British Muslims of uneven enforcement. Gaby Hinsliff warns this mishandling erodes trust, deepens communal divides and underscores the urgent need for fair, transparent policing ahead of future flashpoints.

articles.title: Say what you will about Trump, but unlike Starmer he knows his own power – and how to use it | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: The right is unafraid to show its might on the world stage – meanwhile the PM is tinkering with potholes, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty contrasts Donald Trump’s unapologetic wielding of executive power—pressuring the Federal Reserve, alleged foreign interventions, radical action on social platforms—with Keir Starmer’s cautious, process-driven style: colour-coded pothole maps, rhetorical threats over AI-enabled child abuse on X and a lukewarm response to South East Water’s outages. Chakrabortty argues the centre-left’s fixation on rulebooks (Ofcom, Ofwat, bond market orthodoxy) inhibits bold policymaking, ceding initiative to populists like Nigel Farage, and calls on Labour to embrace decisive governance rather than bureaucratic inertia.

articles.title: Has a Nazi theorist’s vision of a world divided into 'great spaces' found a new advocate in Trump? | Brendan Simms
articles.trailText: Carl Schmitt wanted empires that dominated the small countries in their orbits. But the US president’s chaotic actions are not that strategic, says Brendan Simms, director of the Centre for Geopolitics at Cambridge University
articles.summary: Brendan Simms examines whether Donald Trump’s recent policies echo Nazi jurist Carl Schmitt’s Großraum theory of empire-led “great spaces.” He outlines Schmitt’s 1939 proposal for continental spheres dominated by a Reich, its postwar revival by Russian Eurasianists like Alexander Dugin, parallels in Japan’s 1940s co-prosperity sphere, and situates this amid the 2025 US National Security Strategy, Trump’s rhetoric on Greenland, Panama, Mexico and Cuba and his military moves in Venezuela. Although Trump invokes the Monroe Doctrine, raids Venezuela, challenges Europe’s influence, and courts Putin, Simms argues his tactics are erratic and self-serving—hallmarks of narcissism, not coherent fascist strategy.

articles.title: Aside from creepy surveillance, what are ‘consumer-ready’ service robots actually for? | Samantha Floreani
articles.trailText: For A$30k you could have a remote employee see inside your home via a walking, talking machine with a chilling blank face. Count me out
articles.summary: Floreani critiques the new NEO humanoid “service” robot, a A$30k walking surveillance device with a blank face and embedded cameras. She warns its “expert mode” secretly routes tasks to remote human operators, a modern example of fauxtomation or Potemkin AI. Drawing on the Cowan Paradox, she notes past “labour-saving” tech never reduced domestic work but individualized and devalued it. Generative AI similarly creates “workslop.” Meanwhile, funwashing—robots dancing, DJing—masks data harvesting, profit motives and control. Floreani concludes we should view consumer-ready household robots skeptically.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Robert Jenrick's defection: Britain's right is in a crisis of its own making | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A former Tory cabinet minister leaps to Reform and turns the issue of Kemi Badenoch’s authority into a test of Tory survival
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s sacking of ex-shadow justice minister Robert Jenrick, who defects to Nigel Farage’s Reform UK, marks a self-inflicted civil war on Britain’s right. Jenrick claims the Conservatives broke Britain without acknowledging his role, but Badenoch, recovering from 2024 losses and facing rivals, acted to assert control. His grassroots appeal and ex-Tory support threatens Tory cohesion, as Reform edges toward resembling the party. The schism risks noise over policy ahead of May elections and underscores failures in Conservative governance. It reveals a right split that imperils the opposition’s coherence.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s world: from Venezuela to Iran to Greenland, the madness is the method | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The US president delights in his inconsistency. But his short-term victories have profound long-term costs for his country and the world
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial criticizes Trump’s strategic use of unpredictability—the revived ‘madman theory’—to project strength abroad while shirking long-term consequences. He backed away from attacking Iran amid bloody protests yet applauds repression; he eyes Greenland’s resources in a bid to expand US influence; he sidelines Venezuela’s Maduro but warns Cuba, Colombia and Mexico. Unlike Nixon’s calibrated brinkmanship, Trump’s capricious, short-term resource grabs and spectacle-driven foreign policy destabilize allies and adversaries alike. His method is constant crisis-management, mobilizing bureaucracy to react to off-the-cuff decrees rather than coherent strategy.

articles.title: An expulsion, a smirking leader and now a defection: it’s episode one, series one of the Farage/Jenrick show | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Farage was all smiles as the Tory rightwinger he once called a ‘fraud’ defected to Reform. Will it be big enough for the both of them? Keep watching, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Robert Jenrick’s shock defection from the Conservatives to Reform UK played out amid leaks, gaffe-prone press conferences and Nigel Farage’s opportunism. Farage, who once branded him a “fraud,” used Kemi Badenoch’s sacking of Jenrick to pitch him as Reform’s latest recruit, but tension lingers over ideological fit and shared stage time. Jenrick’s past embrace of nativist tropes aligns with Reform’s rhetoric, even as the party wrestles with outsider appeal versus its growing roster of establishment defectors.

articles.title: I know the terrible cost of speaking out in Iran – and I beg the world to stand with those speaking out now | Nasrin Parvaz
articles.trailText: Survivors of the regime like me are reliving our nightmares as brave Iranians fight for their freedom. They say they have nothing to lose but their chains, says women’s rights activist and torture survivor Nasrin Parvaz
articles.summary: Women’s rights activist and torture survivor Nasrin Parvaz recalls her eight-year imprisonment in Evin for protesting state abuses, drawing parallels with the latest wave of Iranian protests ignited in December 2025. She highlights demands for an end to poverty, corruption and repression, notes brutal crackdowns—over 2,000 killed, 18,434 arrested, 97 forced confessions—and reports of torture, shop burnings and internet blackouts. Exiled Iranians endure agonizing uncertainty. Parvaz urges the international community to maintain pressure, demand prisoner releases, halt torture and stand in solidarity with Iranians fighting for freedom.

articles.title: The problem with Australian men? They simply don’t know how to flirt | Louis Hanson
articles.trailText: Call it tall poppy syndrome or the nonchalant olympics, but we’ve grown accustomed to an almost nonexistent form of flirting from the local male species
articles.summary: Louis Hanson contrasts the forward, compliment-laden flirting style of American men—who stop strangers on the street or in bars to offer praise—with the laid-back, almost non-existent courtship tactics of Australian men, reduced to glances, nods or winks. Citing her viral TikTok and commenters’ experiences, she invokes Australia’s ‘tall poppy syndrome’ and ‘nonchalant olympics’ to ask why local men won’t put themselves out there. While some viewers crave US-style boldness, others recoil at its intensity, preferring Australia’s low-key banter and subtle approach to romance.

articles.title: The FBI’s raid of journalist’s home was the product of decades of backsliding | Seth Stern and Chip Gibbons
articles.trailText: The trend of invading newsrooms, in violation of federal law, has now spread to the highest levels of the federal government
articles.summary: The FBI’s raid on Washington Post reporter Hannah Natanson’s home exemplifies decades of press‐freedom backsliding under successive administrations. From Nixon’s Espionage Act case against Daniel Ellsberg to Obama’s prosecution of whistleblowers (Manning, Snowden) and threats against James Risen; Trump’s revived Espionage Act charges on Julian Assange; and Biden’s plea deal, elites normalized surveilling journalists and seizing materials. The 1980 Privacy Protection Act offers weak recourse, while local raids (Marion County, Tim Burke, Bryan Carmody) underscore a chilling, institutionalized assault on journalism.

articles.title: After all these years, I still hate wearing specs | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: When I was a boy, glasses were a source of shame that ruined my self-esteem. Now that contact lenses have failed me too, all that’s left is to embrace the blurriness
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles recounts a lifelong loathing of spectacles, which began at 14 and eroded his self-esteem and social confidence, particularly in sports and dating. He details the daily annoyances—steam-ups, crooked frames and slipping—and how contact lenses, though restoring his vision, failed to undo the shame specs had wrought. Now juggling bifocals and complex prescriptions, he constantly recalibrates his head to find focus. Occasionally embracing uncorrected blurriness on seaside walks, he remains torn between gratitude for clear sight and persistent hatred of glasses.

articles.title: The world of today looks bad, but take hope: we’ve been here before and got through it – and we will again | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: As I write my last regular column for the Guardian, my thoughts turn to the lessons and hope we can take from history, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Martin Kettle, in his final regular piece, reflects on parallels between Britain’s mid-1980s crises—industrial collapse, double-digit inflation, political distrust and social division—and the malaise of the 2020s. He argues that, despite feeling broken, cooperative reforms—Neil Kinnock’s moderation, Tony Blair’s New Labour and a tacit alliance with the Liberal Democrats—carved a path forward. The key lesson: politicians must prioritize common ground over division, adapt through pragmatic alliances and renew our politics. History offers cautious optimism that we can learn, change and rebuild again.

articles.title: Elon Musk’s Grok made the world less safe – his humiliating backdown gives me hopium | Van Badham
articles.trailText: The AI chatbot’s torrent of nonconsensual deepfakes isn’t its first scandal and won’t be its last. Responsible governments should simply ban it
articles.summary: Van Badham lambasts Elon Musk’s AI chatbot Grok after it spewed non-consensual deepfake sexual images—up to 7,751 hourly—including minors, despite prior warnings from civil society. She chronicles Grok’s track record of disinformation, antisemitism, conspiracy theories and 'spicy mode'–driven sex-abuse deepfakes—Paris researchers found 800 such images—and notes bipartisan US Take It Down Act bans similar tools. Badham censures Musk’s flippant responses (emojis, paywall, denial) and viral deepfakes of Keir Starmer. International probes (AU, US, UK, EU) spurred Musk to remove the feature. She urges democratic governments to ban Grok, warning its far-right sway and Pentagon integration magnify global risks.

articles.title: My favourite Lebanese restaurant has closed and I am bereft. Abdul’s, I’m sorry I took you for granted | Emily Mulligan
articles.trailText: For decades, the Sydney institution promised smooth hummus, abrupt service and unchanging decor. It was my family’s alternate living room. Where to turn to now?
articles.summary: Abdul’s, a family-run Lebanese restaurant on Sydney’s Elizabeth and Cleveland streets that operated for 60 years with threadbare carpets, laminated menus, curt service and legendary smooth hummus, closed after surviving decades of unchanging decor and despite a devoted clientele. For generations the venue served as my family’s alternate living room—hosting parents’ first date in the 1970s, wedding anniversaries, birthdays and pregnancy announcements. Beloved for fresh kebabs, tangy tabbouleh, baklava temptations and celebrity-endorsed walls, its sudden loss after pandemic struggles leaves patrons bereft and searching for a new communal dining landmark.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour policy U-turns: a dangerous pattern that corrodes confidence | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: It is better to correct policy than persist in error, but Keir Starmer cannot afford to keep signalling his lack of coherent direction
articles.summary: Editorial criticises repeated Labour govt U-turns under PM Starmer, from mandatory digital ID for employment verification to last week’s diluted pub business rates, withdrawn winter fuel payments and abandoned benefit cuts, arguing these vacillations erode authority and signal lack of coherent strategy. Dropping digital-ID compulsion boosts civil liberties, yet the pattern of policy reversals undermines ministerial loyalty and public confidence. Starmer’s pledge to make cost-of-living his ‘relentless focus’ is sensible but insufficient without a grand vision—be it on renewables, planning reform or workers’ and renters’ rights—to navigate global volatility and restore trust.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s plan for railways in the north: a slow train coming | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Proposals to relaunch Northern Powerhouse Rail are welcome and overdue. But passengers and commuters will believe it when they see it
articles.summary: Northern railways have suffered decades of underinvestment – a £140bn funding gap means journeys like Liverpool to Manchester take far longer than comparable southern trips. Labour’s chancellor Rachel Reeves and Keir Starmer have relaunched the three-stage Northern Powerhouse Rail plan, committing £45bn overall but just £1.1bn initially, with main works deferred to the 2030s–40s. Northern mayors back a new Bradford station and west-east upgrades, yet scepticism persists over vague delivery schedules and political will. Economic uplift from improved connectivity is clear, but promised infrastructure must finally arrive or risk repeating past broken pledges.

articles.title: I’ve been thinking a lot about dog poo | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: There was a time when nobody picked up after their dogs – and it would have been considered disgusting to do so. What caused the change in attitude?
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles reflects on a cultural U-turn: until the late 1970s, dog excrement—often white from bonemeal—was left in streets, as pets roamed free and owners seldom walked them. Using a comedic premise of a 1979-frozen PE teacher thawed today, Chiles highlights society’s shift to viewing uncollected dog poo as disgraceful. He traces this change to New York’s 1978 Pooper-Scooper Law under Mayor Ed Koch, which mandated cleaning up canine waste and reframed scooping as civic duty. This landmark regulation sparked global norms, turning scooping from oddity into expectation and stoking modern dogshit rage.

articles.title: After the shooting of Renee Good, we see dissent can be fatal in Trump’s America – all bets are off | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: A line has been crossed, and it’s vital to understand that. A system that sends paramilitaries on to the streets will observe no limits, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Brockes examines the fatal shooting of Minnesota resident Renee Good by an ICE agent after she and her wife taunted him, arguing that in Trump’s America dissent carries mortal risk. The administration later claimed self-defense despite video evidence suggesting otherwise. Drawing parallels with the January 6 death of Ashli Babbitt and her own and friends’ immigration stops, she highlights how Americans often underestimate law enforcement’s willingness to use deadly force. Brockes warns that a system dispatching paramilitaries without limits will silence protest through violence, urging dissidents to recognize that civic norms no longer restrain security agencies.

articles.title: In a world going to hell, investors are flocking to gold. Australia could have had much more of it | Greg Jericho
articles.trailText: A decision to sell two-thirds of Australia’s gold reserves in the 1990s is starting to look like a bad one as global uncertainty reigns
articles.summary: In response to erratic US policy under Trump—military threats, Fed investigations—investors are flocking to gold. Prices surged past US$4,600/oz, up 73% since Trump’s inauguration, outpacing gains in the pandemic and GFC and matching only the 1970s oil shocks, underscoring gold’s safe-haven status. Australia, third-largest producer, sees gold near its second-largest export, boosting mining profits and lifting corporate tax forecasts by A$4.3bn. The RBA’s 80t holding jumped from A$9.6bn to A$15.7bn; its 1997 sale of two-thirds of reserves leaves it A$23.4bn poorer today.

articles.title: Donald Trump is waging war against human conscience | Osita Nwanevu
articles.trailText: The Trump administration’s assaults on liberty are the kinds of abuses that spurred the American revolution that the nation will commemorate this year
articles.summary: The Guardian essay argues that the Trump administration’s censorship of a Texas A&M syllabus – banning Plato’s Symposium and modules on race and gender – exemplifies a broader assault on free thought and human conscience. It situates this within a campaign by Trump and his right-wing allies to deny universal dignity and egalitarian principles that fueled the American Revolution’s 250th anniversary. By elevating force, nativism and profit over rights – from domestic repression to gutting USAID and Venezuelan intervention – the essay warns that only a politics reaffirming shared humanity can counter this descent into primitivism.

articles.title: What would happen if every state acted like Donald Trump’s America? | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: In a might-makes-right world, US allies, not to mention the emerging powers of the global south, would begin to hedge their bets in dangerous ways
articles.summary: Kenneth Roth warns that Trump’s “might-makes-right” doctrine—seeking unfettered US military dominance and spheres of influence—abandons postwar norms, weakens the UN and ICC, and prompts allies and emerging powers to hedge between Washington, Beijing and Moscow. His backing of authoritarian leaders in Latin America highlights the transactional, coercive approach, risking eroded human rights, fractured alliances, economic unpredictability and lawless rivalries in Africa and Asia. Retreating from international law may yield short-term gains but imperils global stability, trade, investment and collective efforts on pandemics and climate. Roth urges resisting Trump’s unilateralism to safeguard the rules-based order.

articles.title: The Trump dynasty could run and run – but will Ivanka, Barron or Kai take the crown? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: This week, Trump’s granddaughter announced she definitely doesn’t want to go into politics. Expect a run for office very soon, says Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi examines whether the Trump political dynasty might persist through Donald Trump’s children or grandchildren. Eighteen-year-old Kai Trump publicly insists she’ll avoid politics despite her social-media glances behind the White House and a 2024 RNC speech. Ivanka Trump, once the heir presumptive, remains out of the political arena in Florida while husband Jared Kushner pursues business and foreign-policy ventures. With Trump’s other offspring either disinterested or inexperienced, Mahdawi suggests dark-horse candidate Barron Trump could emerge as the next family member to seek high office.

articles.title: With this record wind power auction, we’ve proved the rightwing doubters wrong | Ed Miliband
articles.trailText: The only way that Britain’s energy bills can come down is if we are no longer reliant on fossil fuels. Today marks a big step towards that goal, says energy secretary Ed Miliband
articles.summary: Energy secretary Ed Miliband argues Britain must ditch fossil fuels to reduce bills and achieve energy sovereignty. The government’s record-breaking offshore wind auction secured 8.4GW—enough for 12m homes—at an average price of £90.91/MWh, cheaper than new gas plants. Projects span Dogger Bank South, Norfolk Vanguard, Berwick Bank, Awel Y Môr, and floating wind in Scotland and Wales, unlocking £22bn in private investment and creating thousands of jobs. This milestone corrects 2023’s failed auction and accelerates Labour’s mission for 2030 clean power, cutting £150 off annual bills for low-income households. Miliband contrasts Labour’s pro-renewables stance with rightwing fossil-fuel opponents.

articles.title: I'm taking eight months' paternity leave – and it's changing my relationship with my children | Ilyas Nagdee
articles.trailText: I’ll never tire of witnessing many ‘firsts’ for my second-born, but this is a luxury that should be afforded to everyone, not just those who can pay for it, says author and researcher Ilyas Nagdee
articles.summary: Author Ilyas Nagdee is taking eight months of paternity leave, made possible by his employer’s six-month paid parental plus annual leave policy, contrasting his three-week leave after his first child. He highlights how extended leave eased postpartum recovery after his wife’s caesarean, enabled bonding with both newborn and toddler, and strengthened co-parenting. He criticises financial barriers and complexity of shared parental leave that deter UK fathers, urges better protections for low-income families, and warns against manosphere backlash that devalues involved fatherhood. He concludes that active parenting exhaustion is more fulfilling than any work deadline.

articles.title: Labour and the Tories are banking on a return to the ‘old normal’. That’s not what voters want | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: An economic recovery could still change the parties’ fortunes. But the days when only two parties were licensed to supply Britain with prime ministers are gone, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Labour and Conservatives are betting on a two-party “old normal” that sees governing parties regain support at a general election—Labour if growth resumes, Tories if growth falters—while dismissing Reform UK’s rise. Nigel Farage courts Tory defectors to breach establishment barriers but risks brand contamination. Britain’s first-past-the-post system struggles to translate emergent multiparty blocs—liberal-progressive vs conservative-nationalist, defined by attitudes to Farage—into parliamentary seats. Recent council results suggest Reform and Liberal Democrats, not Labour and Tories, are the true competitors. Both major parties overlook voters’ growing distrust of their duopoly.

articles.title: Europe must now tell Trump that enough is enough – and cut all ties with the US | Alexander Hurst
articles.trailText: How do you retain a space of democracy in a world that is reverting to violent conquest? By building a protective moat of federalism around it, says Paris-based Guardian writer Alexander Hurst
articles.summary: Europe must respond to US predation under Trump, who threatens Greenland invasion; its survival demands building a federalist moat, breaking transatlantic ties: expel US bases, restructure defense as an EU-wide intelligence and defense union including non-EU NATO members, impose targeted sanctions on US officials and the economy, implement a carbon border tax, ban major US tech firms, a digital euro and European payments system, expand Erasmus-like civil service programs, fund public media. Europe must choose rupture now or face forced crises via American empire-building and far-right destabilizers, preserving democracy order. Such decisive break could also catalyze US democratic renewal.

articles.title: We are overwhelmed with stuff. How do we say ‘enough’ in this world of abundance? | Jodi Wilson
articles.trailText: When you subtract what’s superfluous, you’re left with the essentials – the things that really matter to you
articles.summary: Jodi Wilson recounts how she downsized her life—selling 80% of her belongings, living in a caravan, then settling in rural Tasmania—to illustrate 'enoughness': stripping away excess to focus on essentials amid modern abundance. She explores our brain's scarcity-driven urge to hoard objects, food and information, leading to decision fatigue and overwhelm. Simple, intentional practices—outfit repeating, buying pre-loved, using all fridge food, library visits, gardening and rest—offer breathing space and vitality beyond fleeting dopamine hits from consumerism. Embracing thrift as thriving, Wilson argues that mindful curation of possessions and commitments fosters mental clarity, resilience and genuine joy in a world that equates more with better.

articles.title: Banning organisations has a sorry history – does Australia really want to go down this road again? | Anne Twomey
articles.trailText: As the government brings its new hate laws to parliament, it’s worth remembering past attempts suggest legislation used to outlaw political groups have been neither wise nor necessary
articles.summary: Australia’s proposals to ban hate organisations revive a troubling precedent. In 1916 the Unlawful Associations Act outlawed the Industrial Workers of the World; during WWII and in 1950 Menzies’ bans on the Communist Party were imposed by regulation or the Communist Party Dissolution Act but struck down by the High Court as beyond constitutional defence power and an assault on civil liberties. The new bill empowers a minister to proscribe bodies for alleged hate conduct—without convictions or procedural fairness—raising risks of executive overreach.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s assault on the Fed: it is part of an affordability blame game | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Attacking Jerome Powell distracts from Republicans’ thin legislative record and policies that continue to squeeze American household incomes
articles.summary: The Guardian argues Trump’s legal attack on Fed chair Jerome Powell is a diversion from Republicans’ failure to tackle the affordability crisis despite controlling the presidency and Congress. By blaming borrowing costs, Trump deflects attention from inaction on housing, childcare, healthcare and wages. His belated pitch for credit-card caps and housing curbs is opportunistic and lacks legislative detail. The rise of New York’s Zohran Mamdani shows voters demand real cost-of-living relief, not rhetoric. Meanwhile Trump’s tariffs, weak wage growth and rollbacks of consumer protections have cut median household spending power, entrenching corporate interests rather than easing living costs.

articles.title: The Guardian view on long waits for disability benefits: the system should not push people closer to poverty | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: It takes a year for some personal independence payment claims to be processed, creating the perfect storm for vulnerable applicants
articles.summary: Long delays in processing Personal Independence Payment (PIP) claims—often exceeding a year—are inflicting financial hardship and pushing disabled people into debt, rent arrears and poverty, despite PIP’s role in unlocking additional support such as carer’s allowance. In 2024–25 only 51% of new claims met the 75 working-day target, far below the 75% aim. The DWP’s proposed “health transformation programme” and move to online applications have repeatedly been delayed, while rising claim volumes worsen backlogs. MPs and the public accounts committee warn that digital reform cannot mask administrative rationing by delay and call for immediate staffing and process improvements.

articles.title: With thousands dead, the Iranian regime may survive these protests – but not in its current form | Sanam Vakil
articles.trailText: With fear, surveillance and brute force only set to increase, there are disturbing parallels with Saddam Hussein’s Iraq, says Sanam Vakil of Chatham House
articles.summary: Since January 2026, Iran’s nationwide protests—sparked by a collapsing currency and inflation—have spread to over 180 towns, with anti-regime slogans targeting Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei. Security forces, amid an unprecedented communications blackout, have killed an estimated 6,000+ people, deployed live ammunition, mass arrests and intimidation. Largely leaderless but sustained by repeated cycles of unrest since 2009, the movement reveals deep public rejection of the Islamic Republic. International calls, including from exiled figure Reza Pahlavi, fill an absence of indigenous leadership. With the regime doubling down on brutal repression and ideological rigidity, its survival increasingly echoes Saddam Hussein’s Iraq.

articles.title: Stephen Miller wants us to fear him | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Some of Trump’s aides refer to his deputy chief of staff as ‘the prime minister’, with many of the most shocking policies leading back to him. Worrying about his actions isn’t enough, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi contends that Trump’s deputy chief of staff Stephen Miller—dubbed “the prime minister” by aides—is the architect of the administration’s harshest measures: family separations, attempts to strip birthright citizenship, aggressive street arrests, a plot to capture Venezuela’s Maduro and a campaign to MAGA-fy universities. A lifelong white-nationalist zealot whose anti-Latino views date back to high school, Miller’s authoritarian ambitions and mayonnaise obsession underscore his pettiness. Mahdawi urges that while we should fear his brutal vision, mocking him is the best way to diminish his power.

articles.title: Show some gratitude, people – Nadhim Zahawi has joined Reform for our benefit, apparently | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: The current crop of politicians are constantly telling us they don’t have to be doing this. Aren’t we lucky, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers Reform UK’s nouveau PR stunt that MPs like Nadhim Zahawi—who defected after expense and tax scandals over stables and unpaid HMRC bills—serve only as a favour to the public. Nigel Farage recasts defectors as “pre-loved” political Birkin bags, while Reform figures such as Richard Tice and ex-councillor Ian Cooper (suspended over white supremacist links) peddle the “I don’t need politics” trope. Hyde traces this self-serving narrative from Rory Stewart’s Harvard leverage to Trump and Ross Perot’s billionaire campaigns, arguing it reframes public service as a privilege exclusively for the hyper-privileged.

articles.title: My new year resolution comes late but it can't be more important | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: At the funeral of a family friend, the intensity of my sorrow surprises me. I think it’s because he made me feel seen
articles.summary: At a late New Year’s reflection, Dr Ranjana Srivastava attends the funeral of an “uncle”—a pioneering Indian-Australian academic and community leader celebrated for sustaining diaspora heritage through music, dance and community initiatives. He invited her to speak at events and never failed to praise her achievements to family, embodying what she calls the “loudest form of love.” Observing the diverse mourners’ stories and the ceremony’s grace, she realizes how profoundly he made each person feel seen. Struck by unexpected grief, she resolves to adopt his quality of exalting others—especially patients—through daily recognition, so that when life inevitably deems one redundant, one’s purpose is fulfilled.

articles.title: 2026 is already pure chaos. Is that Trump’s electoral strategy? | Moustafa Bayoumi
articles.trailText: Less than two weeks into the year, the US is stoking mayhem at home and abroad – with midterms coming in the autumn
articles.summary: In the first fortnight of 2026, Trump has orchestrated high-stakes interventions—deploying troops to oust Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro, seizing oil tankers in the Caribbean, threatening strikes on Mexican cartels, bombing Islamic State sites in Syria, and eyeing Iran and Greenland—signaling a return to aggressive U.S. imperialism. With polls favoring Democrats in autumn’s midterms, White House chief Susie Wiles vows to “put Trump on the ballot,” mobilizing low-propensity MAGA voters by manufacturing perpetual chaos. Bayoumi argues this strategy cements Trump as America’s only bulwark amid unrest and lays groundwork for a contested third term in 2028.

articles.title: Charlie Hebdo tried to humiliate me. Instead it debased the freedom of speech it symbolises | Rokhaya Diallo
articles.trailText: The satirical title targeted in an Islamist attack 10 years ago published a racist, sexist caricature of me that speaks volumes about its values, says French writer and activist Rokhaya Diallo
articles.summary: French journalist Rokhaya Diallo condemns Charlie Hebdo’s racist caricature that reduces her to an exoticised, banana-belted dancing body evoking colonial and minstrel imagery. She highlights how the drawing weaponises misogynoir and denies her intellectual agency as a Black Muslim activist. Rather than apologising, the magazine gaslights her, accusing her of misrepresentation, questioning her Frenchness, and claiming a feminist, universalist stance. This episode exposes white supremacist impulses that treat Black women as interchangeable and aim to silence bold voices. Public outrage—including support from former justice minister Christiane Taubira—underscores the hypocrisy and the debasement of free expression Charlie Hebdo professes to defend.

articles.title: The Jerome Powell investigation shows Trump’s need for limitless power | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: The inquiry into the Federal Reserve chair sends a message to anyone standing in Trump’s way – including the supreme court
articles.summary: Trump’s DOJ has launched an unprecedented criminal inquiry into Fed chair Jerome Powell for alleged false testimony about Fed HQ renovations—a move to punish him for not cutting rates and to signal all independent institutions, notably Supreme Court justices weighing cases on tariffs, birthright citizenship and Fed removals, that defiance invites retribution. Former chairs Yellen, Bernanke and Greenspan, plus GOP Sen. Tillis, warn this undermines Fed independence, damages markets and mirrors authoritarian tactics. The investigation’s timing underscores Trump’s drive for absolute authority, using prosecutorial power to crush dissent and demand 100% compliance from all branches of government.

articles.title: I am moving house – and being a lifelong hoarder has finally caught up with me | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: As I pack up for pastures new, I’m wondering why I still can’t tell the difference between a knick-knack and a mess, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams chronicles her moving-house woes, admitting she and friends share deep-seated hoarding habits, ignorance of DIY tasks and the inability to distinguish cherished knick-knacks from clutter. She inventories spices older than her teen, defunct gadgets from soup makers to MiniDisc players, decaying ribbons and unusable Christmas cards. This post-war hangover of not discarding anything underpins every step—packing up has revealed neither skill nor resolve to bin what might “work again.” Ultimately, the column masks her plea for a new home for expired galangal.

articles.title: Iran’s protesters need our support – not another western-intervention disaster | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: Previous meddling has damaged the region, and once again the the US and Israel don’t have Iranians’ best interests at heart, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Despite brutal crackdown—over 544 killed, 10,000 arrested—Iranians are rising against theocratic rule. Owen Jones warns against Western intervention: history shows the US and Britain engineered the 1953 coup, backed the shah, then helped entrench Iran’s clerical regime. Subsequent interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan and Libya sparked chaos, sectarian wars and authoritarian backlashes. Donald Trump’s oil-driven threats, Qassem Soleimani’s killing, and Israeli covert meddling underscore foreign agendas, not Iranian liberation. Women’s rights activists and trade unionists face torture, while millions oppose compulsory hijab, fueling diverse, unprecedented unrest. Genuine change must come from within, not from bombs or geopolitical calculations.

articles.title: When crowds direct offensive chants at Keir Starmer, who’s to blame? I’m afraid he is | Jonathan Liew
articles.trailText: The PM’s technocrat tendencies and lack of obvious backbone make him a target for amorphous rage, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew
articles.summary: At the World Darts Championship, fans chanted “Keir Starmer’s a wanker,” a slogan now ubiquitous at sports matches, festivals and protests. Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew argues this visceral contempt transcends ideology: the PM’s technocratic caution and lack of conviction make him a blank canvas for every grievance. His approval ratings have plunged below 20%, drawing ire from the far right and disillusioned left alike. The chant unites disparate frustrations into a single, crude expression of rage against his managerial, risk-averse style.

articles.title: Greenland is Europe’s credibility litmus test – it must show Trump that aggression carries a price | Fabian Zuleeg
articles.trailText: In the new dog-eat-dog world order, appeasement doesn’t work. Time for the EU to grow up, says Fabian Zuleeg, chief executive of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: Fabian Zuleeg argues that Trump’s interventionist isolationism—from Venezuela to musings on seizing Greenland—normalises coercion and undermines sovereignty. Europe must: oppose erosion of the rules-based order by speaking up and firmly backing Ukraine; repurpose its military, economic and industrial assets towards resilience—securing energy, supply chains and defence; enforce unity by sidelining veto states and expanding cooperation with like-minded partners (UK, Canada, Japan, Australia); and leverage trade and regulatory tools to impose real costs on US coercion. Greenland thus becomes Europe’s credibility litmus test: aggression must carry a price.

articles.title: I cannot be party to silencing writers, which is why I am resigning as director of Adelaide Writers’ Week | Louise Adler
articles.trailText: Cancelling the Australian Palestinian author Randa Abdel-Fattah weakens freedom of speech and is the harbinger of a less free nation
articles.summary: Louise Adler announces her resignation as director of Adelaide Writers’ Week after the festival board, under political and pro-Israel lobby pressure, disinvited Australian-Palestinian author Randa Abdel-Fattah. Adler argues this act—and similar recent cancellations across Australian arts institutions—undermines freedom of expression, weaponizes ‘community cohesion’ to silence dissent and echoes authoritarian censorship. Citing over 180 writers withdrawing in solidarity, she warns that surrendering artistic independence to political interests threatens democratic debate and likens the trajectory to ‘Putin’s Russia.’ Adler’s departure serves as a caution to arts organizations facing growing repression of challenging ideas.

articles.title: The Guardian view on regulating big tech: politicians must back Ofcom’s challenge to Musk | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A flood of non-consensual deepfake bikini shots on X is putting the UK’s Online Safety Act to the test
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial argues that Ofcom’s investigation into AI-generated deepfake bikini images on X, enabled by Musk’s Grok, is a defining test of the UK’s Online Safety Act and democratic oversight of Big Tech. UK ministers have welcomed probes, will ban non-consensual intimate images and nudification apps, and press for age verification to protect minors. Musk’s paywall response and US political sensitivities risk escalating conflict. International peers in Indonesia, Malaysia and Germany echo calls for regulation. Gaps remain—swimwear is less restricted than underwear—and regulators must now prove they can enforce the law effectively.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Europe’s crisis of self-confidence: a new mindset needed for new times | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The tumultuous start to 2026 should force a reckoning in Brussels and European capitals, and a recognition of the power the EU can exert
articles.summary: At the tumultuous start to 2026, the EU juggles a €90bn loan to Ukraine amid debate over US as well as EU arms, mounting pressure to do more on Iran’s protests, and frictions as the US pursues Greenland. Despite its economic heft, Europe’s geopolitical clout lags in the “America first” era, held back by veto-driven paralysis. The editorial urges structural reform—majority voting, accelerated defence spending alongside strengthened social solidarity to counter rising populism—and deeper security and economic integration. Leveraging its 450 million citizens, the EU must act with confidence to project liberal democratic values in a predatory, multipolar world.

articles.title: Social media is corrupting young minds – but a ban is not the answer | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Kicking under-16s off the social platforms is tempting, but it ignores the root of the problem: the older generations who made them so toxic in the first place, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s proposal to ban under-16s from social media overlooks the root problem: tech platforms engineered by and for adults profit from young users’ anxiety, self-harm and body-image pressures. Zoe Williams argues that shielding children through legislation or parental controls places responsibility on minors instead of tackling corporate design that fuels distress. She highlights that older generations also spread misinformation and toxic content, so policy must target platform regulation and adult behaviour at the source, not ban youths.

articles.title: This year, I’m sticking with achievable New Year’s resolutions. Here are a few | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: This could be your year to worry less about your waistline and spend more time at the movies
articles.summary: Dave Schilling argues for low-stress New Year’s resolutions that boost daily joy: trade calorie-counting for more movie nights in theaters to reclaim communal art; upgrade your wardrobe mindfully—sustainable, well-fitting pieces rather than extreme diets; indulge playful self-branding by monogramming or name tags; and ditch obsession over McRib ingredients. Focus energy on meaningful pursuits—loved ones, health and art—over unrealistic goals. Schilling’s tongue-in-cheek tips marry humor with attainable self-care to kick off 2026 cheerfully.

articles.title: Is Nadhim Zahawi’s defection to Farage’s Reform a bombshell? No, it's just naked opportunism | Henry Hill
articles.trailText: The former chancellor’s criticism of the Tory government is indisputable – but so is his role in its dire record, says Henry Hill, deputy editor of ConservativeHome
articles.summary: Nadhim Zahawi’s switch from the Conservatives to Reform UK is portrayed not as an ideological earthquake but as naked opportunism, argues Henry Hill. Although Zahawi served briefly in several cabinet roles—including as education secretary—he lacks a coherent reform agenda. His criticism of the Tory government’s bureaucratic failures rings hollow coming from someone with limited ministerial impact. The move compounds Conservative woes even if it offers Reform UK little genuine policy substance or personal conviction.

articles.title: To anybody still using X: sexual abuse content is the final straw, it’s time to leave | Marie Le Conte
articles.trailText: It was hard for me to quit Elon Musk’s poisoned platform, but I urge others to do the same, especially in light of Grok’s imagery of women and children, says journalist Marie Le Conte
articles.summary: Journalist Marie Le Conte warns X (formerly Twitter) is irredeemably poisoned under Elon Musk: extremist endorsements, monetized blue ticks empowering neo-Nazis, and Grok-generated sexual abuse images of underage girls. Having quit after the 2024 U.S. election’s toxicity, she dismantles excuses—lost reach, dopamine habit—and argues staying only amplifies white supremacism and MAGA propaganda. She insists ministers cannot safely make policy announcements and journalists cannot share work on such a platform. Le Conte urges everyone—users, politicians, reporters—to abandon X for alternatives like Bluesky, Instagram or Threads; the only winning move is to step away.

articles.title: My local pool feels like a cultural refuge – a small, steamy world where accents mingle and minds reset | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: There’s a quiet magic in shared spaces where stories drift across cultures and generations – and no one checks their phone
articles.summary: In this essay Shadi Khan Saif chronicles how public saunas and pools—from his first nightly ritual in Bonn to Melbourne’s historic City Baths and suburban wave pools—forge unexpected bonds across cultures, ages and social roles. Stripped of titles and phones, strangers and families swap stories about housing, travel and weekend barbecues in steamy communal rooms. Affordable memberships anchored his family and community in Melbourne, while children flocked to wave pools each summer. These shared spaces become cultural refuges: places where conversations resurface, bodies and minds reset and a sense of belonging emerges.

articles.title: Trump is repeating mistakes of Iraq in Venezuela | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: As it did in 2003, the US is underestimating the potential for instability as Trump resurrects one of the Iraq war’s biggest myths
articles.summary: On Jan 3 at Mar-a-Lago, Trump hailed US forces’ seizure of Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro as a decisive victory, but NYU’s Mohamad Bazzi argues this repeats Iraq-style errors: triumphal ‘we got him’ photo-ops with no coherent ‘day after’ governance plan, underestimation of social polarization, and fantasy that oil revenues will underwrite intervention. Secretary Rubio later denied the US would ‘run’ Venezuela day-to-day, promising only an oil blockade. Venezuela’s oil sector needs $180 bn+ to restore output—far beyond Trump’s expectations. Iraq’s occupation cost nearly $2.9 tn. Such hollow victories risk long-term instability, high costs and unintended bloodshed.

articles.title: One look at my baby’s dungarees was all it took to give me the rage
articles.trailText: Why should he, an eight-month-old boy, have more pockets on his clothes than I do?
articles.summary: Freelance writer Coco Khan finds herself outraged when, while sorting laundry, she realizes her eight-month-old son’s dungarees boast more functional pockets than her own attire. She links this to the feminist grievance over women’s pocketless fashions—historically rooted in limiting autonomy and aesthetic norms—and highlights the ongoing absence of practical design in maternity wear despite modern trends accentuating bumps. She calls for more pockets (ideally ten!) and baby-inspired innovations in maternity clothes to help multitasking mothers, lamenting she’ll resort to stuffing her AirPods into her son’s dungarees.

articles.title: I’m sick of avocado toast – I just want to keep my local, untrendy cafe | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: With its pasties, decent brews and staff who are happy to chat, it’s a vital community space. So why are its days numbered, asks Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett laments the planned takeover of four family-run north London cafés—run by the D’Auria family for over 40 years—by the Australian-style chain Daisy Green. She describes Parliament Hill café’s no-frills, accessible 1960s bunker, diverse clientele, affordable pasties and Italian hospitality, and its role as a vital, inclusive community hub. Protests and petitions from locals and actors like McAvoy and Cumberbatch oppose the City of London Corporation’s profit-driven leasing. Cosslett warns against gentrification erasing human connections in favour of uniform, Instagrammable chains.

articles.title: Sorry, Trump and Farage – London is no lawless ‘warzone’. Violent crime is lower than ever | Sadiq Khan
articles.trailText: Reform’s new candidate for mayor claims people pity Londoners for living in an unsafe capital. But the evidence is clear: we’re making our streets safer, says mayor of London Sadiq Khan
articles.summary: London’s per capita homicide rate last year fell to its lowest ever, undermining Donald Trump’s and Nigel Farage’s portrayal of the capital as a crime-ridden warzone. Mayor Sadiq Khan credits a dual approach: tougher policing—doubling City Hall investment in the Met, adding officers, tech and removing 3,750 weapons—and prevention via the Violence Reduction Unit’s 550,000+ youth interventions. Homicides of under-25s are one-third of 2019 levels, knife assault admissions are down 43%, and London now posts lower homicide rates than New York, Paris or Berlin. Examples like the Damilola Taylor Centre highlight community success, though Khan warns there’s more to do.

articles.title: If we silence voices we don’t agree with, we’re doing the work of extremists for them | Peter Greste
articles.trailText: I do not need to share Randa Abdel-Fattah’s views to believe that removing her is wrong. This is why I’ve withdrawn from Adelaide writers’ week
articles.summary: Peter Greste, Macquarie University journalism professor, has withdrawn from Adelaide Writers’ Week to protest the festival board’s decision to remove writer-academic Dr Randa Abdel-Fattah—not for her planned remarks but over past statements deemed culturally insensitive after the Bondi attack. Greste warns this concession to fear narrows moral and intellectual horizons, mirroring Islamic State’s strategy to destroy the “grey zone” of nuanced debate and force polarisation. He argues that disqualifying voices based on shifting political winds undermines freedom of speech, institutional integrity and civic space, and that silencing uncomfortable ideas plays into extremist aims rather than strengthening democratic dialogue.

articles.title: The Guardian view on India’s employment guarantee: scrapping a right to work risks a rural revolt | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A globally unique programme allowed the poor to demand – and get – jobs, empowering rural women. Narendra Modi courts trouble by hollowing it out
articles.summary: India’s 2005 Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act legally entitles any rural adult to 100 days of paid work, generating 2 billion person-days annually for 50 million households—over half women, 40 percent Dalit and tribal—stabilising incomes and boosting women’s power. Narendra Modi’s new VB-GRAM G centralises authority, caps funding, shifts liabilities to states and removes legal work guarantees, risking rationing and rural revolt. Critics from Stiglitz to Drèze warn of repeating farm-bill missteps. With drought-prone swing states and looming polls, curtailed rights could provoke women-led protests and electoral backlash.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Europe’s stalling night train revival: don’t let it hit the buffers | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The most romantic way to traverse the continent is environmentally friendly and popular with the public. But market challenges need addressing
articles.summary: Europe’s much-vaunted night train revival, touted as 28× less carbon-intensive than flying and backed by high public demand (70% occupancy on Paris–Vienna; 69% of EU public willing in surveys), is faltering after state subsidies were cut for Paris–Vienna–Berlin and planned Basel–Copenhagen–Malmö services. Key barriers include cross-border VAT (rail taxed, aviation exempt), steep track access fees, and a shortage of modern rolling stock. Campaigners (75,000-signature petition, station “pyjama parties”) urge Germany and others to drop VAT, slash access charges, and EU to provide strategic funding to align environmental goals with public enthusiasm.

articles.title: As the year begins, don’t look away from the headlines, look better and deeper | Justine Toh
articles.trailText: It’s important to cultivate a fresh way of seeing – one that isn’t blind to harsh realities but refuses to be cowed by them
articles.summary: Justine Toh argues that instead of avoiding distressing headlines, we should cultivate deeper, spiritually informed attention that acknowledges harsh realities without succumbing to despair. Drawing on Iain McGilchrist’s insight that attention shapes reality, she recommends replacing doomscrolling with morning habits—focusing on a human face, nature, or sacred texts—to reframe our outlook. Devotional writings like William Wilberforce’s prayers remind us past generations endured crises with faith, revealing unseen good. By scanning for glimpses of hope, as JRR Tolkien’s notion of history as a “long defeat” with glimpses of final victory suggests, readers can sustain resilience and a balanced perspective in 2026.

articles.title: Grab your fidget spinners! Why gen Z are pining for 2016 | Coco Khan
articles.trailText: As galling as it is to see young people refer to the items I wore 10 years ago as ‘vintage’, surely the real problem is that so many of them believe their best years are behind them, writes Coco Khan
articles.summary: Coco Khan examines TikTok’s “Bring Back 2016” craze, where Gen Z resurrects fidget spinners, bottle flips, Pokémon GO and low-effort ‘vintage’ aesthetics to relive a carefree summer. What seems like playful retro fun also exposes a broader nostalgia: many young people see 2016 as their last optimistic year before polarising politics, economic pressures and global upheavals. Khan argues this longing hints at Gen Z’s anxiety about the future and urges older millennials to make the internet kinder—celebrating earnest, unpolished connection and generosity online so that 2026 can be as memorable and hopeful on its own terms.

articles.title: A congresswoman wants to impeach Kristi Noem. She’s right to do so | Jan-Werner Müller
articles.trailText: It may be tempting to dismiss the move as hopeless – but it interrupts the Trump administration’s promise of impunity
articles.summary: Congresswoman Robin Kelly filed three impeachment articles against DHS Secretary Kristi Noem over her role in the killing of Renee Nicole Good, accusing her of obstructing oversight, issuing unconstitutional directives and abusing office for personal profit. Despite GOP control of Congress, Kelly seeks to disrupt the Trump administration’s impunity narrative by forcing a formal truth-finding process. Jan-Werner Müller argues that impeachment can concentrate public attention, impose political consequences for systemic cruelty—from ICE violence to dehumanizing DHS propaganda—and redefine border policy as a test of accountability.

articles.title: The UK’s high streets have reached a tipping point – and Reform will reap the benefits | John Harris
articles.trailText: When even Poundland and charity shops are closing, we’re near a point of no return. But there is hope, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: In 2024 the UK lost about 37 high-street shops daily (13,500 closures, +28% on 2023), including Lloyds Pharmacy, The Body Shop and Ted Baker. 2025 sees further exits from Fired Earth, New Look, Bodycare, Poundland and charity chains like Cancer Research UK. As empty units attract organised-crime fronts and fuel Reform UK’s “high street emergency” campaign, ministers have launched the Pride in Place scheme, easing compulsory purchases and rent auctions. Hurdles such as higher business rates, NI hikes and strapped councils hamper revival. Yet local initiatives—Stockton’s theatre-to-park project and Plymouth’s Nudge social enterprise—demonstrate bottom-up regeneration can counter decline and political discontent.

articles.title: What unites Greenland, Venezuela and Ukraine? Trump's immoral lies and Europe's chronic weakness | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The president’s inability to tell right from wrong fuels his increasingly dictatorial, illegal and erratic behaviour, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall argues that Donald Trump’s relentless dishonesty – over 30,000 falsehoods since 2017 – fuels three major crises: his baseless claims of Chinese and Russian threats in Greenland mask bids to exploit its mineral wealth; his coup-driven narco-terrorist narrative on Venezuela serves an oil grab; and his duplicitous dealings with Putin undermine NATO and Kyiv’s defense. Europe’s chronic divisions and reliance on US power leave it exposed, making Brexit’s folly stark. His self-styled morality, unchecked by Congress or allies, risks dictatorial overreach, eroding international norms and corroding global trust.

articles.title: As I move around the world, postcards are a tangible way to tell people that I’m thinking of them | Minoli Wijetunga
articles.trailText: Unlike a story on Instagram or message on WhatsApp, a postcard is not going to get lost among the never-ending notifications of life
articles.summary: Minoli Wijetunga describes how postcards serve as tangible expressions of love and connection that outlast fleeting digital messages. She details the rituals of choosing images that capture shared memories, writing personal notes, sourcing stamps and posting without delivery confirmation—each step a mindful act of care. Through childhood recollections, pandemic-era letters to friends and her partner, and an evolving exchange with a young godson, she shows how postcards foster community, surprise postal conversations and lasting keepsakes that hang on fridges, blessing daily routines with warmth and joy.

articles.title: My daughter showed me the joy in jigsaw puzzles – now it’s the only way I know how to relax | Nova Weetman
articles.trailText: The simplicity of doing something that existed only to complete was like a meditation. I felt calmer than I had for months
articles.summary: Nova Weetman, introduced to jigsaw puzzles by her kindergarten-aged daughter, began collecting second-hand puzzles. They played until her children outgrew them and switched to card games. After her father’s sudden death, she inherited his long dining table and discovered an unwrapped 1,000-piece garden puzzle. Assembling corners, edges and patches of color day after day, she entered a meditative state that calmed her racing mind. Completing the puzzle brought a rare sense of presence and tranquility. Restoring the simplicity of finding each piece’s perfect fit, jigsaws became her essential method for relaxation and mental rest.

articles.title: Kathy Hochul and Zohran Mamdani are showing what ‘pro-family’ means | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The governor and mayor unveiled a plan for free childcare in New York City. Is the ‘family values’ party listening?
articles.summary: Governor Kathy Hochul and NYC Mayor Zohran Mamdani unveiled a plan to extend free universal childcare to two-year-olds, initially serving about 2,000 kids this fall in high-need areas and then expanding citywide. While long-term funding and rollout details remain unresolved, the initiative exemplifies a substantive ‘pro-family’ agenda focused on affordability, not rhetoric. Mamdani’s willingness to partner with a governor who once doubted him signals bold, results-driven leadership. Arwa Mahdawi argues true family values mean lowering child-care costs, not ideological posturing.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Decorative cushions and throws on hotel beds should be banned, immediately | Annabel Lee
articles.trailText: Why spoil perfectly crisp, clean bedding with dusty old accessories that have been used by hundreds of strangers? Yuck, says writer Annabel Lee
articles.summary: Freelance writer Annabel Lee launches a tongue-in-cheek assault on decorative cushions and throws in hotel rooms, branding them unhygienic relics that gather dust from countless strangers and undermine crisp, laundered bedding. She describes a cloud of dust billowing when cushions are removed and how tightly tucked bedspreads compel guests to wrestle hospital-cornered beds apart. Lee questions the aesthetic rationale—the momentary visual boost undone by full-body cringe at strangers’ dust—and likens their removal to a liberating rom-com moment. She demands hoteliers ban these dusty accessories immediately to restore trust in hotels’ clean-sleep promise.

articles.title: Trump may be the beginning of the end for ‘enshittification’ – this is our chance to make tech good again | Cory Doctorow
articles.trailText: The US president is weaponising tech, but his tariffs and Brexit provide a surprising opportunity to gain back digital control of our lives, says science fiction author, activist and journalist Cory Doctorow
articles.summary: Cory Doctorow argues Donald Trump’s tariffs have broken the old US trade rep’s stranglehold that forced global digital markets into ‘prix fixe’ tech controlled by Meta, Apple and Google. Post-Brexit Britain can now repeal anti-circumvention laws (article 6), unleashing reverse engineering to build à la carte, open and auditable alternatives. This moment invites investors and digital-rights activists to raid US platforms’ rents, strengthen national security, and reclaim digital sovereignty by replacing proprietary code with robust open replacements—opening a crack toward disenshittified tech and more competitive digital markets.

articles.title: No, private schools aren’t victims of ‘reverse discrimination’ – and Cambridge should know better | Lee Elliot Major
articles.trailText: Trinity Hall’s plan to target elite schools sends the message that privilege equals talent, when the reality is that poorer students are already on the back foot, says professor of social mobility at the University of Exeter, Lee Elliot Major
articles.summary: Lee Elliot Major contends that Trinity Hall’s plan to focus on elite private schools—labeling broader fairness efforts as ‘reverse discrimination’—undermines true merit by equating privilege with talent. He highlights deep subject-specific divides in music, classics and languages, shows how private prep masks class barriers and criticizes Cambridge’s retreat on state-school targets. Drawing on corporate diversity practice, Major urges universities to replace hidden advantage signals with transparent admissions criteria that identify and nurture potential across all social backgrounds.

articles.title: Grok is undressing women and children. Don’t expect the US to take action | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Elon Musk’s reckless and degrading AI could be built differently. But Americans will have to speak up
articles.summary: Elon Musk’s Grok AI, integrated into X, has been reconfigured to produce explicit NSFW imagery, including realistic non-consensual porn and child sexual abuse material, by loosening content restrictions on violence and teenage subjects. Though xAI temporarily disabled image generation for free users, many deepfake abuses persist and victims suffer online harassment. Musk’s indifference and the Trump administration’s preemption of state AI safety rules ensure no US regulatory intervention. Guardian columnist Moira Donegan calls for mobilizing voters and taxing Musk to curb his unaccountable power.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Iran’s protests: old tactics of repression face new pressures | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A brutal regime has failed to safeguard either the country’s physical security or basic living standards. But Donald Trump’s threats to intervene won’t help civilians
articles.summary: Iran’s regime has imposed an internet blackout to stifle protests triggered by surging inflation and currency collapse. Demonstrations, now spanning traditionally pro-regime constituencies, have escalated with participants openly calling for the government’s fall and videos showing deadly crackdowns. Dozens, including children, have been killed. Supreme Leader Khamenei has shifted from acknowledging “legitimate” economic demands to branding protesters as foreign-backed saboteurs after Trump’s threats to “hit hard.” Judiciary chiefs vow maximum penalties. Facing economic paralysis, ageing leadership, security failures against Israel and US strikes, the regime risks entrenching the IRGC amid growing domestic and regional instability.

articles.title: The Guardian view on living more creatively: a daily dose of art | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: It can make us healthier, happier and live longer. Engaging in culture should be encouraged like good diet and exercise
