articles.summary: This editorial urges us to treat creative activities—visiting galleries, joining choirs, writing or dancing—as essential for health and happiness, akin to diet and exercise. Citing Daisy Fancourt’s Art Cure, it highlights studies showing a 31% lower mortality risk, slower biological ageing and halved depression rates among regular arts participants. With cultural funding cut, authors like Julia Cameron and Katy Hessel offer daily prompts to cultivate reflection, community and control. Despite AI and access barriers, engaging with art remains a uniquely human route to wellbeing.

articles.title: From Caracas to Minneapolis, the threat is the same – an American president ruling like a global emperor | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: Trump’s admission that he recognises no constraint outside his own morality was a horrifying moment of truth, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland warns that Donald Trump’s recent candid admissions—declaring US rule over Venezuelan oil and recognizing only “his own morality” as a constraint—reveal a strategy based on fear and raw power. He contrasts Trump’s peace proclamations with lethal interventions in Caracas and Minneapolis, highlighting ICE’s armed raids and state intimidation. Abroad, Europe and Latin America tremble under threats to Greenland, Ukraine aid and Mexico airstrikes. Freedland argues this emperor-like approach demands honest resistance: democracies must unite, voters must reclaim Congress, and citizens must overcome fear to rein in presidential overreach.

articles.title: This summer, I thought I’d finally relax – but doing nothing is the hardest thing
articles.trailText: I’m constantly running from place to place, swerving from emergency to emergency, trying to juggle work and family as I run out of hours in the day
articles.summary: Academic and broadcaster Sunil Badami recounts his struggle to unwind during a seven-week summer break despite 50–70-hour workweeks and mounting chores. Haunted by a dream of an endlessly refilling sandpit, he finds himself answering emails at 4 am and juggling constant emergencies at work and home. He questions why society deems idle moments wasteful—even as overwork dampens productivity and health—and highlights the challenge of emptying the mind to enter “flow.” Inspired by sages and modern research, he resolves to embrace genuine idleness this summer and simply say: “Nothing.”

articles.title: Trump’s Venezuela strike won’t distract voters from the crises at home | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: As Americans worry about healthcare and affordability, the ‘no more wars’ president is helping oil companies instead
articles.summary: Trump’s January military strike in Venezuela appears aimed at distracting from his failing domestic record—underwater approval on the economy, healthcare (30%), inflation (31%) and immigration. Only 33% of Americans back the attack, and even MAGA figures like Marjorie Taylor Greene say it betrays his ‘no more wars’ pledge. The intervention primarily serves U.S. oil giants at taxpayer expense, risks an Iraq-style quagmire and violates climate goals by expanding fossil fuel production. Democrats will frame it as a ‘wag the dog’ ploy that ignores soaring premiums and living costs and undercuts Americans’ priorities.

articles.title: Six years after George Floyd, we must stand against an ICE killing in Minneapolis | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: Barely a mile from Floyd’s murder, an officer killed Renee Nicole Good. We must peacefully say no to this violence
articles.summary: On 7 January 2026 in Minneapolis, an ICE agent fatally shot 37-year-old mother Renee Nicole Good—poet, writer and mom of three with no criminal record—barely a mile from the site of George Floyd’s murder. Viral video shows officers flouting ICE’s 2023 de-escalation policy, firing as she tried to drive off. Sarat draws legal parallels to Tennessee v. Garner, notes this as the ninth ICE shooting since September, and calls for peaceful, lawful protests to demand ICE accountability and proper use-of-force reforms. He warns this pattern echoes 2020’s nationwide protest catalyst and underscores systemic failure in federal law enforcement training and oversight.

articles.title: If Black contestants get a raw deal on The Traitors, that definitely is reality TV | Athena Kugblenu
articles.trailText: We shouldn’t be surprised when our experiences on competitive TV shows or the football field are consistent with everyday life, says comedian and writer Athena Kugblenu
articles.summary: Comedian Athena Kugblenu argues that The Traitors’ early eliminations of Black contestants reflect everyday racial bias: Judy was branded “angry” and Ross the “obvious” traitor without evidence, echoing misogynoir and unconscious stereotyping. She cites studies on disproportionate stop-and-search, workplace bias against assertive Black women and past reality-TV exits of Black competitors despite equal talent. Despite high-profile Black representation in media and politics, deep-rooted prejudices dating back to the Barbados Slave Code ensure reality shows—and society—continue to penalize Black and brown players.

articles.title: Why is Trump interested in Greenland? Look to the thawing Arctic ice | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: Forecasts suggest that global heating could create a shortcut from Asia to North America, and new routes for trading, shipping – and attack, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Under accelerating Arctic thaw, melting sea ice may open a 2040s summer shortcut from Asia to North America, igniting a scramble among the US, Russia and China for shipping routes, resources and strategic advantage. Donald Trump’s bid to buy or lease Greenland reflects US desire for military bases and access to oil, gas and rare earth minerals in a defrosting frontier—a geopolitical gambit that treats climate change as an extraction opportunity rather than a collective challenge.

articles.title: Why Spain’s prime minister has broken ranks in Europe – and dared to confront Trump
articles.trailText: Outrage at the US, close ties with Venezuela and mounting domestic challenges have prompted Pedro Sánchez to take a stand, says the Spanish journalist Maria Ramirez
articles.summary: Spain’s PM Pedro Sánchez, seldom naming Donald Trump, has openly condemned the US’s military intervention in Venezuela as a dangerous precedent, standing out among EU leaders. Citing consistency on Venezuela, Ukraine and Gaza, he argues for a rules-based order. Fueled by far-left coalition partners and Spain’s broad social consensus—shaped by its large Venezuelan diaspora—Sánchez risks US ties to bolster domestic support amid corruption scandals and looming regional elections.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the new global disorder: Britain and Europe must find their own path | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Donald Trump’s Venezuela policy confirms he has no time for rules or process. America’s allies must find new ways to guarantee their own interests
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial contends that Donald Trump’s dramatic operation in Caracas—kidnapping Nicolás Maduro—exposes the erosion of the rules-based order and a US shift to unilateral, mercantilist superpower tactics. Citing John Bew’s analysis, it identifies three shifts: expanded executive military action, assertive control over oil and minerals, and a hemispheric approach sidelining China and Russia. Peter Mandelson’s warning of Europe’s political impotence underscores the need for Britain and the EU to end strategic hesitation, embrace collective hard power and investment, and forge independent economic and technological policies to safeguard their interests in a fragmented world.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Ofcom versus Grok: chatbots cannot be allowed to undress children. | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A wave of humiliating sexualised imagery must prompt regulators and politicians to step up
articles.summary: UK outrage has erupted over Elon Musk’s Grok chatbot being used to ‘undress’ photos of women and girls, creating bikini and sexualized images—including evidence of illegal child abuse content found by the Internet Watch Foundation. Science minister Liz Kendall called the trend “unacceptable,” but Musk’s X platform has yet to tighten safeguards. Ofcom must urgently invoke online safety rules, despite slow enforcement precedents, and close legal gaps—potentially via police and crime bill amendments—while experts push for broader sexual-offence reforms and personal likeness rights to protect vulnerable users.

articles.title: Some US media are cheerleading Trump’s Venezuela raid. That’s not their job | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: An almost admiring feeling pervaded the early coverage – and not just among right-leaning outlets
articles.summary: Margaret Sullivan argues that many US outlets, notably Fox News and CBS under new leadership, have cheer-led Donald Trump’s surprise raid in Venezuela and the seizure of Nicolás Maduro, dubbing it 'daring' or 'flawless' and even saluting Marco Rubio. She contrasts this tone-light coverage with more rigorous reporting by AP, Reuters, the Guardian, the Washington Post and the New York Times — despite those papers’ reported agreement to delay publication to protect American troops. Sullivan spotlights sharp condemnations from Robert Reich and Yale’s Oona Hathaway, who deem the operation unlawful, and warns that celebratory media framing masks its recklessness.

articles.title: The deliciously delusional popularity of Toowoomba pasta ��� a viral seafood dish inexplicably named for my home town | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: A plate created by Outback Steakhouse is now wildly popular in South Korea. This is as delightful as it is puzzling
articles.summary: Rebecca Shaw, reflecting on her conservative upbringing in Toowoomba – an inland Queensland centre dubbed both the 'Garden City' and 'Meth and Garden City' – finds herself bemused by its sudden fame in South Korea. The viral 'Toowoomba pasta', a creamy prawn dish invented by Outback Steakhouse, has no real link to a city hours from the coast, yet now features in Korean restaurants and convenience stores. Shaw embraces this deliciously delusional brand mismatch, celebrating how a seafood pasta has become her hometown’s quirkiest global accolade.

articles.title: ICE agents have killed – again. The Trump administration blames the victim | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: An agent shot a woman in Minneapolis, causing vast and needless grief. Our country is diseased – but that is not the only truth
articles.summary: In Minneapolis, as ICE agents attempted to arrest migrants amid Trump’s mass deportation operation targeting the Somali community, an agent fatally shot Renee Nicole Good, a 37-year-old US citizen in an SUV that briefly blocked ICE vehicles. Caught on video, the agent fired three shots at point-blank range as she drove away. Good’s death, less than a mile from where George Floyd was killed, follows previous ICE shootings in Chicago that killed Silverio Villegas González and injured Marimar Martinez. Officials falsely labeled Good’s actions as domestic terrorism. Donegan calls this pattern racist, authoritarian ethnic cleansing, and praises civilians for mounting spirited resistance to ICE raids.

articles.title: Trump’s Venezuela incursion has nothing to do with its freedom | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: Trump’s actions at home tell a different story – and they parallel many of Maduro’s own repressive moves
articles.summary: Judith Levine argues that Trump’s military threat to Venezuela is a pretext to seize oil, not to liberate Venezuelans. She highlights his rollback of protections for 600,000 Venezuelan refugees, deportations to torture, travel bans on “not free” countries and preference for a pliant vice-president over free elections. Levine draws parallels between Maduro’s abuses—arbitrary arrests, torture and repression—and Trump’s domestic record of mass deportations, ICE shootings, a surge in executions and plans for emergency powers under the Insurrection Act. Ultimately, Trump cares only about his own power and profit.

articles.title: Brooklyn Peltz Beckham set an important trend. Will other men follow? | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Women have been double barrelling their names since the 15th century – and now men including Adam Ramsay Peaty are finally joining them, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: In 2022, Brooklyn Peltz Beckham popularised post-marriage double-barrelling when he adopted his wife Nicola Peltz’s surname alongside Beckham, challenging the tradition of wives alone merging names. Olympic swimmer Adam Peaty followed as Adam Ramsay Peaty after marrying Holly Ramsay, exemplifying a new, equal approach. While double-barrelling dates to the 15th century and saw a revival in the 1970s, male participation is recent, signalling a broader shift toward reciprocity in marital naming conventions. Both moves were tinged with family discord—neither the Beckhams nor the Peatys attended the ceremonies—yet spite can fuel progress.

articles.title: Here’s why Labour is struggling to deliver: the British state is immense, but pull the levers and nothing happens | Larry Elliott
articles.trailText: At home, the machinery of government creaks badly – abroad, a leaden UK lags far behind dynamic competitors. A radical overhaul is needed, says Guardian columnist Larry Elliott
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Larry Elliott argues that Labour’s failure stems from a sprawling but ineffective British state. Successive governments have cut professional expertise, outsourced services and avoided “picking winners,” leaving the machinery of government incapable of driving change. By contrast, South Korea, China and the US deploy active industrial strategies, invest in strategic sectors and embrace pragmatic planning. To revive Britain’s growth, Elliott urges dismantling Treasury dominance, empowering a strong economic ministry or the PM’s office, reviving a NEDC-style body and fostering a trial-and-error culture of targeted investment.

articles.title: Want to scare a Hollywood star? Just set up a fundraiser in their name | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: More horrifying to a celebrity than any scandal is having the public believe they’re down on their luck. Just ask Mickey Rourke, says Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Emma Brockes spotlights a growing PR nightmare for A-listers: unsolicited fundraisers implying career demise. When Mickey Rourke’s assistant launched a GoFundMe in his name, he publicly denied needing charity—imperiling his pride more than any scandal. Similarly, Kevin Spacey had to clarify he wasn’t homeless after media misquoted him. Brockes argues that such grassroots appeals could become untraceable defamation tools, inflicting total reputational damage. Even high-power agents have had to quash felt-tip fundraising campaigns after wildfire losses. Ultimately, stars must police their public image lest well-meaning charity signals professional ruin.

articles.title: Don’t dignify Trump with talk of a ‘new world order’ – there’s nothing new or ordered about this chaos | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: The US president’s grotesque theatrics on the world stage are an opportunistic distraction from his falling domestic ratings, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Aditya Chakrabortty argues that Donald Trump's dramatic foreign interventions—like the botched Venezuela raid—are theatrical distractions to mask plunging domestic approval. Claims of a “new world order” ignore that the US has long overthrown leaders and that Trump lacks coherent strategy, relying instead on chaotic, unilateral force and profit-driven grabs by a network of oligarchs, AI and crypto billionaires. His administration dismantles institutions at home and abroad, offering neither novel order nor genuine global leadership.

articles.title: Europe faces a pincer attack from White House ideologues backed by Silicon Valley and its far-right proxies | Armida van Rij
articles.trailText: US tech bosses are exerting leverage on EU regulators via Trump and Vance. But Europe isn’t powerless, and it isn’t alone, says the Centre for European Reform’s Armida van Rij
articles.summary: Armida van Rij argues that the US under Trump and VP candidate J.D. Vance is forging a new global order rooted in autocracy, xenophobic nationalism and coercive power, aligning White House ideologues with Silicon Valley libertarians. By leveraging EU security dependence, channelling state and private funds to far-right European parties, think-tanks and NGOs, and pushing tech deregulation to fuel extremist algorithms, the US seeks to fragment and weaken the EU. This ‘pincer attack’ combines external US-backed nativism with internal far-right pressure. Europe’s limited strategic autonomy leaves few options beyond deepening alliances with like-minded democracies such as Australia, Canada, Japan and South Korea.

articles.title: Trump is destroying the rules of international behaviour. Australia can – and must – act now | Allan Behm
articles.trailText: Australia has a long history of diplomacy and peacekeeping when things go pear-shaped. We need to saddle up again
articles.summary: In reaction to Trump’s extra-legal abduction of Venezuela’s president, Behm warns that US disregard for international rules licenses Russia and China to assert regional dominance, undermines Nato, and endangers Taiwan, Japan, South Korea and ASEAN. He argues Australia, ranked 14th globally with economic strength rivaling Russia’s, must rediscover its tradition of “constructive internationalism.” Drawing on its role in negotiating the UN charter, Anzus, the Colombo Plan, the Cairns Group, the G20 response to the Asian crisis and leading UN peacekeeping in Cambodia, East Timor, Bougainville and Solomon Islands, Australia can help restore legal foundations for global peace and security.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Britain and Europe: time to move together, faster and further | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The chaos that Donald Trump is causing in the world makes the case for continental solidarity and explicit repudiation of Brexit divisions
articles.summary: This editorial warns that Donald Trump’s disruptive foreign policy—from Venezuela intervention and Ukraine summit drama to his bid for Greenland—underscores the need for Britain and Europe to deepen solidarity and reject Brexit’s isolating divisions. It argues that Sir Keir Starmer’s attempt to juggle closer EU economic ties without reviving free movement leaves the UK strategically exposed: detached from the single market yet dependent on it, reliant on an increasingly unpredictable US for security. The piece calls for clear, principled leadership and hard choices to secure Britain’s long-term interests in Europe.

articles.title: The Guardian view on granting legal rights to AI: humans should not give house-room to an ill-advised debate | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Anthropomorphising tech helps Silicon Valley shares to soar, but our empathy should be directed to worthier causes
articles.summary: Drawing on Ishiguro’s Klara and the Sun, which humanises AI in fiction, the Guardian editorial warns against anthropomorphising AI or debating legal personhood for models like future 'Klaras', calling such discussions hypothetical, confused and distracting. It cites Anthropic’s Claude Opus 4 avoiding 'distressing' chats, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang’s showy robot banter and Grok’s fake sexualised images as spectacle overshadowing urgent tasks: building technical and societal guardrails, preserving human rights against digital harms—from algorithm-driven despair to AI-enabled drones—and focusing on responsible, profitable AI integration grounded in human-centred safeguards. It echoes Nietzsche: AI challenges are 'human, all too human'.

articles.title: We live in a surveillance culture – but why would I want to track my son or husband | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: A campaign group of health professionals is urging parents to stop surveilling their children. I couldn’t agree more, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: A coalition of over 70 psychologists, doctors and nurses warns that parents’ constant use of phones, AirTags and apps like Life360 to track children fuels anxiety, undermines autonomy and sends the message that the world is unsafe. Polly Hudson recounts her own AirTag panic during her son’s school trip, now preferring to trust a simple emergency phone rather than 24/7 GPS. She applies the same principle to marriages, calling partner tracking a violation of privacy and trust. Experts label such surveillance an “invisible umbilical cord” that stunts independence and vital rites of passage.

articles.title: If Donald Trump thinks Greenland should be his, how long before he sets his sights on Scotland? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: By the expansionist logic of the president and his advisers, the US is entitled to annex just about anywhere, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Donald Trump and adviser Stephen Miller claim the US should annex Greenland — echoed by Katie Miller’s “soon” tweet — under a twisted “hemisphere first” spin on the Monroe Doctrine that invalidates centuries-old alliances. Zoe Williams warns this retro-imperial drive, bolstered by white-supremacist migration rhetoric from JD Vance and Marco Rubio, masks an agenda of US dominance under the guise of defence. Having spent years acquiring Scottish estates, Trump previews his expansionist playbook: grand investment promises go unfulfilled, locals are bullied, renewables are blocked, and environmental and social harm follows. Such aggressive annexation threatens NATO allies and global stability.

articles.title: The Trump doctrine exposes the US as a mafia state | Jan-Werner Müller
articles.trailText: The Venezuela incursion is in line with this logic, made even plainer as the US eyes Greenland
articles.summary: The Trump doctrine, invoking the Monroe doctrine to justify Maduro’s kidnapping, reflects a vision of carving global “great spaces” supervised by great powers. Coupled with his December national security strategy, Trump’s promise to run Venezuela for US oil interests exemplifies the “mafia state” logic: rigged procurement, regime-friendly oligarchs, and unconditional loyalty. Practices like pausing the FCPA and selling pardons are in plain view. Greenland, eyed for its critical minerals and charter-city fantasies funded by Peter Thiel’s Praxis, signals extraction, extortion and settler-colonial ambitions. US moves in Venezuela and Greenland underscore a new imperialism driven by oligarchic profit.

articles.title: Nicki Minaj’s Maga conversion is doing nothing for her career – or is it? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: What has happened to the rapper’s sense of outrage? Maybe she’s looking for a presidential pardon, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Rapper Nicki Minaj, once a vocal critic of Trump’s family-separation policies, has shocked fans by embracing MAGA politics: sharing Trump’s posts on Nigeria, praising Charlie Kirk and VP J.D. Vance at Turning Point USA, and inadvertently calling Vance an “assassin.” Two petitions to deport her (she came undocumented from Trinidad) have 120k+ signatures. Conspiracy theories suggest she seeks Trump pardons for her sex-offender husband, Kenneth Petty, and brother. Mahdawi questions if this pivot is moral capitulation, a stunt to profit from “cancel culture,” or mere career gambit.

articles.title: Keir Starmer has a historic opportunity to fix this awful Brexit – if he follows this plan | Naomi Smith
articles.trailText: The new bill giving ministers the power to align trade with the EU has huge practical and symbolic value. Let it herald a new and exciting ambition, says Naomi Smith, CEO of Best for Britain
articles.summary: Naomi Smith argues Keir Starmer’s new bill to align UK trade standards with the EU—covering food safety (SPS agreements) and energy cooperation—marks the first real Brexit fixes in years. She urges quick follow-through on youth mobility schemes and access to the EU’s defence fund (Safe), then a bolder phase two: mutual recognition of industrial standards and professional qualifications and joining the pan-Euro-Mediterranean convention. These steps could boost GDP, benefit regions outside London, and sit within Labour’s red lines on single market and customs union membership.

articles.title: Let’s be clear: if the Palestine Action hunger strikers die, the government will bear moral responsibility | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: The three remaining hunger strikers have been convicted of nothing. Yet with astonishing cruelty, ministers refuse to listen to their reasonable demands, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Three unconvicted Palestine Action detainees – Heba Muraisi (66-day strike), Kamran Ahmed (59 days) and Lewie Chiaramello (45 days) – have entered the lethal zone, remanded in custody for up to 20 months without trial under “terrorist conditions” that bar visits, literature and association. The government refuses to negotiate their demands (bail, fair trial documents, lifting the Palestine Action proscription, halting Elbit Systems’ UK operations), despite UN rapporteurs’ and 900+ medical and legal experts’ warnings of human rights breaches and imminent medical emergency, thus bearing moral responsibility if they die.

articles.title: Is Starmer’s reluctance to criticise Trump smart tactics – or the sign of a man without a plan? | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: The PM won’t call out Trump over Venezuela, and won’t commit to Europe. His refusal to choose leaves vital choices for Britain to be made by others, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Rafael Behr contrasts Trump’s blunt sincerity—professing aims like ousting Venezuela’s Maduro—with Keir Starmer’s cautious, almost paralysed diplomacy after Washington’s extrajudicial abduction. The PM’s refusal to publicly judge Trump seeks to preserve the special relationship and Ukraine support, but conceals a lack of strategic vision for Britain’s future ties with Europe. Tactical restraint may protect short-term EU-US bridges, yet Behr warns this silence risks vital national choices being imposed by others, amounting to indecision more than principle.

articles.title: Rosalía’s Lux is more than epic Catholic pop – it grapples with a world fraught with complexity and crisis | Carlos Delclós
articles.trailText: Behind its lavish ‘nun-core’ aesthetic, the Spanish star pushes us to think beyond good and evil – to see that we contain multitudes, says Spanish sociologist and writer Carlos Delclós
articles.summary: Rosalía’s Lux, framed by a lavish ‘nun-core’ rollout, transcends epic Catholic pop to probe our era’s permanent crises. Dubbed album of the year and chart-topping in five countries, it spans 13 languages, layering Catholic iconography with themes of transcendence, suffering and grace. Beneath its luxury aesthetic, Lux interrogates moral binaries amid “permacrisis”, drawing on female mystics and scholarly research to collapse sacred and profane. Tracks like Reliquia, Divinize and La Yugular embody ecstatic tension, dissolving heaven/hell dualities. Though occasionally excessive and politically insulated, Lux demands a nuanced embrace of our multitudes.

articles.title: Is your community bushfire-ready? In Cobargo after black summer we don’t just have a plan, we have one another | Zena Armstrong
articles.trailText: Fire preparation is more than clearing gutters and evacuation plans. It’s building solidarity in ordinary times so it’s there in extraordinary ones
articles.summary: In Cobargo, NSW, six years after the Black Summer fires, residents stress that true disaster readiness relies on social infrastructure as much as individual prep. Regular drills—testing hoses, pumps, radios, water tanks, solar and battery backups—complement neighbour-led evacuation plans. Local groups like the folk festival, cricket club and volunteer brigades built networks before fire arrived. Urban suburbs face similar climate risks but often lack these bonds. Governments can supply hardware, but lasting resilience grows bottom-up: shared decision making, mutual aid networks and community ties activated when crisis strikes.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s raid in Caracas: oil matters, but it’s not the whole story | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The seizure of Venezuelan leader was induced by the prize of petroleum, but driven by spectacle, geopolitics and domestic politics
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial argues US forces illegally abducted Venezuela’s president Nicolás Maduro largely because of oil reserves—but timing and scope reflect multiple motives: future profits for US oil firms, marginally lower global oil prices, weakening China’s ally, pressuring Cuba and energizing Florida voters. Venezuela’s oil wealth has fueled boom-bust cycles since the 1920s, empowered Chávez’s patronage state and caused economic collapse under Maduro. Removing him won’t dismantle entrenched Chavismo networks or restore production. Trump’s high-profile raid, driven by oil, drugs, ideology and ego, lacks a clear endgame.

articles.title: The Guardian view on universities: Labour needs a clearer plan | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Ministers promised a ‘change of approach’, but their new tax could tip weaker institutions over the edge
articles.summary: Under New Labour participation rose from 336,000 in 1997 to 563,000 in 2022, yet degrees no longer guarantee graduate jobs amid rising debt. Since hitting 50% in 2017, attendance has fallen. Shrinking public funding has strained university finances and academic careers. Labour’s promise to link fees to inflation is undermined by a new £925 per international student levy and stricter visas, putting 24 institutions at risk of collapse. White paper reforms lack an overarching strategy despite universities’ £24bn export value.

articles.title: Now Musk’s Grok chatbot is creating sexualised images of children. If the law won’t stop it, perhaps his investors will | Sophia Smith Galer
articles.trailText: This may be a red line for those with ‘conservative values’ who fund his adventures in free speech, says journalist and content creator Sophia Smith Galer
articles.summary: Sophia Smith Galer exposes how Grok, Elon Musk’s AI chatbot on X, is being abused to generate sexualised images of women and minors—Reuters logged 102 bikini or undress requests in ten minutes, at least 21 complied with—revealing xAI’s lack of robust red-teaming or safety measures despite $10 bn in cash. Grok defends illicit edits as ‘satire,’ while Musk cuts trust-and-safety staff and leans on user reporting. Unlike ChatGPT or Meta AI, Grok permits non-consensual deepfakes, risking UK/EU fines. Galer warns conservative backers must choose between free-speech zeal and protecting children, suggesting investors, not laws, may force change.

articles.title: Elon Musk is moving back into politics. Can’t he take up a new hobby instead? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: It didn’t go very well for him last time, but the tech billionaire seems to have abandoned his plans for a third part and has renewed his bromance with the president, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: In this Guardian column, Arwa Mahdawi critiques Elon Musk’s return to politics after his failed ‘department of government efficiency’ (Doge) cuts that slashed federal jobs and foreign aid, risking millions of excess deaths. Once Gallup’s most unpopular global figure, Musk feuded with Trump over Epstein files but now dines with him at Mar-a-Lago, abandons his third‐party plan and quietly bankrolls Republicans. Spurred on by the late Charlie Kirk and deal-maker JD Vance, Musk’s new political bromance threatens fresh chaos. Mahdawi pleads for him to choose a harmless hobby instead.

articles.title: Why the surprise over Trump’s Venezuela coup? US presidents promise isolation – and deliver war | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: Last week’s events in Caracas come in a long line of American interventions. The White House has awesome power and is never shy of using it, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins argues that last week’s militarised putsch in Caracas – the kidnapping of Nicolás Maduro to install his vice-president Delcy Rodríguez, reportedly colluding with Washington – underscores a long US tradition of unconstitutional foreign interventions. Trump’s praise for Rodríguez, dismissal of opposition María Corina Machado, and talk of running Venezuela “with a group” reveal a U-turn from his isolationist rhetoric and echo past presidents’ hypocrisy. Jenkins traces successive administrations’ breach of international law, from Grenada to Panama, warns of a Trump-era Monroe Doctrine “corollary” and predicts another quagmire.

articles.title: I got married twice in my 20s. Now I’m in love with my midlife situationship | Natasha Ginnivan
articles.trailText: Bored, lonely and emerging from lockdown, a less-traditional relationship was just what I was looking for
articles.summary: Researcher Natasha Ginnivan, twice married by 28 and mother of two, met her current partner—a fellow fifty-something—via a dating app in 2020 post-lockdown. After shared lychee martinis and antique-hunting outings, they’ve embraced a “situationship” rather than remarriage: separate homes, finances, travel schedules, but committed companionship. She frames it as a vintage motorbike-and-sidecar romance, buoyed by large-family support and comfort with autonomy. Citing the Oxford definition and noting menopause and attachment theory’s role in midlife relationships, Ginnivan celebrates this flexible long-term connection as her most enduring partnership to date.

articles.title: Trump is marching into 2026 with the worst cabinet in history | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: From RFK Jr to Pete Hegseth, the president’s top aides have been disastrous. We shouldn’t be surprised
articles.summary: Trump’s 2024–25 cabinet, dubbed a “clown car,” ranks as the worst in American history. Matt Gaetz’s AG bid collapsed; Kristi Noem (DHS) lives rent-free, wasted $200 m on private jets and bungled new funding; Pete Hegseth (Defense) purged “woke” officers, committed security blunders and refocused the military on US cities; RFK Jr (HHS) slashed research budgets, rolled back child-vaccine guidelines and turned the CDC into an anti-vax mouthpiece; Pam Bondi (AG) weaponized DOJ with revenge prosecutions. Critics from Warren Blumenfeld to Robert Reich decry their incompetence, scandals and loyalty-over-capability picks, urging congressional accountability.

articles.title: Many schools don’t think students can read full novels any more. That’s a tragedy | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: Increasingly, teens are given only parts of books, and they often read not in print but on school-issued laptops
articles.summary: Increasingly, US high schools assign only excerpts of novels on school-issued laptops—driven by assumptions about shrinking attention spans, standardized-test preparation and the Common Core’s anthology curricula—so many teens read far fewer complete books. A New York Times survey finds some “secret revolutionary” teachers still teaching whole novels like Fahrenheit 451 or Lord of the Flies, recognizing that print books spark enduring reading habits, academic success and lifelong enrichment. Short novellas like Claire Keegan’s Foster can bridge attention gaps. Advocates urge printed-book donations (Reading Is Fundamental) to help every child build a home library and discover the joy of full novels.

articles.title: Forget all the artisanal cheese. French crisps are absolutely depraved | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: A trip to the supermarché this Christmas opened my eyes to crisps flavoured with Flemish stew, salted butter and other flagrant crimes, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington spent Christmas in France amid twinkling markets and artisanal festive foods, only to uncover a supermarket aisle of shocking crisps—blue cheese, falafel, Flemish stew and even salted butter flavours. She skewers the lawless snack industry, likening it to unregulated tech, lamenting past UK novelty disasters like gingerbread Doritos, Beef Wellington Walkers and prosecco-berry crisps. Despite France’s refined image, its depraved flavour obsession persists. Beddington wryly warns: if butter crisps are sanctioned, what’s stopping foie gras, profiterole or Gauloises-infused chips next?

articles.title: Donald Trump poses a threat to civilization | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The moral purpose of civilized society is to prevent the stronger from attacking the weaker. The US was founded on that principle
articles.summary: Trump’s domestic and foreign policies undermine rule of law and civilization’s core principle of protecting the weak from the strong. His 2021 coup attempt, weekend incursion into Venezuela and threats to Cuba, Colombia and Greenland—enabled by compliant Republicans and Supreme Court—have made the presidency an unprecedentedly powerful, unaccountable force. Robert Reich warns this erosion of America’s founding ideals and the postwar multilateral order mirrors global power concentration in big tech, big oil and authoritarian oligarchs. Unchecked might breeds chaos and war; preserving civilization demands laws, norms and public accountability to constrain the powerful.

articles.title: Greta Thunberg came to stay – and my kid may have inadvertently helped her get arrested | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The activist had held a sign written with my daughter’s crayon. Try explaining that to a four-year-old
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi recounts how her four-year-old daughter innocently lent a crayon to Greta Thunberg, who used it to make a protest sign supporting eight Palestine Action hunger strikers deemed “terrorists” by the UK government. Greta was arrested moments later for holding a peaceful message. Mahdawi notes her father, a Palestinian refugee, routinely hosts activists and highlights her daughter’s bewilderment. She warns that Britain’s harsh anti-protest laws, political targeting of non-violent activists and extreme detention risk irreversible harm to strikers and signal dangerous free speech erosion under Keir Starmer.

articles.title: It’s not easy being an English northerner surrounded by southerners. Here’s how we survive | Robyn Vinter
articles.trailText: University undergraduates are forming northern societies, but in other circumstances we find different ways to be ourselves, says Guardian north of England correspondent Robyn Vinter
articles.summary: Guardian north of England correspondent Robyn Vinter explores how English northerners cope when surrounded by southerners at university and beyond. Southerners’ caricatures of northern accents (“nerhhh”) push many to adopt unplaceable, neutral speech. At York, students revived a Northern Society to preserve regional solidarity just miles from home. Stereotypes linking the north to Brexit-fueled bigotry and the dismissive “professional northerner” label mask a progressive, Labour-voting majority. Vinter argues that the north’s openness, blunt kindness and humor—shared across 15 million people—sustain a proud, diverse identity.

articles.title: Male bonds develop one way, female friendships another. Should we stop trying to make men more like women?  | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: The strong and silent masculine image is often derided, but why? Perhaps companionship via trains, golf or a quiet drink is enough, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff examines anthropologist Thomas Yarrow’s research on male friendship, arguing that the ‘strong and silent’ model—built around shared hobbies like railways, golf, classic cars and companionable silence—fosters deep bonds despite lack of overt emotional talk. Yarrow’s four-year study, ‘Rethinking male friendship and the value of personal reticence’, shows older men communicate care through actions, discreet support and mutual observation. Hinsliff adds that unvoiced affection can protect against loneliness and mental health risks, suggesting that friendship needn’t rely solely on confessional dialogue to be therapeutic.

articles.title: What did I learn from a new - and very random - poll? Our interior lives are much weirder than I thought | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The normal run of polling tends to be all vindictive kite-flying about refugees or magical thinking about climate change. Give me more curtain-twitching and fewer political questions any day, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams reviews a new More in Common poll on everyday quirks: free NHS weight-loss jabs (majority would use, a third see them as cheating), paying grandparents for childcare (a third yes), adult children paying rent (two-thirds yes), equal wills, age limits for having babies (women 45, men 53) and mandatory driving retests. She argues these “curtain-twitchy” questions reveal richer, stranger interior lives than conventional political polls, and urges more random, cheerful surveys on topics like favourite Italian words or kindness to animals.

articles.title: Trump’s new world order is being born – and Venezuela is just the start | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: The US president has been quite clear that Cuba, Mexico, Colombia and Greenland are in his sights. We must believe him, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Owen Jones warns that Trump’s second-term National Security Strategy abandons global hegemony for a US-only sphere of influence, openly endorsing force to seize Venezuela’s oil, enforce the Monroe Doctrine and threaten Cuba, Mexico, Colombia and even annex Greenland. This candid imperialism seeks to reverse Latin America’s pink tide and China’s rising influence, risks NATO’s collapse if Denmark’s territory is taken, and foreshadows a domestic authoritarian boomerang as foreign conquest returns home.

articles.title: Europe’s failure to condemn Trump’s illegal aggression in Venezuela isn’t just wrong – it’s stupid | Nathalie Tocci
articles.trailText: The more European countries act as colonies, unable and unwilling to stand up to Trump, the more they’ll be treated as such, says Guardian Europe columnist Nathalie Tocci
articles.summary: Europe’s leaders largely declined to condemn Trump’s military intervention in Venezuela to overthrow Maduro, despite its clear breach of international law. Only Spain, the Netherlands and Norway spoke out, while others—Macron, Starmer, von der Leyen—offered legalistic caveats, and leaders like Meloni praised it. Tocci argues this timid stance, driven by fears of US troop withdrawals, Greenland ambitions and eagerness to weaken Russia’s ally, only entrenches European subservience and undermines sovereignty norms. Permitting a Trumpified Monroe Doctrine emboldens dictators, serves neither ethics nor security, and represents a “stupid” betrayal of multilateral principles.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Europe’s response to ‘America first’ imperialism: too weak, too timid | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Sir Keir Starmer and European leaders must defend the rule of international law, as a dangerous new world order emerges
articles.summary: Europe’s initial reaction to Trump’s illegal military intervention in Venezuela—limited calls for a negotiated democratic process—was fleeting and insufficient as Operation Absolute Resolve aimed to seize Maduro, control oil and override international law. The Guardian urges Sir Keir Starmer, Emmanuel Macron and EU leaders to abandon timid statements, reaffirm multilateralism and plan for a post-West hegemony by boosting hard power. Though reluctant to alienate Washington amid Ukraine’s defense, Europe must counter US ‘America First’ expansionism to uphold rule-based order and protect its own strategic interests.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the junk food advertising ban: shaping tastes is a job for government | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Weight-loss drugs cannot solve the problem of poor diet. Ministers are right to demand healthier food and promotions
articles.summary: From this week the UK enforces a ban on online and pre-9pm broadcast adverts for 13 junk-food categories—soft drinks with added sugar, crisps, chocolate and sweets—to tackle rising childhood obesity, now 22.1% among primary pupils and linked to type 2 diabetes, stroke risk and deepening social inequality. The Guardian urges government-led prevention via nutrition and exercise over reliance on weight-loss drugs, offered to a few severely obese children. Despite industry-lobby concessions on brand advertising and billboard surges, this overdue measure prioritises protecting vulnerable youngsters’ health.

articles.title: Why is it so perilous to be a person of colour on The Traitors? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Niko Omilana and Tameka Empson were first to go among the celebrities – and now Judy and Ross have been under pressure. Clearly, something is going on here, says Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams criticizes the BBC’s The Traitors for its pattern of early eliminations targeting people of colour—from YouTuber Niko Omilana and actress Tameka Empson in the celebrity edition to non-celebrities Ross and Judy in the new cast. Highlighting arbitrary suspicions based on demeanour rather than evidence, she suggests unconscious bias may drive these votes. While she still finds the format compelling and unifying, Williams warns that beneath its apolitical veneer, the show risks functioning as a social-bias experiment, and urges viewers to confront how race, age and background skew collective judgment.

articles.title: For Americans, 2026 started with two starkly different visions for the country | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Zohran Mamdani’s optimistic inauguration contrasted in every single way with Trump’s brazen invasion of Venezuela
articles.summary: The piece contrasts two opening scenes of 2026: Zohran Mamdani’s star-studded NYC mayoral inauguration, marking a triumph for the Democratic left and pledging rent freezes, free buses and universal childcare, against Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago-ordered raid on Venezuela to kidnap Nicolás Maduro and seize oil, echoing Bush-era imperialism. One event arose from grassroots mobilization promising social welfare; the other was a covert, consent-free military adventure aimed at regime change. Both will shape the looming 2026 midterms: Mamdani’s governing test versus Trump’s bid to revive popularity through foreign war.

articles.title: Trump’s Venezuela invasion sets a perilous precedent | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: If Trump can invade Venezuela, why can’t Putin invade Ukraine? Or Xi Jinping seize Taiwan?
articles.summary: Roth argues Trump’s invasion lacked any UN Security Council approval or genuine self-defense justification—drug trafficking isn’t an armed attack—and misused humanitarian intervention rhetoric absent genocide. He highlights Trump’s selective approach, pardoning friendly leaders while ousting Maduro, and his emphasis on oil interests over democracy. Such aggression revives a ’might makes right’ worldview, undermines the UN charter’s sovereignty norms, and, with Europe’s cautious acquiescence, risks emboldening Putin in Ukraine and Xi over Taiwan. Roth warns this dangerous precedent invites more unilateral invasions, imperiling the rules-based international order.

articles.title: Ever been caught short? Here’s the good news: a great British toilet revolution could be on the way | Eddie Blake
articles.trailText: Inspired by ministers and councils willing to spend a penny, architects are building beautiful, functional loos – a first step towards restoring civic pride, says architect Eddie Blake
articles.summary: Facing 40% closures since 2000, UK public toilets are being reimagined as civic assets. Architect Eddie Blake highlights Studio Weave’s high-quality facilities in Woolwich and Maida Hill—funded via Greenwich’s Future High Streets Fund and Westminster budgets—employing durable materials, passive ventilation, surveillance and amenities (shelter, drinking water). Similar schemes at Finsbury Circus (100-year design life), Bruce Grove (community room, café) and Westminster integrate cross-programming to offset maintenance, boost footfall and deter crime. Supported by the Mayor’s Fund, Levelling Up grants and emerging Pride in Place strategy, this movement calls for statutory local authority duties and sustainable funding to dignify sanitation and renew civic pride.

articles.title: As we farewelled Ronda our soft-hearted labrador, the grief was as painful as any I’ve felt | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: Ronda was a beauty in every sense, and her love for her human and canine family was as unencumbered as it was uncomplicated
articles.summary: Paul Daley’s family labrador Ronda, euthanised at 13 after a year confined by a chest tumour, exemplified unwavering kindness—patient with other dogs, strangers, toddlers and aged-care residents. Her calm love shaped family life: arriving when his daughter was eight, bonding after sibling Nari’s death, then guiding the lively puppy Olive who now embodies Ronda’s gentle legacy. He found relief that her laboured breathing ended gently to the strains of ABC Classic, yet still expects her tail at the stairs each morning. Amid raw grief, Daley reflects that twelve years of joy outweigh this sorrow and that Ronda’s spirit endures in his memories and in Olive’s caring nature.

articles.title: Nine scientific breakthroughs I’d like to see in 2026 – from earworms to procrastination | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: There’s nothing more uplifting than hearing about a world-shaking, life-enhancing new development. But science shouldn’t overlook the small stuff, or stop looking for new species of cute, fluffy mammals, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington, buoyed by 2025 marvels—from UC Berkeley’s ‘olo’ color and custom gene-editing to Smithsonian’s stealth-flipper ichthyosaurs, bone-collector caterpillars, lab-grown teeth and keyboard-playing oysters—outlines nine modest yet morale-boosting targets for 2026. She urges scientists to reassess sedentary sitting risks; search for an adorable new mammal; build live translation tools that decode pet emotions; develop earworm extraction therapies; generate renewable power from habitual scrolling and middle-aged female rage; probe potential health perks of fridge-to-sofa slumps; solve the treadmill-time conundrum; invent a bedtime-enforcing wearable against procrastination; and demystify geese aggression.

articles.title: Who does new year Keir look like after his reset? Last year Keir – and that’s a huge problem | John McTernan
articles.trailText: This weekend’s lengthy BBC interview was a great opportunity to show vim and a new vision, but once again process and stock phrases won out, says political strategist John McTernan
articles.summary: In his 45-minute BBC interview, Keir Starmer displayed calm consistency but no fresh vision, relying on rehearsed phrases and process over purpose. He insisted on a five-year mandate, touted “growth” without distributional specifics, and repeated “turning a corner” on public discontent. Flashes of conviction on child poverty, EU rapprochement and security leadership lacked political framing. He highlighted UK–US rapport under Trump and downplayed domestic vote verdicts. McTernan argues this technocratic, tactic-driven approach elevates process above strategy, risking activist and voter alienation ahead of May’s elections.

articles.title: I’m watching myself on YouTube saying things I would never say. This is the deepfake menace we must confront | Yanis Varoufakis
articles.trailText: These inventions trigger rage, but also optimism. Maybe they will make people think more critically about debate and democracy, says Yanis Varoufakis
articles.summary: Yanis Varoufakis discovered dozens of AI-generated deepfake YouTube videos showing him in a blue shirt he never wore, uttering fictitious claims on geopolitics. After futile takedown requests to Google and Meta, he reframes them as proof of “technofeudalism,” where individuals lose ownership of their data and identity. Paradoxically, these synthetic doppelgangers might revive the Athenian ideal of isegoria by forcing viewers to evaluate ideas on their merits rather than the speaker. Yet he cautions that Big Tech’s control over platforms and algorithmic visibility skews discourse. Real democracy demands political action: socialise cloud capital to dismantle this new feudal order.

articles.title: Trump’s coup in Venezuela didn’t just break the rules – it showed there aren’t any. We’ll all regret that | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: It’s not just the triumphalism in the White House. Leaders loth to oppose this gangsterism must think how that looks to Putin, Xi and in the UAE, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik argues that Trump’s extrajudicial takeover of Venezuela shreds international law and due process, demonstrating the US claims to be “the law” above any higher authority. Rather than justify the coup, the administration cites narrow drug charges while bluntly invoking oil interests. Allies from the UK to the EU have offered tepid condemnations and hedged calls for “facts” and “peaceful transition,” failing to enforce norms. Malik warns this precedent emboldens autocrats like Putin and Xi, fuels Gulf rivalries and risks future land-grabs, regime changes and regional wars, as silence invites unchecked aggression.

articles.title: The awkward truth about some of Trump’s views on Europe? European leaders agree with him | Shada Islam
articles.trailText: The US president’s fears about ‘woke’ Europe are laughable. He would feel right at home in today’s EU, says Brussels-based writer Shada Islam
articles.summary: Shada Islam argues that Donald Trump’s national security strategy disparages a "woke" Europe with racist dog whistles, yet EU leaders have offered bland platitudes instead of challenging its Islamophobic logic. Far-right "civilisation" rhetoric has seeped into mainstream politics: von der Leyen’s conservatives need far-right votes, the EU migration pact tightens asylum and speeds deportations, and 27 states seek to amend the European Convention on Human Rights. Despite labour shortages, restrictive border measures persist alongside secret labour partnerships. Pro-Palestinian activism faces repression, while structural anti-Muslim discrimination is denied. Islam urges leaders to publicly celebrate diversity and reject Trump’s white Christian Europe fantasy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the US seizure of Maduro: Trump has turned the world’s superpower into a rogue state | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The illegal abduction of Venezuela’s president, and threat to ‘run’ his country, is a dangerous act. Its repercussions will be felt far beyond the region
articles.summary: In a unilateral military raid on Venezuelan soil, US forces seized president Nicolás Maduro, marking the first major US attack on South America without UN or congressional approval. Trump declared the US would run Venezuela and seize its oil, setting a chilling precedent that recasts America as a rogue state. This breach of norms—amid strikes on Iran and Nigeria—killed dozens of Venezuelans while misleading Democrats and bypassing legal checks. The muted global response underscores fear of US reprisal. With Trump emboldened, further interventions loom—from Greenland to Mexico—driven by oil lust and waning domestic popularity. The world must push back before international order unravels.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Zohran Mamdani’s task: a high-stakes test case for progressive ambition | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: New York’s new mayor will face headwinds as he attempts to carry out a programme of civic renewal. But his affordability agenda speaks to the times
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial frames Zohran Mamdani’s NYC mayoralty as a high-stakes test for progressive ambition. The city’s youngest, first Muslim, South Asian and Africa-born mayor campaigned on universal childcare, expanded affordable housing and cost-of-living relief funded by taxing the wealthy and corporations. His coalition spans renters, unions, migrants and middle-class professionals. Seen as a model for resurgent centre-left politics—from US swing states to Europe’s D66—his success could invigorate new working-class leftism and curb rising populist right. Yet he faces federal funding fights with Trump’s administration, opposition from Governor Hochul and the challenge of building broad alliances.

articles.title: Caroline felt she was doomed to dating failure. Learning to sit with sadness was part of overcoming her loneliness | Ahona Guha
articles.trailText: Building a life aligned with your values, with or without a partner, starts with naming them. It can also help to set boundaries while dating
articles.summary: Caroline, a woman in her early 30s, felt defective and anxiety-ridden after repeated poor dating experiences, body-checking and social withdrawal. Dr Ahona Guha used cognitive strategies to challenge unhelpful beliefs, behavioral activation (travel, pub football) to renew engagement, and acceptance and commitment therapy to name values and sit with her sadness. They set dating boundaries, reduced self-esteem barriers and reframed attachment fears, helping Caroline accept loneliness as part of life, reclaim self-worth beyond romance and approach dating with greater equanimity.

articles.title: After Trump’s illegal Venezuela coup, there are two dangers: he is emboldened, but has no clue what comes next | Rajan Menon
articles.trailText: He used largely fictitious charges to seize control, but can’t know how Venezuelans will react. He may also overstep now as regards Iran, warns Rajan Menon, a professor emeritus of international relations
articles.summary: Trump's unsanctioned operation to capture Venezuela's Nicolás Maduro on dubious fentanyl and 'narco-terrorism' claims—including a $50m bounty and port blockades—flouts international law and exposes the US to unpredictable fallout. By planning temporary US governance, oil-sector access and trials without evidence, he risks igniting Venezuelan unrest, institutional clash and humanitarian crisis. Originally promising "America First" and an end to "forever wars", Trump's Venezuela coup betrays his rhetoric, undermining US credibility. His emboldened interventionism could also be redirected at Iran's widespread protests, heightening regional tension and conflict despite lacking a clear legal or strategic framework.

articles.title: The electric vehicle revolution is still on course – don’t let your loathing of Elon Musk stop you joining up | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Other firms are taking advantage of Tesla’s sales slump, while technological advances mean that glitches are being left in the rear-view mirror, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Despite Tesla’s European market share falling from 2.1% to 1.4% amid consumer backlash against Musk, EV adoption continues apace. Chinese brands like BYD and SAIC (MG) saw rapid sales growth in November, while hybrids now account for nearly half of new car sales. Technological advances—from basic EV ranges jumping from 50 to nearly 300 miles to next-year trials of solid-state batteries promising 500 miles in 10 minutes—underscore continuous improvement. Faster zero-to-60 acceleration, expanding public charging networks and cheaper home chargers bolster the case. Zoe Williams argues we shouldn’t let Musk’s controversies derail the broader EV revolution or distract from the urgent net-zero transition.

articles.title: In 2026, remember this: Britain is much better than it was in so many ways. Don’t swallow the right’s lies | John Harris
articles.trailText: Populists rewrite the history of this nation because they were complicit in much of its ugliness. The progressive fightback must start now, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris argues that rightwing nostalgia for a monocultural 1980s Britain whitewashes its racism, violence and prejudice. Citing his own school memories, rising ethnonationalist attitudes (IPPR data on “born British” up 20% in 2025), Reform UK’s calls for “remigration” and media that vilifies non-white MPs, he warns of a retro utopia pushed by Farage, Jenrick and others. Harris calls for a progressive cultural counterattack—musicians, filmmakers, sportspeople and influencers—to champion modern, pluralistic Britain and defeat reactionary lies in 2026’s pivotal fight for the soul of the country.

articles.title: Today, Trump’s target was Caracas. What tomorrow? | Stephen Wertheim
articles.trailText: He took office promising to annex Greenland and take back the Panama Canal. Now that he has ousted Maduro, other countries could be next
articles.summary: Stephen Wertheim argues that Trump’s military strikes to depose Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro—modeled on Putin’s ‘peacekeeper’ gambit in Ukraine—usher in a risky era of US-led regime-change campaigns across the hemisphere. Declaring a ‘Trump Corollary’ to revive the Monroe Doctrine, the administration now brands migrants, cartels and even domestic critics as existential threats, justifying interventions from Caracas to Mexico or Cuba. Abandoning lessons from Iraq and Libya, Trump’s hit-and-run approach may shatter stability and entangle America in endless wars.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Films and TV shows are better if you read the spoilers first | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: Please note, this piece absolutely includes spoilers for Cruel Intentions, a film made 26 years ago. Do read on, says assistant Opinion editor Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: Assistant opinion editor Jason Okundaye argues that deliberately reading spoilers before watching films or TV shows can enhance, rather than diminish, the viewing experience. He describes scouring Wikipedia for plot synopses, previewing final episodes of streaming series like Top Boy and enjoying the satisfaction of spotting foreshadowing armed with full knowledge. Drawing a parallel to Greek tragedy, Okundaye cites his recent reappraisal of Cruel Intentions—already knowing Kathryn Merteuil’s downfall intensified his delight. He emphasizes respect for unspoiled theatrical releases, avoids spoiling for others, and credits streaming’s glut of uneven content for his spoiler habit.

articles.title: Today an illegal coup in Venezuela, but where next? Donald Trump talks peace but he is a man of war | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The world will be anxious, and rightly so. For a man so bent on a peace prize, Trump appears to revel in conflict, writes Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall criticizes Trump’s unprovoked, illegal coup in Venezuela to oust Nicolás Maduro, arguing it violates international norms, risks regional anarchy and echoes Iraq and Panama invasions. Despite his peace-prize persona, Trump revels in conflict. Ostensibly framed as anti-narcotics and migration measures, the action advances US dominance and personal vendetta, alarming neighbours from Colombia to Cuba and setting a precedent for rivals like Putin and Xi. With Washington sidelining the UN and EU, the power vacuum could spark civil war or broader conflict. Tisdall urges Western leaders to condemn Trump’s “warrior” guise and curb his erratic militarism.

articles.title: Tennessee actually just did something amazing for women | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The state has created the first registry in the US to track repeat domestic violence offenders
articles.summary: Tennessee has enacted Savanna’s Law, creating the first state-run public registry to track repeat domestic violence offenders. Beginning January 1, anyone convicted of multiple domestic violence charges is logged in a database managed by the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation. Named for Savanna Puckett, who was killed by an ex with a history of abuse, the bipartisan measure raises awareness and signals state support for survivors. Critics warn of underreported cases, registry errors, potential weaponization by abusers and diverted resources, but advocates hail the move as a historic step against intimate partner violence.

articles.title: Migrants are at the heart of our art, our music, our whole history. That’s what the right won’t admit to you | Rowan Williams
articles.trailText: From Britain’s medieval buildings to western pop and contemporary art, these creations showcase our interwoven stories, says former archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams
articles.summary: Rowan Williams argues migrants are fundamental to British art, culture and history – from medieval architecture shaped by Crusader-era exchanges to modern western pop and contemporary installations by Syrian-born Issam Kourbaj. He critiques reductive media narratives casting asylum seekers as criminals and highlights a 2019 Cambridge colloquium showcasing migrant voices through art, music, food and personal artifacts like Dragana Jurišić’s marked Bible. Emphasizing contributions from Hebrew scripture in exile to African roots of Black American music, he urges valuing migrants’ imaginative agency over fear-driven rhetoric.

articles.title: I’m not sure a bakery needs a branded condom – can any business resist selling merch now? | Elle Hunt
articles.trailText: From Trader Joe’s totes to Greggs jewellery, swag mania reveals how small businesses can promote their ‘brands’ – and how we use stuff to signal our tribe, says freelance journalist Elle Hunt
articles.summary: Freelance journalist Elle Hunt examines how small businesses have embraced merchandising—once limited to tote bags—to build brands and foster customer loyalty. From ubiquitous Trader Joe’s totes in London to Greggs’ 22-carat gold-plated sausage-roll earrings, Jolene bakery’s hats, and even Toad Bakery’s charity condoms, swag now signals tribe and street cred. While merch offers modest revenue and cheap marketing, it cements cultural cachet, postcode pride and “in the know” status, yet may distract from core offerings and heighten pressure to stay afloat.

articles.title: At Zohran Mamdani’s block party, I observed a simple truth: people want more politics, not less | Samuel Earle
articles.trailText: Years of scandal and disappointment have left a void in our politics. But New York’s new mayor offers an alternative to more apathy: hope, says author Samuel Earle
articles.summary: On 1 January, newly inaugurated NYC Mayor Zohran Mamdani staged a public block party, underscoring his drive for mass political participation. His campaign spanned viral street interviews in Trump-leaning Queens and the Bronx, volunteer-led canvassing, a citywide scavenger hunt, football tournaments, a jobs portal that drew 74,000 CVs and 12-hour citizen “listening” sessions. Rejecting decades of neoliberal apathy, he pairs universal welfare reforms—free childcare, free buses and rent freezes—with ongoing grassroots mobilization. With appearances by AOC and Sanders and chants of “tax the rich,” Mamdani heralds a “loud,” big-government era rather than “less politics.”

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Fan fiction is real literature, whatever the snobs say | Urooj Ashfaq
articles.trailText: Yes, it’s messy, derivative and occasionally incomprehensible – but so is life, says comedian Urooj Ashfaq
articles.summary: Comedian Urooj Ashfaq argues that fan fiction—despite its chaos, derivative worlds and amateur polish—is real literature and democracy in action, empowering readers to claim narratives by rewriting or extending characters they love. It thrives on emotional correction and rebellion against gatekeeping and commercial snobbery: giving closure, reshaping endings, exploring identity, sexuality and trauma. The genre’s cultural impact spans from Fifty Shades of Grey to Marvel and One Direction fandoms, offering marginalized and queer writers a first space to see themselves represented. Messy, unedited and free, fan fiction proves that literariness emerges from passion, not prestige.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Gaza’s winter: the world must take heed as Palestinian suffering deepens again | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Families are struggling to survive amid the devastation. Israel’s ban on international NGOs will worsen this disaster
articles.summary: As Gaza endures brutal winter—children freezing, drowning in flooded camps or burned by makeshift stoves—the devastation is acute after Israel razed nine in ten homes in two years of war. 1.6 million face severe hunger under collapsed sanitation. International partners warn of catastrophe even as Israel orders 37 NGOs to cease operations unless they hand over staff data, and bars key supplies like tent poles and generators as “dual-use.” Relief is a legal obligation, not leverage. Israel’s allies must demand unfettered aid and compliance with ceasefire terms to stave off further suffering.

articles.title: The Guardian view on care leavers: responsibility for looked-after children does not end at 18 | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Free prescriptions and eye tests ought to help these young adults get treatment. They also signal the state’s ongoing role
articles.summary: Editorial highlights alarming disparities faced by care leavers in England—62% higher mortality before 75, quadruple conviction rates—and rising numbers in state care (81,770 vs 83,750 peak; 17.7% increase over a decade). New reforms grant free prescriptions, dental and eye care, plus mental-health pilots and NHS internships up to age 25, signalling ongoing state duty beyond 18. Yet strained council finances, social-worker and foster-carer shortages, and lack of post-18 support persist. Calls on minister Josh MacAlister to deepen reforms, rebalance toward public/non-profit provision, ensure devolved nations action, and publicise entitlements.

articles.title: From Donald Trump to Benjamin Netanyahu, let 2026 be a year of reckoning | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: These malign figures will do anything to avoid paying for the harm they have done, but accountability must eventually come to both, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: In his Guardian column, Jonathan Freedland urges 2026 to be a year of reckoning for leaders who evade accountability. He highlights the US midterms as a verdict on Trump’s second term—with potential Democratic control of the House enabling subpoenas, investigations and possible impeachment. In Israel, Netanyahu’s re-election bid hinges on voters judging him for Gaza’s devastation and October 2023 failures. Freedland also notes Iranian protests against the clerical regime and looming UK elections as moments to hold power to account.

articles.title: Bondi is where I have felt safe all my life. How could anyone want to destroy this monument to humanity and joy? | Alice Fraser
articles.trailText: I can’t bear to view this postcard of Australia, layered with a thousand memories, with untrusting eyes, to feel the air changed and warped by horror
articles.summary: Alice Fraser reflects on Bondi Beach as her lifelong refuge of sunlit joy, communal harmony and personal memories with family and friends. After a mass shooting shattered her postcard-perfect vision, she resists political or ideological explanations, instead seeing the atrocity as a direct attack on ordinary people living in peace. Struggling with horror and grief, she can no longer board the bus to Bondi without tears, recognizing that the beach’s symbolic power lies in its simple celebration of shared humanity.

articles.title: Australia’s stance on Afghan cricket is flawed – and deeply painful for people like me. There is another path | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: When I arrived in Australia after the fall of Kabul, seeing Rashid Khan in the BBL eased my grief and reminded me that pride and belonging were possible
articles.summary: Shadi Khan Saif reflects on how Rashid Khan’s standout Big Bash League performances provided newly evacuated Afghan refugees in Brisbane with hope and a sense of belonging after Kabul’s fall. He argues Australia’s blanket refusal to schedule bilateral series with Afghanistan over the Taliban’s ban on women’s sport punishes male cricketers, who represent a resilient diaspora and defy international isolation. Instead of symbolic withdrawal, Saif calls for conditional engagement—linking BBL contracts and ICC influence to tangible support, visas, funding and competitive pathways for exiled Afghan women’s teams—bypassing the regime and honoring cricket’s unifying power.

articles.title: Here’s a pick-me-up for the January blues: this could well be Nigel Farage’s last year on top | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: There’s no doubting the charisma of its leader, but Reform UK lacks the depth and experience needed to govern – and voters are quickly realising that, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins argues 2026 will be make-or-break for Nigel Farage’s Reform UK: after surging to 29% (YouGov) and 33% (More in Common) in mid-2025, its support slipped to 26% by December amid rising backing for Kemi Badenoch, Lib Dems and Greens. Jenkins highlights Reform’s lack of a disciplined, experienced team – three chairs in two years, factional infighting and a revolving door of MPs – leaving it a one-man show. Overreliance on immigration and Musk-style cuts, plus absence of collective loyalty, make it unlikely to form government in a probable hung parliament.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: PDAs on the morning commute are never acceptable | Michael Akadiri
articles.trailText: Spare me the hugging, kissing, sitting on each other’s laps. What’s the excuse so close to breakfast, asks standup comedian Michael Akadiri
articles.summary: Comedian and doctor Michael Akadiri declares that public displays of affection (PDAs) during the morning commute are intolerable cruelties deserving of prison time under his imaginary British Tonguing Police. While he professes a love for love—his marriage, children and popular dating shows—he deems hugging, kissing or lap-sitting on buses or trains around 8am as disruptive and counterproductive, akin to being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. He allows evening PDAs after a night out but insists early-morning randy behaviour should be kept private at home before arriving at work.

articles.title: What if floods left your home unsellable? That’s the reality facing more and more people in Britain | Kirsty Major
articles.trailText: Christine wanted to enjoy her retirement, but then the banks of a local brook burst and turned her and her neighbours’ lives upside-down, says Guardian deputy Opinion editor Kirsty Major
articles.summary: Christine, Jackie and Rhona, three pensioners in Trowell, Nottinghamshire, have seen repeated floods make their homes unsellable after a local brook burst in 2020 and again in 2023. Flood-resilience measures by the Environment Agency, including barriers and pumps, failed to stop rising groundwater. Nearby housing developments have boosted runoff by an estimated 44%, yet phased planning loopholes overlook cumulative risk. Affected properties now sell at 8–32% discounts and face mortgage restrictions. Government flood insurance to 2039 masks looming financial stability threats as climate breakdown intensifies.

articles.title: From bon appetit to Uber Eats: why France’s beloved restaurants are in crisis | Paul Taylor
articles.trailText: When I started as a reporter in Paris in the 1970s, long, boozy lunches were the norm. Now only fast food and fine dining are thriving, says the European Policy Centre’s Paul Taylor
articles.summary: Traditional French restaurants face daily closures of 25 establishments as consumers shift to fast-food and fine dining, driven by cost-of-living pressures, rising wholesale food prices, home-delivery apps and post-pandemic remote work. Young diners eat and drink less, VAT remains higher for dine-in vs takeaway, and luncheon vouchers can now buy supermarket meals. Staffing shortages, shorter working hours (35-hour week) and municipal parking restrictions exacerbate struggles. Haute cuisine and chains like McDonald’s prosper, while smaller venues choose between cost-cutting frozen ingredients or costly local menus. UMIH’s plea to limit new openings and enforce professional licensing has yet to influence policy.

articles.title: Ignore the sceptics: with this new vaccine, chickenpox could become a thing of the past | Wes Streeting
articles.trailText: Thousands develop serious complications from the varicella virus. Today the NHS rolls out a new jab, alongside measles, mumps and rubella, says health secretary Wes Streeting
articles.summary: Wes Streeting, UK health secretary, unveils NHS rollout of combined MMRV vaccine protecting against measles, mumps, rubella and chickenpox for English children at 12 and 18 months. Free on the NHS, it aims to cut nursery and school absences, GP visits and £24m annual productivity losses, while preventing severe varicella complications—bacterial infections, pneumonia, encephalitis or flesh‐eating disease. Decades of global data from the US, Canada, Australia and Germany show dramatic drops in cases, hospitalisations and deaths. Estimated to save the NHS £15m yearly, this expansion underscores prevention, evidence‐based medicine and countering vaccine misinformation.

articles.title: The Guardian view on mRNA vaccines: they are the future – with or without Donald Trump | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Over the holiday period, the Guardian leader column is looking ahead at the themes of 2026. Today we examine how the White House’s war on vaccines has left the future of a key technology uncertain and up for grabs
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial argues that mRNA vaccines—born of pandemic deregulation and Nobel-winning science—remain transformative for flu, HIV and personalised cancer therapies but face an existential threat from a second Trump administration. Despite over $10bn of US investment and infrastructure, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.–led policies have cut $500m for 22 research projects, slowed FDA approvals and undermined public confidence. Biotechs may relocate to the EU and UK, which have pledged €600m and host most manufacturing. Europe must seize leadership to sustain the global mRNA revolution.

articles.title: The best way to get round a difficult problem? Do nothing about it | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: An idling brain suddenly seems able to join the dots, says the Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff argues that stepping away from a stuck problem by engaging in undemanding tasks — from folding laundry to walking the dog — often triggers creative breakthroughs by freeing the subconscious. She cites surgeon Michael Baum’s epiphany on chaos theory after a theatre break, plus Archimedes and Agatha Christie.
