In an era of intense workloads, she suggests governments and companies should build in “thinking time,” as Google’s 20% rule once did, and leverage AI to relieve routine work so humans can pursue original ideas.

articles.title: At 51, I’m about to start work as a junior doctor. It’s been a wild ride to get here | Ben Collins
articles.trailText: My transformation was most apparent the day I realised that a digital rectal examination can be life-saving
articles.summary: Ben Collins, a 51-year-old former ABC journalist turned medical student, endured four intense years dissecting cadavers, rifling human hearts and facing spurting blood, amniotic eruptions and intimate exams. Initially paralysed by interviewing a depressed patient, he learned trust through patient forgiveness. His pivotal moment came when a digital rectal examination revealed prostate cancer; in paediatrics he matched an expert’s seizure diagnosis from a brief video. Now poised to work as a junior doctor, he reflects on delivering babies, diagnosing tumours and making life-saving interventions, and anticipates a rewarding new two-decade medical career.

articles.title: They tried to smear him as an antisemite – but Mayor Zohran Mamdani walks in a rich Jewish tradition | Molly Crabapple
articles.trailText: When I look at Mamdani, I don’t see some radical departure. I see him as an heir to the Yiddish socialism that helped build New York
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, now NYC’s first socialist mayor, overcame billionaire-funded and Zionist-led smears branding him antisemitic. Rather than a radical break, he embodies New York’s storied Yiddish socialist legacy—from 1900s Bundists like Baruch Charney Vladeck to socialist paper The Forward, garment workers’ unions, and figures like Meyer London. His DSA-backed, multilingual, labor-focused campaign mirrored the mutual aid, picket lines and “roti and roses” ethos of early Jewish socialists, winning broad Jewish and immigrant support.

articles.title: At the turn of the year, I’m facing a pivot point. Midlife crisis? No thanks | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: At 50, I find myself in a gazing-up-at-trees phase. What does it all mean? It’s not completely clear – but it’s certainly bothering my kids, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Brockes turns 50 amid a ‘looking-at-trees’ phase she likens to emotional pivot points that mirror Stanford Medicine’s identified biomolecular ageing spikes at 44 and 60. Observing modern 50-year-olds still dressing and behaving decades younger, she argues midlife milestones have been deferred. Triggered by her kids’ final primary school year, she experiences an ‘anticipation of future nostalgia,’ a diffuse sadness that defies her practiced strategy of pre-emptive grieving. Her children find confronting their parents’ interior lives unsettling, but Brockes insists these unavoidable inflections are worth fully feeling in real time.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Enough of the ‘Hey you!’ faux-friend nonsense. You’re a business, not my mate | Max Fletcher
articles.trailText: No, your communications don’t make me feel valued as an individual. A ‘Dear’ or ‘Sir’ wouldn’t hurt once in a while, says writer Max Fletcher
articles.summary: In this critique, Max Fletcher lambasts corporate use of the second-person “you” as a hollow, patronising marketing ploy rather than genuine personalization. Tracing direct address from Kodak’s 1888 slogan to today’s oat-milk cartons, restaurant emails and ChatGPT greetings, he argues it grants false empowerment while concealing the real power held by companies. Fletcher demands basic courtesy—once-formal greetings like “Dear” or “Sir”—and insists brands stop masquerading as friends when they’re simply pursuing profit.

articles.title: I’ve been a New Yorker for 23 years. Today Zohran Mamdani’s swearing-in makes this city a real home | Mona Eltahawy
articles.trailText: The new mayor embraces social justice, and rejects hate and nationalism. That’s why we’re so excited to see what he’ll do in office, says author Mona Eltahawy
articles.summary: Egyptian-born New Yorker Mona Eltahawy describes attending a Queens fundraiser for Asiyah Women’s Centre, where fellow Muslims and immigrants rallied behind mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani. Praised for championing a rent freeze for 2 million rent-stabilized tenants, proudly admitting to buying legal cannabis, and embodying Muslim identity in a diverse city, Mamdani—Queens-born, the first Muslim and youngest mayor since 1892—symbolizes New York’s pluralism and a youthful turn toward social justice over nationalism.

articles.title: When racists shout ‘Go home’, and you come from 15 places, what to do? | Hugh Muir
articles.trailText: A DNA test showed me that theoretically I have links to a long list of countries – and that the way we look at belonging makes little sense, says Hugh Muir, executive editor, Opinion
articles.summary: Hugh Muir examines the surge of nativist bigotry in 2025 UK – from “go home” taunts at MPs like David Lammy to street-level abuse – and warns that millions, especially dual nationals and minorities, face rising hard-right narratives and risk losing citizenship under changing laws. He uses his own DNA test, revealing links to numerous African, European and Caribbean regions, to challenge simplistic ideas of belonging. Muir argues most Britons share mixed heritage, and identity debates should embrace our multiple roots rather than exclusionary populism.

articles.title: Cecilia Giménez’s botched Monkey Christ became a global meme. The real marvel was the humble, graceful woman behind it | Sam Jones
articles.trailText: The restorer, who died on Monday, brought unwanted attention to herself – and her small Spanish town. Then, slowly, a small miracle took place, says Sam Jones, the Guardian’s Madrid correspondent
articles.summary: At age 81, amateur restorer Cecilia Giménez’s 2012 attempt to fix Elías García Martínez’s Ecce Homo fresco in Borja backfired, sparking the Monkey Christ meme and global ridicule. Yet she had spent two decades preserving the damaged fresco and was midway through restoration when her unfinished work went viral. Borja rallied, transforming the Santuario de Misericordia into a museum and gift-shop hub that funds local care homes, including for Giménez and her son. Celebrated in a Las Vegas opera, she died aged 94, remembered not for the botch but for her humility, devotion and lasting legacy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on hard times for Britain’s charities: struggling to do more with less | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Over the holiday period, the Guardian leader column is looking ahead at the themes of 2026. Today, the challenges facing the voluntary sector as it attempts to cope with an ongoing funding crisis
articles.summary: Britain’s charities, from local hubs like Hands Together Ludlow to national bodies, are under siege as austerity, pandemic fallout and the cost-of-living crisis drive up demand while state funding and donations slump to record lows. Major NGOs—Samaritans, Macmillan, Oxfam, Relate—have cut branches, staff and grants; smaller groups face closure and burnout. Labour’s civil society covenant recalls past “compact” models, but without a funding and volunteer recruitment reset, the 160,000-strong sector’s preventive value and community trust risk being eroded further.

articles.title: Yes, women’s rights are under threat around the world. But we’ve found hope in unlikely places | Rahila Gupta
articles.trailText: From El Salvador to Russia, Iceland and Syria, women are pushing back against the rise of regressive forces. Let’s support their fight, says anti-racist feminist activist Rahila Gupta
articles.summary: Facing global setbacks—from US and UK abortion rollbacks to Taliban and sexual violence in Haiti and DR Congo—women’s rights movements are erupting. In El Salvador, feminists secured release of 72 women imprisoned for suspected abortions. Russian activists don blue–yellow ribbons to protest the war. Iceland’s high gender-equality ranking owes much to a 1975 women’s strike, union power and equal-pay laws, despite enduring wage and violence gaps. In war-torn Rojava, grassroots direct democracy enshrines co-presidency and women’s assemblies with veto authority, bans child marriage and polygamy, and champions secular gender justice under siege by Turkey and Assad.

articles.title: The one trick to nailing parenting this summer? Delete Instagram | Léa Antigny
articles.trailText: Every time I open the app I’m bombarded with reels from accounts I don���t follow, promising they’ve cracked the code
articles.summary: The author recounts how a serene family beach holiday turned sour when an hour lost to Instagram parenting reels left her exhausted and insecure. These “mumfluencers” peddle one-size-fits-all hacks—be the fun mum, the self-care mum—while deepening parental anxiety and eroding attention spans. Antigny argues real nourishment comes from deleting Instagram, trusting gut instincts, and embracing unstructured play and simple joys with children. Parenting should center on genuine relationships, not gamified optimization. By quitting the app’s addictive loop, parents reclaim focus, creativity and presence, rejecting the illusion of perfection sold by social-media slot machines.

articles.title: The WHO learned to love ‘anti-obesity’ jabs in 2025. I don’t fully agree, but I get it | Devi Sridhar
articles.trailText: While GLP-1 drugs promise an easy fix, our bodies still need what they have always needed: healthy food and regular exercise, says chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh, Prof Devi Sridhar
articles.summary: In 2025 GLP-1 injections developed for diabetes became mainstream weight-loss “anti-obesity” jabs, prompting concern in public health circles that pharma profits now trump efforts to reform food systems. Despite evidence these drugs cut weight and reduce cardiovascular and metabolic risk, questions remain about long-term safety, dependency and their use by healthy individuals. The WHO has endorsed global access to GLP-1s, but Devi Sridhar warns that nutritious diets, affordable produce, regulation of processed foods and regular exercise remain indispensable for lasting health gains.

articles.title: A polycrisis has shattered our world this year. But with care, we can put it back together | Elif Shafak
articles.trailText: The challenges and strains have been almost too much to take. But in 2025, words of depth and courage have been an antidote to numbness, says novelist and political scientist, Elif Shafak
articles.summary: Elif Shafak reflects on 2025 as a ‘polycrisis’—a convergence of social, economic, environmental, technological and institutional shocks that have fractured trust in democratic norms, intensified inequality and stirred existential anxiety. As pressure mounts, numbness toward suffering in Gaza, Sudan and Ukraine spreads. Shafak argues that clear language, compassionate journalism and narratives of care—like human stories of malnourished children, water scarcity in Kabul and community resilience in the UK—are antidotes to despair. Drawing on art, literature and the metaphor of a shattered vase, she urges collective healing by recognizing brokenness and committing to rebuild with empathy.

articles.title: Lububus, Taylor Swift and Sydney Sweeney: here’s the deluge that was 2025 | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: It was a tough year (again) and we met it all with a shrug
articles.summary: Dave Schilling’s irreverent year-end review skewers 2025’s collective apathy, tracing the Dictionary.com meme “6-7,” Nicki Minaj at Turning Point USA, LA wildfires and Trump’s second inauguration, ICE protests and No Kings, Labubus gremlin dolls, Sydney Sweeney’s jeans-genes ad backlash, #coldplaygate, virally green Dubai chocolate, and the lightning Louvre jewel heist. His punchline: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce’s engagement was as stage-managed product launch as ever, reminding us that in a numbing age of disasters and distractions, pop-cultural inanity offers the odd, self-aware caviar tin in life’s dumpster fire.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: That stone-cold classic you love isn’t a party starter – it’s a party destroyer | Nels Abbey
articles.trailText: Cameo’s Candy is one of the all-time great funk records, but after a six-minute dance formation everyone is heading for the door, says author Nels Abbey
articles.summary: Author Nels Abbey argues that Cameo’s funk classic “Candy,” long a party staple as Britain’s go-to six-minute electric slide, is actually a “party destroyer.” Its rigid formation dance saps energy, prompts premature exits, undermines DJs’ flow and enforces a one-size-fits-all routine that extinguishes spontaneity. Originating as the 1970s Electric Slide and popularized by 1999’s The Best Man, Candy’s exhausting choreography and lack of inclusivity, Abbey contends, signal social conformism rather than celebration. Abbey also sees Candy’s strict choreography as a quintessentially British ritual, mirroring society’s rigid hierarchies.

articles.title: I could not forgive the father who left me. Until a chance encounter changed my outlook | Carolin Würfel
articles.trailText: In 2025 I learned that reconciliation is less about a grand apology than a shift in perspective, says writer and screenwriter Carolin Würfel
articles.summary: In 2025, screenwriter Carolin Würfel recounts how a chance meeting with her estranged father on a Berlin airport escalator shifted her perspective from pain to possibility. She learned that forgiveness isn’t a destination but a journey—a step off the escalator toward a new plateau. Inspired by Phil Stutz’s ‘active love’ exercise and Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela’s claim that forgiveness demands openness, she reached out, shared a cautious lunch in Berlin and began regular texting. Würfel parallels this with reconciling a friendship after a fight, underscoring that forgiveness is an ongoing practice of small gestures, empathy and resisting the comfort of resentment rather than awaiting a grand apology.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the new Monroe doctrine: Trump’s forceful approach to the western hemisphere comes at a cost | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Over the holiday period, the Guardian leader column is looking ahead at the themes of 2025. Today, how US foreign policy has dramatically – and alarmingly – turned towards Latin America and the Caribbean
articles.summary: The Guardian warns that Trump’s 2025 foreign policy resurrects an 1823 Monroe doctrine with a forceful 'Donroe' approach: threats to seize Greenland, the Panama Canal, and to invade or sanction Latin American countries. He has imposed tariffs, meddled in elections in Honduras, Argentina and Brazil, launched extrajudicial strikes on drug boats, deployed warships off Venezuela, and offered $50m bounty on Maduro. This personalistic 'big stick' strategy aims to check China’s influence and curb migration and drugs but risks regional backlash, refugee surges and fractured Western alliances. Europe-Latin ties need strengthening.

articles.title: The royal family is edging toward modernity – but in 2026, the public will expect yet more transparency | Anna Whitelock
articles.trailText: Despite Charles’s welcome openness about his cancer, polls show declining support for the monarchy. To survive, the royals now need to lift the curtain on their finances, says academic Anna Whitelock
articles.summary: King Charles’s candid updates on prostate treatment and cancer, alongside high-profile state visits, have boosted his personal approval to 62%. Yet public support for the monarchy is at a record low amid the Andrew-Epstein scandal and growing calls for transparency. Whitelock highlights undisclosed royal income streams—£132.1 m sovereign grant for 2025/26, £28.7 m from the Duchy of Lancaster, private estates—and exemptions from FOI, capital gains and employment law. She argues that without clear separation of public and private funds and greater accountability, the monarchy risks irrelevance in 2026.

articles.title: Psst: wanna buy a new year's honour? Once it was simple. And now? Well, don’t rule it out | Stephen Bates
articles.trailText: I’m fascinated by Maundy Gregory, who sold honours for Lloyd George. He wouldn’t be tolerated today, but don’t assume our system is flawless, says author and biographer Stephen Bates
articles.summary: Stephen Bates traces the murky history of honours trading, focusing on Arthur Maundy Gregory, who under PM Lloyd George sold knighthoods (£10,000), baronetcies (£40,000) and peerages (£50,000), funnelling funds into party coffers. Gregory’s office near Downing Street enraged King George V and spurred the 1925 Honours (Prevention of Abuses) Act; he was later jailed and exiled. Bates warns that modern nomination firms—claiming clients are 6.5× more likely to gain awards and boasting an 80% success rate—echo Gregory’s profiteering.

articles.title: As we prepare for 2026, remember we have the power to make our future | Rebecca Solnit
articles.trailText: We enter 2026 with radical uncertainty about the fate of the US – but also with the clarity that people have the power to determine what it will be
articles.summary: Rebecca Solnit argues that as the US heads into 2026, the Trump administration represents an exclusionary, dishonest, and cruel minority regime, peddling lies across policy areas. In contrast, a principled opposition upholds inclusion, truth, science and solidarity—evident in immigrant-rights protests, legal and journalistic defenses of facts, and unified campaigns for Epstein’s victims. Despite escalating extremism, this grassroots resistance has forced policy reversals and Republican defections. Solnit concludes that sustained, values-driven activism can determine the nation’s future amid radical uncertainty.

articles.title: Why is the Democratic party hiding its 2024 autopsy report? | Norman Soloman
articles.trailText: If the DNC isn’t open and transparent about why they lost, then how can we be sure they will learn their lesson this time?
articles.summary: The DNC’s decision to withhold its 2024 election “autopsy” exemplifies its reluctance toward internal critique, privileging PR over grassroots accountability. Under chair Ken Martin, the party suppressed findings likely condemning Biden-Harris leadership—from Biden’s refusal to step aside and Harris’s $1.5 billion campaign spending to ignoring voter discontent over inflation, Gaza policy and plunging youth turnout. This secrecy mirrors 2016’s failures, blocking vital debate on lost voters, corporate donor influence and electability strategies. Norman Solomon contrasts this with RootsAction’s own detailed autopsy highlighting 6.8 million lost voters, working-class abandonment and foreign policy missteps.

articles.title: 2025 was the year we grew tired of celebrity for celebrity’s sake | Nadia Khomami
articles.trailText: Being blasted into space or taking over Venice no longer cuts it. The rich and famous are being punished for their conspicuous vacuity, says Guardian arts and culture correspondent Nadia Khomami
articles.summary: In 2025, audiences grew weary of spectacle without substance. Katy Perry’s 11-minute Blue Origin flight was derided as tone-deaf PR, Jeff Bezos’s £37m Venice wedding sparked “eat the rich” fury, and Sydney Sweeney’s eugenics-tinged jeans ad drew criticism amid her political silence. Meanwhile box office bombs starring Margot Robbie, Dwayne Johnson and Julia Roberts contrasted with socially conscious films like Ryan Coogler’s Sinners. Taylor Swift faced muted sales and scrutiny for staying quiet on Gaza. As trust in institutions wanes, stars from Charli XCX to Jennifer Lawrence debate moral obligation, but fans now insist celebrities use their platforms for genuine engagement.

articles.title: Conditions may feel rife for a coup within Labour – but a change of leader alone isn’t going to fix things | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: For all the talk of coups, this much is clear: without a strong vision, Labour will face a fresh crisis of legitimacy, says Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee critiques Labour’s rumoured bid to oust Keir Starmer, observing that his unpopularity stems from broader anti-politician sentiment and that a mere leadership swap risks renewed instability. She examines precedents—from John Major’s Thatcher-era boost to post-Brown coup failures—warning that new leaders need fresh mandates and cohesive policies. Toynbee urges MPs to prioritize substantive change over optics: revise the manifesto for global crises, abandon rigid tax and Brexit pledges, introduce proportional representation, clean up donations, and coalesce around credible contenders like Streeting, Rayner or Burnham to restore legitimacy.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Never decline an invitation on the day of the event. Ghosting is the humane option  | Phineas Harper
articles.trailText: Either say you can’t make it well in advance or keep stumm, says writer Phineas Harper
articles.summary: As New Year’s Eve approaches, writer Phineas Harper advises that guests should only RSVP "no" well before an event or not at all on the day. Late declines frustrate hosts who have already arranged food, drinks and seating, and disrupt party energy, especially via group-chat drop-out messages. Rather than announce a last-minute cancellation, silent no-shows ("ghosting") spare hosts unnecessary stress. Only for small gatherings might a personal apology suffice. For larger events, simply keep your absence to yourself: the host likely over-invited to accommodate flaky attenders anyway.

articles.title: The Louvre is the pride of France – and it’s on the verge of collapse. Can we rescue it in time? | Agnès Poirier
articles.trailText: From a jewel heist to crumbling galleries, it’s been a dire year for the world’s most visited museum. At least France has woken up to its predicament, says political commentator Agnès Poirier
articles.summary: Since its 18th-century founding as a royal palace turned public museum in 1793, the Louvre has endured revolutions, arson and wartime evacuations—including the 1911 Mona Lisa heist and Jacques Jaujard’s 1939 secret removal of 1,862 art cases ahead of Nazi occupation. This year a high-profile crown-jewels theft, leaking roofs and burst pipes forced closure of ancient Greek galleries and damaged Egyptology records, triggering staff strikes and a damning parliamentary report on neglected maintenance. President Macron’s €1.15 billion “renaissance” plan (2027–2031) promises a dedicated Mona Lisa wing, new entrances, modern security and visitor-funded restoration to salvage France’s flagship museum.

articles.title: The Guardian view on antibiotics: recent breakthroughs are great news, but humanity is losing the bigger race | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Our magic bullets are increasingly rare and ineffective. The golden age of discovery is over and the way we develop and use drugs needs to change
articles.summary: Editorial warns that the golden age of antibiotic discovery is over as rising resistance outpaces only modest gains: since 2017 just 16 mostly analog drugs have reached approval. Recent FDA clearance of two gonorrhoea antibiotics, including Zoliflodacin, stems from innovative funding and trial support by GARDP-Innoviva and underlines the promise of the UK’s subscription model. Yet Zoliflodacin’s novel mechanism only delays inevitable resistance and calls for rationing—challenging in low-resource settings. With natural screening exhausted, AI picks and synthetic chemistry stymied, only coordinated global stewardship can preserve existing drugs and eke out future, limited breakthroughs.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the National Year of Reading 2026: time to start a healthy habit for life | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A Children’s Booker prize, library cards for newborns and a major campaign – initiatives to encourage a love of books in children are a cause for celebration
articles.summary: Government has declared 2026 the National Year of Reading to counter a 36% drop in eight-to-18-year-olds reading for pleasure over two decades, with teenage boys and poorer children worst affected. Only two-thirds of 8–18s now enjoy reading in their spare time and a quarter of primary leavers lack adequate skills. Plans include distributing 72,000 free books to deprived areas, launching a Children’s Booker prize for 8–12s judged by young readers, and issuing newborn library cards to boost early development. The Guardian calls for sustained investment in school libraries, trained librarians, teacher support and accessible books to rebuild literacy and social mobility.

articles.title: The very next day, you gave it away … how to get rid of an unwanted Christmas gift without getting caught| Eleanor Limprecht
articles.trailText: When a friend found out the painting she’d given me had made its way to a charity store, I wanted to dig a hole in the earth
articles.summary: Eleanor Limprecht examines the awkward ritual of disposing unwanted gifts without offending the giver. After donating a friend’s painting to Vinnies—only for its artist to repurchase it—she gathers confessions: Facebook Marketplace sales exposed to well-meaning givers, regifting books with personal inscriptions, art surfacing in kerbside clean-ups and charity shops. Contributors, including creators, argue that rehoming spares gifts from attic oblivion. They advocate upfront honesty—admit a piece isn’t your style—but for the timid, discreet rehoming via op shops, council collections or enlisting a friend offers a polite escape hatch.

articles.title: I knew all about the NHS’s challenges and flaws. But then as a patient, I saw the love and the magic | Anne Perkins
articles.trailText: There is something about the care and professionalism to be seen on a ward that defies abstract analysis: a reminder of what it is to be human, says writer Anne Perkins
articles.summary: Former Guardian reporter Anne Perkins reflects on her transformation from chronicler to emergency patient within the NHS. Confronted by pain, anonymity and shared vulnerability, she witnesses acts of alchemy: ward staff treating even uncooperative, incontinent patients with tireless compassion, and strangers offering warmth amid threadbare wards. Struck by a tangible sense of collective purpose—patients metaphorically aboard a creaking, inclusive bus—she highlights the contagious love, professionalism and solidarity that transcends politics and bureaucracy. While acknowledging systemic flaws, Perkins insists this human generosity makes the NHS’s true value beyond price.

articles.title: Americans are waking up. A grand reckoning awaits us | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: I’d like to believe that the horrific darkness of this past year is a necessary prelude to a brighter and saner future
articles.summary: Robert Reich argues that the brutal reality of Trump’s second term—cruelty, corruption, open racism and attacks on democracy—has jolted Americans awake, sparking record protests and sweeping Democratic gains in red districts. He likens this awakening to past reckonings ignited by televised violence against civil‐rights protesters and early‐20th‐century muckrakers. Reich traces decades of growing inequality, corporate greed, union‐busting, deregulation and political capture by big money, noting that even Democratic presidents failed to reverse the rot. Now, as elites scramble to protect their spoils before 2026, the nation faces a critical moment: leverage this nightmare to rebuild social justice, democracy and broad prosperity.

articles.title: Is it Twixmas or Twixtmas? And other style guide conundrums we have faced this year at the Guardian | Charlotte Naughton and Katy Guest
articles.trailText: Language is constantly evolving, and it’s our job to keep up – even at Christmas, say joint editors of the Guardian style guide, Charlotte Naughton and Katy Guest
articles.summary: Guardian style guide editors Charlotte Naughton and Katy Guest reflect on 2025’s most vexing usage debates: adopting ‘Twixmas’ over ‘Twixtmas’ (traced to Old High German zwiski), lowercase ‘triceratops’, metric vs imperial in space, capitalising US ICE but not Nasa/Nato, and ending the convention of dropping ‘al-’ from Arabic surnames after consultation with Dr Nada Elzeer. They note evolving trends towards Americanisms, growing acceptance of ‘gen AI’, and the politics of terminology around ethnicity, disability and mental health. Committed to balancing readers’ preferences, linguistic diversity and principled rulings, they invite expert and reader feedback to shape future updates.

articles.title: The BBC tells the story of Britain in a way Netflix simply cannot. In the year to come, please remember that | Tony Hall
articles.trailText: I love many shows on the streaming channels, but the BBC is our storyteller. It defines a nation and its culture – and we must defend it, says former BBC director general Tony Hall
articles.summary: Former BBC director-general Tony Hall argues that, despite recent controversies with Trump-backed libel claims, the BBC’s role as a national storyteller and public service broadcaster is unmatched by global streamers. He highlights government endorsements of the BBC as a cultural institution akin to the NHS, its unparalleled local and network news reach, its commission of UK-focused documentaries, drama and radio, and its £4.9bn annual investment outside London. As the charter renewal looms, Hall urges defence of the BBC’s independence, funding and cultural mandate against market-driven content.

articles.title: The mood was jubilant at Italy’s far-right Atreju festival. But has Meloni’s success peaked? | Jamie Mackay
articles.trailText: The PM has been lauded for Italy’s growing role on the world stage. But poverty and precarity are forcing vast numbers to emigrate, says Florence-based writer Jamie Mackay
articles.summary: At Italy’s annual Atreju festival—once fringe neo-fascist carnival, now mainstream far-right fair—PM Giorgia Meloni marked Brothers of Italy’s rise from 2% to coalition leadership. The event blends nationalist myth-making—evoking fantasy lore from The Neverending Story—with pop-up ice rinks and “patriot radio.” Organisers tout Italy’s global assertiveness—US, Africa, India ties—while domestic strains—stagnant wages, hidden budget cuts, soaring poverty and emigration, regional vote slippage and a divisive judicial reforms agenda—threaten Meloni’s ascendancy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the new space race: humanity risks exporting its old politics to the moon | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Over the holiday period, the Guardian leader column is looking ahead at the themes of 2026. Today we look skyward, where a new lunar contest mirrors humanity’s struggle to live within planetary limits
articles.summary: Editorial warns a revived lunar space race from 2026 mirrors Cold War rivalries as the US backs private-led Artemis II and the Artemis Accords, while China, Russia and Global South partners form the International Lunar Research Station. Both camps vie for the moon’s south-pole “peaks of eternal light” and ice deposits, exploiting loopholes in the 1967 Outer Space Treaty. Tech moguls and governments fund nuclear-fission reactors for permanent bases and orbital data centres to bypass Earth’s ecological limits. The race risks exporting terrestrial politics and ownership models to off-world frontiers unless sustainable governance precedes expansion.

articles.title: US strikes on IS targets in Nigeria may only fan the flames of insurgent violence | Onyedikachi Madueke
articles.trailText: The public is looking for relief from terrorism and violence. But Donald Trump’s words bolster narratives of foreign ‘crusader’ aggression, says Onyedikachi Madueke, a security analyst at the University of Aberdeen
articles.summary: In response to IS violence, US airstrikes in Sokoto—endorsed by Nigeria with intel cooperation—were welcomed amid public fatigue, yet misaligned with claims of rescuing persecuted Christians. Onyedikachi Madueke warns that the Christian-genocide framing, bolstered by Trump’s 'crusader' rhetoric after redesignating Nigeria a 'country of particular concern', could fuel extremist propaganda. Precision strikes without civilian casualties offer tactical gains but long-term peace demands tackling inequality, climate stress and weak governance to starve jihadist recruitment.

articles.title: On these in-between days I’m ‘growing down’, sinking into the present moment and savouring small delights | Nadine Levy
articles.trailText: My centre of gravity has shifted. The holidays are no longer something to construct but something to receive
articles.summary: Nadine Levy reflects on the first holidays since her mother’s death last year and her postpartum grief, describing a shift into ‘growing down’—rooting into the present and finding spaciousness amid impermanence. Influenced by Buddhist teachers, she moves from frantic holiday curation to receptive awareness, savouring sensory moments—Turkish coffee in her mother’s kitchen, morning quiet, her children’s delight. Rejecting extremes of indulgence or austerity, she embraces small, freely given gifts in everyday life. Levy acknowledges that not all can pause amid caring burdens or stress, yet presence itself can hold both suffering and sublime joy.

articles.title: Through the lens of history, Trump's legacy will be more of a blotch than a Maga masterpiece | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: Take this hopeful thought into 2026: the tyrants we endure always falter, and their ‘seismic’ upheavals are usually false dawns, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall argues that most historic upheavals—Berlin Wall’s fall, Arab Spring, 9/11—prove false dawns and that genuine world-changing leaders are rare. He sees Trump’s era as a brief, disruptive aberration: his achievements are scant, his populist MAGA coalition fracturing, and his long-term imprint limited. Rather than tectonic shifts, 2026 should emphasize geopolitical continuities—democracy’s resilience, international law, cultural bonds, scholarly progress and the likelihood that authoritarian rulers like Putin or Xi will eventually yield to successors.

articles.title: Need cheering up after a terrible year? I may have just the story you’re looking for | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: A single act of kindness reminded me that, despite so much evidence to the contrary, the better angels of our nature are not necessarily doomed, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Martin Kettle recounts losing his wallet on a train and having it returned intact by a stranger named Natalya, echoing a similar bus-driver find. He uses these anecdotes to critique reflexive collective pessimism fueled by media focus on crises, arguing our social and moral norms are more resilient than assumed. By highlighting positive personal experiences—from recovered wallets to good NHS encounters—he urges us to recognise and nurture society’s ‘better angels.’

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Faux Cyrillic is a load of old crдp | Viv Groskop
articles.trailText: To the designers of film posters, I suppose it looks cleverly exotic – but there are 250 million readers of Cyrillic globally, and its misuse grinds our gears, says comedian and author Viv Groskop
articles.summary: Viv Groskop criticizes the rampant misuse of Cyrillic letters in film posters and branding—STДLIN for STALIN, ВOРДT for Borat—arguing it’s not clever exotica but lazy ‘mimicry typeface’ that alienates 250 million Cyrillic readers. She links the trend to Hollywood’s cheap thrill of othering and notes Reddit users decrying its bad design and latent racism. Groskop parallels faux Cyrillic with gratuitous umlauts in heavy metal (Blue Öyster Cult, Mötley Crüe, Motörhead), both deployed to signal in-group identity and menace. Ultimately, she calls these typographical gags silly, exclusionary and disrespectful to real alphabets.

articles.title: Trump is shamelessly covering America in his name | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: Using the presidency as a branding opportunity, Trump is slapping his name on buildings, monuments and projects
articles.summary: Mohamad Bazzi warns that in his second term Trump has turned the presidency into a personal branding spree: he purged and renamed the Kennedy Center after himself, rebranded the US Institute of Peace, launched TrumpRx.gov and “Trump accounts,” drafted $1-coin designs bearing his image, made his birthday a free-entry national parks day, and has unveiled plans for multimillion-dollar “Trump-class” USS Defiant warships. This unprecedented self-aggrandizement parallels historic authoritarian vanity projects, undermines democratic norms separating office from ego, and risks strategic and financial waste on mere name-slapping.

articles.title: The year in patriarchy: Taylor Swift, Trump 2.0 and the Epstein files | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The year 2025 saw a Swift engagement, a rapid rollback of rights and a slow release of the heavily redacted Epstein files
articles.summary: 2025 saw an all-female Blue Origin flight, the war in Ukraine drawing female volunteers, sexual violence in Sudan and Gaza’s stalled ceasefire amid famine. In the US Trump’s return triggered the reinstated Global Gag Rule, contraception wastage, attacks on birth control and abortion, and threats to voting rights. Italy criminalized femicide; France enshrined consent in rape law; Japan’s first female PM Sanae Takaichi appointed only two women; Thailand and Liechtenstein legalized same-sex marriage. A heavily redacted tranche of Epstein files was finally released. Prince Andrew lost his titles; Sean “Diddy” Combs was jailed for prostitution charges; Meta censored global abortion and queer content.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Online shops, please I beg – stop with endless post-purchase emails | Athena Kugblenu
articles.trailText: You really want me to review my buy? Yes, it was fine. But that is where I would like our relationship to end, says comedian Athena Kugblenu
articles.summary: Athena Kugblenu rails against post-purchase email overload from online shops, insisting she only wants two messages: one confirming her order and another announcing delivery. She likens incessant marketing nudges—browse prompts, “21 people have this in their basket” alerts, checkout pleas, third-party cashback offers and relentless review requests—to harassing in-store assistants, intrusive bus announcements and even mirror etchings. They waste time, not reassure. After joking that she won’t review a shower gel made by a multinational conglomerate, the comedian implores retailers simply to leave customers alone once the transaction is complete.

articles.title: A conversation between Joe Rogan and Mel Gibson summed up 2025 for me – and not in a good way | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: From merrily dismissing climate science, to promoting irresponsible health claims, the podcast was an unintentional warning for our times, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: George Monbiot argues that an early-2025 Joe Rogan podcast with Mel Gibson—who dismissed climate science even as his $14 million California home burned in a wildfire worsened by human-driven heating—encapsulates the year’s trends. They attacked evolution, the scientific method, Governor Newsom’s fire-prevention spending and Anthony Fauci, peddled medical misinformation and conspiracy theories about censorship. Their wealthy detachment, denial amid disaster and embrace of polarizing falsehoods exemplify a broader climate of irresponsibility, where the powerful evade consequences and ordinary people suffer.

articles.title: 2025: a year in political cartoons – from a Bond-villain Trump to a toppled prince | Martin Rowson, Ella Baron, Nicola Jennings and Ben Jennings
articles.trailText: Our cartoonists look back at a year of covering tragedy, farce and everything in between – and having to draw far too many Donald Trumps
articles.summary: Four cartoonists reflect on 2025’s political farce and tragedy: Ella Baron spotlights Prince Andrew’s fall and finds hope in a fragile Gaza ceasefire and Zohran Mamdani’s New York win; Martin Rowson laments an invisible government and the wasted comic potential of figures like Pat McFadden; Nicola Jennings caricatures Trump and Putin to expose their power and motivations, while confessing the toll of drawing them; Ben Jennings recalls a year of déjà-vu horrors—from Gaza and Ukraine to Farage’s resurgence and “Trump 2.0H-NO”—underscoring cartoons’ power to distill chaos into dark humour.

articles.title: The Guardian view on adapting to the climate crisis: it demands political honesty about extreme weather | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Over the holiday period, the Guardian leader column is looking ahead at the themes of 2026. Today we look at how the struggle to adapt to a dangerously warming world has become a test of global justice
articles.summary: Attribution science shows extreme weather—like Hurricane Melissa’s 252 mph winds and record heatwaves in Europe—are far more likely due to warming, yet global adaptation funding and action fall short. COP30 tripled annual adaptation pledges to $120 bn by 2035 but delayed payments, leaving vulnerable, indebted nations without relief. The Guardian urges political honesty: governments must lead state-funded flood defences, resilient infrastructure and climate-proof housing, elevate national adaptation plans alongside emissions cuts, and ensure justice for communities hit by floods, droughts and storms.

articles.title: Our dog’s affections remain a sweet mystery even as Odie turns five today | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: Dog and human finding companionship is understandable – what baffles us is why Odie seeks out our eldest son’s bed even when he’s not home
articles.summary: On Odie’s fifth birthday, the Srivastava family puzzles over their cavoodle’s shifting affections. Initially bonded with their mum during her sabbatical—she fed, walked and studied with him—he later favored his sister until her door was firmly closed, then migrated to their university-aged brother’s spacious bed. Even when that son is away, Odie curls into his sheets, craving gentle company. The youngest sibling, despite regular walks and treats, rarely earns his bed and often pleads for equal affection. On reflection, Ranjana Srivastava marvels at the sweet mystery of a dog’s unpredictable loyalties.

articles.title: In Gaza we’re trapped in an endless maze of waiting – for peace, for the deaths to stop and for our lives to begin again | Aya Al-Hattab
articles.trailText: A ceasefire was announced on 10 October. But despite ‘peace’ being on the lips of world leaders ever since, we Palestinians are still under siege and afraid, says Palestinian writer Aya Al-Hattab
articles.summary: In Gaza, Palestinians remain under siege despite a declared ceasefire on Oct 10; more than 360 killed since, including 70 children. Aya Al-Hattab describes daily life beset by fear of explosions, lack of water, electricity, internet, destroyed homes teetering on collapse and flooding in winter tents. She details an invisible “yellow line” dividing Gaza, patrolled by explosive devices, trapping families. While world leaders debate post-war plans that exclude Gazans, residents wait indefinitely for peace, security and the chance to reunite with loved ones, clinging to hope amid rubble.

articles.title: Fat, fearless and over 50. Thanks to my TikTok outfit posts, I feel powerful and seen | Jen Walshaw
articles.trailText: After a debilitating illness, they’ve given me a reason to get out of bed – and I now have TikTokers who love me back, says founder of muminthemadhouse.com, Jen Walshaw
articles.summary: After a hospital stay and feeding tube, Jen Walshaw, founder of muminthemadhouse.com, began posting TikTok OOTDs to force herself to get dressed and reconnect. Her bio—"fat, flat, over 50 and with a feeding tube"—reclaims descriptors often absent in fashion. She champions sweater vests, bold colors, textures and "granny chic," spotlighting overlooked bodies. With nearly 4,500 followers, her supportive community counters trolls and restores her faith online. Highlighting that women over 50 control 27% of consumer spending, Walshaw advocates visibility for real bodies, urging others to wear what feels good and embrace everyday style.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Washing-up bowls are horrible and should be banned | Jason Hazeley
articles.trailText: These unhygienic, offensive lumps of plastic do everything the sink does, and less. It’s time to get rid, says comedy writer Jason Hazeley
articles.summary: Comedy writer Jason Hazeley rails against the plastic washing-up bowl, arguing it’s a pointless ‘box within a box’ that does everything a sink does – and worse. He mocks its lack of drainage, its grime-trapping grooves, its plastic ‘beards’ and environmental legacy as landfill fodder. He dismisses claims it saves water, noting that conscious sink use could achieve the same. Framing the bowl as an absurd, unhygienic relic on par with toilet-seat covers and air fresheners, Hazeley calls for its outright ban.

articles.title: Our king, priest and feudal lord – how AI is taking us back to the dark ages | Joseph de Weck
articles.trailText: Since the Enlightenment, we’ve been making our own decisions. But now AI may be about to change that, says Joseph de Weck, a fellow with the Foreign Policy Research Institute
articles.summary: Joseph de Weck warns that AI risks reversing the Enlightenment by supplanting human judgment with machine authority. Drawing on Kant’s notion of maturity (“Sapere aude!”) and a new MIT study showing lowered cognitive engagement when relying on AI, he argues that abdicating critical thinking to opaque algorithms parallels past subordination to kings or priests. While AI boosts efficiency, its “black box” logic fosters faith over reason. The challenge: leverage AI��s power without surrendering the human reasoning that underpins freedom and democracy.

articles.title: There’s an itsy-bitsy fear I want to overcome. I will never be a fan, but can I at least be Normal about spiders? | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: In order to be less scared, I imagine the huge Australian huntsman as a girlie, just chilling and listening to us yap. It sounds dumb, but it worked (a little bit)
articles.summary: Guardian Australia columnist Rebecca Shaw chronicles her lifelong arachnophobia focused on Australia’s large huntsman spiders, recalling childhood spray-gun panics and fleeing encounters. Now determined to be merely “normal” rather than terrified, she personifies a frequent window-frame visitor as a calm female companion, rehearses rational truths—harmless to humans and voracious mosquito predators—and practices stillness, controlled breathing and positive reframing. Though she doubts ever catching one in a Tupperware, her small victories affirm that even deep-seated fears can be retrained.

articles.title: My five-year-old daughter is learning to love cricket. It’s a source of delight in a difficult summer | Kate Lyons
articles.trailText: Watching the Ashes has felt like a small bright spot. Something to cheer about when our hearts are broken
articles.summary: Kate Lyons recounts her five-year-old daughter’s newfound fascination with cricket during the Ashes, as they rename 'overs' as 'turns', 'runs' as 'points' and distill rules like lbw, variable durations and scoring. The child’s perceptive questions—about Nathan Lyon’s mood swings, Ben Stokes’s painful groin hit, and the absence of female commentators—highlight both cricket’s weirdness and gender imbalance. In a summer scarred by the Bondi attack and personal bereavement, this budding love offers a precious, normalizing bright spot.

articles.title: The Guardian view on May 2026 elections: a new political geography is coming into view across Britain | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Over the holiday period, the Guardian leader column is looking ahead at the themes of 2026. Today we look at the impact of devolution on growing volatility of party political allegiance
articles.summary: The May 2026 local, Scottish and Welsh elections will pivotally reshape UK politics: devolution-driven volatility threatens Labour’s Welsh hegemony—Plaid Cymru and Reform UK poised to unseat them—and secures an SNP majority in Holyrood. In England, both Labour and the Conservatives risk losing councillors as Liberal Democrats, Reform UK and Greens surge. This reflects a long-standing fragmentation of party loyalties under asymmetric devolution. England’s patchwork of combined authorities and directly elected mayors, coupled with a stalled devolution and community empowerment bill hampered by Treasury reluctance, amplifies centrifugal forces. The historic Westminster duopoly is in chronic decline, yielding a new political geography across Britain.

articles.title: How the French fell in love with family-driven memoirs  and autofiction | Anne-Laure Pineau
articles.trailText: Matriarchs, absent fathers and troubled childhoods: 2025 was the year French literature focused on family, says writer Anne-Laure Pineau
articles.summary: In 2025 French literary output saw 484 new novels centered on family-driven memoirs and autofiction, blurring boundaries between fiction and nonfiction. Triggered by Annie Ernaux’s 2022 Nobel, bookstores created a dedicated feminist-memoir/autofiction section showcasing works by Édouard Louis, Christine Angot, Alice Coffin and Adèle Yon. High-profile novels by Amélie Nothomb, Emmanuel Carrère, Raphaël Enthoven, Matthieu Niango, Anne Berest and Anthony Passeron probed maternal and paternal legacies. Laurent Mauvignier’s Goncourt-winning La Maison vide epitomized the trend. Tracing its roots to Proust and Doubrovsky’s 1977 coinage, this movement reflects a collective urge to reclaim ancestral narratives in a post-truth era.

articles.title: Did 2025 mark the end of British parliamentary democracy as we know it? | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: The conventions and rituals that define the way we do politics rapidly eroded this year – setting the UK on a course into the unknown, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Andy Beckett argues that 2025 saw a rupture in Britain’s century-old parliamentary conventions: Labour–Tory duopoly, predictable pendulum swings and Westminster’s centrality have frayed. Reform UK’s Commons-side boycott and the spread of online fictions reflect historic low trust. Polls show near-even splits between a progressive bloc (Labour, Lib Dems, Greens, SNP, Plaid) and a right-wing alliance (Tories, Reform UK), raising the spectre of multi-party polarization under first-past-the-post, which could distort seats and legitimacy. While some envisage coalitions or PR reform, entrenched traditions and voter volatility—amid cost-of-living pressures and Farage’s unpredictability—mean the late 2020s may bring deeper instability or a reversion to familiar politics.

articles.title: Wild animals are great gift givers – and there’s one present in particular I’d love to receive for Christmas | Helen Pilcher
articles.trailText: Penguins hand over pebbles; scorpionflies give spitballs. But I’m hankering after a sea sponge presented by a dolphin, says science writer Helen Pilcher
articles.summary: Science writer Helen Pilcher argues that gifting predates humans by millions of years and animals have honed gift-giving across five categories—food, home, bling, skincare, and clothing. Brazilian cuckoos offer high-protein prey, great grey shrikes impale “kebab” snacks, scorpionflies present nutrient-rich spitballs to woo mates, Adélie penguins gift pebbles to build nests, and corvids deliver shiny trinkets. In Western Australia, male dolphins harvest sea sponges as protective “hats” and serenade females before gifting—combining skincare and clothing. Pilcher’s Christmas wish? To receive such a stylish, sustainable sponge-hat serenade from a dolphin.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Fruit with meat? What kind of pervert are you? | Katy Guest
articles.trailText: Please don’t ever offer me cranberry sauce with my roast turkey – that’s just jam on your Christmas dinner, and who wants that, asks Guardian Opinion deputy editor Katy Guest
articles.summary: Guardian Opinion deputy editor Katy Guest, a self-declared pedant who has already died on many hills, now bravely dies on the hill that fruit and meat must never meet on a plate. She brands cranberry sauce with turkey as jam on dinner and extends her ban to pork with apple sauce, lamb with redcurrants, mango chutney on curry, duck à l’orange, ham and pineapple pizza or Coronation chicken raisins. Fruit belongs on its own—crumble, banana or berries for pudding or breakfast—while meat deserves gravy, mustard or coleslaw. Tomato ketchup on burgers is fine because tomatoes count as vegetables. This culinary crusade is her immutable ��hill to die on.’

articles.title: This Christmas, peace won’t come from the politics of envy. It will come only by building a more equal Australia | Brad Chilcott
articles.trailText: Wealth is shifting upwards, basic universal services are outsourced and improving the lives of the Australians doing it toughest is being ignored. So where can we find hope?
articles.summary: Brad Chilcott argues that Christmas peace in Australia requires tackling entrenched inequality and social exclusion instead of scapegoating migrants or stoking envy politics. He observes that wealth increasingly flows to shareholders as disability, aged and health care and not-for-profits are outsourced or corporatized, leaving many Australians facing insecure housing, low pay and rising living costs. While hate speech laws and anti-racism campaigns are vital, Chilcott insists structural economic reform is essential to prevent disaffection and extremism. He highlights interfaith solidarity events like Melbourne’s Pillars of Light and Sikh charity initiatives—models of “goodwill to all” and blueprints for a more equitable, inclusive nation.

articles.title: When my father first came to the UK, people bonded and looked after him. Would that happen now? | Nell Frizzell
articles.trailText: I’ve taken in refugees from time to time, and formed lasting ties with them. It’s time to stop demonising those in need, says journalist and author Nell Frizzell
articles.summary: Nell Frizzell recalls her father’s first Christmas in the UK 43 years ago, when warm community support rescued him from culinary peril and made him feel at home. She contrasts that generosity with today’s harsh asylum policies—from seizing refugees’ jewelry and two-decade citizenship bans to barring paid work—championed by the home secretary. Frizzell has hosted Sudanese and Afghan asylum seekers via Refugees at Home, offering her house, meals, friendship and lasting bonds. She highlights how sharing shelter, laundry, a meal and kindness fosters belonging and calls to end refugee demonization, pledging to welcome new guests when her baby grows.

articles.title: A key question for every believer: does God approve of Santa Claus? I hope so, or I’m in trouble | Ravi Holy
articles.trailText: The great Santa deception arguably breaches the ninth commandment (‘Thou shalt not bear false witness’), but I think God would cut us some slack, says vicar Ravi Holy
articles.summary: Vicar Ravi Holy explores whether Santa’s deception conflicts with the ninth commandment forbidding false witness. He recalls a fellow priest’s apology for telling Year 6 children the truth, his own son’s heartbreak when his twin exposed Santa, and the enduring wonder of childhood faith. Dressing as Father Christmas at a school grotto, he experienced a profound sense of unconditional love akin to a religious moment, affirming that God would endorse such joy and hope. He notes Santa’s male-centric spotlight, contrasts Jesus’s servant humility, and affirms Christmas magic as holy.

articles.title: No bickering around the Christmas tree! If your family are trapped by their algorithms, here’s the way out | Dr Kaitlyn Regehr
articles.trailText: My research on social media shows high levels of misinformation and disconnect. Here’s how to talk to kith and kin this week without tears and tantrums, says academic Dr Kaitlyn Regehr
articles.summary: Dr Kaitlyn Regehr advises holiday families fatigued by political bickering to shift focus from debating divisive opinions to exposing the algorithmic processes that shape our ‘filter bubbles’ and echo chambers. She explains how social platforms monetize attention, amplifying sensational misinformation while narrowing our media diets. Instead of challenging relatives on specific issues, families can discuss the economics of the attention economy, recognize personal you-loops, and compare diverse information sources. Regehr’s practical tips include having proactive short conversations about big-picture structures, encouraging critical thinking by explaining how algorithms work, and fostering positive examples to inspire agency. By understanding these dynamics together, they can game algorithms to reclaim control over content.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Being late can be the height of good manners and decorum, actually | Rachel Connolly
articles.trailText: Instead of seeing etiquette as a set of categorical rules, we should recognise that poor form can actually have good consequences, says writer Rachel Connolly
articles.summary: Rachel Connolly argues that, contrary to rigid etiquette rules, strategic lateness can be the pinnacle of courtesy: arriving ten to thirty minutes late to spare an anxious novice host culinary mishaps; giving a smitten date time to compose themselves; letting a busy new mother reclaim rare moments alone; nudging rule-bound cinema companions to loosen up; preventing over-eager airport departures; softening the blow of a breakup; and allowing extra goodbyes at pet rehoming. Good manners, she insists, hinge on understanding each person’s true needs.

articles.title: Labour is living in a fool’s paradise if it thinks it has plenty of time to turn Britain around | Larry Elliott
articles.trailText: Going into 2026, the economy has little forward momentum and things may get worse before they get better, says Guardian columnist Larry Elliott
articles.summary: Labour’s support has plunged from 34% to 18% since the 2024 election, reflecting unprecedented midterm unpopularity despite mediocre economic conditions. Growth has slowed, unemployment risen to 5.1%, yet wages outpace inflation and living standards are rising. Historically, Attlee (1947), Callaghan (1975) and Brown (2010) endured deeper slumps with less voter backlash. Starmer is the most unpopular PM on record. Contributing factors include flatlined incomes over 15 years, exposed policy gaps, slow Bank of England rate cuts and a rise in employers’ national insurance. Consumer spending and business confidence are weak, risking a shallow recession that could be politically fatal.

articles.title: Bari Weiss yanking a 60 Minutes story is censorship by oligarchy | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: Weiss ought to cut her losses, green-light the piece, and try to start acting like an editor – not like a cog in the machine of authoritarian politics and oligarchy
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Margaret Sullivan accuses CBS News editor in chief Bari Weiss of censoring a pre-reviewed 60 Minutes investigative segment on brutal conditions in an El Salvador prison housing Venezuelan migrants stripped of due process. Despite fact-checks, legal clearance and elevated promotion, Weiss halted the broadcast under pressure from powerful interests—ultimately linked to CBS parent Paramount owner Larry Ellison and the Trump administration’s regulatory sway. Sullivan argues this ‘censorship by oligarchy’ betrays journalism’s duty to ‘afflict the comfortable,’ urging Weiss to release the story and prioritize editorial integrity.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the festive season: a suffering world needs messages of peace, hope and goodwill | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The fracturing multilateral order has led to a new age of insecurity. But acts of courage and solidarity can point the way to a better future
articles.summary: In its festive editorial, the Guardian warns that a fracturing multilateral order and rising conflicts—the highest state-based wars since 1946—plus the fourth anniversary of Russia’s Ukraine invasion, ongoing crises in Gaza and Sudan, and terror attacks in Bondi and Manchester have fueled global insecurity and antisemitism. Yet acts of solidarity—from individuals confronting attackers, volunteers sustaining community kitchens, and the resilience of Ukrainians—demonstrate hopeful ‘in-spite-of’ courage. Echoing theologian Paul Tillich, the piece holds that collective love and hope, exemplified by the Festival of Nine Lessons and Carols at King’s College, are vital antidotes to modern darkness.

articles.title: The Guardian view on animal welfare: a timely reminder that cruelty is wrong | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: New protections for hares, and more humane conditions on farms, should be welcomed by all
articles.summary: Guardian editorial applauds England’s new animal welfare strategy, covering wildlife protection (close season for hares), farm animal reforms (phasing out cages for hens, farrowing crates for pigs, new fish slaughter rules), bans on snares and trail hunting, and pet safeguards (tenant pet rights, breeder registration). It acknowledges farmer impacts (with trade policy safeguards) and enforcement hurdles (inspection capacity). The approach centres on recognising sentience, defers tougher debates on meat consumption, emissions and wildlife disturbance, and awaits lengthy consultations, urging ministers to match other UK nations’ progress.

articles.title: Now that phones alter our photos without us knowing, how do we know what’s real? | Isabel Brooks
articles.trailText: Comparing the pictures taken with my camera’s automatic software to those taken with a ‘zero-processing’ app, the results are shocking. Is this a good idea, asks writer Isabel Brooks
articles.summary: Freelancer Isabel Brooks discovers that virtually every smartphone applies unseen, ML-driven auto-processing—boosting contrast, sharpening edges and flattering faces—by comparing default shots with a “zero-processing” app’s raw output. The unedited images appear muted and grainy, while phones produce vivid, crisp photos tailored by consumer-insight teams aiming to maximize quick, non-blurry, beauty-enhanced snaps. Brooks questions the authenticity and creative expression lost when tech firms, not photographers, decide our image aesthetics. Drawing on analog film and family prints, she argues that embedded auto-enhancements narrow our visual narrative and raise concerns about trust in the reality of the pictures we share.

articles.title: Is Susie Wiles an innocent bystander in Trump’s White House? | Sidney Blumenthal
articles.trailText: As chief of staff, she has stifled her temptation to intervene time and time again
articles.summary: Susie Wiles, Trump’s 2024 campaign manager and White House chief of staff, views the president through her experience as a daughter of an alcoholic, labeling him as possessing a “megalomaniacal alcoholic personality.” In eleven interviews for Vanity Fair, she depicts senior aides—JD Vance, Russell Vought, Elon Musk, RFK Jr. and Stephen Miller—as pathological extremists while portraying herself as a hesitant enabler, momentarily resisting Trump’s impulses on pardons, mass deportations and agency purges but ultimately yielding. Her on-the-record discussion of Epstein files risks waiving privilege and exposing her to subpoenas, underscoring her learned helplessness amid White House chaos.

articles.title: Crunch time: are freeze-dried fruit and veg actually healthy to eat or just chips in a different form? | Antiviral
articles.trailText: This food preservation method is being promoted as a nutrition powerhouse, but it shouldn’t be treated as a direct substitute for fresh produce
articles.summary: Freeze-dried fruit and veg use rapid freezing and vacuum to remove water, preserving most vitamins, antioxidants and structure with minimal volume loss. Experts say nutrient retention rivals fresh produce and exceeds dehydration or canning, though flavoured chips often add oil, salt or sugar and differ nutritionally. The crunchy light texture can deceive portion size: higher sugar and energy per volume means moderation is key, along with increased hydration and dental care. While more expensive and not a full fresh produce replacement, they offer a convenient, shelf-stable way to boost fruit and vegetable intake. Overall, they have their place in a varied, healthful diet but should be enjoyed as part of a balanced approach.

articles.title: Bad blood between the Beckhams at Christmas might seem trite. But here’s why it’s important | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: It’s celebrity catnip, but beyond the headlines this is also a tale of family dysfunction. At this time of year, so many people know about that, says Guardian Opinion assistant editor Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: Guardian Opinion examines the Beckham family’s Christmas rift, spotlighting Brooklyn’s estrangement after his wife Nicola Peltz spurned Victoria’s dress and family events—from David’s knighthood to Victoria’s documentary. With Brooklyn blocking his parents on Instagram and choosing the Peltz home this Christmas, the saga amplifies the pain of in-law tensions, public feuds and social media spectacle. Journalist Jason Okundaye reflects on how seasonal gatherings can magnify private ruptures, drawing parallels to his own loss and wider Christmas melancholy. Beneath celeb gossip, it’s a human story of broken bonds, regret and the desire for reunion.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: Ignore the haters, TK Maxx is actually quite good | Hannah J Davies
articles.trailText: The chaos is undeniable, but where else are you going to get a pair of jeans and a pistachio-cream panettone cake for such a reasonable price, asks culture writer and editor Hannah J Davies
articles.summary: Culture writer Hannah J Davies pushes back against TK Maxx’s messy reputation, noting her local London branch is tidy and well-stocked. She highlights snagging Good American jeans, homewares and a £8.99 pistachio cream panettone at half the usual price, exemplifying the fun of ‘little treats’ amid rising living costs. Anecdotes about hoarder tendencies and memories of late friend Dawn Foster’s bargain beauty hauls underscore TK Maxx’s mix of quality end-of-line goods and affordable indulgences, offering budget-savvy shoppers both utility and joy.

articles.title: When the AI bubble bursts, humans will finally have their chance to take back control | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: The US economy is pumped up on tech-bro vanity. The inevitable correction should prompt a global conversation, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rafael Behr warns that 2025’s AI frenzy—fueled by Silicon Valley hype and $1.5 trn in bet-the-farm investments from OpenAI and Big Tech—resembles past industrial bubbles, inflating valuations while masking systemic risks. Evangelists pitch a near-term leap to general intelligence even as models hallucinate, entrench bias and threaten a synthetic pseudo-reality. US and China race for supremacy without global governance, leaving ethics to oligarchs and apparatchiks. When the bubble finally bursts, Behr argues, a critical window will open to reassert human priorities over unchecked AI ambition.

articles.title: Trump and Putin share a craving for status. That’s why they both want to destroy Europe | Henry Farrell and Sergey Radchenko
articles.trailText: Liberal democracies view Putin’s Russia as a bully – and Trump’s US as an angry drunk with a bazooka. The response is pure venom, say Henry Farrell and Sergey Radchenko of Johns Hopkins
articles.summary: Henry Farrell and Sergey Radchenko argue that both Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump are driven by a craving for status that leads them to undermine Europe’s liberal order. Russia’s war in Ukraine seeks to recover lost prestige through fear, while Trump’s hostility to multilateralism and rule-of-law reflects his wish to disrupt a hierarchy that despises him. Europe, forged by US-led postwar reconstruction and the Marshall Plan, epitomizes the liberal values Trump attacks via far-right support and denunciations of American ‘soft power’. Yet by hollowing out US global capacity and retreating from NATO, his administration lacks the means to reshape Europe beyond acting as a spoiler.

articles.title: The NSW parliament is once again rushing through anti-protest laws. Will they survive a court challenge? | Anne Twomey
articles.trailText: The legislation’s opponents will argue that it is over-inclusive and disproportionately limits free speech
articles.summary: NSW parliament has again fast-tracked new anti-protest laws allowing the police commissioner to declare any area off-limits to authorised assemblies for 14 days (extendable to 90) after a suspected terrorist incident, criminalising unauthorised protests and empowering move-on orders. Opponents point to previous 2022 climate-protest and Dural worship-site restrictions struck down as over-inclusive burdens on political communication. They will argue this law is not “reasonably appropriate and adapted”—covering potentially the entire state—and disproportionately limits free speech. Premier Chris Minns has launched an inquiry aiming to draft more targeted, constitutionally “airtight” measures on protest bans.

articles.title: Australia’s gun laws have long been the envy of the world. They must remain so, especially after Bondi | Gideon Meyerowitz-Katz
articles.trailText: As a public health expert and Jewish Australian, I urge our leaders to ensure gun legislation matches the world we live in
articles.summary: After the Bondi attack, epidemiologist Gideon Meyerowitz-Katz warns Australia’s once-envied gun laws are becoming outdated: pre-1996 reforms cut mass shootings from annual to near zero, but gun ownership has since risen and loopholes proliferated. Bondi shooters used single-shot rifles and shotguns—slower than U.S. semi-automatics but still lethal. New South Wales and federal buybacks, plus a national registry, offer reforms, but only a unified, cross-border approach can restore nationwide safety without undermining legitimate rural firearm uses.

articles.title: The Guardian view on hope: with your help, charities can help to repair the social fabric
articles.trailText: Effective challenge to the alarming rise of far-right, anti-migrant politics starts with the grassroots
articles.summary: Damaged by austerity, cost-of-living strains and disinvestment, many UK communities face disillusionment fueling far-right, anti-migrant sentiment. The Guardian’s 2025 charity appeal champions six grassroots partners—Locality (2,000 local groups), Back on the Map (Sunderland regeneration), Citizens UK (organiser training), Hope Unlimited Trust (pro-migrant grants), The Linking Network (bridging school divisions) and Who Is Your Neighbour? (conflict-resolution)—to rebuild civic cohesion. With councils stretched by austerity and early Labour funding reforms (eg. Pride in Place) still unfolding, over £500,000 raised so far underpins efforts to repair the social fabric.

articles.title: The Guardian view on sending letters: the writing’s on the wall
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Danish postal service has announced it will cease deliveries from 30 December after 400 years. Eventually, other countries may go down a similar route
articles.summary: Denmark will end its 400-year state postal service on 30 December, cutting 1,500 jobs and selling off red letterboxes. While private firms will still handle cards and letters, costs will rise. Observers expect other countries to follow: France is already removing postboxes, Germany’s Deutsche Post is axing roles, and UK letter volumes have dropped from 20 bn at their mid-2000s peak to 6.6 bn in 2023–24 amid stamp-price hikes. The piece warns that as digital channels dominate, the intimate, reflective art of letter writing—and its rich literary patrimony—faces extinction, even as new online forms emerge.

articles.title: Let me tell you the good things the government has done in 2025 – because it certainly won’t | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: It’s all there: more apprenticeships, more rights for workers and renters – and most of all, a focus on children. What a shame Labour wavers about saying so, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee highlights a wealth of underreported achievements by Keir Starmer’s government in 2025: prioritising children with free breakfasts, uniform subsidies, 500,000 extra free meals, nursery expansion and 1,000 family hubs; reviving arts in schools, youth centres and 250 college courses; renationalising railways, freezing fares, introducing pay-per-mile pricing; bolstering worker rights via an Employment Rights Act, 6.7% minimum wage rise and higher NI contributions from employers; freezing rents under a Renters’ Rights Act; boosting the NHS, home-building, green energy and rejoining Erasmus. Yet political communication failures leave Labour unpopular despite tangible social reforms.

articles.title: Yet again, released Epstein files raise more questions than answers | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The documents are disturbing. But they seem largely to reflect information that has already been made public
articles.summary: Trump’s DOJ under Pam Bondi released a heavily redacted, partial batch of around 13,000 Epstein-related documents—most previously public—after congressional pressure and GOP infighting. The timing (the Friday before Christmas) and selective redactions drew criticism for legal noncompliance and political self-protection. Files include disturbing images of Epstein’s abuse, evidence of early FBI inaction, redacted victim lists, and scant new material on Trump beyond photos and allegations of introducing underage victims. Abundant Clinton photos suggest a partisan pivot. The release highlights elite impunity, Trump’s hypocrisy and the enduring outrage over Epstein’s crimes.

articles.title: I thought an edible would take the edge off family Christmas. I spent the day on the floor | Bunny Banyai
articles.trailText: If there’s anything worse than children yelling in your ear as you wonder if you’ll regain the capacity to distinguish a door from a window, I haven’t experienced it
articles.summary: Freelance writer Bunny Banyai recounts her Christmas Day meltdown after consuming an edible python candy to cope with family tensions. Expecting a mild buzz, she inadvertently gobbled twice the recommended dose on an empty stomach and became disoriented, collapsing face-down on her bedroom floor for five hours. Amid whispered reassurances from her sister-in-law and bickering children, she experienced vivid hallucinations and panic. When the effects wore off as guests departed, she vowed to endure future festivities sober, forgoing edibles and alcohol.

articles.title: Trump’s shuttering of the National Center for Atmospheric Research is Stalinist | Michael Mann and Bob Ward
articles.trailText: This is the latest in the relentless purge of climate researchers who refuse to be co-opted by the fossil fuel industry
articles.summary: Michael Mann and Bob Ward liken Trump’s decision to dismantle Boulder’s National Center for Atmospheric Research to Stalinist purges of climate ‘heretics.’ Branded “climate alarmism” by OMB director Russell Vought, NCAR joins broader cuts targeting federal climate labs under a fossil-fuel–backed agenda. A DOE report penned by Trump ally Chris Wright’s team, intended to overturn EPA’s greenhouse gas endangerment finding, was debunked by 85 experts and contradicted by a National Academy of Sciences review. Job losses and budget slashes have thinned attendance at key conferences, yet the administration presses on with its “climate Lysenkoism” campaign to suppress scientific evidence and favor oil, gas and coal interests.

articles.title: The EU’s deeds as much as Putin’s words will ensure the war in Ukraine continues | Rajan Menon
articles.trailText: A €90bn loan is a lifeline for Zelenskyy. But the bloodshed won’t end while the Russian president believes he can still win, says Rajan Menon, a professor emeritus of international relations
articles.summary: Rajan Menon argues that Putin’s Dec 19 press conference confirmed his unshakable goal of annexing Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhzhia and Kherson, ensuring the war endures. Trump’s push for a year-end political settlement and Zelenskyy’s offer of neutrality in exchange for security guarantees failed to sway Moscow. Simultaneously, the EU forged a rare consensus to lend €90 billion to Ukraine—repayable only from Russian reparations—underscoring European resolve and independence from the U.S. These factors—Putin’s belief in victory and the EU lifeline—make a swift peace improbable.

articles.title: Reward countries that toe the line, punish those that don’t: that’s how Trump is exerting control in Latin America | Jordana Timerman
articles.trailText: His interference in the region has been aided by the collapse of the leftist forces that once pushed back against US imperialism, says Jordana Timerman, a journalist based in Buenos Aires
articles.summary: In 2025 Trump’s second term, the US reshaped its Latin America policy into a blunt, transactional regime: over 100 killed in maritime strikes deemed extrajudicial, threats to cut aid in Honduras’s election, meddling in Argentina’s midterms. Obedient leaders like Bukele, Milei and Noboa win funding and security cooperation while tariffs and sanctions punish dissenters. Regional bodies (Celac, Summit of the Americas) lie moribund, the pink tide has fragmented, and only Brazil’s Lula and Mexico’s Sheinbaum mount pragmatic resistance. Colombia’s Petro’s confrontations drew punitive threats, underscoring the peril of isolated opposition.

articles.title: The hill I will die on: ‘Small plates’ are fiddly and cost a fortune – ban them | Jonny Woo
articles.trailText: A saucer of pomegranate seeds and something sprinkled with petals? No thanks: just give me dinner, says actor, comedian and drag queen Jonny Woo
articles.summary: Actor, comedian and drag queen Jonny Woo, currently busy staging his punk-pastiche Un-Royal Variety show in Hackney, celebrates London’s global gastronomy but loathes the ubiquitous “small plates” trend. He bemoans overpriced, fiddly saucers of pomegranate seeds and petal-sprinkled bites, despises the enforced sharing culture and QR code menus, and argues diners end up rebuilding a full meal at double the cost. He insists restaurants revert to proper mains—though he still makes an exception for genuine Spanish tapas.

articles.title: It was lethal to be in Gaza this year, and deadly for those who tried to tell the world | Jane Martinson
articles.trailText: The Al Jazeera reporter Anas al-Sharif was the most prominent name among so many targeted for simply bearing witness to the truth, says journalist and media professor Jane Martinson
