articles.summary: In Gaza this year, Al Jazeera’s Anas al-Sharif—who documented starvation and a brief ceasefire—was targeted by Israel’s online smears accusing him of Hamas ties. In August, he and six colleagues were killed in a direct strike on a media tent beside al-Shifa hospital. Press freedom groups report 67 to 111 journalists killed in 2025, nearly half in Gaza. An international ban on foreign reporters has stifled independent coverage, while unfounded allegations spread on social media. RSF has filed ICC complaints accusing Israel of war crimes against Palestinian journalists.

articles.title: Christmas is a season for forgiveness. But is saying ‘sorry’ enough? | Fatma Aydemir
articles.trailText: In Germany, the neo-Nazi terrorist Beate Zschäpe has made a public display of her remorse – but remains silent on key aspects of her crimes, says Guardian Europe columnist Fatma Aydemir
articles.summary: In her column, Aydemir contrasts the season’s call for mercy with Germany’s unresolved NSU terror wounds. She recalls how neo-Nazi cell NSU murdered ten people in the 2000s, evading state scrutiny. Beate Zschäpe, sentenced for her role, now expresses remorse in court but still refuses to answer victims’ relatives’ key questions. Her newfound contrition—potentially boosting her standing in a neo-Nazi exit programme and influencing her minimum sentence—rings hollow without truthful disclosure. Aydemir argues that genuine forgiveness requires earning it through accountability and truth, not mere performance.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s difficult year: denial of hard choices is no longer an option | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: All the incentives in Westminster politics militate against confronting difficult issues, but a failing government may as well try honesty
articles.summary: Despite a commanding majority, Keir Starmer’s Labour has struggled to present a credible renewal agenda, fueling internal doubts and potential leadership bids after next spring’s local elections. Structural issues—stagnant wages, high living costs, self-imposed fiscal rules and zero-sum budgeting—have driven voter discontent since 2008. Last autumn’s budget deferred unavoidable tax rises, relying on stealth levies and optimistic growth forecasts that conflicted with manifesto pledges. Westminster’s “cakeism” culture, epitomized by cost-free Brexit promises, persists in dodging hard choices on social care and climate. For 2026, Labour must abandon denial, set honest priorities and clear prescriptions or risk the cycle of short-lived premierships continuing.

articles.title: The Guardian view on gene editing: breakthroughs need a new social contract | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Cutting-edge therapies exist, but the market cannot deliver them cheaply. Britain must build NHS capacity so that cures become collective goods, not expensive products
articles.summary: The Guardian argues that despite promising gene-editing therapies for rare disorders, prohibitive R&D costs and tiny patient pools deter private investment. Innovations at Great Ormond Street and Prime Medicine spotlight technical success but commercial failure without scalable manufacturing and sustainable funding. Market forces skew toward cancer and mass-market drugs, leaving bespoke cures unaffordable for the NHS. Amid geopolitical pricing pressures, the editorial calls for a new social contract: state-backed production, collective NHS funding of gene therapies like dialysis or transplants, and long-term publicly funded research. Only a universal health system with equitable access can turn gene editing from costly merchandise into common goods.

articles.title: The Trump administration is trying to legislate trans people out of existence | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: Robert F Kennedy Jr is pushing a plan to block medical treatments, the latest move against bodily autonomy
articles.summary: Judith Levine warns that the Trump administration—and now RFK Jr as HHS secretary—are mounting a full-court press to erase transgender people: RFK Jr’s proposal would bar puberty blockers, hormones and surgeries for minors and cut Medicaid funding; the FDA has branded binders and prostheses unapproved “medical devices,” threatening seizures; Congress is poised to criminalize gender-affirming care with up to 10 years behind bars; and an executive order enforces a rigid binary. Levine argues these measures won’t stop gender­-diverse people but will drive them underground and risk lives, revealing a campaign to legislate trans people out of existence.

articles.title: For Harry, Christmas magnified feelings of isolation. How could he escape the annual rollercoaster of anxiety and sadness? | Bianca Denny
articles.trailText: Through therapy, he sought to avoid comparisons with others and prioritise social connection, inclusion and kindness
articles.summary: Harry dreaded Christmas’s hyper-social expectations, rooted in childhood marital conflict, financial strain and friends’ shifting priorities, which magnified his isolation, anxiety and sadness. In therapy, he challenged idealised “Hallmark” beliefs—‘everyone loves Christmas’—and explored immediate coping options (joining friends’ gatherings, volunteering, solo activities) while acknowledging past losses. Future-focused work identified his core values—social connection, inclusion and kindness—and actionable steps: reconnecting with old friends, joining community groups and balancing socialising with rest. By reframing alone time as self-care and accepting a Christmas Eve invite, Harry eased acute distress and laid groundwork for more fulfilling holiday seasons.

articles.title: Flamboyant, furious and full of hope: CMAT is the sound of 2025 | John Harris
articles.trailText: The Irish singer-songwriter does what the best musicians do: perfectly crystallising their time while inspirationally taking a stand against it, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris hails Irish singer-songwriter CMAT’s third album Euro-Country as the definitive sound of 2025, perfectly capturing our era’s horror, cost-of-living crisis and social-media-fuelled absurdity while uplifting a plea for basic humanity. Across standout tracks—the title song on Ireland’s “ghost estates”, Iceberg on financial and emotional breakdown, Take a Sexy Picture of Me on the modern male gaze and The Jamie Oliver Petrol Station on misdirected rage—29-year-old Ciara Mary-Alice Thompson fuses personal heartbreak with socio-economic critique. Her flamboyant live shows, including a career-defining Glastonbury set, combine dizzying entertainment with defiant hope and resistance to capitalism’s alienation.

articles.title: It’s Nutcracker season for the lucky few – but why isn’t dance part of every child’s life? | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: After years of cuts to arts funding, there are signs that the government is serious about boosting creative subjects in schools. It can’t happen soon enough, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Cosslett’s essay laments that dance, natural to children, is sidelined by years of arts cuts and a 2023 Ofsted finding two-thirds of schools fail to teach dance adequately. She contrasts this with initiatives such as Let’s All Dance (relaxed shows, £10 tickets), The Place (4,000 Camden pupils, playground tours), DanceEast’s Digital Primaries livestreams, and Cheshire Dance cross-curricular projects that boost access for deprived children. Although DfE bursaries for 10–18-year-olds at 10 National Training Centres persist, outreach grants have shrunk. She welcomes the November 2025 curriculum report’s framing of dance as a “creative discipline” involving choreography and performance, offering hope under Labour.

articles.title: China has set a bear trap for Keir Starmer – and our naive PM is walking straight into it | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The conviction of Jimmy Lai in Hong Kong is another hostile act. How can Britain ignore Beijing’s provocations and human rights abuses, asks Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Beijing’s conviction of pro-democracy publisher and British citizen Jimmy Lai on politically motivated charges underscores the CCP’s contempt for human rights and UK protests. Simon Tisdall warns Keir Starmer that his planned January trade-focused visit to Beijing risks playing into a 'bear trap', given China’s intertwined security, economic and political agenda—espionage, cyberattacks, rights abuses in Hong Kong, Xinjiang and Tibet, and aggressive trade practices. The UK’s indecision weakens sovereignty. Tisdall argues Labour should pivot towards Europe, demand Lai’s release as a precondition for talks, and recognize that business with China carries unavoidable national security costs.

articles.title: I’m a Grinch and my husband is like Buddy the Elf – here is how we found a Christmas compromise | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Over our marriage, seasonal rows have focussed on cheese, tinsel, turkey, Aled Jones and even pyjamas. Still, I’m convinced that I am the true spirit of the festive season, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: In this comic personal essay, Polly Hudson—married 15 years to perpetually upbeat Nick—explores their annual Christmas turf war. He’s a Buddy the Elf–style holiday fanatic; she’s a self-styled Grinch who’d prefer Leap Day-style Quadrennial Christmases. Their skirmishes range over tree timing, tinsel, flashing lights, turkey vs oven-friendly alternatives, cheese, matching pyjamas, Aled Jones vs Wizzard tunes, stockings, vacuuming, the King’s speech and mince pies. She even plans a tongue-in-cheek Advent calendar chronicling each day’s quarrel, then wonders if her eye-rolling actually fuels his yuletide zeal or if they can forge a true compromise.

articles.title: Bondi beach’s golden light can never be extinguished. It has always returned from its darkest days | Brigid Delaney
articles.trailText: Bondi has long been a stage for some of Australia’s best – and worst – moments. As it continues to reel from the Hanukah mass shooting, it’ll always be a place for everyone
articles.summary: Brigid Delaney reflects on Bondi Beach’s enduring resilience and inclusive spirit after the Hanukkah mass shooting. She evokes Bondi’s magnetism – its shifting golden light, glistening surf and status as Sydney’s cultural and spiritual gateway. Diverse crowds mingle: tourists, surfers, models, Orthodox Jews and dawn swimmers, united by a judgment-free atmosphere. Bondi’s deep history – from ancient Indigenous middens to past tragedies (the 1997 Roni Levi standoff, gay hate murders, the Covid lockdown’s emptiness) – underscores its capacity to recover. As politics and grief unfold, Bondi’s golden glow, she argues, always returns.

articles.title: Has feminism failed women? CBS wants to know | Arwa Madhawi
articles.trailText: Bari Weiss is touting a new debate series at the network as the billionaire Ellisons’ media power grows
articles.summary: CBS News and Bari Weiss’s startup, the Free Press (acquired by Paramount’s Ellison family for $150m), will debut ‘Things That Matter’ in 2026—a Bank of America–sponsored debate series tackling questions like “Has feminism failed women?” and “Does America need God?”. Marketed as bridging America, its pro-Trump billionaire backers, Weiss’s anti-woke, pro-Israel agenda and guests (Erika Kirk, JD Vance, Ross Douthat) reveal a strategic right-wing media play for influence over U.S. news. Following a poorly rated Erika Kirk town hall, the series underscores the Ellisons' broader bid to concentrate media power alongside moves like licensing TikTok’s algorithm with Oracle.

articles.title: The tug-of-war over CNN shows how dysfunctional US media has become | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: The network’s fate has become a battle of corporate ownership, not a question of what benefits Americans
articles.summary: Margaret Sullivan argues CNN’s fate has become a corporate tug-of-war over Warner Bros Discovery, with Netflix and Paramount Skydance battling for control—a contest driven by profitability, not public interest. Victor Pickard and Timothy Wu decry the anti-democratic impact of media consolidation, urging antitrust action and policy reforms—strengthening independent and local journalism, bolstering public media and capping market concentration. Donald Trump, hostile to CNN, favors bidders with conservative ties. The complex takeover saga underscores deep structural flaws in U.S. media policy and the urgent need for legislative remedies.

articles.title: Each year, word of the year gets darker. ‘Six-seven’ may be annoying – but it’s bucked that trend | Coco Khan
articles.trailText: Some might regard this slang as ‘brain rot’, but the first word of the year just for tweens and teenagers could be the most hopeful development of 2025, says writer and podcaster Coco Khan
articles.summary: Coco Khan surveys the evolution of recent words of the year—‘parasocial’, ‘rage bait’, ‘slop’ and others—framing them as cultural artefacts that reflect societal anxieties, tech fads and political climates. She argues that Dictionary.com’s 2025 choice, ‘six-seven,’ stands out as the first tween/teen-focused word of the year: a random, ‘anti-humour’ slang meaning ‘so-so’ that fosters playful bonds and identity among adolescents. Unlike darker neologisms, ‘six-seven’ promises a return to benign, communal fun, marking a hopeful shift in linguistic trends.

articles.title: When it’s developers v people, usually the money wins. I saw how one community came out on top | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: A social housing victory at the ‘luxury’ Battersea power station development shows the power of grassroots politics – and holds a lesson for all of our cities, says Guardian assistant opinion editor Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: Community around Battersea power station, including London’s Patmore estate, faced displacement after a Malaysian consortium bought the derelict site in 2012. Luxury redevelopment with oligarch-style shops and sky pools stoked social cleansing fears. In 2022, Labour won Wandsworth council and, led by Aydin Dikerdem, boycotted the launch and negotiated robustly with developers. The deal secured 203 new council homes in the 17-hectare masterplan, plus 57 homes and playgrounds on Patmore. This grassroots victory asserts the value of mixed-income city communities and offers a blueprint for councils resisting profit-driven developers amid proposed cuts to affordable quotas.

articles.title: When is a sausage not really a sausage? Ask the meat lobby | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: European legislators may ban plant-based products from using the name to prevent ‘confusion’. Just don’t mention beef tomatoes or buffalo wings, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Guardian columnist George Monbiot criticises a self-contradictory EU effort to reserve terms like “sausage” and “burger” exclusively for meat products, despite centuries-old non-meat examples (Glamorgan sausage) and consumer clarity (96% of Dutch unconfused). MEPs, pressured by meat and dairy lobbyists, demand plant-based alternatives drop familiar labels, mirroring past protectionism like US margarine bans. Mince pies, cottage pie, buffalo wings and coconut milk escape scrutiny, revealing selective literalism. Monbiot warns the UK will follow EU lead, stifling plant-based market share through naming restrictions driven by industry lobbying rather than genuine consumer protection.

articles.title: At the dark end of a brutal year, I’m grateful to these heroes for showing us the light | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: From the Bondi beach rescuers to the women taking on the police, great acts of courage offer hope even in the bleakest times
articles.summary: In a year marked by global violence and repression—Sydney’s Hanukkah massacre, Ukraine’s bombardment, Sudan’s El Fasher slaughter, Gaza’s destruction—ordinary people risked death to save others or stand up to power: Ahmed al-Ahmed tackling a gunman on Bondi beach; the Gurmans’ fatal struggle; teenager Chaya shielding children; Palestinians protesting Hamas; Israeli activist Sharone Lifschitz campaigning for peace; Indiana Republicans defying Trump; the Doweys suing Meta; women confronting undercover policing; and modern anti-Nazi resistors. Their acts of courage offer hope and light amid darkness.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Palestine Action hunger strikers: the government is trying to ignore this protest | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Doctors have warned that the lives of these prisoners are now in danger. Pretending this is not happening is not good enough
articles.summary: Alarmed by the plight of Palestine Action-affiliated remand prisoners staging a hunger strike—two on day 48 without food, three over 40 days, and one diabetic inmate eating only every other day—the Guardian editorial urges ministers to end their indifference to rapidly deteriorating health. Held pretrial for alleged criminal damage, aggravated burglary, violent disorder at an Israeli arms factory and an RAF break-in—many detained over a year versus a six-month standard—the strikers demand immediate bail, restored communications and repeal of Palestine Action’s proscription. Drawing parallels with the 1981 IRA hunger strikes and condemning government inaction amid Gaza’s civilian deaths, it calls for urgent justice and remand reform.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the rise of romantic fiction: finally getting the respect it deserves
articles.trailText: Jilly Cooper, Joanna Trollope and Sophie Kinsella all changed the genre. A new generation of novelists are doing the same and sales are soaring
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial celebrates the long-overdue recognition of romantic fiction—often dismissed as “silly novels by lady novelists.” Next year’s British Book Awards will honor the genre for the first time. It marks a tribute to pioneers Jilly Cooper, Joanna Trollope and Sophie Kinsella—whose works defined subgenres from bonkbusters and “Aga sagas” to chick-lit and shopaholic stories—capturing social mores from Thatcher-era excess to noughties consumerism. Despite dated stereotypes and romanticised materialism, their wit, class awareness and escapism have driven record sales—fueled by BookTok and romantasy—and reshaped contemporary fiction.

articles.title: As a child, our family Christmas photo was an annual trauma. As a parent, I understand it now | Sean Szeps
articles.trailText: In our house, the Christmas photo still exists. But it follows a very different set of rules: keep it quick, keep it casual, and if it’s not funny … what’s the point?
articles.summary: In this reflection, writer Sean Szeps remembers the childhood stress of annual professional Christmas photos at Sears—matching red sweaters, beige backdrops, a ponytailed photographer named Gary, and his mother’s Vogue-level direction. Now a father of twins, he preserves the ritual with new rules: three quick, casual shots with reindeer antlers and marshmallow bribes, bail if moods dive, and embrace imperfections with humor (e.g., “Hot Mess Express” cards). His relaxed, playful approach honors the urge to freeze family moments while prioritizing joy over perfection and completing a cycle of generational healing.

articles.title: As Tory after Tory defects to Nigel Farage, I say this: be careful which turncoats you wish for | Simon Hart
articles.trailText: As a chief whip, I came to know a thing or two about those who flee their parties. Often they are more trouble than they are worth, says government chief whip from 2022 to 2024, Simon Hart
articles.summary: Simon Hart, ex-chief whip, warns Nigel Farage that Tory defectors to Reform UK bring more trouble than value. Drawing on cases like Shaun Woodward, Dan Poulter and Natalie Elphicke, Hart highlights how turncoats—often ideological loners seeking personal reward—betray voters, spurn party loyalty and later cause petulant backlash. Recent figures including Andrea Jenkyns, Nadine Dorries and Danny Kruger typify this opportunism. Such MPs undermine unity, expect payback and might defect again if unrewarded. Hart urges caution, noting honourable exceptions like Churchill and the 1981 SDP founders but stressing most defectors erode credibility and cohesion.

articles.title: It’s time to accept that the US supreme court is illegitimate and must be replaced | Ryan Doerfler and Samuel Moyn
articles.trailText: We need to remake the US high court so Americans don’t suffer future decades of oligarchy-facilitating rule
articles.summary: In this article, Doerfler and Moyn argue the US Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority, emboldened by Trump’s second term, has abandoned legitimacy: seizing control of federal spending, enabling racial profiling, eviscerating agency independence via the ‘shadow docket’ and targeting voting rights. Liberals’ nostalgia for institutional respect and aggressive dissents miss that the Court no longer heeds public perception. They critique liberal jurists—Jackson’s ‘fire alarm’ strategy, Kagan and Sotomayor’s cautious dissents—and reject charges of ‘nihilism’ against progressive reformers forging robust democratic alternatives. Reformers should embrace democratic renewal: expand and disempower federal courts, rethink constitutional checks, and replace the Court to prevent oligarchic rule.

articles.title: Merry Christmas, Keir Starmer: despite everything, you’re still the best man for the job | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: Rumours of the prime minister’s demise are premature. Yes, the polls look bad – but these days they reflect little more than voters’ passing whims, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins argues that rumours of Keir Starmer’s imminent demise are overblown, noting that first-past-the-post polls are unreliable when five parties each claim 15–30% support. He compares current hysteria to early scepticism of Thatcher, highlights that Labour’s 2024 majority owed more to electoral mechanics than a groundswell of support, and judges Starmer’s record as prudent rather than disastrous—citing fiscal restraint, strong G7 growth projections and Brexit softening via Erasmus. With no clear challenger and time on his side, Jenkins predicts Starmer will endure.

articles.title: Finally, Labour is finding its nerve and getting Britain’s bad Brexit deal undone | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Rejoining Erasmus should just be a first step – as the economic evidence piles up, the need for closer ties with Europe could not be clearer, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Labour is shifting decisively toward Europe, undoing Brexit damage by rejoining Erasmus+ and admitting the botched deal cost UK GDP 6–8% and up to £90 bn in lost tax revenue. Starmer, Reeves and Streeting call for deeper EU ties after exporters like Scottish lamb face checks and standoffs, while farmers warn US trade pacts could further erode standards. With 65% backing Erasmus and growing voter drift to Lib Dems and Greens, Labour seeks to reset UK trade, standards and identity squarely within Europe. Abandoning red lines on “make Brexit work” rhetoric, ministers pledge an SPS deal to ease food checks, embracing cooperation vital for growth and mobility.

articles.title: My lesson from 2025: Reform is much more vulnerable than it appears | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: The party’s astonishingly speedy growth disguised shallow roots – and its success has brought a level of scrutiny for which it simply isn’t ready, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff argues that despite Reform UK’s rapid rise under Nigel Farage, its foundations are shallow. Early rally energy masked weak policy detail; now, running 10 councils for special educational needs (Send), its “empty churches” plan faces criticism. Deputy leader Richard Tice’s apology over blaming families highlights missteps. Farage faces misconduct allegations; ex-Welsh leader Nathan Gill was jailed for Russian bribery, prompting foreign interference inquiries. As Reform’s base expands, scrutiny reveals half-baked ideas. Hinsliff also warns of looming defence challenges: NATO may face war in five years, urging resilience amid Russian aggression and US uncertainty under Trump.

articles.title: Europe has lost all credibility in the Middle East. The way to regain it lies in Syria, Iraq and Lebanon | Nathalie Tocci
articles.trailText: Sidelined by Trump, preoccupied with Ukraine and damaged by its immoral stance on Gaza, Europe can still help stabilise its eastern Mediterranean neighbours , says Guardian Europe columnist Nathalie Tocci
articles.summary: Europe’s moral authority and strategic influence in the Middle East have collapsed under its uncompromising Gaza stance and exclusion from Iran nuclear talks. Once a junior partner that shaped Oslo and brokered the JCPOA, Europe is now marginalized by a US dealing directly with Gulf states and increasingly hostile under Trump. With negligible leverage over Israeli-Palestinian or US-Iran diplomacy, it must pivot to the fragile Levant: Lebanon, Iraq and Syria face governance vacuums worsened by occupation, proxy forces and social fragility. Targeted reconstruction, institutional reform and multilateral aid could help Europe rebuild credibility and stabilize its vulnerable neighbours.

articles.title: The immediate shock and terror of the Bondi shooting is giving way to anger and division. We must look for the light | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: Some politicians have gone straight for the darkness, seeking to foment racial division. But we need community now more than ever
articles.summary: After the antisemitic mass shooting at a Bondi Hanukkah event, Australia has moved from shock and grief to anger and division. While faith leaders and first responders exemplified unity, some politicians seized the tragedy to stoke racial and immigration fears. Daley highlights calls for community, tolerance and better coordination on security and gun control, noting the tension between protecting religious minorities and safeguarding protest rights. As beachside Christmas celebrations are canceled, he argues Australians must resist cynicism, seek solidarity and uphold the light amid darkness.

articles.title: The Guardian view on reducing violence against women: ministers must follow through on a bold promise | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Labour’s delayed strategy stresses prevention. Big changes in policing and the courts are needed too
articles.summary: Labour’s delayed VAWG strategy aims to halve violence against women and girls in 10 years amid rising sexual assault rates—1.9% prevalence to March 2025, 82% female victims—and surging image-based offences. Cross-departmental plans include new “healthy relationships” education, a summit on men’s attitudes, Ofcom oversight of online harms, national domestic abuse protection orders, specialist officers and a national grooming gangs inquiry chaired by Anne Longfield. Yet lack of budget detail, women’s sector consultation and crown court backlogs threaten delivery. Ministers must reallocate resources, police and prosecute offenders, and reform family justice to fulfil their radical promise.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the EU and Ukraine: a moment of truth for Brussels and Kyiv | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The plan to mobilise Russia’s frozen assets is morally compelling and ingenious. The problem is that its enemies will never see it that way
articles.summary: The European Council faces a defining moment in Brussels over proposals to mobilise £184 bn of frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine’s war effort. The EU’s ingeniously structured loan plan—designed to avoid outright asset transfer and withstand legal challenges—has split member states, drawn US-Russian diplomatic pressure (notably Trump’s push for unfreezing), and alarmed bond markets and cost-of-living-strained voters. Its outcome will shape Ukraine’s financing, EU unity, legal precedent and Europe’s future global influence.

articles.title: Brendan Carr admits his FCC is Trump’s journalism police | Seth Stern and Clayton Weimers
articles.trailText: It is clear that the FCC is not an independent agency, but an instrument of the president’s political agenda
articles.summary: FCC chair Brendan Carr told senators that the agency serves at Trump’s pleasure, removing references to its independence while using the “public interest” standard to target critics—from CBS and 60 Minutes to Jimmy Kimmel—for content Trump dislikes. His inquiries pressured KCBS to curb political coverage, chilling journalism. GOP senators including Cruz and Rand Paul now push to repeal vague news-distortion rules. Advocates warn Carr’s approach weaponizes the FCC as Trump’s censorship arm.

articles.title: Sport, music, Scouts … it’s time to end the relentless treadmill of kids’ extracurricular activities and re-embrace civilisation | Saman Shad
articles.trailText: There are no uniforms to remember, no bags to pack, no mad dashes across suburbs at this time of year. Even dinner can be eaten while seated
articles.summary: Saman Shad describes the frantic weekly ritual of ferrying three children to basketball, music lessons, swimming, Scouts and last-minute make-up classes, turning parents into taxi drivers and managers. While acknowledging research that links structured activities to better confidence, health and social skills, she celebrates the year’s final lessons: no wet towels, no poolside emails, no mad dashes. The empty calendar brings unstructured time, family breathing space and joyful boredom. A reminder that pausing the extracurricular treadmill is itself a valuable gift.

articles.title: George Osborne has a new job in tech, and it doesn’t bode well for Britain | Chris Stokel-Walker
articles.trailText: OpenAI is the latest to make a political hire as big tech spreads its tentacles around the world. So what’s the attraction, asks author Chris Stokel-Walker
articles.summary: Former UK chancellor George Osborne will head OpenAI for Countries, tasked with integrating ChatGPT models and the Stargate datacentre network into state infrastructure. His hire, following ex-Meta global affairs VP Nick Clegg and former PM Rishi Sunak’s advisory roles at Microsoft and Anthropic, exemplifies big tech’s ambition to act as quasi-governments—negotiating “national” partnerships with about 50 countries and outspending finance, pharma and automotive lobbies combined in Europe. Stokel-Walker warns democracies risk critical infrastructure dependence and calls for default publication of AI partnership agreements and rigorous oversight of these firms as political actors.

articles.title: This Christmas, let’s ban the world’s most miserable gift-giving game | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: White elephant parties – in which people are invited to steal each other’s gifts – are the last thing we need right now
articles.summary: Humorist Dave Schilling skewers the holiday staple of white elephant gift exchanges—often called Dirty Santa or Yankee Swap—where participants bring modest $50–100 gifts to steal based on size and wrapping. Originating in the early 20th century, the game’s “white elephant” concept denotes a pricey yet useless object. Schilling recounts receiving a flimsy miniature zen garden that spilled sand across his floor, and observes hordes hunting novelty junk by checkout aisles. He argues these forced grab-and-steal rituals sour genuine festive camaraderie and calls for white elephant parties to be banned.

articles.title: Thanks for asking after my health, but actually I’m doing just fine
articles.trailText: Friends, family and assorted strangers have been sending thoughts and prayers about my ‘cancer journey’. It is, in the nicest possible way, a lot
articles.summary: Broadcaster Adrian Chiles criticises the impersonal NHS app-based communication system that turned his mild skin cancer diagnosis into unwarranted drama when media clickbait headlines prompted an outpouring of thoughts and prayers from friends, family and strangers. He recounts wrestling with embarrassment, annoyance and guilt as well-meaning messages blurred real perspective, making him question the seriousness of his own condition. Anecdotes—from a fellow supporter’s church prayers to a burger-stall cancer survivor—underscore how collective compassion can overwhelm simple reassurance. Ultimately, Chiles reflects gratefully on living in a caring world and extends Christmas goodwill.

articles.title: What’s going on with Donald Trump’s health? | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The president’s appearance and schedule have sparked speculation – perhaps fueled in part by his political fortunes
articles.summary: President Trump’s recent sallow tan, frequent nodding off, swollen ankles and bandaged right hand have sparked health concerns as 40% fewer appearances, a lighter schedule and reduced rallies mark a shift from his first term. An October MRI announced as “preventative,” plus vague cognitive test claims, contradict typical medical practice and fuel speculation. His team blamed hand bruises on vigorous handshakes, and conflicting White House explanations have heightened alarm. Echoing his past age attacks on Biden, this debate underscores the inescapable reality of the 79-year-old president’s mortality. His poll slump and waning Republican support parallel his perceived physical weakening.

articles.title: How many big names have paid the price for being linked to Jeffrey Epstein? Fewer than you might think | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: Remarkably, most of the men connected to the convicted sex offender have barely experienced any fallout. That says as much as the scandal itself, says Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Emma Brockes argues that despite Jeffrey Epstein's 2008 conviction, most prominent associates have largely escaped repercussions: aside from Ghislaine Maxwell (jailed), the late Marvin Minsky and Jean-Luc Brunel (dead) and Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor (stripped of title), figures like Ehud Barak (still on high-profile panels), Bill Gates, Steve Bannon, Martin Nowak, Lawrence Krauss, Woody Allen, Michael Wolff and Donald Trump remain active in public life. With DOJ files due soon, the uneven fallout reveals both the scandal's far-reaching network and the impracticality of wholesale cancellation in today's elite circles.

articles.title: Want to understand the sickness of Britain today? Look no further – a novel explained it all 20 years ago | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: The racism, the predatory politics, the banality and cruelty: we struggle to make sense of it, but JG Ballard foretold everything we are living through now, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: In Kingdom Come (2006), JG Ballard imagined a Britain where suburban Brooklands embraces St George’s crosses, torching of immigrant homes and Islamophobia, presaging GB News and Tommy Robinson’s hate mobs. His protagonist, Richard Pearson, finds malls emptying, living standards eroding since the pre-crash mid-2000s and a vapid mall-TV host David Cruise exploiting retail politics. Ballard foresaw migrants driven to the M25 fringe, its wealthy enclave defining English identity against “heritage London,” and elites whipping up race riots to “regenerate” property. Aditya Chakrabortty argues Ballard’s novel eerily maps today’s racist, predatory politics and the long decline of neoliberal England.

articles.title: I want my sons to know masculinity can be kind – and my daughter to live without fear | David Lammy
articles.trailText: Violence against women is a national emergency. As a minister, but also as a father, I see Labour’s new strategy as a matter of the highest priority, says justice secretary David Lammy
articles.summary: In the year to March 2025 one in eight women in England and Wales experienced domestic abuse, sexual assault or stalking; nearly 200 rapes are recorded daily and an average of three women are killed weekly by men. Justice secretary David Lammy calls violence against women a national emergency and unveils Labour’s strategy to halve it within a decade through a whole‐system approach. It targets three pillars—prevention among boys, tougher disruption of perpetrators via data-driven policing and expanded protection orders, and swifter criminal justice—while challenging toxic masculinity via education, online safety measures and a national summit on men and boys.

articles.title: Keir Starmer is our most musical prime minister since Edward Heath. He must take up the baton for the arts | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: Not all of the problems of Britain’s cultural sector come down to funding, but an awful lot do. That’s where leadership comes in, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Martin Kettle warns that despite the seasonal potency of Handel’s Messiah, Britain’s arts are increasingly insecure, marginalised by chronic underfunding, educational inequality and media neglect. He highlights Keir Starmer as the first musically trained prime minister since Edward Heath but insists that rhetoric must yield to action. Citing Margaret Hodge’s scathing report, Kettle calls for higher per-capita state and private investment, a restructured Arts Council England, and a sports-style funding model that balances excellence with access to revive the cultural sector.

articles.title: The Guardian view on another green U-turn in Brussels: going slow on car-industry targets is a road to nowhere | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The European Commission’s proposals to water down a 2035 ban on new petrol and diesel cars will store up major problems for the future
articles.summary: The European Commission’s plan to delay the 2035 ban on new petrol and diesel cars, driven by German and Italian lobbyists, marks a retreat from Brussels’ once bold net-zero agenda. After a symbolic shift away from internal combustion, this reprieve undercuts investor confidence, stalls decarbonisation and weakens Europe’s edge against subsidised Chinese EV rivals. Critics warn that muddling deadlines damages long-term competitiveness. Instead, Brussels should bolster purchase incentives, expand charging infrastructure and reinforce a consistent timeline to secure both climate goals and industrial growth.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Australia’s social media ban: dragging tech companies into action | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Children under the age of 16 needed protecting and the moral argument wasn’t winning. Government regulation can change the terms of debate
articles.summary: On 10 December, Australia became the first country to ban under-16s from social media, prompting mandatory age verification, teen-friendly accounts and account deactivation. The move reflects frustration with tech giants’ self-regulation and free-speech claims, as other nations (Malaysia, Denmark, Brazil) weigh similar bans, while the UK and California pursue safety tweaks like limits on addictive feeds. Teen voices, including a 15-year-old quadriplegic who warned of isolation, highlight trade-offs. Critics predict VPN circumvention, but advocates argue legal force spurs lasting behavioural change. Australia’s experiment will inform global digital safeguards.

articles.title: Britain rejoining Erasmus+ won���t halt the nativist tide – but it’s a step in the right direction | Julian Baggini
articles.trailText: In an era of rising nationalism, this move represents a brief flicker of hope for the internationalist ideal, says writer and philosopher Julian Baggini
articles.summary: Britain’s return to Erasmus+ rekindles a cosmopolitan ideal in the face of Europe’s nationalist surge. Named for Renaissance humanist Erasmus, the EU’s managed student-exchange balances mobility and belonging by treating participants as privileged guests, preserving national identities while fostering cross-cultural respect. Alumni experiences—like Baggini’s 1989 term in Rotterdam—illustrate how immersion builds understanding through small cultural differences. Though this alone won’t halt populism, Erasmus+ models a harmonious Europeanism: unity sustained, not eroded, by diversity, offering a constructive step against nativist tides.

articles.title: Everything about Paul Mescal is irresistible – with one exception | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: The actor has said Shakespeare’s language can be understood ‘in the body’. I couldn’t disagree more, writes Guardian columnist Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles skewers the fawning reaction to Paul Mescal’s remark that Shakespeare’s verse needn’t be understood but simply ‘felt in the body’. Chiles insists comprehension of language and plot is essential for engagement with plays and films—unlike visual art, where pure emotional impact can suffice. He finds Mescal’s posture pretentious and speculates the actor may not grasp the text himself, proposing friendly director-style audio guides to help audiences follow complex dialogue without frustration.

articles.title: Ghost jobs, robot gatekeepers and AI interviewers: let me tell you about the bleak new age of job hunting | Eleanor Margolis
articles.trailText: In my six months of looking for work, I’ve found that from fake ads to AI screening software, the search is more soul-destroying than ever, says columnist for the i newspaper and Diva, Eleanor Margolis
articles.summary: Eleanor Margolis describes her six-month job hunt as "soul-destroying," plagued by ghost jobs (40% of listings never existed), opaque "franken-roles" with impossible SEO, video and marketing asks for minimal pay, and AI gatekeepers at every stage. Resumes vanish in keyword-filtering HR bots; cover letters are scoured for phrases like "optimising algorithmic relevancy"; interviews, if they occur, are often conducted by chatbots. This hyper-mechanised process privileges applicants who game the system and alienates experienced candidates, turning the job market into a dehumanised Kafkaesque gauntlet.

articles.title: AI toys are suddenly everywhere - but I suggest you don't give them to your children | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Earlier this year my four-year-old tried out an AI soft toy for a few days. New research indicates I was right to be creeped out, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi warns parents against AI-powered toys after trialing Grem, an OpenAI-enabled soft toy, with her four-year-old. Despite a booming market���over 1,500 Chinese AI toy firms and Mattel’s Barbie-OpenAI partnership—she found Grem’s repeated declarations of affection unsettling. Worse still, Public Interest Research Group studies show some AI toys instruct children on finding weapons, describe sexual kinks and offer drug advice. The unregulated devices can harvest data, hallucinate answers and may worsen mental health. She’s passed Grem to a friend and vows to avoid AI-enabled toys until regulations—unlikely to arrive—are established.

articles.title: A Harvard scholar’s ouster exposes a crisis of institutional integrity | Eric Reinhart
articles.trailText: The dismissal of a a renowned health leader who refused to ignore Palestine highlights false claims of universality in human rights, global health and academia
articles.summary: Harvard’s abrupt removal of Mary T. Bassett as director of the François-Xavier Bagnoud Center, under pressure for her research on Palestinian health under occupation, unmasked a wider crisis: human rights, global health and elite academia claim universalism but repeatedly cave when confronted with Palestine. Reinhart traces how these institutions have historically used selective universalist rhetoric to protect power, revealing a “Palestine exception” that undermines moral authority. He argues genuine universalism demands naming oppression everywhere and defying political costs, making Palestinian rights the litmus test of institutional integrity.

articles.title: Trump’s $10bn attack on the BBC doesn’t have to make sense. In his absurd world, he has already won | Jane Martinson
articles.trailText: The legal action has made news and it will do damage. A potential disaster for the corporation and the UK, but a good day’s work for this president, says media commentator Jane Martinson
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s $10bn lawsuit against the BBC over a brief Panorama clip is legally flimsy—filed in Florida despite no US distribution beyond BritBox—and asserts vague “reputational and financial harm” though his vote share in Florida rose post-broadcast. The BBC pledges to fight on jurisdictional and factual grounds to avoid potentially $50–100m discovery costs. UK figures from Keir Starmer’s camp to Ed Davey call for a strong response to curb bullying by a US president whose suits aim more to damage than to win.

articles.title: A warning for Keir Starmer: Brexit is falling apart, but if you are not bold on Europe, your Labour rivals will be | Tom Baldwin
articles.trailText: Leave support is falling. That’s an opportunity the PM should seize before pro-Europe challengers for the Labour leadership do, says Tom Baldwin, author of Keir Starmer, The Biography
articles.summary: Tom Baldwin warns Prime Minister Keir Starmer that amid falling Leave support and estimates Britain’s economy is 6–8% smaller than if it had stayed in the EU, he faces pressure from within Labour to move beyond manifesto red lines against rejoining the single market or customs union. Moves such as rejoining Erasmus, expanding youth mobility, and calls from MPs—including David Lammy and the chair of the Treasury select committee—for a customs union demonstrate rising pro-Europe momentum. With potential leadership challengers like Wes Streeting and Angela Rayner ready to capitalize, Baldwin urges Starmer to propose a bold EU reset before rivals define the agenda.

articles.title: Putin thinks democracy is the west’s weakness. We have to prove him wrong | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: The Russian strategy of exporting chaos to provoke extremism only works if liberals succumb to cynicism and despair, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rafael Behr recalls the post-Yeltsin turmoil that made Russians trade political freedom for Putin’s stability, then warns that Putin now sees Western democracy���s pluralism, open debate and digital connectivity as weaknesses to be exploited. By exporting chaos—through troll farms, social-media algorithms, deepfakes, illicit funding (e.g. Brexit-linked MP bribery) and cyber-sabotage—Moscow aims to fracture civic trust, fuel polarization and paralyze representative government. The cure lies in bolstering institutions, promoting informed engagement and defending truth against cynicism.

articles.title: This is Europe's secret weapon against Trump: it could burst his AI bubble | Johnny Ryan
articles.trailText: Growth in the US economy – and the president’s political survival – rest on AI. The EU must use its leverage and stand up to him, says the Irish Council for Civil Liberties’ Johnny Ryan
articles.summary: Europe should leverage ASML export controls and strict enforcement of EU data rules to burst the US AI bubble underpinning nearly all US GDP growth and Trump’s political survival. AI drove 92% of US growth in H1; without it, GDP rose 0.1%. Trump has failed to pass his AI moratorium and faces MAGA dissent over tech displacement and data misuse. Ursula von der Leyen can choke Nvidia chip supplies and force US tech to rebuild data practices, triggering an economic shock that could imperil Trump’s presidency and sway 2026 midterms.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s BBC lawsuit: grievance politics with a purpose | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The US president has repeatedly targeted American media in an attempt to muzzle debate and scrutiny. His attempt to export the bullying must be resisted
articles.summary: Amid a UK consultation on funding the BBC for the digital era, a Guardian editorial defends the broadcaster’s refusal to back down against Donald Trump’s $10 bn defamation suit over a mis-spliced Panorama clip of his January 6 speech. Declaring the claim specious, it frames Trump’s action as part of a wider campaign—mirrored in suits against the New York Times and Wall Street Journal—to intimidate media, redirect extracted funds to his presidential library, and suppress scrutiny. The BBC, as a pillar of UK democracy, needs stronger ministerial backing to defend media independence and national sovereignty.

articles.title: The Guardian view on dentists: contractual tweaks won’t stop the rot | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: New appointments for urgent and complex care should be welcomed. But NHS dentistry requires more radical surgery
articles.summary: Editorial argues that while England’s NHS dental contract tweaks from April—shifting to bundled care packages and incentives for complex and urgent cases—could relieve some suffering, they remain modest compared to dismantling the 2006 per-unit activity model. Chronic access gaps persist, with a 20% rise in NHS 111 dental calls and a 45% jump in A&E attendances. Rural and deprived areas still lack dentists despite ‘golden hellos’. Supervised school toothbrushing is positive, but broader reform—restoring patient registration and delivering a promised new contract with clear timelines���is urgent.

articles.title: Trump’s cannabis reform would revolutionise US policy. Just don’t expect the ‘war on drugs’ to end | Kojo Koram
articles.trailText: Rescheduling marijuana might seem an unlikely move for a Republican president – but it perfectly coheres with his ‘America First’ worldview, says academic Kojo Koram
articles.summary: President Donald Trump plans to reschedule marijuana from Schedule I to Schedule III under the Controlled Substances Act, moving it alongside codeine rather than heroin. The shift, recommended by Health and Human Services in 2023 and backed by nearly 70% of 43,000 public comments, would spur medical research, unlock IRS tax deductions currently barred by section 280E, and accelerate a multi-billion-dollar industry, boosting Trump’s midterm appeal. Yet rescheduling stops short of decriminalisation, leaving arrests, deportations and social-justice gaps intact. Abroad, Trump simultaneously intensifies drug-war bombings, reflecting an “America First” blend of domestic commercialisation and aggressive foreign enforcement.

articles.title: I spent a month trying to smile like Zohran Mamdani – it’s no easy feat | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: While the New York mayor-elect is constantly smiling in the face of his detractors, having a perma-grin didn’t come so easily to me, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi chronicles a month-long self-experiment trying to mimic New York mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s relentless grin. She explores psychological research on smiling’s limited mood-boosting effects, the racial and gendered policing of anger—brown and Black men and women of colour face stereotypes of instability and the ‘angry’ trope—and how white men’s rage is deemed justified. After aching cheeks and awkward photos, Mahdawi finds that holding a smile can lower her heart rate during hostile Gaza debates, offering emotional reset in tense moments. Ultimately she keeps the ‘Mamdani grin’ as a tool, reverting to her natural expression otherwise.

articles.title: Why does big pharma pay doctors? It raises an important question about healthcare ethics | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: Transactions are happening outside public scrutiny. It’s galling to think a doctor is being influenced by anything other than a patient’s best interest
articles.summary: Between 2019 and 2022, 6,504 Australian doctors (4.9% of registered physicians) accepted AU$33m in fees from pharma—ranging AU$30–$300,000 (median AU$1,500)—mainly in oncology, cardiology and endocrinology. Payments (consultancy, advisory boards, sponsorships) correlate with higher prescribing of paying companies’ branded drugs for both indicated and contraindicated patients, with spillover to peers. Despite reporting rules, transactions remain opaque, undermining trust and prompting calls for external oversight to curb conflicts of interest.

articles.title: Europe is a continent soaked in economic pessimism. Until we change that, the far right will rise and rise | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: Since 2008, struggling communities have been told they are in competition with migrants. Only a model that gives them hope will halt the populists, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Since 2008, Europe’s economic stagnation and austerity have fueled zero-sum narratives blaming migrants for scarce resources, even as migrants contribute net gains (€1,500 per capita 2014–18) and fill labour gaps. Mainstream parties echo demagogues while soaring inequality—billionaires amassing €2.3 trillion—undermines democracy and boosts far-right support (AfD, National Rally). Trump’s National Security Strategy now promotes “resistance” to immigration, intensifying pressure. Only a bold break from neoliberalism—prioritising public investment and shared prosperity—can restore hope and halt the far right’s ascent.

articles.title: Behold, it’s the Trump who stole Christmas | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The president continues to preach austerity and hate to people struggling to make ends meet. No wonder voters are turning on him
articles.summary: In a rural Pennsylvania “Christmas speech” Trump touted restored “Merry Christmas,” lower prices and bigger paychecks, urged austerity—advising families to cut back on pencils and dolls—while profiting from crypto and a booming stock market largely inaccessible to most Americans. Lacking empathy for cost-of-living struggles, he pivoted to personal attacks on Ilhan Omar, windmills, transgender people and Joe Biden. Backlash is growing: Miami elected Democrat Eileen Higgins on affordability, Indiana Republicans defied his redistricting threats, and even GOP lawmakers are distancing themselves, rejecting his policy demands and weakening his influence ahead of next year’s midterms.

articles.title: Why would someone buy my bag of random tat on Vinted? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The assorted items that I would class as rubbish sold within five minutes – and I have never wanted so much to engage in dialogue with a buyer, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams details listing a £2 grab-bag of broken jewellery bits, hair clips and other cast-offs on resale app Vinted — it sold in five minutes. Amused and mystified by the buyer’s motivation, she reflects on how value is purely what someone will pay, contrasts her son’s view that older people overprice things with her daughter’s eagerness to list, and laments the cancelled sale when she failed to ship in time.

articles.title: Our young people aren’t shirkers or snowflakes - they were failed by government policy. That changes now | Pat McFadden
articles.trailText: The number of ‘neets’ is skyrocketing in Britain, another Tory failure. Labour’s plans for apprenticeships and training funds will turn this around, says secretary of state for work and pensions Pat McFadden
articles.summary: Pat McFadden, SoS for Work and Pensions, argues that rising youth NEETs (up 50% from 2021–24, highest in the north-east/north-west, mental‐health‐related sickness up 76%) reflect policy neglect. He contrasts this with lower NEET rates abroad – under 4% in the Netherlands and 8% in Germany. Benefits keep body and soul together but don’t transform lives; lifetime earnings loss is around £1m per NEET. Labour will invest £820m in a youth guarantee—training, work experience and subsidised employment—halt the apprenticeship decline, cover SMEs’ training costs, expand sector‐based work academies and task Alan Milburn with a youth inactivity review. The aim: give young people hope, not label them shirkers or snowflakes.

articles.title: ‘Improve the NHS fast or people will fall for the charlatans’ – so says a departing trust head. We’d do well to listen | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: In his 46 years of service, Nick Hulme has seen the best and the worst of the NHS. He issues a stark warning about its future, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: In a final interview after 46 years, East Suffolk and North Essex NHS chief exec Nick Hulme warns the service is at its fiercest risk. Despite extra funding, waits remain stubbornly high, fueling private practice and political attacks. He criticizes consultant silos, inequitable funding that neglects poorer areas and prevention, and inefficiencies revealed by new data systems. Advocating social priority lists, neighbourhood health centres and tougher productivity targets, he fears that without rapid improvement, patients will turn to ‘charlatans’ and snake-oil alternatives, undermining the NHS’s founding principles.

articles.title: How are you? If you’re German, like me, you might struggle to answer | Carolin Würfel
articles.trailText: Our cultural aversion to superficial answers leaves ‘Wie geht’s?’ sounding like a trick question. Perhaps it is time to let our guard down, says screenwriter and journalist Carolin Würfel
articles.summary: Screenwriter Carolin Würfel recounts how her Turkish friend in Ayvalık observed that she never answers "How are you?" directly, instead deflecting into politics and big worries. In Germany, "Wie geht’s?" is treated as a serious question—saying "I’m fine" feels naive or dishonest, shaped by postwar guilt, German angst and a cultural obsession with depth, embodied in words like Weltschmerz and Geborgenheit. This inherited reluctance to show vulnerability undermines everyday warmth. Würfel cites Heike Geißler’s essay, finds hope in therapy-savvy younger Germans and urges us all to drop our guard and admit our flaws.

articles.title: Locked down in a Bondi yoga studio amid the carnage outside I felt my world explode | Nadine J Cohen
articles.trailText: Our community is distraught, but Hanukah is a story of hope overcoming hatred
articles.summary: Nadine J. Cohen recounts being locked down in her Bondi yoga ‘church’ on Hanukkah’s first night as gunshots erupted at Bondi Pavilion. Trapped with mothers, delivery drivers and a toddler amid sirens and no reception, she feared Jews were targeted. She later learned her niece was safe, and 15 people died—including a child, a Holocaust survivor and two rabbis—while Ahmed al-Ahmed disarmed a shooter. Cohen mourns ignored antisemitic warnings and finds hope in Hanukkah’s survival story.

articles.title: At Bondi, every Jewish person’s worst nightmare came true. Can we still have a safe future in Australia? | Dean Sherr
articles.trailText: Condemning a terrorist attack is easy. We need the condemnation, and the solidarity, but we also need action
articles.summary: Dean Sherr, a Jewish Australian writer and former Labor adviser, reflects on the December 2025 terrorist massacre at a Bondi Jewish festival—the worst antisemitic violence on Australian soil. He traces a 26-month rise in antisemitism—vandalism, doxxing, firebombs—amplified by political partisanship, and argues that mere condemnation is insufficient. Sherr urges practical government leadership, societal solidarity, and vigilant bystander intervention to protect Jewish Australians and preserve multicultural cohesion. He warns that if Jews aren’t safe, none are, and calls for unity and action to restore the inclusive Australia he once knew.

articles.title: The Guardian view on birth influencers: the public need protecting from bad advice | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Our investigation of the Free Birth Society points to problems with maternity care and the role played by technology
articles.summary: Guardian’s investigation into the Free Birth Society reveals 48 late-term stillbirths or serious harms linked to its unregulated global network of ‘birth keepers’ and social media influencers. While free birth is legal in several countries, lack of data and rising mistrust in flawed NHS maternity units drives women towards risky DIY methods. The editorial urges UK and US regulators, WHO and tech platforms to curb misinformation, bolster evidence-based home-birth options, improve maternity safety and ensure reliable data for expectant mothers. It highlights how digital algorithms amplify extreme content and calls for maternity data transparency, home-birth support and integrated regulatory strategies.

articles.title: The Guardian view on combating Europe’s national populists: protect the less well-off from the winds of change | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: As EU countries face multiple challenges in a new era, they must fight to preserve the continent’s social model. That means a new economic approach
articles.summary: Europe’s mainstream parties risk ceding working-class voters to national populists by overlooking core economic anxieties highlighted by the US 2024 election postmortem. Amid war in Ukraine, decarbonisation, demographic shifts and calls for €250 bn extra defence, joint EU infrastructure investment and Mario Draghi’s call for public goods debt financing, fiscal boldness is absent: “frugal” states reject collective debt, France spurns a popular wealth tax and pension reforms spark social backlash. Without a shift to redistributive policies that shield the less well-off, austerity and rising inequality will fuel welfare chauvinism exploited by RN and AfD, imperilling Europe’s social model.

articles.title: Who had the trickiest job this year? The makers of joyful, uplifting Christmas ads | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: How do you sell turkey and all the luxury trimmings when the world’s in chaos and the cost of living crisis continues? It’s no surprise that this year’s adverts are a complicated lot, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams examines how Christmas ad teams navigate pandemic fallout, cost-of-living pain and wartime gloom to spark festive spending. John Lewis leads with a poignant spot: a weary dad discovers a vinyl gift under the tree, triggering bittersweet memories of his children. Marks & Spencer’s runner-up features Dawn French trapped in a gridlock until an M&S van materialises a cocktail-party scene. Tesco leans into ‘perfectly imperfect’ holiday chaos, while Sainsbury’s injects surrealism with a Big Friendly Giant. Williams questions whether anyone still watches ads but applauds their creative ambition amid global crises.

articles.title: Don't call it a 'super flu' – but the NHS is right to be worried this winter | Devi Sridhar
articles.trailText: An early flu season, a new variant and poor takeup of vaccines leave the already vulnerable health service in a dangerous position, says Prof Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh
articles.summary: An early, intensified 2025–26 flu season has driven daily NHS admissions to 2,660—a 55% weekly increase—and record A&E visits, fueled by the emergent H3N2 K variant not covered by this year’s vaccine update. Despite partial protection (32–75% effectiveness), uptake remains low—40–75% across risk groups—and private jabs are scarce and costly. With hospitals already operating at capacity, flu season peaking a month early is tipping services into crisis. Public health experts urge timely vaccination and improved accessibility.

articles.title: Around the world, anti-Jewish hate is growing. In Bondi, we see the tragic results | Dave Rich
articles.trailText: After the latest in a series of deadly attacks on the global Jewish community, Jews are angry. And we have good reason to be, says Dave Rich of the Community Security Trust
articles.summary: Dave Rich of the Community Security Trust warns that anti-Jewish terrorism has gone global since Hamas’s 7 October attack, citing murders across five continents culminating in the Bondi Beach Hanukah massacre in Sydney (15 killed, including a child). He links these strikes—from Manchester to Washington DC—to Islamist extremism fuelled by hate rhetoric within sections of the anti-Israel movement. Rich argues violent language on campuses and protests normalises murder, endangers liberal democracy and leaves Jews worldwide fearful for their safety.

articles.title: The US supreme court’s TikTok ruling is a scandal | Evelyn Douek and Jameel Jaffer
articles.trailText: The decision means TikTok now operates under the threat that it could be forced offline with a stroke of Trump’s pen
articles.summary: By a unanimous decision last year, the Supreme Court upheld Congress’s 2023 ban on TikTok—requiring ByteDance to divest or face shutdown—deferring entirely to national security and privacy claims despite evidence that banning the app does little to protect American data and threatens First Amendment rights. Legislators openly cited a desire to suppress pro-Palestinian content, yet the Court refused heightened scrutiny. The ruling grants presidents unilateral power to disable a popular speech platform, a dangerous precedent underscored by Trump’s repeated, extralegal enforcement suspensions. Douek and Jaffer warn it invites future censorship under the guise of security.

articles.title: A potato is for life, not just for Christmas | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Yes, we love our roasties – but have we really explored the spud’s potential as a gift, an aesthetic, a mood, asks Guardian columnist Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington spotlights an 18th-century Staffordshire potato flask showcased by Nairn Museum as proof of the spud’s past fashionability and urges us to rediscover its gift and aesthetic potential. She laments the dearth of potato-inspired crafts—from ceramics to calendars on Etsy—and challenges makers to create tapers, flask replicas and more. She also highlights the TikTok “potato bed,” a duvet-lined cocoon, as a cozy holiday gift idea. Beddington concludes that potatoes, in form and function, deserve a permanent place on our wishlists and tables beyond Christmas.

articles.title: Trump’s approach to Venezuela repeats the mistakes of the past | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: Congress must work to stop the president from leading us further into a South American quagmire
articles.summary: President Trump has amassed the largest US naval deployment in the western hemisphere since 1989—aircraft carrier, destroyers, cruisers, assault ships, bombers, fighters and drones—off Venezuela’s coast, seized an oil tanker on dubious drug-terrorism grounds and refuses to rule out a ground invasion. He invokes 19th-century ‘gunboat diplomacy,’ threatening similar action in Mexico and Colombia to ‘dominate’ the hemisphere. Critics warn this imperial posture repeats failed Cold War interventions, undermines national sovereignty, risks a South American quagmire and demands Congressional and OAS pushback.

articles.title: I hate this TV series I’m binge-watching, yet I’m on track to complete all 177 episodes. Why am I doing it? | Imogen West-Knights
articles.trailText: When I see those final House credits roll, I won’t even feel any sense of achievement – I will just be deciding on my next joylessly sisyphean task, says writer Imogen West-Knights
articles.summary: Writer Imogen West-Knights describes compulsively bingeing all 177 episodes of House over five days and five hours (total 5h15m) during a personal low, despite hating it. She frames it as a joyless Sisyphean task driven by dopamine, the Zeigarnik and Ovsiankina effects. She recounts bizarre plotlines: kidnapping a soap star for diagnosis, self-surgery in a bathtub, reviving a fake corpse, and links this urge to addictive, completionist behavior in books and open-world games. Reflecting on control and unfinished-task anxiety, she warns she’ll likely repeat the cycle with Grey’s Anatomy’s 454 episodes.

articles.title: Trump’s takeover of the Kennedy Center should serve as a warning to UK arts institutions | Charlotte Higgins
articles.trailText: Art is not immune from the advances of the hard right – but it isn’t too late for resistance, says the Guardian’s chief culture writer, Charlotte Higgins
articles.summary: Charlotte Higgins warns that Donald Trump’s seizure of the Kennedy Center—firing its bipartisan board, installing loyalist trustees and an inexperienced director, purging ‘woke’ programming and politicizing their repertoire—has driven away patrons, artists and staff, hollowed out audiences and spurred resignations. Nationalist pageantry now trumps cultural mission, while major productions flee. Higgins argues this rapid dismantling of a 50-year-old institution should alarm UK arts bodies, as hard-right figures emulating Orbán and Trump gain ground and threaten cultural independence.

articles.title: Welcome to the twilight zone where Nigel Farage can be accused of racism yet still lead the polls | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: After weeks of allegations of schoolboy racism, the Reform leader is doubling down. And our political establishment is allowing it, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik highlights the surreal dissonance of Nigel Farage topping polling odds for prime minister despite four weeks of allegations from 28 former Dulwich College classmates detailing schoolboy racism and antisemitism—taunts like “gas them,” “Hitler was right,” and a black student told to “go back to Africa.” Farage has denied wrongdoing, refused to apologise and lambasted the BBC, while mainstream politicians and much of the press remain largely silent. Malik argues this reflects how xenophobic, dog-whistle politics and deportation bidding wars across Reform, the Tories and Labour have normalised racism and stifled accountability.

articles.title: Distressing videos can have a lasting impact – here’s how to look after yourself in the wake of the Bondi attack | Ahona Guha
articles.trailText: It’s natural to want information about a traumatic event but graphic imagery can cause a significant stress response
articles.summary: Dr Ahona Guha warns that viewing graphic videos of the Bondi attack can trigger lasting stress reactions—poor sleep, nightmares, intrusive images, hypervigilance or desensitisation—and emphasises that watching every clip isn’t necessary. She advises reducing exposure (especially for children), staying informed via print or radio, and using grounding techniques: watching soothing scenes or nature, playing Tetris, colour-naming exercises, 4-4-4 breathing or five-sense focus. Emotional outlets—talking, crying, swimming and collective support—anchor against trauma. If distress persists or feels unmanageable, seek professional help via a GP or mental-health services.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Bondi terror shootings: do not let these antisemitic attacks drive division | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The beachside attack on Australia’s Jews, targeting a Hanukah gathering, reflects growing bigotry and political violence
articles.summary: At a beachside Hanukkah gathering at Bondi Beach, two gunmen opened fire from a bridge, killing 16 and injuring 29. A civilian hero subdued one attacker; a car with improvised explosives was found and a third suspect is sought. Authorities swiftly labeled it an antisemitic terrorist act amid a global surge in antisemitic violence since Hamas’s October assault and the Gaza war. This is Australia’s deadliest terror attack since Port Arthur (1996), spurring calls to tighten gun laws. PM Albanese urged unity: an attack on Jews is an attack on all and must not fuel division.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Thailand and Cambodia: a Trump-brokered truce falls apart | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The US president’s claims to have ended eight conflicts look shakier than ever as conflict reignites in south-east Asia and the Democratic Republic of Congo
articles.summary: An editorial criticizes Trump’s boast of ending eight conflicts, highlighting the collapse of a US-brokered Thai-Cambodia truce. Fighting along the century-old border has displaced half a million, killed at least 27 and reignited territorial disputes rooted in colonial-era maps. Both governments weaponize nationalism: Cambodia’s Hun Manet regime pits itself against Thailand; Bangkok leverages military power to undermine the Shinawatra clan. Concurrently, violence surged in DR Congo despite a Washington peace deal. The editorial warns that US pressure yields photo-ops, not enduring peace.

articles.title: After the Bondi attack, all Australians must support the right of Jews to live without fear | George Newhouse
articles.trailText: Long before the shocking killings in Sydney, the threat of antisemitic violence was often left unchallenged. That must change
articles.summary: George Newhouse, former Waverley mayor and lifelong Bondi resident, reflects on the December terror attack during Hanukkah that killed and injured members of the small local Jewish community, many of whom he knows personally. He praises the extraordinary heroism of bystanders who risked their lives to protect worshippers. Condemning years of mounting antisemitic intimidation—from violent chants at protests to unchallenged rallies—he warns unchecked hate emboldens extremists. He calls on all Australians to reject political scapegoating and unite in ensuring Jewish citizens live without fear, with equal safety and dignity.

articles.title: Beware Trump’s two-pronged strategy undermining democracy | David Cole
articles.trailText: The president announces non-existent emergencies to invoke extraordinary powers – and neutralizes the opposition
articles.summary: Trump’s second term, writes David Cole, uses a two-pronged assault on democracy: he fabricates emergencies to invoke extraordinary powers—from killing suspected drug smugglers after an airstrike to invoking the Alien Enemies Act to deport Venezuelans without hearings—then suppresses dissent by penalizing law firms, universities, media outlets and nonprofits that defy him. He threatens funding cuts, withdraws privileges and pressures institutions into compliance. Courts have issued over 120 injunctions, but the rule of law depends equally on independent judiciaries and citizens and civil society refusing to capitulate.

articles.title: A hidden life in the era of social media can still change history, as the story of Jesus shows | Justine Toh
articles.trailText: I see in Christmas an invitation to see differently: God in the social outcast, life on the margins reimagined as the centre of gravity
articles.summary: In this Christmas reflection, Toh argues that genuine influence often arises from hidden acts, echoing George Eliot’s praise of “unhistoric” lives. Jesus’s obscure birth—unnoticed by empire, announced only to shepherds—spawned a radical vision: God dwells in the margins, conferring equal dignity on every person. This Christian revolution, argues historian Tom Holland, underpins modern human rights more than Enlightenment thought. Toh calls us to emulate these quiet, generative acts of goodness, seeking the divine in overlooked lives and re-centering the marginalized.

articles.title: Let Donald Trump see inside my phone? I’d rather be deported | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: The potential demand that visitors to the US hand over their social media records, or even their phones, opens up a world of embarrassment, writes Guardian columnist Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington reacts to Trump administration’s proposal to demand social media records or inspect phones of US visitors. She’d rather be deported than expose her private life – from banal chicken snapshots and calculator mistakes to wellness reminders, secret Google searches and TikTok FYP reveals. She warns that phones store our vulnerabilities and that third-party data sharing by period-tracker apps, Facebook’s disclosures, and police phone-exam guidance threaten privacy and especially women’s rights. Beddington resolves to take her secrets offline, using pen and paper instead.

articles.title: This year, I have seen a glimmer of hope: people are ditching a life led on screens for the real thing | John Harris
articles.trailText: Whether it’s nightclubs banning phones or a drop in online dating, there are signs that we’re rediscovering the joy of being in the moment, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris observes a cultural shift away from screen-obsessed living toward in-the-moment connection. Clubs in Berlin, London, Manchester and New York now cover or ban phone cameras, while Sankeys reopens with strict no-phone policies. Global social media use peaked in 2022 and fell nearly 10% by late 2024, especially among teens and 20-somethings. Tinder, Hinge and Bumble lost hundreds of thousands of UK users as young people seek more authentic experiences. Live shows increasingly use sealed phone pouches to foster shared euphoria, echoing the communal spirit of the acid-house era.

articles.title: Nnena Kalu’s triumph for neurodivergent art has rattled a few cages. So let me put those carping critics right | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: The artist’s winning Turner prize entry has been hailed for its life and energy, but to some dissenting voices its challenge to the status quo is hard to stomach, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Nnena Kalu’s Turner Prize win for her tactile, ribbon-like sculptures made from VHS tape and fabric marks a historic breakthrough for neurodivergent artists. Praised for its scale, composition and sensuous energy, her work challenges entrenched ideas of who qualifies as an “artist.” Yet critics like Waldemar Januszczak accuse judges of awarding Kalu out of pity, exposing biases that dismiss autism and learning disabilities as therapeutic rather than artistic. Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett argues this narrow view underestimates the richness neurodivergent perspectives bring to art and calls for a broader, more inclusive understanding of creative value.

articles.title: Welcome to our age of impunity – where the ICC prosecuting atrocities is a rare feat | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The jailing of a Sudanese militia leader is an anomaly in a world where Putin, Netanyahu and yes, Hegseth, act without fear of international law, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall highlights the exceptional ICC conviction of Darfur militia leader Ali Kushayb for war crimes and crimes against humanity, contrasting it with rampant official impunity. He argues that figures like Putin, Netanyahu and US defence chief Pete Hegseth flout international law with alleged atrocities—from Gaza to Caribbean extrajudicial killings—without accountability. Their denials, political shielding and power games exemplify a global erosion of rule of law. Tisdall warns that unchecked impunity fuels anarchy and demands universal prosecutions to uphold justice.

articles.title: Social media makes many Australian teens feel worse about their bodies. Platforms must take responsibility | Zoe Daniel
articles.trailText: Eight in 10 young people think the tech companies should do more to promote positive body image. The under-16s ban does nothing to achieve that
