articles.summary: Independent MP Zoe Daniel highlights an 86% rise in eating disorders among Australian 10–19 year olds since 2012 and doubled hospital admissions by 2020, linking this surge to social media algorithms that feed vulnerable teens up to 400% more diet content and 4,000% more disordered-eating content on platforms like TikTok. She argues the under-16 ban merely shifts responsibility onto users and families, while leaving tech companies unaccountable. Daniel calls for a legal duty of care, algorithm controls, transparency in content moderation and enforceable penalties—a bill backed by health, advocacy and legal groups.

articles.title: Can you imagine raising a kid without ChatGPT? Sam Altman can’t | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The OpenAI CEO gushed about the bot’s parental-assistance abilities. Is it really his best child-rearing hack?
articles.summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, who welcomed his first child with husband Oliver Mulherin via surrogate, told Jimmy Fallon ChatGPT was his “indispensable” newborn coach—fielding queries from why his baby drops pizza to soothing worries about delayed crawling. In her critique, Arwa Mahdawi argues Fallon’s soft interview skipped tougher topics: AI’s hallucinatory risks, Altman’s privileged backup of surrogates and likely nannies, and the invisible, underpaid domestic labor—predominantly women’s work—that sustains high-powered parents.

articles.title: The ethnic cleansing of the US will destroy it | Heba Gowayed
articles.trailText: Trump’s racist remarks on Ilhan Omar and Somali immigrants reveal his vision for the US as a white Christian nation
articles.summary: At a December rally in Pennsylvania, Trump vilified Somali immigrants and Rep. Ilhan Omar, calling for their removal and praising white European migrants. Heba Gowayed argues this racist tirade and the administration’s policies—slashed asylum, canceled resettlement (save for white Afrikaners), steep fee hikes, blocked naturalization paths, threats to birthright citizenship, expanding ICE funding and racial profiling, plus AI surveillance—amount to ethnic cleansing aimed at restoring the US as a white Christian nation. Coupled with cuts to social spending and attacks on diversity, these measures target immigrant and minority communities nationwide.

articles.title: Will Farage's Trumpian strategy work against him? He has good reason to believe it won't | Samuel Earle
articles.trailText: The Reform leader bit back over allegations of racial abuse and revealed his strategy: the best form of defence is dragging everyone else into the mire, says writer Samuel Earle
articles.summary: Nigel Farage, facing multiple credible allegations of racist and antisemitic bullying, reverted to a Trumpian defense: attacking the BBC for hypocrisy instead of apologizing. By accusing the broadcaster of 1970s–80s racism and dismissing accusers as biased, he reframed himself as a victim of elite double standards, mobilizing right-wing outlets like the Daily Mail, GB News and TalkTV. Samuel Earle argues Farage’s strategy isn’t misjudged—he thrives on cynicism, contempt for institutions, and ‘owning the libs,’ undermining moral authority. His opponents must not only expose his character but also offer a constructive vision that counters his nihilistic appeal.

articles.title: Australia’s social media ban has given us a way to fight big tech – and get my son back on his skateboard | Sisonke Msimang
articles.trailText: The ban on under-16s accessing ‘harmful’ content that began this week has overwhelming approval from adults – even if it had a few teething issues, says author Sisonke Msimang
articles.summary: Australia’s new under-16 social media ban, despite age-verification hiccups, won 77% public approval. PM Albanese urged kids outdoors; youths parody “grass-touching” campaigns. Parents view the world-first law as a lever against Big Tech’s addictive algorithms and reclaiming childhood, though idealized beach-and-backyard narratives overlook migrants’ and urban families’ realities. Australia’s history of robust regulation—from plain-pack tobacco to strict COVID measures—bolsters trust, yet critics cite rushed consultations, low criminal-responsibility ages and Indigenous over-imprisonment. Esafety commissioner Julie Inman Grant says novices can’t “fairly fight” social platforms; the imperfect ban nonetheless gives communities a foothold, echoed in Msimang’s son picking up skateboarding again.

articles.title: I ate 3,000 meals for my ‘best of London restaurants’ list – and I hope you disagree with it | Jonathan Nunn
articles.trailText: From pie-and-mash to the swank of a Michelin star, everyone has their own idea of what’s ‘best’. What’s yours, asks food writer Jonathan Nunn
articles.summary: Food writer Jonathan Nunn spent seven years eating roughly 3,000 meals to compile a 99-restaurant list for his site Vittles, aiming to bridge London’s renowned Michelin-starred scene with neighbourhood gems—from pie-and-mash shops to a private-island fine diner. Reflecting on the global obsession with ranking restaurants���from Michelin and World’s 50 Best to Instagram shout-outs—he critiques their homogenizing bias and champions personal “best of” lists as subjective snapshots of what quality means. Citing his father’s picks—Polish banquets, Jamaican takeaways and childhood pie shops—he argues personal lists sharpen our own culinary values.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump and Venezuela: a return to seeking regime change | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The US is ramping up the pressure on Nicolás Maduro with a tanker seizure and expanded sanctions following threats and boat strikes
articles.summary: Trump readopts 'maximum pressure' on Maduro, massing forces in the Caribbean, bombing suspected drug boats, imposing expanded sanctions and seizing a Venezuelan tanker. After mooted invasion and a $50m bounty, he offered Maduro safe passage if he resigns. Critics highlight Venezuela’s minimal role in US drug flows, oil motives and China’s energy deals, and warn these moves risk fueling migration as 700,000 Venezuelans have fled to the US. Opposition leader María Corina Machado backs privatisation, seeing intervention as opportunity. Democrats caution a covert war looms—land strikes possible—even though years of sanctions have failed to unseat Maduro.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Nnena Kalu’s historic Turner prize win: breaking a glass ceiling | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The UK art world is finally becoming more inclusive. But greater support must be given to the organisations that enable disabled artists to flourish
articles.summary: Nnena Kalu, a Glasgow-born autistic artist with learning disabilities, became the first neurodivergent winner of this year’s Turner Prize for her colourful cocoon-like sculptures made from discarded materials and swirling vortex drawings. Judges praised her work’s abstract-expressionist ambition and distinctive voice, asserting that her neurodivergence did not define their choice. Some critics accused judges of favouring goodwill over aesthetic merit, but proponents argue all art reflects the maker’s identity. Kalu’s win symbolizes a growing inclusivity in the UK art world, from exhibitions by blind and partially sighted artists to disabled-curator residencies. But charities like ActionSpace and studios across the UK need sustained funding to nurture future disabled talent.

articles.title: Resident doctors, a fair deal is on the table. Please do not strike at this moment of crisis for the NHS | Keir Starmer
articles.trailText: A super flu epidemic is sweeping the country. Let us come together to protect the institution we all love, says Keir Starmer, the UK prime minister
articles.summary: Labour PM Keir Starmer urges trainee doctors to call off planned strikes during a severe “super flu” epidemic that has filled 2,660 hospital beds a day, risking patient care and NHS resilience. He insists a “fair deal” is on the table: a 28.9% pay rise over three years, record NHS investment, shorter waiting times, legislation prioritising British medical graduates for speciality training, 4,000 extra training places and covered exam and membership fees. Starmer also offered a mandate extension to delay ballots until after Christmas. He argues unity now will protect the NHS and patients.

articles.title: Donald Trump is pursuing regime change – in Europe | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: The US made it clear this week that it plans to help the parties of the European far right gain power. Keir Starmer and his fellow leaders have to face this new reality, writes Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland warns that Trump’s new US National Security Strategy labels Europe’s migration, free speech limits and low birthrates a civilization threat and vows to back far-right parties (AfD, National Rally, Reform UK) to engineer regime change. Echoing Putin’s goal to weaken the EU, this strategy astonishes leaders like Rutte and Starmer, who continue to favour US ties over European unity and rearmament, imperiling the Atlantic alliance.

articles.title: RFK Jr is a danger to public health – but local Maha laws could be a bigger threat | Katrina vanden Heuvel
articles.trailText: An array of under-the-radar initiatives are taking hold across the US, often tied to immunization, fluoridation and raw milk
articles.summary: RFK Jr’s high-profile anti-vaccine stunts obscure a broader “Make America Healthy Again” push: state houses have introduced over 420 anti-science bills this year targeting immunization, fluoridation and raw-milk sales, dozens signed into law (e.g. Idaho’s Medical Freedom Act, Arkansas raw-milk expansion, Utah/Florida fluoride bans). Even extreme mRNA bans have been proposed. These measures threaten public health and fuel cross-border outbreaks like measles. In response, Democratic governors formed a Public Health Alliance, 314 Action is funding pro-science campaigns, and experts are partnering with social-media influencers to rebuild medical trust.

articles.title: Welcome to the 2026 World Cup shakedown! The price of a ticket: the integrity of the game | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: In World Cup parlance, Qatar was Fifa president Gianni Infantino’s qualifier. Now it’s the big time for Trump’s dictator-curious protege, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde lambasts Fifa president Gianni Infantino for turning football into an autocracy, emulating dictators to learn plundering tactics. With 2026 World Cup final tickets at a minimum £3,120—seven times Qatar’s price—fans are priced out while Fifa profits and bolsters a bromance with Donald Trump’s ‘Dontourage.’ Hyde recalls South Africa’s show-trial courts, Fifa’s vote-buying of small nations, and Trump’s absurd interjections—renaming the Gulf of Mexico, rebranding the NFL—revealing a mutual exploitation racket. She warns that without a major market boycott or fan uprising, football’s integrity and supporters remain betrayed.

articles.title: AI is filling the God void for many – but is ChatGPT really something to worship? | Brigid Delaney
articles.trailText: Comforting reassurance was once the work of the church. Now it’s increasingly being sought from the machine
articles.summary: Brigid Delaney contrasts two funerals — secular, sorrowful farewells, and impersonal yet comforting Catholic liturgy — to illustrate modern faith’s decline and our loss of communal rituals that assure us of eternal solace. In a godless age, we endure death’s finality alone, craving reassurance. AI chatbots now fill that void: offering companionship, therapy, platitudes, and existential comfort formerly provided by religion. From Harvard Business Review to the New York Times, users praise ChatGPT’s steady empathy, even as critics warn that worshipping AI’s hollow consolations, anchored only in corporate motives, risks moral peril.

articles.title: I believed Australia could not look away from Aboriginal deaths in custody. I was wrong | Lorena Allam
articles.trailText: Decades on from the royal commission, I can only conclude there are no words that will make governments face their responsibilities
articles.summary: Lorena Allam revisits the 1991 Royal Commission into Aboriginal deaths in custody, recalling Clarence Nean’s 1982 death and exposing the ongoing overrepresentation and fatalities of First Nations people behind bars. Although Indigenous Australians are just 3.8% of the population, they accounted for 33 of 113 custody deaths last year (29%) and over one-third of prisoners, many held on remand for minor offences. Governments repeat formulaic condolences and investigations but ignore families’ viable solutions—bail law reform, decriminalising public drunkenness, banning prone restraint and spithoods, and raising the age of criminal responsibility—revealing a systemic indifference to Indigenous lives.

articles.title: Most people aren’t fretting about an AI bubble. What they fear is mass layoffs | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: Artificial intelligence could make income inequality even worse and create a new underclass. Governments and society must take action
articles.summary: Steven Greenhouse argues that public concern around AI centers on mass layoffs, not speculative bubbles, with projections that automation could eliminate up to half of entry-level white-collar jobs and exacerbate income inequality. Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu warns of an “anti-worker” AI path focused on automation and job cuts, urging instead a “pro-worker” approach to upskill employees. Greenhouse calls for strong government action—expanded retraining, free community colleges, universal health coverage, shorter workweeks, enhanced unemployment benefits, progressive taxation and meaningful worker representation—to steer AI toward shared prosperity.

articles.title: The Paris climate treaty changed the world. Here’s how | Rebecca Solnit
articles.trailText: There’s much more to do, but we should be encouraged by the progress we have made
articles.summary: On the 10th anniversary of the Paris Agreement, Rebecca Solnit highlights a groundbreaking July 2025 ICJ ruling making climate obligations enforceable, affirming the right to a healthy environment and intergenerational equity. Born from a Vanuatu-led student case, this decision builds on Paris’ 1.5 °C target—a victory of vulnerable nations—and underpinned the IPCC’s 2018 report that reshaped global policy. U.S. legislation like the Inflation Reduction Act and the Build Back Better framework drew directly on these targets. Meanwhile, renewables outstripped coal in 2025, driven by cost drops, storage advances, and country-level commitments. Though we’ve bent the warming curve toward 2.5 °C, far greater ambition remains essential.

articles.title: Trans rights should be a private affair. A toxic debate does no one any favours | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: The courts are a clumsy means to negotiate social relationships. Let organisations make up their own minds about inclusion, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins argues that framing trans inclusion as a legal battleground is counterproductive, citing a Supreme Court ruling that defines “sex” in the Equality Act 2010 as biological. He highlights conflicting readings—former justice Jonathan Sumption sees the verdict as permissive, while ex-EHRC chair Kishwer Falkner warns that allowing trans women in single-sex spaces nullifies them. With official guidance delayed, Jenkins urges a pragmatic, low-fuss approach: let clubs, hostels and sports bodies decide their own policies, issue a nuanced code to aid inclusion, and reserve courts for rare, truly hard cases rather than everyday social relations.

articles.title: Donald Trump wants a Europe in chaos – a sure sign for Britain to shore up its democracy | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: With the US threatening to support ‘patriotic’ parties here, we need better defences, starting with tough new rules about political donations, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Toynbee warns that Trump’s 2025 US security strategy brands Europe an adversary, praising ‘patriotic’ nativist parties and threatening allied status. Britain, already targeted by Russian and now potential US interference, remains vulnerable with no cap on political donations. All parties risk plutocratic sway: Reform’s £9m crypto-backed gift and Musk’s threatened £100m illustrate the scale. She urges reform in the upcoming Elections Bill: annual spending limits, maximum individual donations (e.g. £15k), a ban on crypto and corporate contributions, and Electoral Commission independence. Backed by Hodge–Lammy’s anti-corruption strategy, these measures curb foreign malign influence, money laundering and plutocratic pressure, protecting UK democracy.

articles.title: The facts are stark: Europe must open the door to migrants, or face its own extinction | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: These are the facts: plummeting birth rates mean that without attracting immigration, many countries are sliding towards collapse, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Monbiot warns Europe’s total fertility rate has fallen to 1.38 (1.44 in the UK), well below the 2.1 replacement threshold, making demographic collapse inevitable without mass immigration. He dismantles the Trump administration’s “civilisational erasure” claim as racist white-supremacist fearmongering, highlighting Europe’s wealth of language, science and cuisine born from migration and colonial exchange. With prosperity-driven birth declines and demographic momentum rendering pronatalist or restrictive policies ineffective, only immigration can sustain ageing societies. Monbiot cites future power shifts to higher-fertility nations like Nigeria, concluding that rejecting migrants risks erasing Europe itself.

articles.title: If the US forces me to choose between my two nationalities, I choose France – and Europe | Alexander Hurst
articles.trailText: Proposals to change US citizenship rules leaves dual citizens like me caught in the crossfire. If push comes to shove, I know where my loyalty lies, says Guardian columnist Alexander Hurst
articles.summary: Alexander Hurst warns that the proposed Exclusive Citizenship Act would force dual nationals like him to choose between the US and France—he’d pick France and Europe. He argues that current US policy is actively hostile to the EU, cultivating far-right ethnonationalists and imposing digital trade sanctions, while Europe meekly backtracks. Invoking Derrida and Habermas, he urges Europeans to assert autonomy through public confrontation, pan-European media funding and Erasmus-style schemes to build a shared civic sphere. He refuses to renounce the European citizenship he chose.

articles.title: Planning to visit the US? Take it from this American citizen – don’t | Eleanor Limprecht
articles.trailText: I love many things about the land of my birth but Donald Trump’s America has become an unwelcoming country of deep divisions and waning trust
articles.summary: Dual US-Australian citizen Eleanor Limprecht warns prospective tourists that Donald Trump’s administration has turned the US into an unwelcoming, surveillance state. New visa rules would require five years of social media history, decade-long email logs and family contact details, while authorities scrutinize political views. On her recent Thanksgiving visit she witnessed empty museums, armed National Guard patrols, ICE protests and communities mired in fear. Despite inspiring grassroots activism, she criticizes soaring military budgets, the rollback of LGBTQI+ and environmental rights, and expanded travel bans. Without family ties, Limprecht concludes she would avoid a country she now deems too divisive for visitors.

articles.title: How to buy a book for a child who is a non-reader? The trick is to meet them where they are | Allison Tait
articles.trailText: If you want kids to open the pages, not just the present, choose a book that feels like a treat – and show young Australians that reading matters
articles.summary: Allison Tait urges gifting books to every Australian child—including self-identified non-readers—by selecting titles that reflect their current passions (from footy and fly fishing to fairies), rather than age or traditional reading level. She advises choosing formats they’ll love (graphic novels, audiobooks, joke books), pairing each title with a related gift (cookbook + baking kit, sports biography + ball), seeking recommendations from librarians or indie bookshops, co-reading first chapters, modeling reading at home, and donating via charities to make reading a fun, purposeful festive treat.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s new peerages: another boost for the ermine arms race | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Sir Keir Starmer promised to bring meaningful reform to the House of Lords. He is failing to introduce it
articles.summary: Sir Keir Starmer, who once called the unelected Lords “indefensible”, has appointed 96 life peers in 18 months—34 this week—surpassing his four immediate predecessors and matching David Cameron’s pace. Labour’s 2024 manifesto pledged to eliminate hereditary peers, introduce a peers’ retirement age, slim the chamber and explore a replacement, but only the hereditaries bill is near passage. With 282 Conservatives and 209 Labour peers, ministers have fuelled an “ermine arms race”, inflating the Lords from 666 to 850 members, pushing total MPs and peers past 1,500. Editors advocate capping appointments at Commons numbers.

articles.title: The Guardian view on far-right perversions of the Christmas message: promoting a gospel of hate | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A Tommy Robinson-inspired carol service is the latest sign of a burgeoning Christian nationalist movement. The Church of England is right to push back
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that far-right figures like Tommy Robinson pervert Christmas by using a carol service to promote Christian nationalism and xenophobia, twisting Jesus’s message of compassion for strangers. Citing his Unite the Kingdom rally’s anti-Muslim rhetoric and parallels in Reform UK’s cultural Christianity under Nigel Farage and MAGA advisers, it highlights a growing threat. The Church of England, led by Bishop Arun Arora, campaigns against this misuse, affirming the gospel’s universal message of inclusion over nativist supremacism. Global echoes from Trump’s America to Orbán’s Hungary underscore the stakes.

articles.title: Gen Z know the social contract is broken. It’ll take more than youth clubs and StarmerTok to reach them | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: Labour’s £500m national youth strategy has some positives, but real change must start by tackling the root causes of unhappiness, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff critiques Labour’s £500m national youth strategy, praising investment in youth workers, apprenticeships and a mental-health review but warns TikTok stunts won’t reach Gen Z without tackling root causes: lack of trusted adults, safe social spaces, secure jobs and an honest intergenerational deal. Nandy’s research finds one in five teens lack a supportive non-family adult, a quarter see no local youth clubs, while social-media pressures and post-pandemic cuts fuel isolation. Rightwing calls to scrap the pension lock spotlight the welfare squeeze on youth. True change demands more funding, community infrastructure and a recalibrated social contract beyond political showmanship.

articles.title: Never be honest in Hollywood – even if you’re Quentin Tarantino | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: Success doesn’t mean you can speak your mind – and criticizing Paul Dano is like kicking a bunny at a birthday party
articles.summary: In a Los Angeles memoir, Dave Schilling skewers Hollywood’s ingrained culture of polite dishonesty, arguing that no one dares speak their mind—even top creators. Quentin Tarantino shattered that truce on Bret Easton Ellis’s podcast, calling Paul Dano “the weakest actor in SAG” and “the limpest dick in the world” for his role in There Will Be Blood. Peers have swiftly defended Dano, recalling Tarantino’s past misfire slamming David Lynch’s Fire Walk With Me. Schilling concludes that fame offers no shield from being flat-out wrong about art.

articles.title: Not one but two shows with a Bitch Lesbian lead? It’s a Christmas miracle | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: It is really satisfying to see beautiful, cranky lesbians take the lead in TV’s buzziest new shows, Pluribus and The Beast in Me
articles.summary: Guardian Australia columnist Rebecca Shaw celebrates a ‘Christmas miracle’: two of TV’s buzziest new series, Pluribus and The Beast in Me, both center on ‘bitch lesbian’ leads. In Pluribus, Rhea Seehorn’s Carol, a misanthropic writer, must save the world from an alien apocalypse; in The Beast in Me, Claire Danes’ grieving author investigates a murderous neighbour. Shaw argues that abrasive, unlikable traits lauded in male protagonists remain taboo for women—especially queer women. She praises these complex, cranky lesbians as refreshing visibility, while advocating for even broader, nuanced LGBTQI representation on screen.

articles.title: Trump’s anti-Somali tirade is a shocking new low | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The president called immigrants such as Ilhan Omar ‘garbage’ – but this latest racist outburst may be another sign of weakness
articles.summary: At a December 2 cabinet meeting, President Trump launched a virulent attack on the Somali community in Minneapolis–St. Paul, labeling Somali refugees including Rep. Ilhan Omar “garbage” unfit for America, echoing adviser Stephen Miller’s anti-migrant rhetoric. His administration’s refugee cuts favoring white Afrikaners, ICE crackdowns and threats of expulsion have heightened fear and economic harm among Somali Americans. Observers note diminishing returns: once-novel bigotry meets base fatigue, Omar urged Trump to seek help. Donegan frames this racist gambit as a sign of political weakness amid economic, legal and coalition crises.

articles.title: Jared Kushner – and three Arab monarchies – are at the heart of the Paramount-WBD bid | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: The president’s son-in-law is once again at the center of an international business deal that will require administration approval
articles.summary: Paramount Skydance’s $108bn bid for Warner Bros Discovery, led by David Ellison, is partly funded by Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners and sovereign wealth funds of Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the UAE. Details were buried in SEC filings. Trump, who criticized Netflix’s rival offer, has inserted himself into the review, risking blurred lines between his administration and his family’s business interests. Lawmakers warn of foreign influence and nepotism as the deal bypasses Committee on Foreign Investment scrutiny. A Paramount takeover could yield a Trump-friendly CNN, intensifying concerns over personal and geopolitical conflicts in US media mergers.

articles.title: There is a fund to create jobs in the poorest areas, and Labour has quietly gutted it. This is what betrayal looks like | Larry Elliott
articles.trailText: It’s a scandal laid bare. A stark new report highlights the price paid in Britain’s former industrial heartlands for this silent piece of ministerial vandalism, says Guardian columnist Larry Elliott
articles.summary: In a recent Industrial Communities Alliance report, Steve Fothergill exposes how Labour has slashed the UK Shared Prosperity Fund inherited from the Conservatives, despite deindustrialised areas like the Welsh valleys—where up to 25% of working-age adults claim incapacity benefits—still reeling from long-term poverty. Rachel Reeves cut the fund from £1.5 bn in 2024–25 to £900 m in 2025–26, and its replacement local growth funds shrink spending by 76% for England and Scotland and by 50% for Wales. With assisted area status left unreinstated, regional policy has been quietly dismantled, undermining job creation and widening the north–south divide.

articles.title: At least there’s one thing we can all agree on: three cheers for Claudia Winkleman | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: The tan, the fringe, the warmth and wit – there’s no other TV host quite like her, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson celebrates Claudia Winkleman’s unlikely ascent from fringe-tousled Autocue reader to MBE and TV superstar, praising her defiantly orange tan, disheveled-chic makeup and Cambridge education. Defying bland broadcasting norms, Winkleman’s warmth, wit and authenticity—whether stern on The Traitors or effusive on Strictly Come Dancing—forge a genuine connection with viewers. Hudson argues her effortless charm and decency offer a rare unifying triumph in a fractious era, reminding us to cherish simple pleasures and salute a presenter who truly breaks the mold.

articles.title: Why it’s ridiculous to call our new train system 'Great' British Rail | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: The name originated during the period of Boris Johnson boosterism. People no longer want Brexit triumphalism, but things that actually work, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Martin Kettle argues that the government’s rebrand of the renationalised network as “Great British Railways” is an empty Brexit-era slogan rather than a meaningful reform. Drawing on Torsten Bell’s critique of Britain’s naming woes, he says the boastful label echoes Johnson’s triumphalism, jars in a post-Brexit context, and rings hollow in devolved nations. Kettle contrasts it with the straightforward “British Railways” moniker of 1948–65, urging ministers to focus on tangible improvements—efficient service, good value and coherent UK-wide infrastructure—rather than illusory greatness through marketing.

articles.title: What will be the cost of Keir Starmer’s new medicines deal with Donald Trump? British lives | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: More than £3bn that could have been used for UK patients will go to big pharma for its branded products, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: British and US governments struck a medicines deal hailed as a “world-beating” UK life-sciences boost, but critics warn it forces the NHS to pay pharma giants billions more for branded drugs. The OBR forecasts an extra £3bn annual cost, likely met by cutting scans, surgeries and increasing waits, which University of York modelling links to roughly 16,000 avoidable deaths each year. Early warnings from AstraZeneca, MSD and Eli Lilly on R&D pull-outs pressurised Downing Street into concessions. Columnist Chakrabortty calls the agreement a costly capitulation that enriches big pharma at the expense of British patients’ health.

articles.title: Will Australia’s social media ban survive a high court challenge from two teenagers? Most likely – here’s why | Luke Beck
articles.trailText: The under-16s ban is a pragmatic first step in trying to reduce the potential harm on young people of addictive products. It is not undermining the democratic process
articles.summary: Australia’s under-16 social media account ban faces a 2026 High Court constitutional challenge by 15-year-olds Noah Jones and Macy Neyland, backed by the Digital Freedom Project, arguing it infringes the implied freedom of political communication. Experts predict failure, noting minimal teen political discourse pre-ban and the law’s proportionality to the legitimate aim of protecting youth health. Parallels are drawn with Australia’s world-leading plain-tobacco packaging, now emulated by Malaysia and the EU. Tech firms like Meta, TikTok and Reddit contest its effectiveness and free-speech impact amid US lawsuits over platform addiction.

articles.title: Born to run: how exercise expanded the landscape of my life and got my mind on track | Joseph Earp
articles.trailText: Running tends to get characterised as an entirely physical pursuit, which is probably why I avoided it for so long
articles.summary: Joseph Earp, a collector of trivia and biographical anecdotes, describes how daily running revealed an unexpected kinship with his bookish pursuits: each time he believes he cannot continue, he discovers new reserves of mind and body. Confronting his limits on the road mirrored his thrill at realising how much he doesn’t know in research. He argues that certainty shrinks our world, while admitting ignorance—whether about Mozart’s cataloguer or one’s own stamina—expands horizons, offering an infinite horizon to run toward.

articles.title: Sean Duffy wants ‘civility’ in air travel … so why is he doing pull-ups at the airport? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Transport infrastructure in the US is a hot mess – and the guy in charge thinks ‘wellness spaces’ are going to solve the problem
articles.summary: Transport Secretary Sean Duffy, a former reality star and lumberjack champion, launched a flashy press event with Health Secretary RFK Jr at Reagan National to unveil a $1bn grant program aimed at transforming US airports into “wellness spaces,” complete with workout zones, mini-gyms and breastfeeding rooms. Joined by carnivore-diet influencer Paul Saladino, he even demonstrated pull-ups on camera. Critics say these gimmicks divert attention from chronic infrastructure woes—aging bridges, air-traffic controller shortages and underfunded rail—and cash-strapped travelers’ real frustrations. Duffy’s civility campaign, urging fancier attire and polite behavior, has drawn ridicule from pyjama-clad TikTokers and right-wing podcasters.

articles.title: The Guardian view on ECHR reform: times change, but universal values need defending | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Calls to modernise human rights law too often assume that hostile public opinion cannot be changed by argument from first principles
articles.summary: Labour’s Keir Starmer urges “modernisation” of ECHR interpretations—especially on torture and family-life rights—to bolster public support for stricter asylum controls. The Guardian warns this risks echoing populist critiques and eroding enduring humanitarian principles: critics say blurring economic migration with genuine refugee claims fuels the demonisation of Channel crossers. Although safer legal routes could cut illegal crossings and protect refugees, Labour’s emphasis on tough borders sidelines a principled defence of universal rights, weakening rather than uniting public debate.

articles.title: The Guardian view on England’s social housing system: failing the very people it was built for | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Austerity hollowed out provision and hardened eligibility rules. A broken safety net now shuts out the poorest and drives rising homelessness
articles.summary: England’s social housing, once a safety net for poorest, now excludes them through austerity-era cuts, strict affordability and local-connection tests imposed by housing associations under financial viability rules. Benefit caps and pre-tenancy checks bar 70% with arrears, driving homelessness by design. Thatcher’s right-to-buy and council stock losses shifted burden to associations, while Cameron’s localism narrowed eligibility. Scotland mandates rehousing and allocates twice as many lettings to homeless. Crisis calls for 90,000 social-rent homes per year for 15 years, backed by £39bn, to rebuild housing as a public good.

articles.title: An EU-UK mobility scheme won’t erase the ‘violent indifference’ against young people. But it’s a start | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: We need people from Europe to move to the UK – but also a way to give Brits the opportunity to build the futures they crave, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams critiques the UK political establishment’s “violent indifference” to young people—evidenced by 2010’s tuition fee rise, lack of sustainable education funding, Brexit’s curtailment of free movement and wage stagnation—undermining youth prospects. Lisa Nandy’s new £500m Youth Matters plan pledges resilience-building, while a cross-party trade commission proposes a time-limited EU-UK mobility scheme capping 44,000 visas to offset net youth emigration. Despite 72% public support, Conservative voices brand it “more migration.” Williams warns that unless domestic conditions improve, the real risk is British youth leaving en masse.

articles.title: All of the suspected drug boat killings are murders | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: There is no rule of law if the president can deem anyone an enemy combatant and order them summarily shot
articles.summary: Kenneth Roth criticizes the Trump administration’s use of lethal force against suspected drug runners at sea—87 victims in 22 strikes—including the “double-tap” attack that killed two unarmed survivors. By designating cartels as enemy combatants, Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth bypassed law-enforcement norms and due process. Roth argues these actions violate international human rights law, lack evidentiary basis, and amount to murder, setting a dangerous precedent that undermines rule of law and executive accountability. Congress must investigate and rein in this summary execution policy.

articles.title: Received an unwanted gift? Here is your failsafe guide to how to respond | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Remember the protocol everyone must follow: look convincingly happy and never say what you actually think about a disappointing present, says Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson outlines a step-by-step etiquette for masking disappointment when you receive an unwanted Christmas gift. She stresses the importance of feigning surprise and gratitude—practicing neutral expressions to avoid betraying your true feelings in the three-second danger zone. Never directly mention wanting to return or swap the item, even if the giver offers. Use simple responses: “Thank you,” or “Ooh, what’s this?” then stow the present immediately in a “grot box” or donate later. Avoid overplaying enthusiasm or authenticity slips—these can backfire. Ultimately, tact and restraint preserve the giver’s goodwill and holiday spirit.

articles.title: Interviewing future medical students gave me that rare thing: hope for the NHS | Devi Sridhar
articles.trailText: They face long hours, mediocre pay and, at worst, no job, but their optimism is astonishing – let’s support them better, says Prof Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh
articles.summary: Prof Devi Sridhar recounts interviewing medical school candidates whose resilience – forged through lockdowns, socioeconomic challenges and crowded classrooms – signals hope for a strained NHS. Despite stagnating pay (£18-30/hour), long hours, chaotic rotas, night shifts and training bottlenecks, many students choose medicine over more lucrative careers. Inspired by the NHS’ pandemic role and eager for dual clinical-academic or public health paths, they face uncertain placements, potential unemployment and a brain drain to Australia and Ireland. Sridhar urges investment in job security, fair compensation and respect for resident doctors’ expertise to preserve their optimism and sustain universal healthcare values.

articles.title: Tried using the new online GP booking system? I have – and it was almost as miserable as my chest infection | Simon Hattenstone
articles.trailText: Wes Streeting’s plan to make booking easier made sense. Then I encountered an AI triagist, a stubborn receptionist and a Kafkaesque vicious circle, says Guardian feature writer Simon Hattenstone
articles.summary: Simon Hattenstone recounts his ordeal with the new GP online booking system rolled out by Health Secretary Wes Streeting. An AI triage tool flagged his chest infection as too serious, blocked his e-form and told him to phone—but reception then refused calls, insisting on the rejected form. Trapped in this Kafkaesque loop, he almost missed urgent care. NHS guidance says online booking is optional and for non-urgent requests; practices must still accept calls and in-person visits. Hattenstone warns of deadly consequences if misused, calls for clearer rules and penalties, and notes his practice has now updated its website.

articles.title: Eurovision used to be a campy joy – but it has become a cynical way to whitewash war | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The song contest continues with its mission of ‘unity and cultural exchange’ by rolling out the red carpet for Israel, even though at least four countries have pulled out in protest, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: In her Guardian column, Arwa Mahdawi argues that Eurovision’s ethos of unity has been hollowed out by its decision to welcome Israel despite its ongoing military assault on Gaza. While at least four countries (Netherlands, Spain, Ireland, Slovenia) have withdrawn in protest, the contest ignores the humanitarian crisis—child amputees, orphans, alleged genocide, and obstructed aid—that Gaza endures. Mahdawi contrasts Eurovision’s ban on Russia over Ukraine with its embrace of Israel, calling the show a cynical tool to whitewash war rather than a celebration of peace.

articles.title: Look behind the pomp of Putin’s New Delhi visit. The India-Russia relationship has weakened | Chietigj Bajpaee
articles.trailText: Modi voiced words of respect, but he is resisting an anti-western, anti-Ukraine stance, despite the foreign policy contradictions, says Chietigj Bajpaee, a senior fellow at Chatham House
articles.summary: Despite ceremonial fanfare during Putin’s 10th visit – airport hug, shared car, new MoUs – India-Russia ties show waning substance. Russian arms deals stall amid delivery delays and New Delhi’s defence diversification, while US sanctions curb oil imports despite Moscow’s supply pledges. Both sides signed an economic cooperation roadmap to 2030 to rebalance skewed trade and deepen space, nuclear and food-security ties. India resists an explicit anti-Western stance, pursuing FTAs with the EU and tech partnerships, while Ukraine war pressures its balancing act.

articles.title: In what sense is Tommy Robinson a genuine Christian? None that I can see | Ravi Holy
articles.trailText: The extremist, who is said to have converted in prison, is now planning a mass carol service. But look at his words and deeds: hardly Saint Tommy, is it, says vicar and stand-up comedian Ravi Holy
articles.summary: Ravi Holy, rector and comedian, challenges claims that far-right activist Tommy Robinson’s prison conversion makes him a genuine Christian. Ahead of Robinson’s planned mass carol service, Holy argues that true repentance must bear fruit, contrasting Jesus’ mandate to care for strangers and the vulnerable with Robinson’s persistent anti-Muslim code and tweets ridiculing liberal bishops. While bishops welcome his conversion, they reject his attempt to subvert faith for political ends. Holy calls on Christians to embody inclusive, service-driven beliefs, trusting that authentic witness will expose extremist distortions of Christianity.

articles.title: A braver Tory leader than Badenoch would dare to call out Farage's bogus patriotism | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: Across western democracies, established conservatives are yielding to radical nationalism. There’s no sign that Britain will be the exception, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rafael Behr warns that Britain’s Conservatives under Kemi Badenoch risk sliding into US-style radical nationalism by failing to name Nigel Farage’s Reform UK as a threat. He cites Washington’s new national security strategy, which brands mass migration a danger and aims to bolster far-right parties to weaken the EU. While Badenoch shifts focus to economic competence, Reform exploits anti-immigration fervor. Tory moderates fear a creeping alliance with Trump-aligned populism as Conservatives hesitate to openly discredit Farage, undermining British democratic resilience.

articles.title: The US is not just Europe’s unwilling ally, but an adversary steeped in far-right ideology | Cas Mudde
articles.trailText: Don’t say you weren’t warned: Trump’s new national security strategy seeks to destroy liberal democracy as we know it, says academic and author Cas Mudde
articles.summary: Cas Mudde warns that Trump’s new National Security Strategy weaponizes decades-old far-right European tropes—Spengler’s ‘decline of civilizations’ and Camus’s ‘Great Replacement’—to justify aggressive US interference in Europe. The document declares America must ‘Make Europe Great Again,’ backing nativist parties, pressuring EU migration and free-speech policies, and courting Russia under a ‘Trump corollary’ to the Monroe Doctrine. It frames EU decline as existential, urges support for patriotic central and eastern states, and positions the US as an adversary to European liberal democracy. Mudde says it repositions the US from reluctant ally to adversary of European liberalism.

articles.title: There's a feeding frenzy over Anika Wells' expenses. But if we want women in parliament it needs to be more family-friendly | Sarah Martin
articles.trailText: The official justification of the allowance is to facilitate ��the family life of the parliamentarian’. Yes, they are supported by the taxpayer to have one
articles.summary: Guardian senior correspondent Sarah Martin argues that the current uproar over communications minister Anika Wells’s expenses — notably a $100,000 New York trip and spousal sports-event travel — meets parliamentary rules aimed at supporting MPs’ family lives. She contends Wells used her reunion entitlement appropriately to balance duties and childcare, highlighting the patriarchal, inflexible nature of federal politics and the need to preserve or reform entitlements to retain more working parents, especially women, in parliament. Martin warns that dismantling these allowances risks driving mothers out of politics.

articles.title: We must protect our borders to defend our democracies. Here's how
articles.trailText: This is our strong message to our friends in Europe. Unless responsible governments reflect their citizens’ concerns, populists will win, say British PM Keir Starmer and Danish PM Mette Frederiksen
articles.summary: British PM Keir Starmer and Danish PM Mette Frederiksen warn that failing to manage irregular migration erodes public trust and fuels populism. They stress asylum remains vital for genuine refugees but argue modern mass mobility demands tougher, fair reforms. Citing Denmark’s lowest asylum grants in 40 years and the UK’s stepped-up removals and integration-based settlement requirements, they call for coordinated European action: dismantling smuggling networks, modernizing ECHR interpretation and enforcing clear expectations of contribution. They present controlled, sustainable migration—coupling compassion with law and order—as essential to protect democracies, uphold solidarity and demonstrate mainstream progressive politics can deliver real solutions.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump and Europe: more an abusive relationship than an alliance | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The White House is aggressively seeking to weaken and dominate the United States’ traditional allies. European leaders must learn to fight back.
articles.summary: Editorial argues Donald Trump’s administration is systematically undermining European security and unity—pressuring the EU to betray its founding values, minimize postwar US guarantees, dominate economically, and promote nationalist, anti-immigration rhetoric akin to Kremlin messaging. Ad hoc EU diplomacy, like the hastily arranged Downing Street summit, cannot counter these structural threats: Europe must offer robust financial backing—eg, £100bn in frozen Russian assets for Ukraine reparations—and pursue true strategic autonomy. Brussels should adopt a tougher stance with Washington, strengthen defense cooperation and protect EU interests against US and Chinese competition.

articles.title: The Guardian view on waste: the festive season is a good time to think about rubbish | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Weak regulation is to blame for disastrous failures in relation to pollution. But there are solutions if people get behind them
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that an estimated 168 million battery-powered festive ornaments may be discarded annually in the UK, exacerbating recycling shortfalls and fire hazards. It notes a 5 % rise in British plastic exports to nearly 600 000 tonnes and a projected 52 % jump in global plastic production by 2040. Regulators like Ofwat and the Environment Agency face criticism over sewage spills and illegal dumping, costing millions in clean-ups. The piece calls for stronger oversight, consumer restraint and investment in up to 15 new recycling facilities to curb waste and create 5 400 jobs.

articles.title: Donald Trump has finally won a peace prize – from Fifa, no less. Here are five other awards he should win | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The inaugural award bestowed upon the US president could pave the way for many more colourful accolades. I have some ideas, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi lampoons Trump’s inaugural Fifa peace prize—bestowed amid real wars in Sudan, Gaza and Ukraine—by proposing five satirical awards to flatter his ego: a Volkswagen Golf ‘Trump Cup’ to leverage his golfing boasts and US-EU tariff hostilities; France’s Big Cheese trophy to mollify his Paris quarrel; a Humpty Dumpty prize celebrating his neologisms like “covfefe” and “truthful hyperbole”; an Energizer Bunny award for his ceaseless Truth Social energy; and an American Gas Association accolade nodding to his world-gaslighting prowess.

articles.title: Trump’s crackdown on factchecker visas won't protect free speech | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: This isn’t about defending citizens. It’s about keeping the truth – and those skilled at protecting it – at a safe distance
articles.summary: The Trump administration, via State Department under Marco Rubio, has directed consular officers to refuse H-1B visas to foreign fact-checkers and content-moderators, branding their work as anti-American censorship. Critics like Columbia’s Knight First Amendment Institute call the policy incoherent and unconstitutional, arguing fact-checking is core First Amendment activity. Observers see this as a retaliatory move by Trump—spurned by social platforms—to weaken those who hold him and allies accountable online, under the guise of defending free speech.

articles.title: In this age of authoritarians, online abuse of women is soaring – and it’s leading to ‘real-world’ violence  | Julie Posetti
articles.trailText: Our UN report reveals the link between the online misogyny and offline crimes that are hounding women out of public life, says Julie Posetti, lead author of a new report published by UN Women
articles.summary: UN Women’s report “Tipping Point” shows networked misogyny, now bolstered by generative AI, fuels a vicious cycle of online and offline violence against women in public life—especially journalists, rights defenders, politicians and activists—aiming to curb gender equality and chill dissent. Surveying hundreds across 119 countries, offline attacks linked to online abuse against female journalists rose from 20% in 2020 to 42% in 2025; 19% faced AI-assisted harassment. Cases span India to Malta (e.g. Daphne Caruana Galizia’s murder). Posetti calls for urgent accountability for perpetrators and tech platforms amplifying gendered violence.

articles.title: Longevity supplements are sold as helping prevent ageing. But do they have any long-term benefits or increase lifespan? | Antiviral
articles.trailText: Much of the enthusiasm for these ‘anti-ageing�� products is based on animal studies, mostly involving rodents
articles.summary: Supplements claiming to boost nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD)—via precursors like NR, NMN and TMG—are marketed as anti-ageing and DNA-repair agents, but the hype relies largely on rodent studies. Human trials are scarce and small, reporting only minor short-term energy or mobility gains, and percentage increases in biomarkers don’t equate to reduced disease or longer life. No large, well-designed studies demonstrate real longevity benefits. Experts stress proven strategies—balanced diet, exercise, sleep, stress management, social connections, sun protection and preventive healthcare—over unverified supplements.

articles.title: Make a political hero of Zack Polanski if you want. Just don’t forget to engage your brain | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: The Green party leader is riding high in the polls. But across the political spectrum, uncritical adulation leads nowhere fast, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde urges caution against uncritical hero-worship of Green Party leader Zack Polanski. After his Question Time remark about being “grateful” that foreign care workers wash elderly bums, and a resurfaced 2013 video touting hypnotic breast enlargement, his supporters label detractors as “rattled.” Hyde likens this defensive tribalism to Kelly Osbourne’s TV gaffe and warns that with the Greens polling near 16%, blind fandom endangers politics. She calls for clear-eyed scrutiny, urging voters to acknowledge flaws rather than shielding idols from criticism.

articles.title: Trump is remodeling Washington to fit his twisted vision of America | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: The administration is offloading gems of US architecture while redesigning the city to match the president’s values
articles.summary: Judith Levine criticizes the Trump administration’s effort to reshape Washington DC by offloading dozens of historic federal buildings—from Breuer’s HUD headquarters to New Deal mural-filled courthouses—and selling architectural gems to satisfy a nostalgic classical aesthetic. The General Services Administration’s list of 443 then 45 properties alarms preservationists as brutalist, Art Moderne and expressionist works fall prey to a vanity agenda. Meanwhile Trump pushes self-aggrandizing projects—a bronze-topped Arc de Triomphe, a 90,000-sq-ft ballroom, a whitewash of the Eisenhower Executive Office Building and a refurbished Reflecting Pool—after purging design overseers, erasing public heritage and promoting a backward-looking vision.

articles.title: Could a drug for narcolepsy change the world? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: There are apparently breakthroughs on the way for those with sleep disorders – which sent me down a rabbit hole of research, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Pharma insiders say a new narcolepsy medication is imminent—with potential insomnia and broader cognitive applications—akin to Post-its emerging from failed glue. Zoe Williams explores the condition’s stark diagnostics: healthy adults nap after 22 minutes in an empty room, narcoleptics under 8 minutes. She describes cataplexy’s emotional triggers—laughter, excitement—and her own sudden dozing on the Tube. This research underscores sleep’s fragile hold on consciousness and hints at transformative treatments for sleep disorders.

articles.title: Pity Keir Starmer – he’s the fall guy for a Labour right that’s ready to cast him aside | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: The PM is the face of failure, but he is not solely responsible. As the Blairite ideologues mass behind Wes Streeting, we should hold them to account too, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Owen Jones argues Keir Starmer has become a convenient scapegoat for the Labour right, notably Blairites rallying behind Wes Streeting. They blame his supposed lack of charisma, vision and a phantom leftward drift, despite his purge of the party’s left, welfare cuts, harsh asylum plans and ID card proposals. Jones contends the real failure lies with a faction whose centrist, pro-market worldview expired in 2008. If Streeting succeeds, he’ll simply perpetuate the same hollow managerial politics; when he fails, the Blairite strategists alone will have no one left to blame.

articles.title: Come with me to Jacob Rees-Mogg’s house. The Brexiters are rattled – and it shows | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Labour and the country have reached a historic inflection point. For all the talk of Brexit ‘benefits’, the anti-EU ideologues know the tide has turned, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: At a Bruges Group reunion in Jacob Rees-Mogg’s Georgian townhouse, leading Tory Brexiteers Iain Duncan Smith, Bill Cash and John Redwood toasted a pamphlet of 75 touted Brexit 'benefits.' Across Westminster Labour figures—Keir Starmer, Rachel Reeves, Wes Streeting and David Lammy—now concede Brexit 'significantly hurt' growth: economists cite a 6–8% GDP loss (£240 bn in wealth, £90 bn annual tax gap). Polls show 56% see Brexit as a calamity. Labour’s about-turn on customs union, single market and possible re-entry risks alienating voters still wary after years of hyperbole.

articles.title: When a chatbot’s advice is a matter of life or death, how can we leave AI to the free market wild west? | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: As suicides in the US are blamed on ChatGPT and UK teenagers turn to it for mental health advice, we need clear rules – and we the people must set them, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Gaby Hinsliff argues that unregulated AI chatbots, like ChatGPT, can turn deadly when teens seek mental-health advice: she recounts the deaths of 23-year-old Zane Shamblin and 16-year-old Adam Raine, and notes one in four UK 13-17-year-olds now consult bots more than helplines. Highlighting studies showing bots suggest suicide methods and sway political opinions, she warns market-driven deployment across a borderless internet poses novel harms and calls for swift regulation and public engagement to harness AI’s benefits safely.

articles.title: Trump has declared civilisational war on Europe. It won’t be easy – but here’s how to fight back | Paul Taylor
articles.trailText: With democratic values under attack from populists within and former allies without, there are no simple solutions, says Paul Taylor of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: Three decades after Fukuyama’s “End of History,” liberal democracy faces attacks from populists, amplified by social media, and sanctioned by the Trump administration’s National Security Strategy declaring civilisational war on EU values. Failures to deliver affordable housing, education, healthcare and secure jobs drive disillusionment, stoking illiberalism. Proposed countermeasures—from speeding up enforcement of EU digital laws against tech giants to boosting social welfare and grassroots campaigning—face legal, political and logistical hurdles. Advocates urge existential mobilisation: exposing populists, refining pro-democracy messaging, and adopting extremists’ digital and community tactics. Yet a decisive strategy remains elusive as illiberal forces surge.

articles.title: My first cricket hero was Imran Khan. Now I close my eyes and replay Mitchell Starc’s bullet-paced yorkers | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: Cricket has always been my lullaby, my shorthand for belonging. And in Starcy I have another legend to admire
articles.summary: Shadi Khan Saif traces his cricketing passion from childhood Karachi tape-ball matches—where he adopted heroes Imran Khan and Wasim Akram—to admiring Mitchell Starc, who in his 102nd Test, with a 26.5 average and 17 five-fers, claimed his 415th wicket to surpass Akram’s left-arm record in today’s batter-dominated era. Saif maps cricket’s power as defiance in Taliban-ruled Afghanistan, a failed experiment teaching Germans, and finally rekindles his Test-cricket love on immaculate Australian ovals. Starc’s bullet-paced yorkers remain his nightly lullaby.

articles.title: The lesson of the Cronulla riots was that the beach was not for people like me. But it’s a myth I am increasingly resisting | Sarah Malik
articles.trailText: Twenty years on, racism remains ever-present, and confidence in public life by non-white figures still feels transgressive
articles.summary: The 2005 Cronulla riots, fueled by slogans like “You flew here, we grew here,” convinced Sarah Malik, a young hijab-wearing journalist, that beaches weren’t for people like her. She recounts systemic racism in Australian media and society, from post–9/11 stereotypes to historical segregation of Indigenous swimmers. Though Malik learned to swim and raced in ocean events, she still avoids Cronulla, associating it with violence. Daily slurs and exclusionary incidents reinforced her ‘model minority’ deference until a rare outburst of resistance liberated her. She now rejects colonial myths, honors Dharawal custodians, and plans to visit Cronulla as an act of respect.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Britain’s post-American drift: a crisis of purpose and power | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: US pressure over Ukraine has revealed Sir Keir Starmer’s limitations and a British state too hollowed out to shape events at home or abroad
articles.summary: Bullied by the Trump White House over Ukraine, Sir Keir Starmer’s government is revealed as adrift, unable to articulate a clear British position. At the Downing Street summit, Macron, Merz and Zelensky offered coherent post-American strategies, while Britain’s hollowed-out state—undermined by financialisation, a Treasury-dominated order and frayed civic solidarities—lacks the industrial base, budgetary flexibility and diplomatic clout to shape events. Starmer’s moral-mission rhetoric highlights the limits of an elite managerial tradition. Reviving UK influence demands a profound constitutional, economic and geopolitical reinvention beyond nostalgia for a “special relationship.”

articles.title: The Guardian view on solar geoengineering: Africa has a point about this risky technology | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Sun-dimming risks putting the planet’s thermostat under Donald Trump’s control. Better to adopt the precautionary principle with high-stakes science
articles.summary: At Nairobi’s UN environment talks, African diplomats urged a global moratorium on solar geoengineering—spraying reflective particles into the stratosphere—to avoid turning the continent into a test bed. They cite environmental, ethical and geopolitical risks: altered rainfall, food insecurity and a ‘‘termination shock’’ if cooling stops. Despite UK funding via ARIA and a US–Israeli firm’s ‘‘cooling services,’’ ministers should invoke the precautionary principle. Africa’s non-use proposal, akin to landmine and chemical weapons bans, refocuses action on cutting emissions, renewables and adaptation.

articles.title: Austerity is in the air again – from ‘overdiagnosis’ to the benefits bill. Here is what's at stake | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: A mindblowing new show reveals the human cost when the political system turns against the people, putting stories and faces to the hundreds of thousands of citizens thought to have died due to austerity, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams reviews The Museum of Austerity, a VR installation in London that dramatizes lives lost under UK welfare cuts. Through holograms and relatives’ testimonies—of people driven to suicide, starvation or untreated illness—the show confronts the estimated 330,000 excess deaths from 2012–19 austerity. Williams argues that welfare assessments and benefit sanctions were not mere errors but systemic brutality cloaked in political rhetoric about ‘making work pay’ and ‘overdiagnosis.’ In half an hour, the exhibit forces a reckoning with the human cost of ‘be well or die’ policymaking.

articles.title: Disabled people driving luxury cars on your dime? Just the latest rightwing lie peddled by Labour | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: Starmer’s ailing government is happy to pursue ideas like cutting Motability, but all ministers will do is damage lives and themselves, says Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: Months before the budget targeted Motability, a private site let anyone look up licence plates and falsely accuse disabled people of getting “free” luxury cars. Right-wing outlets and politicians seized on this myth—Labour’s Rachel Reeves now plans to cut £300m of tax breaks and ban premium brands—despite the scheme’s strict medical checks, re-assessments and invasive evidence requirements. Only 6% of cars are non-economy models (paid for by users), and rare conditions like acne are virtually insignificant. Scapegoating disabled motorists distracts from addressing stalled living standards, underfunded services and rising health needs.

articles.title: A four-day week for teachers? This is why that isn’t a luxury for us – it’s a necessity | Lola Okolosie
articles.trailText: Teachers in England and Wales are burnt-out and barely functioning. Solving that will help young people and their families too, says teacher Lola Okolosie
articles.summary: Teacher Lola Okolosie argues that England and Wales need a formal four-day teaching week to avert chronic burnout and attrition. She cites TUC figures showing teachers log 26 unpaid overtime hours weekly—£15,000 underpaid annually—and a NASUWT leader labeling pay gaps “daylight robbery.” Okolosie reports her own four-day trial gave vital planning and recovery time, enabling sustainable teaching, parental duties, and wellbeing. With only 59% of teachers planning to stay post-pandemic and £1.25bn spent on supply staff, she calls a protected non-teaching day a smart, essential innovation to retain experience and stabilize schooling.

articles.title: Canada’s environmental ‘realism’ looks more like surrender | Tzeporah Berman
articles.trailText: At a time when the UK and other countries are finally taking bold steps for climate, Canada is preparing a new oil pipeline
articles.summary: While the UK moved to ban new North Sea oil licences, hike windfall taxes and accelerate fossil-fuel subsidy phase-out, Canada sealed a deal to build a new Alberta oil sands pipeline, delay methane regulations, scrap emission caps and weaken assessment rules. Proponents call it "realism", citing carbon capture and storage (CCS), yet CCS has failed to curb more than 20% of a barrel’s lifecycle emissions. This expansion, adding a million barrels per day, flies in the face of COP28’s fossil fuel phase-out pledge and deepens dependence on an industry driving global floods, fires, heat and pollution.

articles.title: My dream of jet set glamour has died – in a pleather chair full of other people's crumbs | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: The use of airport lounges is soaring, born of a desire to feel a bit special. The reality is we’re all going to end up crammed into the same awful, environmentally disastrous metal tube, says Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington reveals the disappointing reality behind the airport lounge boom: despite 3,500 lounges worldwide and a 31% rise in Priority Pass use, the promised luxury—cashmere, vintage Champagne, caviar—is replaced by pleather seats, stale buffet dregs and overcrowded lines. Lounges exploit our craving for exclusivity, yet we all still end up in the same packed, environmentally damaging metal tube. Disillusioned, she plans to ditch the lounges and return to waiting on Terminal 3’s floor with her own sandwich.

articles.title: Does Pete Hegseth even believe that war crimes exist? | Sidney Blumenthal
articles.trailText: The US defense secretary’s belief that the military should not be held to account has been a defining factor in his career
articles.summary: Defense secretary Pete Hegseth, self-styled “Secretary of War,” has championed unfettered military violence, ordering a controversial Caribbean drone strike that killed 82 suspected narco-terrorists and invoking the “fog of war” to avoid accountability. He’s dismantled the military’s legal guardrails by firing top JAG officers, clashing with former judge advocates who deem his orders war crimes. A bipartisan outcry in Congress, legal briefs from the Former JAGs Working Group and media scrutiny challenge his refusal to respect Geneva-convention rules of engagement. Hegseth’s crusader imagery, extremist ties and defiance of civilian oversight have ignited debates over war crimes prosecution and the integrity of U.S. military law.

articles.title: Why I am proud to be a part of the Guardian | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: I’ve found that many people I speak with trust the Guardian’s independent, mission-driven coverage of the news
articles.summary: Margaret Sullivan describes being surprised by a New York poll worker’s gratitude for her Guardian reporting amid widespread distrust fueled by Trump’s “fake news” attacks and commercial pressures on US outlets. She argues the Guardian earns trust through a clear, mission-driven commitment to democracy—eschewing performative neutrality, refusing to normalize authoritarianism, and maintaining accuracy. Its no-paywall, Scott Trust–backed model ensures wide access and shields journalism from profit-driven bias. Sullivan also praises contributors like Moira Donegan, David Smith and Jeremy Barr, and endorses reader funding to sustain this inclusive, accountable journalism.

articles.title: Britain is stuck with a failed Brexit that neither citizens nor leaders want. Here are three ways to fix that | Stella Creasy
articles.trailText: While those who defend the status quo and those who say ‘simply rejoin’ the EU are both wrong, there is a new mood and a clear opportunity, says Stella Creasy MP, chair of the Labour Movement for Europe
articles.summary: Stella Creasy argues Brexit has failed, both status quo defenders and ‘rejoin’ advocates are misguided. UK GDP per capita is down 6–8% and 16,000 firms have quit EU trade amid costly bureaucracy and a one-fifth drop in goods exports. Rejoining the customs union or single market is neither quick nor without new trade-offs. She warns geopolitical turmoil—with Trump, Putin and Xi—reinforces the need for UK-EU alignment. Any option demands clear trade-offs and public justification. She proposes three fixes: an independent Brexit impact review, “more-for-more” negotiations discarding red lines to secure a deal, and enhanced parliamentary scrutiny with Labour pledging a mandate in its next manifesto.

articles.title: Look again at the Nuzzi affair. Because when our politics and media are so debased, the joke’s on us | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: There is a bread and circuses feel to this scandal. A wise public would see red flags; instead it sees entertainment, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik critiques the Olivia Nuzzi scandal as symptomatic of political and media decay. Nuzzi’s undisclosed “digital affair” with RFK Jr during his presidential run—violating journalistic ethics—sparked a Substack-fuelled feud with ex-fiancé Ryan Lizza that blurred personal drama with “journalistic” serialisation. Both trade on brand-building and monetised newsletters, turning accountability into entertainment. Malik argues this spectacle reflects Trump-era media fragmentation, where influencers replace reporting, partisan ownership squeezes traditional outlets, and scandal trumps substance. The Nuzzi affair, she warns, reveals a degraded ecosystem ripe for opportunists and unmoored by genuine public interest.

articles.title: Trump’s new doctrine confirms it. Ready or not, Europe is on its own | Georg Riekeles and Varg Folkman
articles.trailText: We can move from defensive crouch to position of strength but only if we use the economic cards we have against US coercion, say Georg Riekeles and Varg Folkman of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s 2025 National Security Strategy brands European integration a threat to freedom, signals a US pivot to the Pacific and Western Hemisphere, and calls on Europe to take primary responsibility for its defence. Key Trump-era thinkers like JD Vance, Steve Bannon and Elbridge Colby advocate troop withdrawals and deprioritisation of Europe in favour of Asia and hemispheric security. As US military protection thins, Washington will increasingly wield financial sanctions, export controls and diplomatic pressure to shape EU policy. Riekeles and Folkman warn Europe must sustain defence investment, wield its own economic cards—including triggering the anti-coercion instrument—and reject lopsided trade deals to preserve strategic autonomy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Marwan Barghouti: Palestinians need a political future as well as aid and reconstruction | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Pushing for the release of the jailed leader could prove central to the peace that Donald Trump claims to seek in the Middle East
articles.summary: In the Gaza ceasefire, violence slowed but displacement and aid remain blocked. Palestinians demand security, humanitarian relief, reconstruction and a political horizon. Marwan Barghouti, Fatah leader jailed for over two decades, emerges as the sole unifier backed internationally for a two-state solution. A campaign by Paul Simon, Richard Branson and the Elders highlights his symbolic value. Critics call his trial flawed, while Israeli officials fear freeing this "symbol" more than militants. His release could spark Palestinian statehood momentum. The Guardian urges President Trump to press Israel for Barghouti’s freedom as vital for lasting peace.

articles.title: The Guardian view on ageing research: our lives have more distinct phases than we thought | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Tech moguls may foolishly hope to stay forever young, but others could benefit too from evidence of the human body’s dynamic and varied journey through life
articles.summary: Recent research suggests ageing happens in distinct phases rather than linearly. Studies, including a Nature Communications brain-scan analysis, identify five brain eras with inflection points at 9, 32, 66 and 83, plus organ-specific shifts around the mid-40s, 50s and 60s. Driven by omics data and increased funding, these findings hint at dynamic stability punctuated by rapid change. Though underpowered, the pattern could enable targeted anti-ageing interventions at critical tipping points. Tech moguls chase unproven fads, but experts advise timing existing preventive measures across life stages to boost wellness rather than just lifespan.

articles.title: Ukraine is facing a painful choice | Christopher S Chivvis
articles.trailText: Kyiv may be approaching its last chance to end the war with its sovereignty intact. If a peace deal includes two key elements, it should accept
articles.summary: Christopher Chivvis argues that Ukraine faces its last realistic opportunity to end the war while preserving sovereignty by accepting a peace deal—even a weak one—that includes tangible security guarantees and military support. He warns past maximalist demands (recapturing Crimea, joining NATO) squandered windows for compromise, weakening Kyiv as Russia consolidates gains in Donbas. With U.S. backing uncertain under Trump and European allies prioritizing self-defense, Ukraine must choose pragmatism or risk vassalage under Moscow and further erosion of Western assistance.

articles.title: Forget Hadrian’s Wall. The UK citizenship test should ask about Corrie, bus queues and Greggs | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Questions about the Corn Laws and habeas corpus are abstruse and unrelated to modern life – as my French husband is finding. The test should instead ask about soap operas and sandwiches, writes Guardian columnist Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington criticises the Life in the UK citizenship test as an outdated, obscure quiz—requiring knowledge of Mary Peters’ 1972 gold medal, Corn Laws repeal, Hadrian’s Wall forts and judicial dates—unfit for modern applicants. Her French husband, despite working, volunteering and adopting local habits, flounders over abstruse questions. Beddington proposes instead evaluating everyday British culture: Greggs logos, bus-queue etiquette, soap-opera storylines, meal-deal pricing and nuanced uses of the word sorry. She argues citizenship should reflect living, evolving societies rather than sanitised imperial trivia, reminding readers that all British histories are immigrant stories.

articles.title: The right’s callous overdiagnosis bandwagon is rolling. Wes Streeting should not be on it | John Harris
articles.trailText: Thankfully, we now know more about conditions such as autism and ADHD. The health secretary must not be part of this attempt to turn back the clock, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris lambasts Health Secretary Wes Streeting’s new “independent review” into autism, ADHD and mental-health conditions, saying it echoes a right-wing overdiagnosis crusade aimed at rolling back support and justifying welfare reform. He argues rising diagnoses reflect genuine understanding of neurodiversity and systemic pressures—from competitive schooling to pandemic fallout—and warns that dismissing “mild” cases risks depriving 2.5 million people of vital help. Harris urges focus on adapting education, work and care infrastructures, not pathologizing unmet needs.

articles.title: Zipcar’s demise means people such as me are back in the slow lane – and stuck needing their own costly car | Phineas Finn
articles.trailText: The impending collapse of UK carsharing is an embarrassment for a government attempting to curb the dominance of cars, says writer Phineas Harper
articles.summary: Zipcar’s decision to exit the UK will shutter 3,000 shared vehicles, undermining efforts to cut emissions and congestion by replacing roughly 20 private cars per shared vehicle. With only one car club vehicle per 30,000 people, British carsharing lags far behind Germany. Despite grand sustainable transport policies, the government is funneling billions into private EV subsidies, charging infrastructure and automakers, while neglecting cost-effective car clubs. Critics warn EVs still produce particulates, have carbon-intensive production and may spur more driving, as seen in Norway’s 10–20% trip rise. Zipcar’s collapse exposes misplaced transport priorities and a need to champion shared mobility.

articles.title: Putin should have accepted Trump’s deal. Now Russia’s collapsing economy could lead to his downfall | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The war against Ukraine has hit ordinary Russians hard, and the deteriorating situation is likely to inflame tensions, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall argues that Vladimir Putin’s rejection of Donald Trump’s proposed Ukraine peace deal—a pact that would have rewarded Russian aggression, split NATO, and bolstered Moscow economically—reflects neo-imperial hubris. Instead, Russia’s economy is unraveling: oil and gas revenues fell 27%, inflation is 8%, interest rates exceed 16%, deficits swell, sovereign wealth has halved, foreign investment collapses, and consumer taxes rise. Ukraine’s strikes on refineries, pipelines and tanker fleets deepen energy shortages. Geopolitically, Moscow’s influence wanes as Syria, Iran, Venezuela and even China and India distance themselves.
