Mounting casualties, social divisions and elite unrest risk undermining Putin’s regime, notes Tisdall. Trump’s meddling prolongs the war; Europe and NATO must reinforce Ukraine to hasten Russia’s decline.

articles.title: I’m no hate-watcher. I really do love Meghan and her Christmas special | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: The Duchess of Sussex is back and suddenly her show makes sense. It is cringingly ultra-extra, of course, but isn’t that what Christmas is all about?
articles.summary: In her Guardian column, Polly Hudson reevaluates Meghan Markle’s Netflix special With Love, Meghan: Holiday Celebration, arguing that the extravagant, ultra-extra style critics mocked in series one and two finally feels appropriate in a Christmas context. Hudson recalls the infamous pretzel-rebagging vignette and Meghan’s penchant for psychobabble, yet argues these quirks become charming in a yuletide setting. From wreaths to calligraphy-laden advent calendars, every element feels meticulously curated. She likens Meghan to an eccentric but reassuring festive aunt whose polished hosting and artisanal cooking comfort amid uncertainty, inviting viewers to embrace the seasonal cheer or simply look away.

articles.title: Whether trapped inside Gaza or out, the world is shrinking for Palestinians | Plestia Alaqad
articles.trailText: Sometimes I feel like the world is more afraid of me as a Palestinian refugee than it is afraid of the genocide and wars that create refugees in the first place
articles.summary: Alaqad portrays a shrinking world for Palestinians—bombarded and starved inside Gaza’s ever-diminishing borders, and locked out abroad by visa refusals. She recounts endless airport lines, confused passport officers demanding her mother’s name, and double standards treating her identity as a security threat. She criticizes a ‘ceasefire’ that merely reshapes genocide, leaving families displaced in winter tents. Palestinians, she argues, are mourned when under rubble but feared when alive. Trapped by borders, bombs and identity, she asks, ‘where should the birds fly after the last sky?’

articles.title: Want to be hotter? Try this one weird Republican trick | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The right has found a new pitch for young women: conservatives are better-looking
articles.summary: Republicans pitch conservatism to young women as a beauty hack, branding “Mar-a-Lago face” as instantly more attractive. On Fox News, Jesse Watters and Katrina Campins touted Sydney Sweeney’s “Mar-a-Lago makeover,” claiming “all Republican women are hot.” Plastic surgeons report surging requests for puffy lips, frozen foreheads and filler. Meanwhile, wellness influencer Alex Clark, a Turning Point USA speaker, cultivates “cuteservatives” via lifestyle content—“less Prozac, more protein”—transforming MAGA into an aspirational fashion and health brand more than a policy platform, even as its substance remains hollow.

articles.title: Trump wants to recreate a white America that never existed | Rebecca Solnit
articles.trailText: The persecution of brown people and mass deportations will not create the white country of far-right fantasy
articles.summary: Rebecca Solnit argues that Trump’s escalating targeting of brown people—through slander, mass ICE raids and deportations—reflects a far-right fantasy of a ‘white America’ that never existed. He attacks immigrants indiscriminately—from Somali Americans to US citizens—to bully demographics, while pushing pronatalist policies to boost white births even as he cuts Medicaid and other supports. His climate denial and fossil fuel favoritism, alongside anti-scientific health schemes, expose incoherent, racist governance. But across US cities—from LA to NYC—local communities are mobilizing to defend migrants, rejecting violent ICE operations and Trumpism itself.

articles.title: Nigel Farage was once run out of Edinburgh. Now Scottish voters are embracing his rabble-rousing | Dani Garavelli
articles.trailText: The Reform leader is exploiting growing resentment towards migrants and hosting a sold-out event - something unimaginable just a few years ago, says freelance columnist Dani Garavelli
articles.summary: Once driven out of Edinburgh by anti-racism protesters in 2013, Nigel Farage will now host a sold-out Reform UK rally in Falkirk, where demonstrations against a hotel housing male asylum seekers have turned xenophobic. Polls suggest Reform UK could finish second in May’s Holyrood vote, exploiting local anger over migrant dispersal, asylum-case backlogs and housing shortages—policies inherited from UK and Scottish governments. Farage weaponises tropes about “illegal” migrants and cultural threat, while the SNP struggles to rebut without amplifying his message, as Reform UK revels in a record £9m crypto donation.

articles.title: The Trump administration sinks to a new low – opening fire on drowning men | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: These deadly US boat strikes are the latest example of a president corrupting both the law and morality, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland condemns the Trump administration’s lethal boat strikes on suspected drug traffickers in international waters, which have killed at least 87 people across 22 attacks. He highlights the “double tap” incident ordered by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth��strikes on survivors that may breach U.S. and maritime law. Freedland also critiques Trump’s Russia policy: envoy Steve Witkoff’s back-channel talks to reintegrate Russia’s $2 trn economy for business gain, and the blurred public-private interests seen in Kushner’s UAE investment deals.

articles.title: The Guardian view on reducing child poverty: with the two-child limit gone, Labour must go further | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The new strategy has gaps. But ministers have shown that they are serious and capable of listening
articles.summary: Labour’s child poverty strategy, anchored by scrapping the two-child limit, is set to lift 550,000 children out of poverty by 2029. Alongside extending free school meals and piloting rehousing for families stuck in B&Bs, ministers demonstrate real commitment after years of rising child poverty under the Conservatives. Yet gaps remain: the plan lacks the ambition of Blair’s pledge and ignores the benefits cap and frozen local housing allowance. With public support for a strong safety net, Labour must now challenge welfare myths and build on these measures to eradicate deep material deprivation.

articles.title: The Guardian view on reboots of A Christmas Carol and Paddington: refugee tales for today | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: An Asian Scrooge, a break-dancing Bob Cratchit and a musical bear – new versions of classics keep stories alive
articles.summary: An editorial examines contemporary reimaginings of Dickens’s A Christmas Carol and Paddington as refugee allegories. Gurinder Chadha’s Christmas Karma casts Mr Sood, a 1972 Ugandan Asian refugee, as Scrooge, and Sadler’s Wells East’s Ebony Scrooge recasts the miser as a Dominican fashion diva, highlighting parallels between Victorian-era fears of “surplus population” and today’s anti-immigration rhetoric. Meanwhile a new Paddington musical updates the 1958 evacuee-inspired bear into a multicultural London carnival, championing tolerance. With child poverty and homelessness rising, these festive reboots—alongside Michael Rosen and Helen Oxenbury’s Big Issue story Pax—underscore compassion, redemption and the political spirit Dickens embedded in his classics.

articles.title: The Liz Truss Show will confront the big issues of the day. For example: who on earth would watch Liz Truss? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Everyone’s favourite former PM is back! Her mission? To save Britain from its current ‘doomloop’ with, you guessed it, a YouTube talkshow, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers Liz Truss’s new post-PM media ventures, chiefly her YouTube talkshow 'The Liz Truss Show', launched to 'confront issues others tiptoe around' and framed as an antidote to experts despite Truss’s market-driven downfall. Hyde lampoons the save-Britain-from-the-doomloop narrative, noting Truss’s 31-day premiership, her flop book Ten Years to Save the West, and the show’s ‘cultural battles’ pitch across YouTube, Spotify, X and Substack. The article also critiques Truss’s £500,000-a-seat private members’ club The Leconfield, branded mockingly as a ‘WeWork for arseholes.’

articles.title: I don’t care if Reform calls me a bad word on WhatsApp. But the story behind its gaffe is far more worrying | Will Hayward
articles.trailText: The leaked exchange shows how much the party dislikes scrutiny – which reveals a lot about its approach to governing, says Guardian columnist Will Hayward
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Will Hayward unpacks leaked WhatsApp messages from senior Reform UK Wales figures calling him the “c-word,” exposing the party’s contempt for scrutiny. He recounts being initially barred from interviewing Nigel Farage at a party conference and contrasts this with preferential access granted to sympathetic media. Hayward warns that this access-for-favour attitude mirrors actions in Reform-run councils—banning a local paper in Nottinghamshire and slashing scrutiny committees in Kent. He highlights no-shows by elected members and recurring internal disputes, arguing these patterns reveal a chaotic party whose disdain for accountability should alarm Welsh and UK voters.

articles.title: Labour has a groundbreaking plan for child poverty. Finally, this government has found its mission | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The new strategy lays out Britain’s social disgrace in painful detail. But it also offers hope and a clear way forward that is worthy of a leftwing party, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Labour’s new child poverty strategy, led by ministers Liz Kendall, Alison McGovern and Bridget Phillipson, will abolish the two-child benefit cap, aiming to lift 550,000 children above the poverty line by 2030 while 4m remain poor. It mandates cross-department action on housing, health, transport and Best Start hubs in every council by 2028, with annual progress updates. Addressing that nearly three-quarters of impoverished kids are in working families, it contrasts Tory-era cuts and “Benefits Street” rhetoric and embeds children’s welfare as government priority.

articles.title: Labour wants to ramp up facial recognition. What if our data ends up in the wrong hands? | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: We know from recent hacks, and even the Snowden revelations, how vulnerable information gathered is to theft and misuse, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins criticises the UK government’s new consultation on nationwide facial recognition, warning that no online or biometric system is ever secure. He highlights existing live facial surveillance by London’s Met and six other forces, touting arrests for sex offenders and other crimes. Jenkins recalls the collapse of the NHS data project and Snowden’s revelations to argue that safeguards inevitably fail against hackers or state overreach. While the technology promises crime-fighting gains, he warns it threatens individual privacy, will leak or be misused by corporations and authorities, and should be resisted.

articles.title: Give credit where it’s due: Labour is finally doing things its supporters actually want | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: From tackling child poverty to being honest about Brexit, the party seems to have recognised the growing electoral threat to its left, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff argues that Labour has begun addressing its grassroots agenda by lifting the two-child limit on welfare payments, expanding early-years support via Best Start family hubs with a focus on speech, language and early reading, and directing new revenues from higher earners to the poorest families. The party has also adopted a more candid stance on Brexit’s economic fallout and secured a zero-tariff pharmaceutical deal with the US. This strategic shift towards jobs, child poverty and Europe risks internal pushback but could reclaim voters from Reform and the Greens.

articles.title: Over a pint in Oxford, we may have stumbled upon the holy grail of agriculture | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: I knew that a revolution in our understanding of soil could change the world. Then came a eureka moment – and the birth of the Earth Rover Program, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: George Monbiot describes how a chance meeting in Oxford sparked the Earth Rover Program, applying seismology—dubbed ‘soilsmology’—to map soil non-invasively at high resolution. Inspired by farmer Iain Tolhurst’s fertilizer-free, high-yield methods, the project repurposes affordable sensors and simple seismic pulses to measure soil volume, density, moisture, porosity and carbon at scale. Backed by the Bezos Earth Fund and UBS, with open-source tools and a global database, it aims to guide farmers toward higher yields and lower environmental impact.

articles.title: The Great European Bake-Off: if the EU wants closer integration, how about using pop culture? | Paula Erizanu
articles.trailText: The commission wants Moldova to join the union – so it should drop its dry bureaucratic culture and instead meet people where they are, says Moldovan journalist Paula Erizanu
articles.summary: EU’s enlargement commissioner Marta Kos swapped technocratic briefs for pop-culture outreach in Moldova—appearing on local TV, hosting influencer pie-making sessions and convening rival church leaders—to involve citizens beyond political elites. With >90% of Albanians and 53–65% of Moldovans favoring accession, Erizanu argues the EU must counter Kremlin narratives by making integration relatable through Europeanized hit shows (e.g., Europe’s Got Talent, The Voice, Top Gear, The Great European Bake-Off). Alongside cultural soft power, Brussels should facilitate migrant language learning and foster social inclusion—inviting cleaners and staff to office gatherings—to build trust, solidarity and a cohesive European identity.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the crown estate inquiry: a necessary probe and a wider debate | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Parliament’s ban on discussion of the royals is infantile. A committee of MPs has the chance to end the secrecy over their finances
articles.summary: Britain’s House of Commons has long banned discussion of the monarchy, but MPs’ public accounts committee has launched a rare inquiry into the Crown Estate, sparked by revelations that Princes Andrew and Edward pay “peppercorn rents” on extensive properties. The 1961-established, £15.5bn public body funds the annual sovereign grant, due for review in 2026, and gains from offshore wind. The probe will assess value-for-money, terms of grace-and-favour residences and wider accountability for royal finances, heralding a shift in parliamentary scrutiny.

articles.title: The Guardian view on regulating pornography: a £1m fine does not prove the Online Safety Act is working | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: As technology advances, so does the problems it causes. Ministers as well as regulators need to be tough and proactive
articles.summary: Rising awareness of online pornography harms, including strangulation content and deepfake imagery, prompted government pledges to ban depictions of choking and criminalise non-consensual deepfakes. Ofcom’s £1m fine to Belize-based AVS Group for inadequate age checks under the Online Safety Act signals enforcement. Yet 90 more platforms face scrutiny, and legal challenges from US-based forums threaten regulatory reach. Campaigners call for a “duty of candour,” proactive regulation and closing of legal gaps, especially to protect children from harmful AI “suicide coach” chatbots. Critics warn Ofcom must strengthen oversight on porn, racism and misinformation to maintain public trust and online safety.

articles.title: I realise now that my view on mental health overdiagnosis was divisive. We all need better evidence | Wes Streeting
articles.trailText: The surge in mental ill health is hugely distressing. That’s why I’ve commissioned a review to find out what’s driving it, says health secretary Wes Streeting
articles.summary: Health secretary Wes Streeting admits his off-the-cuff claim of mental health overdiagnosis overlooked the issue’s complexity amid a 50% rise in adult disorders since 1993, a 50% jump in young people’s referrals during the pandemic and a 13-fold increase in autism assessment waits. Conceding services are overstretched—109,000 children wait over a year for specialist care despite 50% more funding—he has convened a review led by Prof Peter Fonagy, Sir Simon Wessely and Prof Gillian Baird, backed by Mind, the Mental Health Foundation and others. While recruiting 7,000 extra staff, expanding NHS Talking Therapies, opening crisis units and school support, he insists on robust evidence to diagnose underlying drivers and shape effective policy.

articles.title: Ali Faqirzada is an Afghan refugee. He deserves to stay in America | Francine Prose
articles.trailText: In a more reasonable, more compassionate country, we would thank Ali Faqirzada for how much he has done on behalf of his people and our own
articles.summary: Afghan refugee and Bard College computer science student Ali Faqirzada, who aided U.S. and NATO women’s education initiatives, fled Taliban threats and applied for asylum on Long Island in October. Despite endorsements from local leaders and Bard’s president, he was detained by ICE at Delaney Hall, NJ, under restrictive new DHS asylum pauses targeting Afghans. His case has spurred broad advocacy—from New York officials to community vigils—against punitive immigration policies. Francine Prose urges a return to compassion and the reversal of these measures.

articles.title: Kids’ parties are hell on earth but may be the cure to the world’s ills | Emily Mulligan
articles.trailText: As society becomes increasingly weird, birthdays are a chance to build connection. Even if it means 300 attempts at conversation with other tired parents
articles.summary: Emily Mulligan describes the evolution of her children’s birthday parties from a simple pub get-together celebrating her to elaborate themed events driven by sugar feasts, balloon quotas and Pinterest-worthy décor. She details the parental scramble for gifts, the awkward small talk with strangers, the manic kids’ interactions and the rise of specialized catering (even sugar-free crimes). Despite the exhaustion—300 attempts at civil conversation, frenzied set-up and clean-up—Mulligan argues these gatherings mark children’s milestones, spark intergenerational connection and may counteract modern social isolation by forging lasting real-world relationships in a phone-mediated age.

articles.title: Messy, combative and intoxicatingly fierce – don’t write off Your Party just yet | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: Spending time with its activists, I’ve seen signs of a refreshing challenge to stale mainstream politics, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: At its fractious Liverpool founding conference, Your Party – born from disillusion with Labour’s rightward shift – displayed open factionalism between Corbynists and grassroots activists. Despite clashes over Zarah Sultana’s dominance, leadership models and membership rules, activists secured a member-led structure allowing dual affiliations. Sultana’s fiery anti-establishment speech and participatory sessions evoked 1970s Labour stirrings, while a YouGov poll shows 12% support amid volatile UK politics. With four MPs, potential electoral pacts with the Greens and a review of leadership, the party may endure to influence a hung parliament rather than fade away.

articles.title: Rightwingers are trying to destroy women’s right to vote | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Calls for disenfranchisement rest on a single assumption: that women’s citizenship is partial and conditional
articles.summary: Since Democrats’ election wins, fringe and mainstream rightwing figures—from extremist pastors Joel Webbon and Dale Partridge to influencers like Andrew Tate and theorist Helen Andrews—have revived calls to repeal the 19th Amendment, arguing women’s supposed intellectual, moral or biological inferiority (via religious doctrine, pseudoscience or open misogyny) disqualifies them from voting. Even political elites like Peter Thiel and Pete Hegseth echo these views. Although repeal is impossible, this coalition frames women’s full citizenship as conditional, scapegoating their political participation for societal ills and normalizing sexist bigotry.

articles.title: Watch Simon Cowell’s TV search for a new boyband – and see how our world has changed | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: Twenty years on, the social media-savvy contestants will have greater power. His brutal approach to judging them will have to change, too, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Two decades after launching his first TV talent show, Simon Cowell returns with Netflix’s The Next Act to form a new boyband. Emma Brockes notes Cowell’s awareness that Gen Z contestants, armed with social-media followings, will command more narrative control than auditionees of the mid-2000s. Having publicly apologised for his notorious harshness, Cowell now presents a softer image—complete with cameo family shots—and must modernise a stale TV format in a TikTok-driven music landscape. The piece questions whether his trademark incredulous persona can evolve into genuine warmth.

articles.title: Europe is holding the line against Trump’s and Putin’s plans for Ukraine. But it won’t be able to for ever | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: In the 21st-century imbalance of power, Europe and Nato have neither the arms nor the wealth to impel Russia or the US to take its peace settlement seriously, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Martin Kettle argues that Europe and NATO minus the US have repeatedly thwarted Trump’s and Putin’s attempts to strike a bilateral peace deal on Ukraine, but warns this resistance cannot last. The article describes a familiar cycle: Trump refuses further arms, courts Putin for a deal at Ukraine’s expense, Russia presses its offensive, and Europe scrambles to bolster Kyiv. Yet Europe lacks the military weight or economic leverage to force Russia or a US administration to accept a just settlement. If Washington withdraws fully, conflict will intensify and Europe faces an arduous, costly strategic recalibration without its longstanding US partner.

articles.title: Bruce Lehrmann an ‘inspiration’? Only to litigants whose cases have crashed and burned | Richard Ackland
articles.trailText: Lehrmann failed to retrieve what was left of his well-munched hat when he appealed against the defamation judgment that found he raped Brittany Higgins
articles.summary: Richard Ackland skewers Bruce Lehrmann’s self-styled “inspiration” narrative, noting his failed defamation bid against Channel 10 and Lisa Wilkinson over rape allegations by Brittany Higgins. Judge Michael Lee branded him a “poor witness” as Higgins’s cross-examination salvaged the truth defence. While Lehrmann pocketed nearly $500,000 in ABC and News Corp settlements, costs owed to Ten exceed $2m, yet he secured a cost-free appeal. Amid defamation fatigue, former allies like Bettina Arndt and News Corp have moved on. Lehrmann continues legal gambits—seeking public funds for ACT housing, Commonwealth-funded defence in a corruption probe, and potential High Court leave.

articles.title: The Guardian view on US-Russia talks on Ukraine: a warning to Europe to move faster on security cooperation | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Washington’s betrayal of its allies has been averted for now, but preparations must be made for a world where its support cannot be relied on
articles.summary: Editorial warns Europe to accelerate security cooperation as US under Trump proves unreliable. Trump’s bid to end the Ukraine war is driven by personal glory, offering Russia unfair concessions without Ukrainian input. Putin seeks territory and constraints on Ukrainian sovereignty, and US envoys have failed to press him. Ukraine’s interests are upheld by Zelensky, European allies, and UK PM Starmer’s “coalition of the willing,” but EU defense integration stalls. Europe must build autonomous capacity, as Republican-led US hostility to allied trade and defense warns against betting on transatlantic reassurance. Vague EU ambitions require urgent concrete deals.

articles.title: The Guardian view on a four-day week for teachers: a clever way to end the staffing crisis
articles.trailText: Editorial: England’s teacher shortage is fuelled by burnout and unpaid overtime. New working patterns would help without compromising results
articles.summary: England’s teacher shortage, driven by burnout and an average of 26 hours of unpaid overtime weekly, has left many schools without key subjects. The 4 Day Week Foundation proposes a four-day in-class schedule plus a flexible fifth day for marking and preparation, keeping schools open five days without reducing pupil contact. Early trials—Dixons’ nine-day fortnight boosting retention by 43% and Forest Gate’s four-and-a-half-day week improving results and morale—show protected time, smaller classes and basic healthcare are as valued as pay rises. With £1.25bn spent annually on supply cover, a structured shorter week could cut costs, boost retention and tackle the staffing crisis, if funding and reliable cover are secured.

articles.title: Letters. Text messages. Passwords and more passwords. Why can’t the NHS just give me someone to talk to? | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: I can forgive shabby hospitals, confusion over appointments, even doctors’ poor bedside manner, but all the apps in the world can’t replace a real person, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles recounts his exasperating NHS experience substituting letters, apps, passwords and generic call-centres for real-time dialogue with a clinician. He cycled through multiple platforms – text messages, DrDoctor and Patients Know Best portals – but never an avenue for two-way exchange. After a brisk consultation and potentially cancerous lesion excision, weeks passed with impersonal notifications and no results or human contact. Only a hastily arranged phone call with a skin cancer nurse delivered the benign squamous cell carcinoma outcome and a direct email link, underscoring Chiles’s plea for accessible personal communication in healthcare.

articles.title: Farage and the Tory right will unite because they want power. Will the left just stand by? | Neal Lawson
articles.trailText: It’s time for a harsh reality check. A progressive bloc of parties refusing to see a common threat risks disaster, says Neal Lawson of Compass
articles.summary: Neal Lawson argues that while Nigel Farage and the Tory right are poised to form an electoral alliance to overcome dispersed support and win power—Compass analysis shows their split cost them 202 seats in 2024—Britain’s progressive parties remain fragmented across Labour, Lib Dems, Greens, regional nationalists and independents. To resist, the left must abandon coercive ’least bad’ tactics, offer a clearly progressive platform (eg wealth taxes, asylum and jury reforms) and embrace pluralism, proportional representation and agile alliance-building to forge long-term consensus and transformative change.

articles.title: Cracks have emerged in the Maga coalition | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The Republican party is far from moving beyond Trump – but signals of his waning influence are everywhere
articles.summary: After a decade dominating the GOP, Trump’s grip is showing cracks: his approval is slipping, a federal court barred his appointee Alina Habba and conservative justices may strike down his tariffs. Indiana Republicans defied his redistricting push, and figures like Laura Ingraham, J.D. Vance and Ben Shapiro publicly disputed his economic claims. Revelations of Trump’s ties to Jeffrey Epstein have even alienated QAnon adherents and driven Marjorie Taylor Greene to break with him. As Democrats gain momentum and Trump’s charisma wanes, Republicans are quietly eyeing life—and power struggles—beyond the Maga era.

articles.title: The Sarah Everard report part two: a catalogue of repeated and preventable failures | Joan Smith
articles.trailText: So many reviews, so much hand-wringing, yet misogyny in England and Wales’s police forces and impunity for offenders remains the norm, says Joan Smith, former co-chair of the Mayor of London’s VAWG Board
articles.summary: In her second report, Lady Angiolini finds persistent misogyny and systemic lapses in English and Welsh police post-Sarah Everard’s murder: a non-retrospective ban on officers with sexual-offence convictions was agreed 18 months late; a quarter of forces lack basic rape-investigation policies; only nine criminal and 88 disciplinary probes followed 461 database referrals in 2023–24. VAWG efforts remain fragmented and underfunded, victims still face invasive scrutiny while perpetrators go unchallenged, and promised crime-prevention strategies have yet to materialise. Smith warns that this catalog of preventable failures follows decades of reactive reports—yet officials still treat violence against women as lower priority than terrorism, perpetuating impunity and victim-blaming.

articles.title: Trump is using a tragic shooting to demonize millions | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: The administration is heightening its anti-immigrant crackdown – and punishing people from a country the US helped destroy
articles.summary: After an Afghan national and former CIA-backed ‘Zero Unit’ operative allegedly ambushed two US National Guard members, killing one, Trump seized the tragedy to demand a permanent ban on Third World migration, strip naturalized citizens’ rights and end all non-citizen benefits. His deputy Stephen Miller echoed a ‘mass migration’ threat narrative. Bazzi argues this hate-filled response ignores US responsibility for Afghanistan’s collapse and the ‘blowback’ from two decades of wars, paramilitary abuses and repeated interventions that displaced millions and fueled the very violence now used to justify a harsher anti-immigrant agenda.

articles.title: Can you be on a six-figure income and still be considered poor? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: A viral essay has caused outrage in the US with its argument that the poverty line for a family of four is now $136,500. But is this so wrong, asks Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi examines a viral Substack essay by asset manager Michael Green claiming the US poverty line for a family of four should be $136,500, far above the official $31,200 benchmark. Critics argue his figure exceeds the $83,730 median household income and mislabels middle-class status as poverty. Mahdawi concedes flaws in his methodology but says the debate underscores plain realities: soaring housing, childcare and healthcare costs make even six-figure earners feel financially squeezed, fueling broader economic discontent.

articles.title: Fear of facing the future has British politics stuck in the past | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer and Rachel Reeves claim to be dealing with the world as it is, but seem to yearn for a world that has disappeared, says the Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rafael Behr likens British politics to Hollywood’s safe sequels, arguing both Labour and the Conservatives recycle past scripts instead of pioneering fresh ideas. Rachel Reeves’s “Budget II” echoes last year’s fiscal play, clinging to manifesto pledges while hiking taxes, and Kemi Badenoch resorts to age-old Tory rhetoric on welfare and immigration. Keir Starmer’s 1990s-style strategy and Reeves’s cautious “securonomics” lack a bold growth vision, while his equidistant foreign policy downplays looming geopolitical shocks, leaving the UK stranded in nostalgia.

articles.title: I have a lifelong connection to Victoria’s state library – which is why I am aghast at its crude self-lobotomy | Gideon Haigh
articles.trailText: If the ‘suits’ can come for the State Library of Victoria, they can come for anyone, and no public institution is safe
articles.summary: Gideon Haigh, a longtime State Library of Victoria devotee, criticises a management proposal to cut nearly 40 staff, halving reference librarians to just 10 despite 3 million annual visits. He warns that anonymous corporate-style ‘Strategic Reorganisation’ gambles the library’s core research services and treats books as scenery, replacing expert-led guidance with events and digital gimmicks like a Ned Kelly “web experience.” With a CEO accountant at the helm and the beloved cafe lease handed to a chain, Haigh argues this self-lobotomy endangers public institutions everywhere.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s plan to cut jury trials: it's wrong to remove a pillar of British justice | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Instead of rebuilding a cash-starved system, ministers propose removing protections. The country needs investment, not the hollowing out of justice
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy’s plan would strip defendants’ right to opt for jury trials in ‘either-way’ cases with likely sentences under three years, replacing juries with judges alone and reserving lay verdicts for only the most serious crimes. The Guardian warns this sweeping change misrepresents Sir Brian Leveson’s call for bench trials combining judges and magistrates, undermines a centuries-old safeguard, and ignores that backlogs stem from austerity-driven court closures, staff cuts, legal aid and CPS shortages. Magistrates already juggle 361,000 pending cases and prisons are bursting. True reform demands reinvestment in courts, judges, legal aid, digital forensics and CPS resources, not eroding civic participation.

articles.title: The Guardian view on policing: the lesson of Sarah Everard’s murder is that a culture of impunity must be stamped out | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Angiolini inquiry and a new report on Hillsborough make the need for new laws and higher standards in police forces brutally clear
articles.summary: Sarah Everard’s abduction and murder by serving officer Wayne Couzens revealed police neglect of his earlier sex crimes. Lady Angiolini’s report calls public sexual violence a “whole-society problem”, demands national Project Vigilant and Operation Soteria rollouts, data collection, early intervention, education, planning for women’s safety, and culture reforms. An IOPC Hillsborough inquiry exposing 12 officers’ misconduct and cover-up further underscores the need to overhaul policing laws, culture and accountability.

articles.title: Won’t somebody please think of Britain’s poor £2m homeowners? Oh, wait – everyone already is | Jonathan Liew
articles.trailText: Contrast the furious reaction to Rachel Reeves’s ‘mansion tax’ to the response offered to those living with real housing injustice: indifference, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves’s new mansion tax on homes over £2m has prompted a media frenzy and plaintive outcry from affluent owners worried about council surcharges, yet their privileged complaints eclipse deeper housing injustices. In Tyldesley, Wigan, modest homeowners watch 18m‐high warehouses go up metres from their gardens, triggering damage and relentless noise with no media or policy attention. Elsewhere students endure soaring rents, new buyers live on half‐built estates and elderly tenants cope with failing lifts. Liew argues this skewed public discourse privileges the wealthy, leaving systemic housing inequality unaddressed.

articles.title: Ellen DeGeneres left Trump's America. Will the British weather force her to return? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: She’s far from the only celebrity to have declared her intention to live outside the US. As with many others though, it looks like a reverse ferret could be in the works, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi critiques Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi’s move to the Cotswolds after Trump’s 2016 victory, noting their vow to stay in "sane" Britain may falter in winter gloom. She contrasts their fairweather exile with celebs like Amy Schumer, Miley Cyrus and Barbra Streisand who threatened to leave but stayed, and true expats like Courtney Love (seeking UK citizenship) and Rosie O'Donnell (moved to Ireland for her non-binary child amid Trump’s threats). Mahdawi warns that fleeing creeping fascism only to retreat from cold undermines street cred – a phenomenon mirrored in a broader brain drain of scientists and experts.

articles.title: John Roberts has badly weakened our democracy. Will he ever stand up to Trump? | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: Under the chief justice, the US supreme court has bolstered authoritarian agendas while undercutting the voice of voters
articles.summary: Chief Justice John Roberts, despite vows of impartiality, has led a right-wing judicial revolution that has weakened American democracy by: authorizing extreme partisan gerrymandering (Rucho v Common Cause); dismantling campaign finance limits (orchestrating Citizens United); eviscerating the Voting Rights Act (Shelby County v Holder and pending Section 2 challenges); enabling sweeping presidential immunity (Trump v United States); curbing Congress’s spending power; and threatening independent agencies’ autonomy. Critics liken him to Roger Taney. Greenhouse urges Roberts to begin reining in Trump, citing his rare rebuke of unlawful tariffs as a hopeful sign.

articles.title: It’s entirely reasonable to be in awe of surgeons – but patients need someone they can talk to | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: Technical prowess must not come at the cost of good bedside manner – and being able to balance facts with empathy
articles.summary: Oncologist Ranjana Srivastava argues that while patients rightly revere surgeons’ technical skill, they also need empathy, clear communication and shared decision-making. Studies show patients value emotional support, optimism, plain-language information and decision aids, plus honest discussions of quality-of-life trade-offs and prognosis. A multidisciplinary team—from nursing and allied health to palliative care—ensures holistic care. Surgeons should balance facts with compassion, elicit patient values and hone communication skills. In one case, understanding an 87-year-old’s priorities led her to decline a radical surgery, exemplifying patient-centered care.

articles.title: Reeves and Starmer are a two-for-one deal - if she goes, he goes. What a cheering thought | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: It’s week two of budget black-hole gate. When will it all end? Probably after the May elections, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde skewers the government’s budget “black hole” chaos: after the OBR’s draft forecast leaked via an insecure WordPress site and its chair resigned, doubts swirl over whether Chancellor Rachel Reeves misled Britain about a £4.2bn deficit that may have been a surplus. Meanwhile PM Keir Starmer doubles down on Labour unity—scrapping the two-child benefit cap, expanding free childcare and defending his chancellor—yet critics warn both lack coherent strategy, waiting for poor local election results to topple their “package deal.” Hyde paints Reeves as hapless and Starmer as rhetorically inert, calling for genuine mission-driven leadership.

articles.title: AI poses unprecedented threats. Congress must act now | Bernie Sanders
articles.trailText: Despite the speed at which it is progressing, AI is getting far too little discussion in Congress, the media and within the general population. That has got to change
articles.summary: Sen. Bernie Sanders warns that rapid AI and robotics advances pose unprecedented threats to economy, democracy, privacy, environment, labor and even human identity. He highlights that a few tech billionaires—Musk, Gates, Zuckerberg and others—dominate AI’s future, urging democratic oversight to prevent oligarchic control. Citing potential replacement of 100m US jobs, risks of mass surveillance, ecological strain from power-hungry data centers, AI-driven warfare and emotional isolation, Sanders calls for Congress to adopt specific regulations and ensure AI benefits all, not just the wealthy, while averting existential dangers.

articles.title: What the story of eight-year-old Lati-Yana Brown tells us about Britain’s callous disregard for Caribbean people | Nadine White
articles.trailText: From enslavement to Windrush to Hurricane Melissa, there is a clear pattern to the way Britain has extracted wealth and fractured families, says journalist and film-maker Nadine White
articles.summary: Journalist Nadine White spotlights eight-year-old Lati-Yana Brown’s post-Hurricane Melissa destitution in Jamaica and the UK Home Office’s erroneous visa refusal—despite her UK-based parents’ appeals and MP Dawn Butler’s intervention—as symptomatic of Britain’s enduring exploitation of Caribbean families. Tracing a lineage from slavery’s child separations, unpaid slave-owner reparations and Windrush injustices to restrictive post-1971 immigration laws, she warns these policies perpetuate intergenerational trauma and urges emergency visa relief, reparative action and swift family reunification.

articles.title: Why did I ever buy my kids refillable advent calendars? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Twenty-four tiny drawers of fun stuff sounds delightful – but not when you’re the one filling the thing, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams recalls buying Scandi-style refillable Advent calendars for her kids to avoid sugar overload and balance gifts between two households. She struggles annually to fill 24 tiny drawers equally—one year with batteries (rejected as “boring”), another with unisex lip balm, minis swear-word cards and whistles. Despite meticulous July planning some years—and an abundance of erasers—she forgot this December, quipping she now needs “72 reptile eggs” to make amends.

articles.title: The White House’s new media ‘bias’ tracker is a desperate gimmick | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: The site isn’t exposing misleading reporting – it’s revealing the bubble Trump increasingly inhabits
articles.summary: Margaret Sullivan critiques the White House’s new media “bias tracker” as a transparent stunt to deflect increasingly negative coverage of President Trump. Alongside personal jabs—calling reporters “piggy,” “terrible,” and “ugly”—and threats to sue the BBC, the site’s Hall of Shame singles out outlets like Boston Globe and CBS for exposing Trump’s demand to prosecute six Democrats over a video urging troops to refuse illegal orders. Sullivan argues the tracker exposes Trump’s isolation in a MAGA echo chamber and desperate need to shift blame as his approval dips to 38% with midterms approaching. She warns this gimmick won’t sway a skeptical public.

articles.title: It is not too late to put the brakes on assisted dying, and focus on what is really needed | Gordon Brown
articles.trailText: Palliative care is deeply underfunded and unequal. Assisted dying cannot go ahead until politicians right that wrong, says former UK prime minister Gordon Brown
articles.summary: Gordon Brown warns that England and Wales’s assisted dying legislation is premature while palliative care is deeply underfunded. Citing National Audit Office and Hospice UK data—380 hospice beds idle, 60% ending deficits, 310,000 patients plateaued—he urges MPs and the Lords to delay implementation until end-of-life services are strengthened, contracts formalised and funding secured. He highlights geographic, socioeconomic and ethnic disparities, notes divergence between UK and Scottish bills, and calls for coordinated consultations. A Care Not Killing poll shows 65% back prioritising palliative care before assisted dying.

articles.title: It’s under fire from left and right – but Labour’s workers' rights bill is a huge achievement | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: It makes no sense for union leaders to cry betrayal when it will be their members who benefit from these sorely needed reforms, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Labour’s flagship employment rights bill, championed by Angela Rayner, survived Tory opposition in the Lords by replacing day-one unfair dismissal protection with a six-month qualifying period—an improvement on today’s two-year wait. It curbs zero-hours shift cancellations, guarantees sick pay from day one, introduces new parental leave and flexible-working rights, and enables sector-wide fair pay agreements and union access to workplaces. Despite union leaders’ protests over dilution, TUC and employer talks averted delays that a parliament act would incur. Popular public backing and lower-paid worker advocacy group support signal this as a rare, once-in-a-generation reshaping of work power dynamics.

articles.title: The most misleading thing about Rachel Reeves’s budget? Who it was really for | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: Labour backbenchers have been cheering it as a win for the most vulnerable in society. In fact it was aimed at the bond markets, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty argues that Rachel Reeves’s autumn budget was pitched as a reluctant response to grim Office for Budget Responsibility forecasts, but in reality its main purpose was to reassure bond investors. Of the extra £26 billion a year in taxes from 2029, only around 17% fund new spending, while over half serves as a fiscal buffer and a quarter covers policy U-turns. By framing choices as forced, Reeves sidelines democratic accountability and sustains the same market-driven model, exposing a Westminster ‘uniparty’ disconnected from voters’ needs.

articles.title: The opening of Melbourne’s Metro Tunnel has turned me into a shameless train ambassador | Brodie Lancaster
articles.trailText: After eight years, $15bn and endless disruptions, seeing people flood the new platforms feels like a true reopening of the city
articles.summary: Brodie Lancaster, critic and columnist, describes how Melbourne’s $15bn Metro Tunnel project transformed her into an enthusiastic ‘train ambassador.’ After years of construction, disruptions and lockdowns, she marked the public soft launch on her calendar, tracked naming contests for tunnel boring machines, and followed government updates. On opening day, she joined thousands of locals exploring the four new underground stations—characterized by uniform modern design, long escalators and Patricia Piccinini artworks—collecting themed merch and applause. Lancaster contrasts the fresh infrastructure with the stately City Loop and Sydney Metro’s aesthetic, celebrating the tunnel as a symbolic reopening of Melbourne, uniting commuters and reviving hidden parts of the city.

articles.title: The Guardian view on OBR v the Treasury: ministers have embraced the theatre of errors | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The government is trapped between Labour’s instincts and bond traders’ demands. Sensible fixes exist, but require imagination ministers have yet shown
articles.summary: An overblown row over the OBR’s medium-term forecasts highlights the absurdity of treating a projected £20bn current-budget surplus in 2029-30 as gospel when the watchdog itself admits frequent errors in inflation and productivity estimates. Labour’s leadership has bound itself to this fiscal rule to placate bond markets, forcing a self-imposed austerity straitjacket at odds with MPs’ spending ambitions. Meanwhile Britain’s economy remains depressed, necessitating a deficit to avoid higher unemployment. Sensible alternatives—taxing banks’ rate windfalls, tiering reserve bank remuneration, ending QE indemnities—could boost revenues without social harm, but demand political imagination absent so far.

articles.title: The Guardian view on men’s health: the needs of different groups can only be addressed in a functioning system | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The specific health issues faced by boys and men deserve attention. But waiting lists stand in the way of improvement
articles.summary: Men’s average life expectancy in the UK trails women’s by four years, with men accounting for three-quarters of suicides and higher rates of smoking, obesity, accidental deaths and prostate cancer. The government’s new men’s health strategy, led by Health Secretary Wes Streeting, earmarks £300m for community projects, a GP funding review to target deprived areas, enhanced sex-disaggregated data, walking/running campaigns, peer support networks and a Men’s Health Academic Network. A £42m prostate screening trial is under way. However, long NHS waiting lists and reorganisation risk blunting its impact.

articles.title: Your Party's antics assume a luxury the left does not have: time | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: Legal spats, public denunciations and an obsession with internal process must be consigned to the past, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Your Party, launched in July with 800,000 sign-ups amid soaring radical-left interest, squandered momentum in public spats between founders Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana. Threats of legal action, factional expulsions and anonymous leaks overshadowed its Liverpool launch conference of 2,500 delegates. In-fighting between SWP militants and "Democratic Socialists," debates over dual membership and calls for a 20-member collective leadership repelled non-activists and drove some radicals toward the resurgent Greens. Corbyn’s unpolished, non-dogmatic socialism clashed with Sultana’s militant platform—nationalisation, NATO withdrawal, full Israel divestment—and a social-media strategy echoing New York’s new left. With climate, economic collapse and far-right threats looming, the party risks self-immolation unless it overcomes sectarian drama.

articles.title: I needed new bras but what really lifted me up was a moment of connection with my bra fitter | Jodi Wilson
articles.trailText: These fleeting human interactions are an antidote to loneliness in an increasingly online world
articles.summary: On a work trip to Melbourne, journalist Jodi Wilson visits a department-store bra fitter and experiences more than a proper fit: Debbie’s steadying hand and empathetic advice amid perimenopausal changes become a moment of genuine human connection. Wilson reflects on how such brief, caring interactions in retail—now eroded by online shopping—provide comfort, stability and early mental-health support against loneliness. She argues that these casual encounters are essential doses of care in an increasingly isolated, AI-driven world.

articles.title: ‘Conversion therapy’ is homophobic and dangerous. Yet it threatens to make a comeback | David Kirp
articles.trailText: Bans on the dangerous practice, condemned by national mental health organizations, could soon be struck down
articles.summary: Despite unanimous condemnation by major mental health bodies and bans in 23 states, conversion therapy—a discredited, homophobic practice linked to depression, anxiety, drug use, homelessness and suicide among LGBTQ+ youth—is poised for a comeback. The US Supreme Court is weighing whether state bans unlawfully restrict free speech, with a conservative majority signalling they may strike them down. Survivors’ testimonies highlight lasting harm. Critics link this resurgence to the Trump administration’s rollback of LGBTQ+ protections and call for unified resistance.

articles.title: Tired of being a woman in 2025? Why not become a nun… | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Nuns are having a moment. It’s not the religion women crave, however – it’s a sense of purpose, community and peace, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Nuns are having a moment as symbols of refuge from the pressures of womanhood in 2025: online and onscreen portrayals—from Isabella Rossellini’s Sister Agnes in Conclave to #nuntok—showcase community, purpose and peace over strict religiosity. Memes and media reflect dissatisfaction with unsolicited dick pics, workplace bias and soul–sapping scrolling. Modern women crave single-sex solidarity and calm retreats akin to medieval beguines. Emma Beddington cites Convent Wisdom, a self-help book on sixteenth-century nuns who asserted autonomy under male authority, endured mystical visions and bilocated, inspiring readers with resilience, financial savvy and pursuit of serenity—even if levitation remains an aspirational #fitnessgoal.

articles.title: The US love of football is reaching new levels. Just look at Arsenal super-fan Zohran Mamdani | Bryan Armen Graham
articles.trailText: The New York mayor-elect’s devotion to a north London club shows how the global game is winning hearts across the US, says Bryan Armen Graham, deputy sport editor of Guardian US
articles.summary: New York mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s delighted reaction to an Ian Wright video highlights how football fandom in the US has matured from a niche, coastal immigrant pastime into a mainstream, cross-class, multi-ethnic cultural force. His Arsenal devotion—shaped by both the club’s African spine of Kanu, Lauren and Touré and its early-2000s Wenger-era 'European' sophistication—reflects a broader convergence of curated and inherited fandom, fueled by diaspora ties, social media, Premier League marketing and next year’s home World Cup. His campaign against FIFA’s dynamic pricing underscores soccer’s view as community infrastructure over commercial spectacle.

articles.title: Hello, foreign oligarchs and corporations! Please come and sue the UK for billions | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: The case of a planned Cumbrian coalmine shows how governments around the world are being threatened by litigation in shadowy offshore courts, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Monbiot warns that foreign multinationals and oligarchs are suing the UK through secret ‘investor-state dispute settlement’ tribunals—offshore courts with no appeal—that can award billions in hypothetical profit damages. A Cayman Islands–owned firm has launched an ISDS claim against the government over the blocked Whitehaven coal mine after a high court victory and licence withdrawal; MP Geoffrey Cox represents it. Meanwhile, Russian oligarch Mikhail Fridman is suing over UK sanctions. With fossil fuel investors winning $84 bn via ISDS, governments worldwide are chilling climate action. Despite zero evidence ISDS boosts investment, the UK quietly seeks similar treaty clauses—Monbiot calls for public resistance.

articles.title: It's not just Gaza. From the West Bank to Syria and Lebanon, Israel's onslaught continues | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: Broken ceasefires, bombing, ground incursions and mounting deaths: Israeli imperialism is now expanding across the region, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik argues that Israel’s so-called Gaza ceasefire is merely a “reducefire,” with near-daily strikes killing over 300 Palestinians and blocking vital aid since 10 October. She warns this lull masks a broader campaign: an intensifying military siege, settler violence, mass displacement and extrajudicial executions in the West Bank; cross-border raids into southern Syria using colonial tactics; and near-daily bombings and ceasefire breaches in Lebanon. This regional onslaught, she contends, leaves no path to genuine peace.

articles.title: I’m a Guardian journalist who has covered Victoria police’s new search powers. On Sunday, police searched me | Lisa Favazzo
articles.trailText: I was covering Sunday’s Put Australia First Rally in Melbourne’s CBD when two officers approached, explaining the process as though reciting a script
articles.summary: Multimedia journalist Lisa Favazzo recounts her own experience of Victoria police’s new ‘designated area’ search powers when covering Melbourne’s Put Australia First rally. Minutes after the zone was declared, two female officers stopped and informed her—via scripted explanation—that they could pat down anyone without warrant or suspicion. They metal-detected and inspected her camera gear before ending the brief search once her colleague produced a Guardian media pass. Favazzo highlights concerns raised by rights groups over this broad power’s potential for bias or hostile encounters.

articles.title: There are those on the left and right who offer only grievance: Labour is getting on with the job of economic renewal | Keir Starmer
articles.trailText: Judge last week’s budget in the light of our bold plans to sweep away red tape, tackle inactivity among young people and pursue a closer trading relationship with the EU, says prime minister Keir Starmer
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer argues last week’s budget made fair choices—cutting energy bills by £150, removing the two-child benefit cap, protecting NHS funding and taxing wealth—driving down inflation and stabilising bond yields. Building on £120bn in infrastructure investment, planning reforms, airport expansions and new trade deals, he vows to sweep away red tape, reform welfare to support disadvantaged young people, and pursue closer EU ties. Rejecting both a borrowing spree and a return to austerity, Labour’s mission is long-term economic renewal of growth, communities and state.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Send crisis: Bridget Phillipson must be tough with the Treasury so children aren’t penalised | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Tory special needs reforms upended council finances, but Labour’s plan to rebuild public provision won’t come cheap if it’s done properly
articles.summary: England’s special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) system faces financial and legal breakdown after unfunded Tory reforms saddled councils with obligations they cannot meet, pushing projected overspends to £6.6 billion by March. The Guardian urges Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson to reassign funding to the Department for Education, publish a comprehensive white paper on education, health and care plans and tribunal reform, and secure Treasury support. Labour’s approach prioritizes inclusive mainstream schooling but must tackle diverse needs, rebuild public specialist provision to forestall private equity capture, recognize the complex, resource-intensive nature of lasting reform, and commit to lifting children out of poverty.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the inequality emergency: why a Nobel prize winner’s warning must be heeded | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Rising economic division is destabilising nations and eroding accountability. Joseph Stiglitz’s G20 blueprint offers a way toward global economic renewal
articles.summary: Joseph Stiglitz warns global inequality is an emergency that buys policy access and destabilises societies. G20’s first inequality report finds the richest 1% captured 41% of new wealth since 2000 while the bottom half gained 1%, and 2.3 billion people face food insecurity. The US and UK top G7 inequality rankings. Policy choices—deregulation, weakened labour rights, privatisation and tax cuts—drive disparity, democratic backsliding and climate harm. Stiglitz rejects the growth-through-inequality thesis, urging a Bretton Woods-style overhaul of IP, trade, tax and debt rules and creation of an International Panel on Inequality to unite facts and guide reform.

articles.title: The ‘squeezed middle’ is back – and this time it could be Labour’s undoing | John Harris
articles.trailText: Last week’s budget left middle-income families anxious and angry. The party is turning its back on voters it can little afford to lose, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: John Harris warns that last week’s budget freezes on tax thresholds and ‘smorgasbord’ levies intensify the pinch on the ‘squeezed middle’—nurses, teachers, police and £50k earners facing stagnant incomes (<0.5% annual disposable growth to 2030) and stealth tax hikes. Coupled with severe SEND funding gaps, stretched councils and public service cuts, Labour’s focus on red wall appeal risks alienating its suburban base hungry for cost-of-living relief and robust local services.

articles.title: How can we navigate difficult conversations these holidays? Buddhism offers some guidance | Making sense of it
articles.trailText: Choosing to bring intentionality to our speech challenges our tendency to abandon and disconnect from those we do not agree with
articles.summary: Dr Nadine Levy argues Buddhism reframes difficult holiday conversations as opportunities for radical communal care rather than battlegrounds. Beyond formal meditation, everyday speech should follow the Eightfold Path’s wise speech—timely, true, gentle, beneficial, loving—and stem from clarity, not fear, ego or passive aggression. Drawing on interpersonal neurobiology and Gilligan’s ethics of care, she urges self-awareness, timing and trust to co-regulate relationships, soften polarization and clarify values. When we speak intentionally and courageously—even on social media—we sow safety, solidarity and integrity, transforming conflicts into deeper connection and collective well-being.

articles.title: China is bearing down on Taiwan – enabled by Trump’s weakness and vacillation | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The US hasn’t just left Ukraine vulnerable; it is also provoking Xi’s intensifying attitude towards what he considers a renegade province, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall argues that China’s leadership, blinded by propaganda, underestimates Taiwanese commitment to democracy and is escalating an “anaconda strategy” of military drills, economic coercion, diplomatic isolation, cyber-operations and disinformation to force capitulation without war. President Lai Ching-te warns of intensifying annexation pressure. Meanwhile, Japan’s rightwing PM Sanae Takaichi’s call to defend Taiwan triggered sanctions and military posturing in a China–Japan crisis. Donald Trump’s erratic trade-first diplomacy—imposing then lifting tariffs, seeking a Beijing visit without formal Taiwan assurances—deepens Taipei and Tokyo’s doubts about US reliability, emboldening Xi who leverages rare-earth export curbs to press US acceptance of One China.

articles.title: Don’t filter your dates by age and hobbies, ask them how they shop | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Big deal-breakers are all very well, but the seemingly small things often tell in the end. How do they feel about sell-by dates? Will they walk out of a bad film? Not asking will come back to haunt you, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson argues that instead of filtering partners by age or hobbies, daters should tackle seemingly trivial but revealing lifestyle preferences—airport arrival habits, tolerance for a bad movie, grocery shopping styles, food-expiry strictness, Christmas decor timing and even reaction to distant conversation. Referencing a Plenty of Fish report on a 2026 shift toward upfront deal-breaker discussions, she warns these small-talk topics can erode relationships more than major issues. Yet even the frankest early conversations can’t predict every quirk—her husband’s 15-year feud over takeaway coffee cups illustrates the limits of pre-dating disclosures.

articles.title: What Rosa Parks can teach us about resistance today | Jan-Werner Mueller
articles.trailText: Rosa Park’s story is about courage. But, lest one forget, it is also a story about breaking the law
articles.summary: Mueller argues that Rosa Parks’s famed bus protest was no spur-of-the-moment act but the product of her NAACP activism since 1943, coordinated organizing, and a 381-day boycott fueled by pamphlets and private taxis. He draws on John Rawls’s definition of civil disobedience—public, non-violent, conscientious political speech paired with acceptance of punishment—and warns that today’s fragmented media, right-wing distortions, and the Trump administration’s politicized prosecutions and threats against dissent make such principled resistance harder to execute and less likely to persuade authorities or the public.

articles.title: When it comes to alcohol, gambling and domestic violence in Australia, it’s essential we connect the dots | Zoe Daniel
articles.trailText: What is happening behind closed doors in your street while the game is on, the grog is flowing and the bets are failing?
articles.summary: Zoe Daniel argues that Australia’s domestic violence crisis is exacerbated by the “toxic trio” of sport, alcohol and gambling. With 74 women killed last year and police attending incidents every two minutes, services remain underfunded, forcing survivors into motels. Studies show problem gambling triples intimate-partner violence, especially during major sporting events. Despite a federal review recommending bans on gambling ads, alcohol restrictions and limits on poker machines, political inaction persists amid calls for a conscience vote.

articles.title: Trump keeps insulting female journalists | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Trump has a disconcerting tendency to attack the press – but especially female reporters, whom he holds in particular ire
articles.summary: Over Thanksgiving, Trump used Truth Social to lob an ableist slur at Minnesota’s governor and an Islamophobic jab at Rep. Ilhan Omar, then publicly called a female reporter “stupid” when asked about a DC National Guard attack. In recent weeks he has repeatedly insulted women journalists—calling New York Times reporter Katie Rogers “ugly,” ABC’s Mary Bruce “a terrible person,” and Bloomberg’s Catherine Lucey “piggy”—a pattern echoed by his communications director. Critics, including his niece Mary Trump, say these gendered attacks reveal his comfort with misogyny, growing anxiety, and pose a threat to press freedom.

articles.title: The Russia-Ukraine peace deal is not a loss. Nor is it a victory | Stephen Wertheim
articles.trailText: The conflict is neither a clearcut defeat nor a feelgood victory, but an in-between outcome that contains profound elements of each
articles.summary: Stephen Wertheim argues that a prospective Russia-Ukraine settlement is a mixed outcome: not a defeat nor full victory. He notes the US 28-point plan offers Ukraine strong military autonomy and unprecedented security guarantees but concedes territory. History shows Washington’s refusal to accept partial wins or losses in Vietnam, Afghanistan, Gulf War prolonged conflicts. Ukraine should accept a “dirty deal” preserving its remarkable resilience and deterrence while minimizing further devastation, rather than chasing moral absolutes. Total security via NATO is unrealistic, so Kyiv must rely on its own strength and realistic external support.

articles.title: What Chicago's fight against ICE can teach us all about how to resist oppression | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: A harrowing US podcast documents a community’s struggle against immigration raids – and warns us about herd mentality, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: In Rogers Park, Chicago, residents formed Protect Rogers Park to shield undocumented immigrants from ICE’s new raids on schools, churches and hospitals under Trump. They deploy nonviolent tactics—walking in front of agents, coded whistle alerts and rapid community call lines—to warn and slow deportations. The podcast Criminal reframes the federal government as the true “criminal” breaching law. Columnist Zoe Williams warns against herd mentality and argues that resisting xenophobic policies early is key to preventing authoritarian drift. Drawing on Hannah Arendt’s notion of synchronisation, she connects these actions to broader threats of enforced conformity under authoritarian regimes.

articles.title: What could be putting young women off marriage? It really isn’t that much of a mystery | Naoise Dolan
articles.trailText: Survey data suggests more and more girls can’t imagine getting married, while their male counterparts are keener. That disparity holds a clue, says writer Naoise Dolan
articles.summary: Post-pandemic marriage rates in England and Wales have fallen nearly 9% while civil partnerships rose comparably; US data show similar declines. The Vatican’s 40-page note ‘Una Caro’ defends monogamy. A University of Michigan survey finds only 61% of high-school girls versus 74% of boys hope to wed. Naoise Dolan argues women are deterred by unrealistic male expectations, the proliferation of "situationships," and objections to marriage’s legal coercion—tax incentives, hospital visitation rights and exclusion of non-monogamous or communal relationships. Financial instability, pandemic-era care burdens and the reframing of marriage as an economic capstone further shift young women away from tying the knot.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Ukraine peace talks: Putin is taking Trump for another ride on the Kremlin carousel | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Russia’s president is only interested in a deal on Moscow’s terms. Equipping Kyiv with the resources to fight on is the quickest route to a just settlement
articles.summary: Editorial warns Putin sees Trump’s expired Thanksgiving deadline as leverage to impose a Moscow-centric settlement on Ukraine, demanding further eastern territory and rejecting any ceasefire that secures Ukrainian sovereignty. Kremlin signals show Russia prefers battlefield attrition or a Trump-brokered deal over genuine negotiations. Meanwhile Andriy Yermak’s resignation deepens Kyiv’s vulnerability. The Guardian urges Europe to counter this by swiftly supplying robust financial and military aid—potentially via frozen-asset reparations, EU funds or joint borrowing—to strengthen Ukraine’s negotiating position and dissuade both Putin and Trump from a cynical carve-up.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Turner and Constable: radical in different ways | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Capturing the changing landscapes of the 18th century, the rivals transformed British art. The climate emergency gives new urgency to their work
articles.summary: Marking Turner and Constable’s 250th anniversaries, Tate Britain’s first dual exhibition frames them as rival radicals: Turner, daring with dramatic seascapes, steam trains and abolitionist critiques; Constable, revolutionary for elevating bucolic scenes and common life above classical themes. Both captured technological, political and environmental upheavals of their age—echoed today in works by George Shaw, David Hockney, Emma Stibbon and Olafur Eliasson—and survive reappraisals from abolitionist reframings of Turner’s Slave Ship to Peter Kennard’s anti-nuclear Hay Wain. Their art’s resonance underlines its urgency amid the climate emergency, inviting fresh perspectives on familiar masterpieces.

articles.title: Antisemitism allegations against the teenage Farage matter – look at what he went on to do | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: Farage has cosied up to US figures who espoused conspiracy theories about Jews. That kind of talk is becoming alarmingly mainstream on the Maga right, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland examines allegations from over 20 former schoolmates that Nigel Farage taunted Jewish peers with Nazi chants and gas jokes, highlighting his evasive, shifting denials. Freedland links this troubled youth record to Farage’s adult politics—repeated use of antisemitic tropes (‘globalists,’ George Soros, cultural Marxists), nods to conspiracy theories alongside figures like Alex Jones and Rick Wiles—and recalls rebukes from the Board of Deputies and CST. He warns this mirrors a broader MAGA-era turn toward conspiracy-driven antisemitism and aggressive Christian nationalism, a trend that puts global Jewish communities at risk and haunts Farage’s bid for power.

articles.title: Congratulations everyone! Starmer survives another week, and it’s only cost us £26bn | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Labour can proudly say this was a budget for working people – that is, if your job happens to be prime minister, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde skewers Labour’s latest budget, accusing Starmer’s government of a “buy-one-get-one-free” manifesto U-turn by scrapping day-one unfair dismissal rights for workers while preserving them for MPs until 2029. Deputy PM Angela Rayner, now resigned over tax controversies and rumored ITV stint, watches backbench malcontents extract more concessions. Business Secretary Peter Kyle claims the switch honors a non-existent “compromise” pledge. Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s tax-raising Budget piled on another £26bn, prompting IFS warnings of stagnating growth. Hyde argues the exercise was less about policy than placating backbenchers to keep Starmer safe ahead of May.

articles.title: Juries make baffling, flawed, human decisions. That's why we must keep them | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: David Lammy’s plans for justice on the cheap risk cutting the public out of the legal system – which will only hit confidence even more, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff warns that Justice Secretary David Lammy’s plan to scrap jury trials for all but the most serious offences threatens public confidence in the legal system. While juries can err, their diversity, transparency and peer representation bolster legitimacy and guard against biased judges or politicised courts. The real culprit behind delays is chronic underfunding of courts and allied services, not juries—Leveson’s cost-driven proposals free 20% of sitting time but fail to address backlogs rooted in budget cuts and growing case complexity.

articles.title: David Lammy is right to slash the use of juries – it’s an open-and-shut case | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: Barristers and criminals may not like the idea, but it’s key to reforming Britain’s antiquated and overloaded justice system, says the Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins argues that Britain’s jury system is an archaic drag on an overburdened courts system, with 80,000-case backlogs and two-year rape trial delays. He welcomes Justice Secretary David Lammy’s plan to limit juries to grave offences and shift most cases to judge-only trials, echoing Leveson’s recommendations. Highlighting that most European jurisdictions already rely on professional judges with lower prison rates, Jenkins criticizes the costly, performative rituals of jury service and the outdated barrister-solicitor split. He urges modernizing UK justice, prioritizing expertise, efficiency, and restorative approaches over spectacle and retribution.

articles.title: Why Starmer’s desire to govern as ‘Mr Rules’ is bound to fail | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: In the face of multiple crises, disruptive technology and populism, making Britain orderly again is an impossible goal, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: Andy Beckett argues that Keir Starmer’s rule-fixated Labour is failing to lift polls because voters reject its sober, rigid agenda amid fluid crises. Communication gaps, minor scandals and weakened state capacity hinder enforcement of fiscal, immigration and protest rules. Public fears shift constantly—fueled by right-wing rhetoric—and remain drawn to radical or populist figures promising change or entertainment. In a digital, disruptive era, restoring order alone won’t inspire. Labour may need a more agile, less obsessively disciplinarian leadership to reconnect with voters.

articles.title: Germany raised its citizens to hate war. Now it wants us to enlist in the army – but we say no | Mithu Sanyal
articles.trailText: The war in Ukraine is a crime. But European leaders should be working for peace, not preparing young people to fight and die, says German academic Mithu Sanyal
articles.summary: Germany’s anti-war culture has been reversed by Chancellor Merz’s drive to transform the Bundeswehr into Europe’s strongest army, reintroduce conscription—rebranded ‘voluntary’—and even use lotteries if recruit numbers lag. Mithu Sanyal outlines Germany’s journey from post-1945 pacifism through 1999’s Kosovo turn to today’s cognitive warfare propaganda, citing proposals like prostate exams for conscripts and the Bundeswehr Reservists’ 1,000-daily-casualty expectation. She critiques awarding NATO the International Peace of Westphalia prize, the Protestant church’s rejection of pacifism, and feminist debates over gendered conscription. She argues true solidarity with Ukraine demands peace diplomacy, not mass mobilization, amid rising youth refusal and conscientious objection.

articles.title: The Guardian view on restricting trial by jury: a shabby evasion of responsibility | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The criminal cases backlog requires radical action, but the problem has been caused by government cuts, not by an ancient and fundamental liberty
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that Justice Secretary David Lammy’s leaked plan would remove juries from most England and Wales criminal cases—limiting jury trials to murder, manslaughter, rape and public interest offences, and raising the non-jury threshold to five years’ maximum sentence. It argues that a 78,000-case backlog and time savings stem from austerity cuts to the Ministry of Justice and under-resourced magistrates courts, not juries. The piece notes Sir Brian Leveson’s more moderate three-year proposal and decries attacking an ancient liberty as a ‘shabby’ evasion of responsibility.

articles.title: The Guardian view on city living: an urban species is still adapting to our new environment | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: UN figures show that four-fifths of the global population now live in major settlements. We’re still figuring out how to cope
articles.summary: A new UN report finds over 80% of people now live in urban areas—up from 30% in 1950—with almost 500 cities exceeding one million residents. Jakarta’s surge to 42 million highlights infrastructure strain, pollution, flooding and inequality. State-planned relocations, like Indonesia’s new Borneo capital, often lag behind organic urban growth driven by rural hardship and economic opportunity. While cities generate unparalleled GDP and innovation—New York’s $1.8 trillion rivals nation-states—they also concentrate health risks, housing shortages and environmental harm. Achieving sustainable, equitable urban–rural integration and climate resilience is crucial as humanity adapts to its own urban ecosystems.

articles.title: How Amazon turned our capitalist era of free markets into the age of technofeudalism | Yanis Varoufakis
articles.trailText: Amazon Web Services owns the basic infrastructure for other businesses to operate online, turning even governments into its serfs, says the leader of MeRA25, Yanis Varoufakis
