articles.trailText: The chancellor is levelling with us about the pain to come. Is there anyone outside Planet Rachel who couldn’t see that truth two years ago, asks Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s abrupt pivot ahead of the December budget, accusing her of robotic delivery and broken pre-election pledges against higher taxes or borrowing. Reeves, Hyde argues, blames global headwinds and a disappointed OBR for downgraded growth while her own party won’t back cuts. Hyde ridicules the Treasury’s new definition of “working people” (under £45k earners), contending it betrays voters and that Labour’s failure to level with the public has already haunted its fiscal credibility.

articles.title: Applying for benefits is anxiety-inducing - and the weird language makes it much worse  | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The staff are really helpful, but stark warnings, unnecessary cliffhangers and demonising language in the application forms all add up to unnecessary stress, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams recounts her six-week struggle moving her severely mentally ill stepbrother, D, onto universal credit. While helpline staff are patient—respecting privacy, managing family bickering and name quirks—the online forms deploy stark warnings about losing all benefits over one wrong answer, require clicking through cliffhanger questions (‘Have you left the UK in two years?’) without context, and repeatedly use loaded terms like “migrating.” For someone prone to anxiety, this demonising language compounds stress, even if advisers soften the blow.

articles.title: There is a thriving shadow economy in Britain – but migrants are not to blame | Emily Kenway
articles.trailText: Labour is desperately trying to mimic Reform’s line on the cash economy, says former policy adviser Emily Kenway
articles.summary: Official research shows Britain’s hidden economy—about 8.8% of adults, or 4.4 million people—consists mainly of legal-sector work undeclared for tax or regulation, not migrant-run illicit businesses. Most participants are young, low-paid ‘moonlighters’ in deprived areas topping up apprenticeships and early-career trades (mechanics, electricians, hairdressers) with sub-£250 jobs. Customer demand for VAT-free deals drives under-the-table work. Politicians from Reform UK to Labour scapegoat migrants with ID cards and stricter checks, misdiagnosing a problem rooted in broader economic hardship.

articles.title: Public servants are being targeted and MPs have been murdered. But we will prevent fear from destroying our politics | Dan Jarvis
articles.trailText: A new law will restrict protests outside the homes of public office holders. The right to demonstrate is a given, but to menace private homes is just not right, says security minister Dan Jarvis
articles.summary: Security minister Dan Jarvis warns that escalating harassment, intimidation and the murder of MPs including Jo Cox and David Amess have triggered self-censorship, deterred candidates—especially women—and narrowed participation in British politics. Reports of threats, online abuse, bricks through windows, and protests outside homes are eroding democratic debate and risking fewer voices in decision-making. To safeguard public servants and their families, a new law will ban protests at private residences while upholding the right to peaceful assembly in public spaces. Jarvis frames this measure as a proportionate defence of democratic participation and respect for those who serve.

articles.title: In their darkest moments, too many Australians are being met with lethal force instead of love and care | Lorena Allam
articles.trailText: Police are often not equipped to deal with mental health callouts. Alternative first responders are better placed to de-escalate tension and reduce harm
articles.summary: After police fatal shootings of mentally unwell Australians—including 95-year-old dementia sufferer Clare Nowland, disabled Warlpiri man Kumanjayi White and Somali refugee Abdifatah Ahmed—an internal NSW review found officers often escalate crises, attending calls every nine minutes. The National Justice Project urges a “180-degree shift” toward alternative unarmed responders—community mediators like Groote Eylandt’s Peacemaker program (88% drop in offending) and WA’s Night Place—to de-escalate, respect autonomy and provide care. Campaigners call for law reform, sustainable funding and community-led first-response models to prevent further deaths.

articles.title: Say what you like about ‘Sadiq Khan’s no-go hellscape’ – Britain’s cities prove the rightwing agitators wrong | Jonathan Liew
articles.trailText: To rightwing populists, places of fluidity and freedom will always be the enemy, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew skewers rightwing myth-making that portrays Sadiq Khan’s London as a “no-go hellscape,” exposing how agitators and parts of the media distort isolated incidents into proof of a violent, subsidised metropolis. He highlights absurd misconceptions—free buses, multiple motorways to Brighton—and contrasts London’s slight rise in knife crime with sharp spikes in rural counties. Framing anti-urbanism as a cousin of white supremacy that simplifies complexity, Liew argues that cities’ fluidity, diversity and everyday chaos are humanity’s fullest expression. Despite pandemics and crises, urban populations keep growing, and the city itself remains its best champion.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Huntingdon train stabbings: an immigration-fixated right is failing the public | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Kneejerk responses undermine the emergency services and contribute to a damaging climate of suspicion
articles.summary: Editorial praises driver Andrew Johnson’s diversion of an LNER high-speed service to Huntingdon and emergency crews after a knife rampage on a Cambridgeshire train that injured ten (five discharged, one crew member still critical). It condemns rightwing figures for prematurely naming two black British suspects—one later released—stoking fear and anti-immigrant sentiment. Citing Nottingham and Southport non-terrorist stabbings linked to mental health and public-service failures, it calls for improved NHS capacity, police information-sharing and an end to opportunistic scapegoating of asylum seekers to restore public trust.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Britain’s new class divide: the professional middle is being hollowed out | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A micro-elite in finance and tech hoovers up talent while-white collar jobs lose their lustre. A society that rewards proximity to capital over contribution risks rupture
articles.summary: The editorial warns that Britain’s highest-paid micro-elite in quant finance and tech — with starting salaries of £250K–£800K — is siphoning off top graduates, while traditional white-collar professions stagnate at roughly £33K median, only marginally above the £26.4K minimum wage. Employers citing low graduate pay and rising university debt plan to use AI or offshore roles to curb costs. This dynamic is hollowing out the professional middle, misallocating human capital, entrenching inequality, and risking social rupture.

articles.title: It’s the Nigel Farage chameleon show – flashy, ever-changing pledges, but only one real policy: xenophobia  | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The Reform leader’s speech was full of contradictions and damaging cuts. But if he makes it to No 10, Labour will be to blame, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: In his Reform speech Nigel Farage pulled off a political chameleon act, abandoning his £90bn tax-cut bonanza for deep public-spending and benefits cuts, scrapping the two-child cap except for British working couples, and posing as both pro-worker and pro-business. He even revived the non-dom tax break to lure expats. Yet the only core policy binding his coalition is xenophobia—‘net zero migration’ and anti-immigrant dog whistles. Labour must highlight Brexit’s economic damage and push electoral reform to prevent a PM Farage under FPTP.

articles.title: Releasing a suspect’s nationality will do nothing to satisfy those who are not looking for the truth | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Grifters are always racing to a new low. Nothing can be done to appease them – they just want to find any way they can to denounce migrants, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams argues that disclosing a suspect’s nationality, ethnicity or skin colour—illustrated by the Doncaster-to-London train stabbing’s initial misreporting of two “Black” and “Caribbean” suspects—feeds anti-immigrant agitators rather than quashing misinformation. She recalls the 1997 sentencing of Slovak toy thieves in royal grief’s aftermath to warn judges against mirroring public outrage. No level of transparency appeases those racing to new lows, she insists, and authorities must resist strident demands for identity details simply to placate baseless campaigns.

articles.title: The generational divide is so overrated – here’s how I crossed it and forged new friendships | Zoya Patel
articles.trailText: I have the benefit of friends who are both much younger and older than me. Our exchanges of ideas and points of view are making me a better person
articles.summary: Zoya Patel argues that despite pervasive generational tensions—from baby boomers to Gen Z—cross-generational friendships yield unique benefits. Drawing on her bond with Sally*, seven years her senior, she credits older friends for mentoring pivotal decisions, and on her relationship with Milly*, 18, she highlights the reverse: staying connected to emerging culture and slang while offering judgment-free wisdom. Patel urges challenging stereotypes, embracing diverse life experiences across ages, and cultivating intergenerational dialogue to enrich personal growth and societal understanding.

articles.title: Are your kids obsessed with ‘6-7’? Here’s my plan to break the spell | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: Rules seem unlikely to help – kids will just rebel. Instead, try saying it all the time yourself
articles.summary: Dave Schilling, a Los Angeles-based humorist and father of an eight-year-old boy, critiques the Gen Alpha fixation on "6-7"—a meaningless numeric slang named Dictionary.com’s 2025 Word of the Year. His son uses it in every lull—asking for "67" in the car, choosing 67 on his Dodgers jersey—prompting a teacher ban. Schilling argues that strict prohibitions only heighten rebellion. Instead, parents should offer transparent reasons for rules and, counterintuitively, monopolize "6-7" themselves—stenciling it on T-shirts, birthday cakes, pepperoni arrangements—so its novelty evaporates, deflating its trolling power and steering kids toward more meaningful expression.

articles.title: It’s clear why Zohran Mamdani is leading in the New York mayoral race | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: There’s a clarity about Mamdani’s message that stands in sharp contrast to most Democratic politicians
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old New York state assemblymember and democratic socialist, has surged into a double-digit lead in the NYC mayoral race, energizing young voters with his clear stance on rent relief, grocery affordability, immigrant rights and Gaza solidarity. Despite attacks from Andrew Cuomo, Bill Ackman, Murdoch-owned outlets and the New York Post’s “SCAMDANI” smear, focus groups praise his authenticity and consistency. Mainstream Democrats, including Gov. Kathy Hochul, have endorsed him, viewing his inclusive outreach and principled messaging as a stark contrast to Washington-style triangulation and a pathway to a more affordable, equitable city.

articles.title: How the European convention on human rights became a battleground between the centre and the right | Daniel Trilling
articles.trailText: For 20 years, populists have been blaming the ECHR for endangering Britain by offering basic protections to immigrants, says author Daniel Trilling
articles.summary: In the UK, the ECHR, enshrined in the 1998 Human Rights Act, underpins protections from Article 2 duties on life to fair trials. Since its 75th anniversary, centre-right populists have rallied to withdraw the UK, with Kemi Badenoch proposing exit and Nigel Farage’s bid voted down. Polling shows 46% oppose withdrawal, 29% support it, revealing an alarming narrative that rights only benefit ��undeserving’ immigrants. Originally embraced by Thatcher as a bulwark against tyranny, then championed by Blair yet lacking a public awareness campaign or social-rights expansion, the ECHR now risks forfeiture unless tied to a broader politics of equality.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves's housing scandal was a small administrative error, but a big political mistake | Oliver Eagleton
articles.trailText: At a time of austerity, and with Labour’s housing policies needing years to take effect, the public doesn’t want to hear about ministers with multiple homes, says Oliver Eagleton, managing editor of Phenomenal World
articles.summary: Oliver Eagleton argues that Rachel Reeves’s failure to licence her south London rental is a minor administrative slip but a major political misstep for Labour, already under scrutiny over Angela Rayner’s second-home taxes and Rushanara Ali’s tenant evictions. Despite progressive reforms—£39bn for 300,000 affordable homes, a Renters’ Rights Act and planned council-tax hikes on expensive properties—these measures won’t ease public austerity pains fast enough. With ministers among Britain’s 85 landlord MPs and real-terms cuts looming in public services, Reeves’s surplus property income and past expense controversies reinforce perceptions of a political class at odds with voters, fuelling right-wing attacks.

articles.title: Blood spilled in Sudan can be seen from space. Nobody can feign ignorance about what’s going on | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: The massacres carried out by the RSF in El Fasher, Darfur, with the support of its UAE sponsors, will only stop when the international community acts, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: RSF seized El Fasher, Darfur after an 18-month siege, unleashing mass killings and starvation; satellite imagery shows blood-soaked streets. In one hospital nearly 500 were killed. This follows a two-and-a-half-year war between Sudan’s army and the RSF, rooted in a 2019 power struggle, displacing millions and killing an estimated 150,000. Ethnic cleansing targets non-Arab Darfuris as the RSF—heir to the Janjaweed—deploys 4x4s, drones and UAE-supplied arms in return for gold. Western powers tolerate this proxy conflict for geopolitical gains. With civilians trapped in a killing field, the author demands urgent international pressure on the UAE and RSF sponsors.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Dutch election: an uplifting victory for the politics of hope not hate | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Targeting the negativity of the far right, the big winner of last week’s poll was able to cut through with voters
articles.summary: One of the closest Dutch elections saw D66 under 38-year-old Rob Jetten triple its vote with an Obama-style “Yes we can” optimistic campaign, edging out Geert Wilders’ PVV by a whisker. Jetten’s pro-EU, pro-climate unifying message cut through after Wilders’ polarising tenure, though smaller far-right rivals still grew. Coalition talks are stalled, the centre-left collapsed with the Greens/Labour alliance leader resigning, and looming housing, healthcare and immigration crises will test whether “hope not hate” can deliver radical change.

articles.title: The Guardian view on art and health: the masterpiece can cure the body as well as the soul | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: From a Van Gogh self-portrait to Gauguin’s dreamscapes, new studies show that seeing original art can calm stress and boost health
articles.summary: New research shows viewing original masterworks—Van Gogh, Manet, Gauguin—lowers stress, inflammation and heart-disease risk and strengthens immunity, compared with seeing reproductions. Studies at the Courtauld Gallery (King’s College London) and Kettle’s Yard (Cambridge) underline art’s role in public health, echoing DCMS findings of £1,000 in yearly productivity and healthcare savings per person. Nature and The Lancet now endorse art therapy. Deep engagement fosters psychological distancing and human empathy. Amid funding cuts, the Guardian urges more cultural investment and suggests doctors may soon prescribe gallery visits as medicine.

articles.title: Is it really outrageously uncool to have a boyfriend?
articles.trailText: Vogue magazine thinks so – but there are other relationships that are much more embarrassing. I should know, I’m in one myself
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington critiques British Vogue’s verdict that having a boyfriend is 'culturally loser-ish', mocking the anti-#couplegoals stance embraced by singletons online. She jokes that husbands are even more uncool, lamenting her own spouse’s invisibility on social media—he shuns it as the 'opium of the intellectually feeble'—and jests about erasing him from Instagram. Surveying other bizarre attachments, from helicopter parents and infatuation with a defunct ChatGPT to parasocial bonds, men’s love affairs with watches and even Eiffel Tower marriages, she ultimately defends all affectionate, non-abusive relationships except dating Leonardo DiCaprio and explains why she’d never work for Vogue.

articles.title: The ghost of Ronald Reagan has spooked Trump over tariffs | Sidney Blumenthal
articles.trailText: The president is lashing out before the supreme court’s impending decision on his absurd policy
articles.summary: Halloween came early for Donald Trump. Reacting to an Ontario TV ad quoting Reagan’s 1987 warning on trade wars, Trump slapped an extra 10% tariff on Canada and accused it of influencing the Supreme Court ahead of Trump v VOS, which challenges his use of IEEPA to impose tariffs. Two lower courts deemed his measures unlawful, and amicus briefs from conservative lawyers pile against him. Facing a Nov. 5 hearing, Trump vows to attend in person to intimidate justices. His erratic tariffs have fractured Republicans, hit US GDP forecasts, and revived debate on separation of powers and protectionism.

articles.title: Don’t believe everything you see: why Buddhist scepticism is vital in the age of generative AI | Bertin Huynh
articles.trailText: Because our senses are so limited and the nature of all things so transient, what we know to be objective reality is a momentary snapshot of the whole picture
articles.summary: As generative AI like Sora 2 blurs fact and fiction, Buddhist scepticism reminds us our senses and thoughts are transient constructs. Drawing on the Heart Sutra’s teaching that the five skandhas—form, feelings, perception, mental forces and consciousness—lack inherent essence, Bertin Huynh argues that only by recognising reality as a provisional snapshot can we avert suffering. This middle way of acknowledging emptiness, rather than succumbing to nihilism or credulity, offers a vital antidote to the misinformation era.

articles.title: Forget Jomo, gezellig and hygge – this winter, let’s get a grip and go out | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: The dark nights are here and staying in is more appealing than ever. But there’s a very real cost to not venturing out, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington argues that winter’s embrace of Jomo, hygge and gezellig masks a costly “Great Retreat” into home. She cites data: Americans spend 99 more minutes at home daily than in 2003; only 30% socialise each day, down from 38% in 2014. Social isolation raises mortality risk comparable to smoking 15 cigarettes daily. Retreat shrinks our “middle circle,” eroding community oversight—like neglected playgrounds or closed libraries. Beddington urges us to resist inertia: join digital detox sessions, outdoor pudding meet-ups, anti-loneliness gatherings or simply re-engage with imperfect public life to avoid missing out.

articles.title: A year after Trump won, why won’t Democrats change their playbook? | Norman Solomon
articles.trailText: The corporate-friendly party refuses to learn the lessons of the past decade. When will it implement a truly humane agenda?
articles.summary: Norman Solomon diagnoses a self-defeating corporate-centrist playbook within the Democratic Party—from Obama’s bank bailouts and Clinton’s Wall Street ties to Pelosi and Schumer sidelining Sanders and the Green New Deal, through Russiagate distractions and an uncritical Biden 2024 run—that has alienated younger and progressive voters, hemorrhaging millions of Democrats to Republicans. He calls for a grassroots insurgency demanding populist policies—Medicare for All, free college, a Green New Deal, and fairer taxes—to reclaim party control, defeat Trumpism, and restore genuine democracy.

articles.title: Dutch voters have been seduced by positivity – liberals elsewhere, take note | Simon van Teutem
articles.trailText: By selling hope alongside progressive patriotism, the centrist D66 party widened its appeal and beat the far right, says Dutch journalist Simon van Teutem
articles.summary: Simon van Teutem argues that the centrist Dutch party D66 under Rob Jetten tripled its seats by selling hope through progressive patriotism. Five strategies defined its success: can-do optimism; reclaiming national pride without exclusion; directly confronting the far right; championing left-leaning economic reforms such as higher inheritance taxes and better rewards for work; and building a big-tent coalition across ideological lines. Though critics warn coalition deals may dilute progressivism, Jetten’s confident, positive campaign outperformed a gloom-driven VVD, proving that optimism combined with pragmatic policies can broaden liberal appeal.

articles.title: President JD Vance or Marco Rubio? We’re seeing the first signs of the battle over Trump's succession | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: It’s currently a two-horse race – and the next US leader is guaranteed to be a careerist who knows nothing of statesmanship, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall argues that as Trump’s third-term flirtation fades, the GOP’s 2028 succession contest boils down to JD Vance and Marco Rubio—neither fit for statesmanship. Vance, a brash Ohio senator-turned-vice-president, relies on vulgar social‐media attacks, flip-flops on wars and civil liberties, and lacks coherent policy. Rubio, once a principled 2016 contender, now functions as an ineffectual secretary of state who has gutted foreign aid, sidelined human‐rights promotion and spearheaded militarized Latin American interventions. Both, Tisdall warns, embody careerist ambition over leadership and threaten to prolong Trump’s uninspiring legacy.

articles.title: Australia must put politics aside and pass nature laws that benefit the economy and the environment. We owe it to our kids | Zoe Daniel
articles.trailText: There’s no such thing as a perfect legislative solution. It’s about finding one that’s workable – for the community, for the economy and for nature
articles.summary: Amid accelerating biodiversity loss and outdated legislation, Australia’s revamped Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act—rooted in Graeme Samuel’s 2021 review—has stalled five years in political gridlock. The 1,500-page bill tightens offset rules, mandates climate impact assessments under new national standards and promises faster approvals to drive a jobs-rich, low-emissions economy. Conservationists, business leaders and crossbenchers urge compromise on ministerial powers and targeted amendments to deliver a workable law for communities, nature and future generations.

articles.title: Democrats must not cave in to Trump | Bernie Sanders
articles.trailText: The government shutdown is not an accident. Trump’s budget would push millions into poverty and must be stopped
articles.summary: Bernie Sanders urges US Senate Democrats to resist Trump’s demands in the current government shutdown, arguing that his proposed budget cuts would push millions into poverty by doubling ACA premiums, stripping healthcare from 15 million Americans and withholding SNAP funding for 42 million people. He portrays Trump as an authoritarian seeking unchecked power—undermining the Constitution, threatening opponents, deploying ICE raids—and criticizes Republicans for refusing to negotiate. Sanders warns that caving would betray working-class families, embolden Trump’s oligarchic $1 trillion tax-break agenda and accelerate his assault on democracy and social safety nets.

articles.title: Katie Miller is threatening the citizenship of a critic | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Threatening to deport your critics, even those with US citizenship, seems to have become Maga policy
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi criticizes Katie Miller, co-author of Trump’s hardline immigration legacy, for threatening to strip critic Cenk Uygur of his US citizenship during a Piers Morgan panel. Mahdawi recalls Miller’s and husband Stephen’s roles in family separation policies and her pivot to a ‘momfluencer’ podcast. She situates Miller’s denaturalization threat within a broader MAGA strategy—citing GOP figures like Rep. Randy Fine and recent DOJ denaturalization pushes—to intimidate critics, chill dissent and weaponize deportation fears reminiscent of McCarthyism.

articles.title: If the right really wants free speech in universities, why is it so obsessed with discrediting students? | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: The media loves to manufacture outrage about what students get up to – and to discipline those who dare challenge conservatives, says Jason Okundaye, a Guardian assistant newsletter editor
articles.summary: Guardian assistant newsletter editor Jason Okundaye reflects on his own media–fuelled harassment after a Cambridge tweet to critique the recent storm over Oxford Union president-elect George Abaraonye’s jokes about Charlie Kirk’s fatal shooting. He argues the right and media obsessively manufacture outrage at universities to discipline dissenting students—especially at Oxbridge—and stoke fears of radical campuses. While some campus abuses warrant exposure, most student missteps harm no one. This selective crackdown betrays hypocrisy in claiming to defend free speech.

articles.title: World leaders, remember that future generations will judge you. At Cop30, you can define how | Gordon Brown
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer is taking the lead on tackling the climate crisis. With the US backing away, now is the moment when other nations must step up, says former UK prime minister Gordon Brown
articles.summary: Former PM Gordon Brown warns that with the US stepping back on climate action, Cop30 in Brazil offers a vital chance for new global leadership. While China’s emissions targets disappoint, the EU, Norway, UK and Japan must strengthen green industrial policies and scale up finance for the global south. Keir Starmer’s presence signals an urgent focus on mitigation, adaptation and lives lost to heat, floods and drought. Ahead of Brazil’s Nov 6–7 leaders’ summit, Brown urges: accelerate Paris pledges, mobilise $1.3 trn climate finance, safeguard forests, cut methane and protect vulnerable communities and children’s education.

articles.title: Poor Nicolas Sarkozy. His hardline views on crime and punishment have come back to bite him
articles.trailText: The former French president zealously promoted a zero-tolerance penal system. Luckily for him, his prison visitors include powerful friends, says Guardian Europe columnist Rokhaya Diallo
articles.summary: Rokhaya Diallo recalls the 2005 deaths of teenagers in Clichy-sous-Bois and criticizes Nicolas Sarkozy’s zero-tolerance crime policy. Now convicted for criminal conspiracy over illicit Libyan campaign funding, Sarkozy received a five-year sentence—an unprecedented prison term for a French head of state—yet enjoys privileged treatment: delayed detention, private cell, visits by the justice minister and calls for clemency from Macron supporters. Diallo contrasts this with the routine, harsh pre-trial incarceration of ordinary suspects and deplorable prison conditions, calling for a shift toward reparative justice rather than punitive excess.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Andrew’s downfall: Britain’s relationship with the royals needs a reset | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The former prince’s retirement from public life is welcome. Problems around royal secrecy and entitlement remain to be tackled
articles.summary: Prince Andrew, now Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, has been stripped of his royal title, evicted from royal property, and forced into retirement after revelations about his friendship with Jeffrey Epstein and Virginia Giuffre’s abuse allegations. Buckingham Palace framed these “censures” as consequences of his deceit—claiming he cut ties with Epstein in 2010—and entitled behaviour. Despite a £12m settlement, no liability was admitted. The editorial argues this episode underscores persistent issues of secrecy, privilege and lack of accountability in the monarchy, and calls for a comprehensive reset in Britain’s relationship with its royals.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the atrocities in El Fasher: the responsibility for these horrors extends beyond Sudan’s borders | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The world said ‘never again’ after Darfur’s genocide. Yet it stood by as catastrophe loomed
articles.summary: After an 18-month siege, RSF forces captured El Fasher, committing mass killings, sexual violence and ethnically targeted atrocities. Despite UN warnings and satellite evidence, global response remained underfunded and complicit. External actors, including the UAE, EU and Western states, have legitimized, funded and armed the RSF for political and economic gains, fueling Sudan’s brutal conflict. With de facto partition entrenched, atrocities will likely spread. The editorial urges sustained international pressure—especially on the UAE—and accountability to prevent further genocide in Darfur.

articles.title: Democrats should be taking the fight to Trump – the problem is, he’s got them battling each other | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: Elections across the US next week should be easy pickings for the opposition. But they’re finding it hard to beat a player who breaks all the rules, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: October 2025 off-year elections in New Jersey, Virginia and NYC reveal Democrats’ struggle to capitalize on Trump’s low 39% approval. Despite states favoring Biden/Harris, the NJ gubernatorial race is neck-and-neck, prompting big investments and Obama’s intervention. In New York City, Socialist Zohran Mamdani clashes with establishment ex-governor Andrew Cuomo, exposing a sharp generational and ideological split. Debates over progressive versus moderate strategies mirror broader uncertainty: stick to democratic norms and risk losing, or adopt aggressive tactics like California’s partisan redistricting and jeopardize institutional guardrails. Trump’s disruptive influence leaves Democrats divided and directionless.

articles.title: Now Andrew has been fired from the Firm, a nation wonders: who'll be next? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: The king is reduced to a blustering CEO, Prince William to his head of HR. This de-princing could leave the entire House of Windsor facing redundancy, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde argues that King Charles’s decision to strip Prince Andrew of his royal status—while restoring dignity to those who lived on Andrew-named streets—marks a dangerous shift. By demoting Andrew the monarchy courts commoner HR dynamics, undermining the ethereal nature of royalty established since the 1936 abdication precedent. Hyde warns this corporate-like personnel policy will prompt further “de-princings,” destabilize the Windsors, and hasten the monarchy’s end by subjecting royals to feedback and appraisals. She contrasts this with the late Queen Elizabeth’s lifelong reign as a bulwark against such reforms, and expresses doubt about Prince William’s future stewardship.

articles.title: California’s gerrymandering measure would move the nation backwards | David Daley
articles.trailText: Proposition 50 would undermine the best example of reform in redistricting – and any benefit to Democrats might be negligible
articles.summary: Proposition 50 would suspend California’s independent redistricting commission, empowering Democrats in the legislature to redraw a 47-1 congressional map as a mid-decade “retaliation” against GOP gains. Backers claim it’s temporary to reclaim seats lost to Sun Belt shifts and protect the House majority, but history shows politicians seldom relinquish such power. It would eliminate all of California’s competitive districts, weaken accountability, and undermine the nation’s preeminent anti-gerrymandering model. Any short-term gain—roughly five extra seats—may be offset by long-term reapportionment losses and erode reform momentum nationwide.

articles.title: The crescendo of pre-budget lobbying has rarely been so loud. Rachel Reeves must tune it out  | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: There is no popular way to raise taxes, and with Labour tanking in the polls, my advice to the chancellor is this: do it anyway, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee warns that ahead of the UK budget, every sector from banks and gambling to property and pensions is lobbying fiercely against proposed tax rises—even when public backing exists only for taxing the wealthy, banks, mansions and gambling. Campaigners demand a windfall levy on bank profits; gambling firms decry higher duties; estate agents and landlords resist home and NI reforms; supermarkets and pension funds threaten price hikes and industry damage. With no popular path to raise universal taxes, Toynbee urges the chancellor to ignore both lobbyists and fickle public opinion and pursue fair, long-term measures soon.

articles.title: Trump is toying with a third term. Don’t expect the constitution to stop him | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: What is and is not constitutional is determined, in effect, by loyalists on the supreme court and their bad-faith enablers
articles.summary: Bannon and Trump have floated an unlawful third-term bid for 2028—Trump even joked about entering via a sham vice-presidential ticket—despite the 12th and 22nd Amendments explicitly barring it. Speaker Mike Johnson acknowledged the 22nd Amendment’s ban, but Moira Donegan warns that a right-wing majority on the Supreme Court and allied scholars are already subverting constitutional limits—greenlighting Trump’s dismantling of the Department of Education and challenging birthright citizenship under the 14th Amendment. With legal checks eroded by bad-faith interpretation, Donegan insists only mass public mobilization, not the courts, can stop Trump.

articles.title: Horror movies have an ableism problem. Isn’t it time we found new ‘monsters’? | Kathryn Bromwich
articles.trailText: Films such as Frankenstein still use disability as shorthand for moral depravity. But human behaviour is far scarier than human appearance, says journalist Kathryn Bromwich
articles.summary: Kathryn Bromwich, a disabled horror fan, argues that mainstream and arthouse horror persistently weaponize disability—using scarring, prosthetics or wheelchair use—as shorthand for villainy or to heighten unease. She criticizes Guillermo del Toro’s Frankenstein for casting able-bodied actors in disabled roles and reiterating the trope that physical difference equals moral depravity. From classics like Nosferatu’s “arthritic” hands to modern prosthetic approaches in Longlegs and Midsommar, films other disabled bodies as monsters. Underrepresented, disabled creatives account for just 2% of the industry. Bromwich calls for more authentic representation driven by disabled writers, directors and actors: “Nothing about us without us.”

articles.title: Lily Allen’s new album shows the pain behind the ‘cool girl’ myth – that’s why women are obsessed with it | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: The singer’s lyrics about an open marriage gone sour resonate with many women her age. They’re sick of pretending to be fine with relationships that are not, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Lily Allen’s new album West End Girl unpacks the emotional toll beneath her ‘cool girl’ persona, tracing a sour open marriage narrative that blurs her real-life split and ignites debates on ethical non-monogamy versus genuine commitment. Gaby Hinsliff argues the record resonates because it channels women’s frustration with situationships and the pressure to appear unfazed, while reclaiming the right to want stability and to reject performative progressiveness in love.

articles.title: What would you do if democracy was being dismantled before your eyes? Whatever you’re doing right now | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: In California, daily life under Trump is marked by sporadic resistance and avoidance. Neither will defeat the autocrats, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: In California, Trump’s second term sees uneven local reactions: suppressed Latino communities avoid public spaces fearing ICE; privileged gentrified zones absorb consumerism; spontaneous “No Kings” protests in Beverly Hills contrast with apathetic disengagement in San Francisco. Beckett cites Trump’s immigrant purges, power centralisation, suppression of dissent and contempt for law as hallmarks of his volatile regime. He warns that a cycle of avoidance and sporadic resistance won’t defeat autocracy’s showmanship; sustained, inclusive, compelling politics are essential to counter illiberal populism worldwide.

articles.title: I’d have been shattered in year 12 if I’d studied the wrong Caesar for my exam. Wouldn’t you? | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: As someone who still has anxiety dreams about high school exams, my heart goes out to the Queensland students who studied the wrong Roman emperor
articles.summary: Paul Daley, reflecting on his own decades-long exam anxieties, empathises with Queensland year 12 students who crammed for Augustus only to face Julius Caesar in their history exam. He recounts his recurring nightmare of arriving unprepared for an unfamiliar syllabus, links it to the universal grip of anxiety dreams, and critiques the intense pressure traditional schooling places on young people. Daley concludes that despite emotional scars, these students deserve credit for their resilience.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump and China: stepping back from the brink, but not solving problems | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Though the US president’s meeting with Xi Jinping appears to have staved off a global trade war, this is far from a win for Washington
articles.summary: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping’s meeting in South Korea paused a looming US–China trade war but failed to resolve core disputes. Trump agreed to roll back his proposed 145% tariffs to an average of 45% and suspend new tech export controls; China committed to buying US soybeans and held off rare-earth export curbs. This year-long truce buys time but leaves uncertainty for US businesses amid Trump’s erratic tariff threats. Beijing continues strengthening its economic resilience while Washington forges new alliances. Underlying tensions, from AI chip access to supply-chain dependencies, remain unaddressed.

articles.title: The Guardian view on deprived neighbourhoods: incomes as well as places need a boost | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Labour must not ignore the warnings contained in the updated index of multiple deprivation
articles.summary: Updated index of multiple deprivation highlights entrenched poverty in England’s post-industrial and coastal neighbourhoods, led again by Jaywick & St Osyth and seven Blackpool areas. Labour, lagging in polls, must heed the data—dominated by income and employment but also health and education—to revive place-based and household support. Current government’s levelling-up failure is offset by increased north-east investment; Labour’s Pride in Place will award £20m to 169 communities for youth clubs, high-streets and civic projects. But long-term progress hinges on tackling high rents, benefit caps and boosting family incomes alongside physical regeneration.

articles.title: Britain would do well to remember where its power over China lies | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: It’s ridiculous for the government to splurge on defence while it slashes spending on its most valuable asset: culture, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins contends Britain misallocates resources by expanding defence budgets against a hypothetical war while slashing its foremost asset—cultural influence. As China emerges as an economic and digital superpower and US–China tensions shift global order, the UK oscillates between viewing Beijing as friend or foe. Unlike military might, Britain’s soft power—through education, the British Council, and popular culture—yields tangible geopolitical returns. Jenkins urges policymakers to realign strategy: engage rather than demonize China, preserve cultural institutions abroad, and leverage Britain’s unique global influence instead of defaulting to hard‐power posturing.

articles.title: Want to know what’s really up with Britain? Take a look at our no-longer-chocolatey biscuits | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Talk of ‘small boats’ may dominate politics and the media, but the cost of living crisis is what most adults spend their time worrying about, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams argues that while UK politics and media obsess over immigration and “small boats,” households still wrestle with a relentless cost-of-living crisis. From 37% butter price hikes and shrunken packs to 17.5% grocery inflation in 2023, brands have quietly shrunk biscuits, toothpaste and more while charging the same. Consumers report acute anxiety — particularly renters, parents and younger adults — yet public debate has shifted. Williams calls out this “omertà” and corporate price-gouging, urging scrutiny of inflation drivers and policy inertia. Households faced an extra £683 annual grocery bill, while essential shrinkflation persists.

articles.title: Selling the left’s message in the digital age is an art – Ireland’s new president mastered it | Una Mullally
articles.trailText: From Mamdani-style visual branding to basketball clips, Catherine Connolly found her audience and spoke in a language they understood, says journalist Una Mullally
articles.summary: Catherine Connolly, Ireland’s newly elected leftwing pacifist president, harnessed authenticity and digital-savvy branding to unite left parties and engage voters bored by centrist blandness. A seasoned lawyer from a working-class Galway background, she showcased her personality via viral soccer and basketball clips, grassroots podcasts, memes and Celtic-inspired visuals. Eschewing soundbites and negativity, she championed anti-war, Palestinian solidarity, marriage equality, abortion rights, climate action, housing reform and Irish-language revival. Her porous campaign used decentralized volunteer networks—folk-music fundraisers, murals, TikTok and Instagram influencers—to forge emotional, culturally resonant connections and exemplify modern progressive mobilisation.

articles.title: The leftwing defense of Graham Platner is rooted in a false Democratic vision | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Tolerance for behavior like Platner’s is tied to a wrongheaded theory of the male working class. Zohran Mamdani illustrates a different path
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Moira Donegan contrasts progressive insurgent Zohran Mamdani’s disciplined, pluralist victory in New York with Maine Senate hopeful Graham Platner’s scandal-marred campaign. Platner’s deleted Reddit posts—racist tipping stereotypes and victim-blaming sexual assault commentary—and his long-held SS Totenkopf tattoo have drawn calls to withdraw, yet left-wing pundits defend him as essential to winning white male working-class votes. Donegan argues this defense rests on an outdated, sexist vision of a masculine working class, distracting from inclusive, policy-focused populism and valorizing a narrow, white male identity over broader electoral needs.

articles.title: This isn’t a real ceasefire in Gaza – it’s a holding pattern before war returns | Sanam Vakil
articles.trailText: Israel’s airstrikes have exposed the fragility of Trump’s ‘peace plan’. Without international support, it risks crumbling altogether, says Sanam Vakil of Chatham House
articles.summary: Israel’s resumed airstrikes in Gaza – killing over 100 – expose the fragility of Trump’s 20-point ceasefire, which lacks timelines, verification or enforcement. Both sides interpret violations to their advantage: Israel cites Hamas fire in Rafah; Hamas denies involvement. Partial troop withdrawals and hostage swaps belie an undeveloped second phase: full Israeli exit, technocratic governance, international stabilisation. Gaza’s infrastructure and services collapse, West Bank clashes intensify, and a US monitoring centre without authority leaves this ‘truce’ a temporary pause before renewed war.

articles.title: Slang terms like ‘six-seven’ have no definition. But they’re loaded with meaning | Matthew Cantor
articles.trailText: Older generations are demanding explanations of the viral phrase – but slang doesn’t have to make logical sense
articles.summary: “Six-seven” exploded online without a fixed definition—tracing roots to Skrilla’s song (67th Street), LaMelo Ball and a Starbucks ranking stunt. Its upturned-palm gesture signals insider status rather than concrete meaning. Sociolinguists Nicole Holliday and Daria Bahtina argue such ephemeral slang serves identity, community and differentiation from elders. Parallels range from 1905’s “23 skidoo” to millennials’ “1738,” and regional tags like Memphis’s “mane” or Philly’s “jawn.” Social media amplifies trends but adult coverage drains their exclusivity, forcing constant reinvention. Yet public use can bridge generations, as when a Berkeley professor echoed “six, seven” at a 6.7-mile marker.

articles.title: Is it OK to talk at the cinema? How about if it’s just during the trailers? | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Some might argue that streaming movies at home has given us all etiquette amnesia. But when it comes to disrupting a screening, I think the rules have some nuance, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson explores nuanced cinema etiquette, debating whether brief chatter during trailers is acceptable if silence is restored once the main feature begins. She describes a recent outing where nearby moviegoers conversed loudly over Dolby surround previews, eliciting bemused double-open-palm gestures from her and a friend. Hudson contends trailers can be rewatched online and are worth chatting over, contrasting this minor offense with a true disruption: a mobile phone’s loud, extended call in the middle of the film. She argues home streaming has fostered “etiquette amnesia” but rules still matter.

articles.title: Trump is using the shutdown to make life tougher for millions of workers | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: Food stamps are in danger and hundreds of thousands of federal workers may go unpaid, as thousands more are laid off
articles.summary: During the October shutdown, President Trump sharply escalated pressure on Democrats by barring the USDA’s $5 billion SNAP contingency fund—risking food stamps for 42 million Americans—after previously approving its use. Two dozen states sued, calling the cutoff unlawful. He also threatened to withhold backpay from 670,000 furloughed federal workers despite the Fair Treatment Act and announced permanent layoffs of 4,000 mid-shutdown—a move a federal judge enjoined as capricious. Critics denounce these moves as blatant legal violations and cruel anti-worker tactics.

articles.title: Just beads in a glass jar: this is how the Tories dehumanise migrants and those in need | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: The Conservatives, like Reform, are rooting their immigration policy in the language of welfare dependency. It’s deeply harmful, says Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: Frances Ryan criticises the Tories’ dehumanising rhetoric that frames migrants as welfare-dependent, highlighted by MP Katie Lam’s video showing beads in jars representing migrants with ILR and benefits. The party proposes retrospectively stripping residency from anyone claiming social security. Turn2us research reveals deep distrust in the benefits system, fuelled by decades of punitive reforms that stigmatize claimants. Right-wing politicians and media conflate immigration and welfare to spread prejudice, labelling some as "contributing" citizens and others as "burdens." Ryan warns this logic could criminalize routine support—from sickness pay to pensions—and cautions that cutting the safety net empowers the far right and risks unraveling solidarity.

articles.title: Ministers can raise taxes if they come out fighting. But no one in this cowardly Labour government seems able | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: Ahead of the budget, Rachel Reeves should be out making her arguments. Instead, there is silence – and a huge opportunity for Labour’s opponents, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Aditya Chakrabortty argues that ahead of Rachel Reeves’s crucial budget, Labour ministers remain inexplicably mute about planned tax rises and cuts totalling £20–30bn, despite having broken pledges on income tax, national insurance and VAT. He condemns this ‘cowardly’ government’s aversion to argument—bound by last year’s self-imposed fiscal rules—and warns the silence will cede the narrative to Nigel Farage, Tory critics and the press. Unlike past figures such as Blair, Brown or Osborne who fought publicly for policies, today’s Labour frontbench fears confrontation, leaving voters uninformed and opponents ready to exploit every vacuum.

articles.title: France needs its own No Kings day to protect its most valuable treasure | Patrick Boucheron and Pierre Singaravélou
articles.trailText: We have no crown jewels: the Louvre panic is a distraction from the real threat the far right poses to our democracy
articles.summary: After a minor Louvre burglary of historic gems often misbranded as ‘crown jewels,’ Patrick Boucheron and Pierre Singaravélou argue conservatives sensationalize the heist to evoke monarchist nostalgia and distract from chronic cultural heritage underfunding. They trace France’s jewels’ role as solvency assets, not royal regalia, and warn of a new right–far-right alliance exploiting symbolic outrage to undermine revolutionary principles, judicial independence and fuel authoritarian populism. They propose a French ‘No Kings Day’ to reaffirm democratic culture and civil society’s resistance to emerging anti-republican forces.

articles.title: Nothing used to be off-limits when talking about sex. Now I’m in a long-term relationship, why is it taboo? | Natasha Sholl
articles.trailText: There’s an assumption sex in the throes of new lust is hot, but in long-term relationships it’s three humps in missionary. Does married sex need a rebrand?
articles.summary: Natasha Sholl examines why candid discussions about married sex—once commonplace in youth—become taboo after 17 years of marriage. She notes friends freely share parenting fails, work dramas and health crises, yet avoid talk of sex even amid miscarriage, IVF or a child’s brain surgery. Citing Robert Delaney’s account of intimacy beside hospital corridors as proof of sex’s role in trauma and bonding, she urges rebranding long-term relationship sex, embracing fantasies, quickies and self-pleasure as vital life topics.

articles.title: The Guardian view on hospices: investment in end-of-life care is a national priority | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A new National Audit Office report reveals a sector in crisis. As the needs of an ageing population grow, it must be a wake-up call for the government
articles.summary: England’s independent hospice movement, founded in 1967 by Cicely Saunders to improve quality of life for the terminally ill, now faces an “ominous financial squeeze,” according to a National Audit Office report. Reliant on donations, fundraising and limited NHS support, nearly two-thirds of adult hospices ran deficits in 2023-24, leading to bed cuts, staff layoffs and reduced psychological, bereavement and home-care services. With an ageing population driving demand, a postcode lottery in access and rising costs, current one-off capital support and children’s-hospice funding fall short. The Guardian urges the government to rethink funding models, boost state support and expand end-of-life care rather than retrench.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Argentina’s election: one step closer to becoming a Trumpian client state | Ediorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A $40bn rescue may have helped Javier Milei scrape through midterms, but it leaves Argentina’s democracy and economy more dependent than ever on Washington
articles.summary: In Argentina’s congressional midterms, rightwing president Javier Milei’s coalition secured about 40% of the vote—buoyed by low turnout and a $40bn US rescue from Donald Trump’s administration that briefly stemmed the peso’s collapse and cooled consumer prices. His ‘chainsaw’ programme of privatisations and spending cuts has slashed real wages, cost 200,000 jobs and deepened inflation. Economists warn that IMF-backed removal of capital controls leaves any stability illusory, binding Argentina as a Trumpian client state reliant on Washington’s credit and demanding a return to currency management and industrial policy for true resilience.

articles.title: Trump is often angry but rarely hurt – yet Canada has managed to pull it off | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: Why has an ad quoting Ronald Reagan’s criticism of tariffs triggered such a reaction from the president, asks Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: In a striking overreaction, President Trump lashed out at a Canadian TV ad featuring a 1987 Ronald Reagan clip denouncing tariffs, declaring it 'fake' despite unchanged sentiment. He halted U.S.-Canada trade talks and imposed an additional 10% tariff, later threatening 60% on select goods, risking harm to American consumers and supply chains. Guardian columnist Emma Brockes argues the fury isn’t policy-driven but ego-driven: by juxtaposing Reagan’s hooded, rugged authenticity and enduring Republican iconography with Trump’s polished MAGA persona, the ad pierced the president’s self-delusion, exposing deep insecurities and the volatile core of his grievances.

articles.title: The UK bond markets have become a political trap that strangles public spending. But there’s a way out | Sahil Dutta
articles.trailText: With living standards falling and the far right on the rise, the chancellor has the power to make decisions, not simply accept diktats from the markets, says lecturer in political economy Sahil Dutta
articles.summary: Lecturer Sahil Dutta warns UK bond markets, echoing 1990s US, have become a political straitjacket strangling public spending, yet yields remain modest. He argues the government can raise taxes for housing, transport and local investment, and use the Bank of England to buy debt, cap yields and introduce price caps or rent controls to shield households. Labour’s self-imposed fiscal rule adds market uncertainty; a tax-system overhaul could secure stable revenues and cut borrowing. Dutta calls for reclaiming democratic control over debt management—halting loss-making bond sales, revising Bank rules and recouping QE costs—to revive pre-1970s monetary-fiscal cooperation, uplift the poorest 40% and drive growth by political choice, not market diktat.

articles.title: Are you a ditherer, sharer or pre-preparer? What your menu ordering style says about you | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: We’re just human beings, out at a restaurant, struggling against the horror of food envy or orderer’s remorse. But how you approach this can be very revealing, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson explores how diners’ ordering habits—dithering, sharing, pre-preparing or experimenting—reveal personality quirks. Using Rishi Sunak’s 10-minute menu indecision over Dover sole as a case study, she categorises diners: persistent “ditherers” who canvas opinions, rigid contrarians who never match others' orders, novelty-seekers chasing new dishes then trading plates, collaborative sharers who swap halves, and hyper-organised pre-preparers who study menus in advance. She jibes at those who solicit waiter advice and warns against orderer’s remorse, arguing that menu-style divides reflect deeper human traits amid the anxiety and envy of dining out.

articles.title: Jared Kushner is back – and so are big questions about his financial ties | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: Kushner’s investment firm is backed by three Arab petrostates critical to the Gaza agreement. And the deals keep coming
articles.summary: After staying out of Trump’s administration on his 2025 return, Jared Kushner re-emerged to broker a Gaza ceasefire and postwar framework, hailed as a dealmaker. Yet his firm Affinity Partners—backed by Saudi, Qatari and UAE sovereign funds (a $2bn Saudi PIF investment plus $1.5bn more)—collected $157m in management fees without returning profit, prompting Senate concerns over conflicts and influence-peddling. As Kushner advances Gaza reconstruction talks and a $55bn Electronic Arts deal with Saudi partners, his private investments and diplomatic clout remain tightly interwoven and lightly overseen.

articles.title: What’s with the sponcon slop in Nobody Wants This? Netflix, nobody wants this | Alaina Demopoulos
articles.trailText: Season two of the Adam Brody and Kristen Bell-starring show feels like a long infomercial thanks to endless product placement
articles.summary: Netflix’s season two of Nobody Wants This, starring Adam Brody and Kristen Bell, is so saturated with product placement—from Estée Lauder to Dunkin’ coffee, Flamin’ Hot Cheetos, an Airbnb pasta class, a Jennifer Meyer necklace and Seventh Generation spray—that the plot about an atheist podcaster’s conversion and cultural clashes becomes an afterthought. Viewers on Reddit called it a “giant infomercial” with scenes written around brands. The author warns Hollywood’s growing reliance on sponcon undermines storytelling. Tracing Netflix’s brand integrations from House of Cards to Stranger Things and Emily in Paris, she argues the incessant hawking distracts from character-driven narratives and urges Netflix to dial back its corporate pitches.

articles.title: Am I a type A personality - and should I care? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Videos about personality science are going viral on social media, but beware of giving them credence, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: In the 1950s a San Francisco medical receptionist noticed chairs used by coronary patients wore out faster: they sat on hard seats, fidgeted and rushed up, sparking Friedman and Rosenman’s 1959 “Type A” model linking competitiveness to heart disease. Tobacco firms later misused it to downplay smoking risks. Today TikTok teens obsess over Myers-Briggs and humoral labels, despite scant science. Author Arwa Mahdawi chronicles her own ADHD-type procrastination and ChatGPT’s false attribution of “Mrs Mabel Adams,” concluding most personality frameworks are compelling yet unsubstantiated bunk.

articles.title: Dear Donald Trump, here’s how you can win that Nobel peace prize | Mehdi Hasan
articles.trailText: Make Israel release Marwan Barghouti, the ‘Palestinian Mandela’. The future of peace in the region depends on it
articles.summary: Mehdi Hasan urges Donald Trump to secure the release of Marwan Barghouti, the 66-year-old Palestinian leader jailed in Israel, as his ticket to a 2026 Nobel peace prize. Barghouti, dubbed the “Palestinian Mandela,” commands broad support across Fatah and Hamas, has long advocated a two-state solution, and was allegedly denied a fair trial. Endorsed by Ron Lauder, Ami Ayalon and the Economist, his release could unlock genuine Israel-Palestine negotiations. Hasan challenges Trump—who has pardoned US prisoners and claims to seek peace—to pressure Netanyahu now for enduring regional stability.

articles.title: I was happy to drop my pants for medical science (and money). Come on, gen Z – it’s your turn | Rich Pelley
articles.trailText: Young people are eschewing medical trials, to their own detriment. Maybe my tales of pills, tubes and paydays can inspire a generation, says freelance writer Rich Pelley
articles.summary: Freelance writer Rich Pelley laments Gen Z’s growing reluctance to volunteer for paid human medical trials—an essential phase mandated by the MHRA to detect side-effects and repurpose drugs—arguing their withdrawal stalls new therapies and obscures age-specific risks. He recounts as a student in Nottingham earning £20 for cognitive tests, as a journalist under UV lamps and placebo-controlled anti-ulcer studies in Sydney, nearly netting £900 in a Parkinson’s trial, and enduring a 17-lumen silicone tube through his digestive tract for £200. While recalling both drug setbacks (Theralizumab) and successes (Viagra), Pelley urges young adults to “pull their pants down” for science, balancing personal gain with societal benefit.

articles.title: Do we really expect five-year-olds to sit at desks? I want a school that understands play is learning | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: In England, young children go from glitter clay and building dens to classrooms a Victorian would recognise – and that system is failing many of them, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett argues that England’s abrupt shift at age five from the playful, self-directed learning of reception to rigid desk-based lessons undermines children’s development. Ex-deputy head Ruth Lue-Quee’s petition—close to 100,000 signatures—seeks statutory play-based pedagogy in Key Stage 1. Unlike England, many high-performing and European systems delay formal schooling or integrate play. Research links play to language, motor skills, critical thinking and wellbeing, yet since 2014 policy changes have accelerated formal teaching. Rising school refusals and unmet SEND needs underscore these harms. Campaigners urge the new government to reform; parents hunt for play-rich schools.

articles.title: From CBS to TikTok, US media are falling to Trump’s allies. This is how democracy crumbles | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: We’re watching the Orbánisation of the US – and as in Hungary, control of the media is key to consolidating power, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Owen Jones warns of the “Orbánisation” of US democracy as Trump allies seize media power. Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison and son David funded Skydance’s Paramount takeover, controlling CBS News and installing ideologue Bari Weiss. They’re poised to bid on Warner Bros Discovery and US TikTok, embedding pro-Trump and pro-Israel bias in algorithms. Meanwhile Meta’s Zuckerberg dropped fact-checking, the White House expelled AP, defunded public broadcasters and pressured mainstream media. Judge-gerrymandering, election centralization and legal threats signal a stealth authoritarian shift. Paralleling Viktor Orbán’s Hungarian model, Jones highlights Trump’s lawsuits against CBS and CNN plus threats over alleged left-wing bias.

articles.title: Too many want to do Britain down – Labour will defy the doomsayers and beat the forecasts | Rachel Reeves
articles.trailText: I don’t pretend the choices will be easy, but my budget has one focus: to invest in building a better future for everyone, says UK chancellor Rachel Reeves
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves insists Britain’s economy is robust: interest rates have dropped five times, wages outpace inflation and major trade deals are secured. While acknowledging challenges—stagnant productivity, cost-of-living pressures and global uncertainty from austerity, Brexit and pandemic—she rejects Conservative doom-mongering and vows no return to austerity. Her autumn budget will prioritise targeted investment in the NHS, infrastructure, housing, energy, defence and growth, tied to fiscal discipline to reduce debt costs. She aims to defy Office for Budget Responsibility forecasts by balancing responsibility with ambition, deepening EU ties and reforming planning to build a fairer, thriving future.

articles.title: The Guardian view on state failure: Britain’s crisis is not just one of investment, but also of upkeep | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Fixing prisons, hospitals and local councils means rejecting austerity’s logic and recognising that state spending builds competence, not waste
articles.summary: Guardian editorial argues Britain’s state crisis stems not from investment shortfall alone but from neglect of upkeep. Austerity since 2010 cut prison budgets by 25% and staff by 30%, triggering a “slow-motion collapse” with mistaken prisoner releases doubling last year. While capital spending barely outpaced historic trends, maintenance lagged, hollowing public services. The Office for Budget Responsibility now admits public investment can boost output if slack exists. The piece urges rejecting austerity’s logic and funding upkeep of prisons, hospitals and councils to restore competence and lift productivity.

articles.title: The Guardian view on press freedom in Italy: at a low ebb on Giorgia Meloni’s watch | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The professional environment for journalists taking on powerful interests is worsening in a polarised climate
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that press freedom in Italy is eroding under Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, as mafia intimidation and government harassment converge. After a powerful car bomb targeting Rai investigative journalist Sigfrido Ranucci prompted comparisons with 1980s terror, Meloni voiced solidarity but her right-wing coalition has sued reporters, pressured state media and resisted defamation reforms. EU bodies have flagged threats to public-media independence, while Ranucci faced a parliamentary grilling over an exposé on the Senate president’s neo-fascist past. Vexatious litigation and political interference now threaten hard-hitting investigative shows, while Italy slides down global press-freedom rankings.

articles.title: Trump’s third term? Don’t laugh. He’s never let the rules stop him before | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: He has floated the idea more than once – and his inner circle is already gaming it out. The US constitution might say no, but Trump has a habit of finding his way around even the biggest obstacles, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi warns that Trump and allies, including Steve Bannon and the Heritage Foundation’s Project 2025, are actively plotting a third presidential term despite the 22nd Amendment. They’re exploring legal workarounds from a constitutional convention to repealing the amendment, even declaring a manufactured emergency to delay the 2028 vote. Simultaneously they’d leverage social-media bots, press censorship and propaganda, while a divided Democratic Party struggles to counter. Mahdawi argues US democracy hinges on institutions Trump has relentlessly weakened.

articles.title: What will Labour sacrifice for its housing targets? A standoff in south London is putting it to the test | Anna Minton
articles.trailText: In Peckham, developers unwilling to meet affordable housing quotas are facing down residents and the council, says author Anna Minton
articles.summary: In Peckham, London, Berkeley Homes proposes 877 units on the Aylesham Centre site but cut affordable housing from 35% to 12%, prompting Southwark council to reject the scheme. The developer has appealed directly to the national planning inspectorate, bypassing local objections. Campaigners argue this luxury-led model excludes residents like Teekall’s family, who face displacement despite decent incomes. The public inquiry, coinciding with new government fast-track rules lowering affordable quotas to 20% and boosting mayoral call-in powers, tests Labour’s housing targets and the real trade-off between growth-driven construction and genuinely affordable homes.

articles.title: What is protein water – and can it help me lose weight and gain muscle? | Antiviral
articles.trailText: The macronutrient is better coming from a range of wholefoods, dieticians say – and nearly all of us get enough, anyway
articles.summary: Protein water blends whey and collagen, offering ~20g protein per serve in a sports-drink style. Marketed on social media as a light, low-calorie alternative for muscle building and weight loss, dietitians warn most healthy Australians already meet protein needs via whole foods. These drinks are ultra-processed, pricier per gram of protein, and lack nutrients (fats, fibre) that aid satiety. Excess protein is stored as fat, and there’s no urgent post-workout window. Electrolytes and additives add little value and can increase sodium intake. Experts recommend diversifying protein sources and boosting fibre intake over trendy supplements.

articles.title: It's the noblest battle of our new free-speech age: Sarah Pochin's anti-woke couch crusade | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: The Reform MP was driven ‘mad’ by the number of black and Asian people on the telly. What totally settled non-issue will her party tackle next, asks Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers Reform MP Sarah Pochin’s recent TalkTV rant against sofa adverts featuring Black and Asian families as trivial populism. Hyde contrasts Pochin’s fixation on non-white faces with real economic and political crises—pointing out DFS and Tesco’s rising profits from diverse marketing—and ridicules echo-chamber defenders like Richard Littlejohn. Quoting David Ogilvy, Hyde underlines that ads exist to sell products, not police cultural representation. Pochin’s stance, Hyde argues, exemplifies how populist deflections avoid complex problems by obsessing over irrelevant spoofs, rather than offering substantive solutions. She highlights the irony that TalkTV, where Pochin aired her comments, depends on the very diverse ad revenue she decries.

articles.title: Trump’s saber-rattling in Venezuela is illegal | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: Trump’s threats against the country and attacks on nearby boats cannot be justified under international law
articles.summary: Trump’s deployment of an aircraft carrier and helicopters near Venezuela, coupled with bellicose regime-change threats, violates the UN Charter’s ban on the threat or use of force without Security Council authorization or genuine self-defense. Attempts to invoke the moribund Responsibility to Protect doctrine collapse absent mass atrocities. His lethal strikes on alleged drug-running boats—premised on a secret legal memo and the false pretext of an “armed conflict”—breach international law’s demand that law-enforcement operations use deadly force only as a last resort. Kenneth Roth argues these acts constitute illegal aggression and murder, undermine the rule of law and risk ICC prosecution.

articles.title: Some tenants can now force landlords to make their home liveable. What about the thousands who can’t? | Kwajo Tweneboa
articles.trailText: Awaab’s law imposes new duties on those who own social housing. Millions who rent privately, or are in temporary accommodation, remain unprotected, says housing activist Kwajo Tweneboa
articles.summary: Housing activist Kwajo Tweneboa hails 'Awaab’s law'—which forces social landlords to remedy mould, damp and hazards within set deadlines—but warns it omits 11 million private renters and over 100 000 in temporary accommodation. He urges extending enforceable repair duties to all landlords, properly funding under-resourced local authority enforcement teams, and protecting tenants from retaliatory evictions. Highlighting a £1.4 billion annual NHS burden and the tragic death that spurred the bill, he argues true reform needs comprehensive coverage, robust inspections and eviction safeguards to guarantee safe, habitable homes for everyone.

articles.title: Want to go to a UK university? Don’t ask me to help you write your personal statement  | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: How do you impress admissions tutors? Apparently not by waffling on about babysitting experience, or a love of crochet, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams skewers the annual UCAS personal statement ritual, where 17- and 18-year-olds cram answers to three generic prompts (motivation for their subject, academic preparation, extracurricular relevance) into 4,000 characters. Students agonize over unique selling points—babysitting syndicates, climate‐march leadership or thesaurus swaps for “passionate”—only to sound formulaic or exceed limits. Even high‐fliers feel overshadowed by imagined Eton interns. Williams urges admissions tutors to recognize genuine effort over flashy clichés and cuts through the contrived waffle, urging: accept these kids.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani represents the future of the Democratic party | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: Democratic party leaders like Chuck Schumer refuse to endorse Mamdani, and the New York Times wrongly cautions against him. Both are wrong
articles.summary: Robert Reich argues that Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old New York state assembly member and mayoral candidate, embodies the future of the Democratic Party by focusing on kitchen-table issues like the cost of living. His platform proposes free buses, free childcare, a four-year rent freeze, a $30 minimum wage and $9 billion in new revenue via a 2% tax on incomes above $1 million and an 11.5% corporate rate. Unlike corporate Democrats and centrist moderates, Mamdani inspires young activists, champions working- and lower-middle-class interests and offers authentic, practical solutions to inequality.

articles.title: This hotels saga isn’t really about asylum seekers: it’s a window on to a far bigger scandal  | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: A blistering new report tells a tale of billions wasted and vulnerable people left traumatised, while companies profit from a blundering state, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff exposes how the Home Office’s 2019 contract with Serco, Clearsprings and Mears to house asylum seekers in private rentals and hotels has ballooned from £4.5 bn to £15.3 bn, wasting billions and trapping vulnerable people in unsuitable hotel rooms. A report blames political bluster—eg Rwanda policy—for neglecting basic case processing, which fell from 87% to 16% six-month decision rates. Meanwhile influencer landlords profit and hotels eat over half the asylum budget. Labour proposes speeding claims and using military sites to replace hotels by 2029.

articles.title: Yes, Keir Starmer is Britain’s most unpopular PM ever. That could liberate him | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Forget the public vitriol and use the next four years to get things done – first and foremost, whatever it takes to stop Reform, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee argues that although Keir Starmer is historically unpopular, his mandate allows bold social-democratic reforms. Burdened by Brexit’s £80bn cost, asylum crises and poor by-election showings, Labour lacks visible change and has misjudged its voters. Instead of chasing Conservatives or Reform supporters, Starmer should ignore polls, raise taxes fairly, enact working rights, green investments and youth guarantees, and rally progressives to block Reform. With new rules allowing leadership challenges, pressure mounts for renewal. Toynbee urges using this majority and despair-driven politics to pursue radical policies, form progressive coalitions and restore respect by prioritising purpose over popularity to avert a nativist threat.

articles.title: Forget diplomatic niceties: it's beyond time Europe denounced Trump's trashing of democracy in the US | Paul Taylor
articles.trailText: The convention to stay out of allies’ internal affairs does not apply. What happens in America does not stay in America, says Paul Taylor of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: Paul Taylor criticises nine months of European appeasement of Donald Trump’s dismantling of US democratic institutions—judiciary, civil service, media and elections—and warns that his threats to invoke the 1807 Insurrection Act recall Kent State (1970) and Selma (1965). European inaction risks exporting illiberalism to Hungary, Serbia and Germany’s AfD. Taylor urges EU leaders to break non-interference norms: publicly denounce Trump’s authoritarian drift, back US protesters, offer visas and scholarships to scientists hit by research cuts, forge state-and-city climate and rights partnerships, and affirm separation of powers and rule-of-law values to safeguard democracy at home and abroad.

articles.title: Westpac’s work-from-home complaint was a cultural miff that doesn’t resonate in today’s Australia | Van Badham
articles.trailText: Women who manage to perform their jobs well while caring for children should get a bloody medal, not a trip to Fair Work
articles.summary: The Fair Work Commission ruled Westpac lacked reasonable grounds to rescind a long-time employee’s work-from-home arrangement, which she used to meet primary-school childcare obligations and had performed under “very high” standards. Westpac’s stance—labeling her move and family commitments a clash with corporate culture—exposed entrenched hierarchical attitudes that overlook proven productivity gains from flexible work. Van Badham argues this case spotlights enduring gender inequities in Australia, where women bear a triple-care burden, and few companies offer childcare support despite evidence that remote work boosts performance and work-life balance.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s new deputy leader: Lucy Powell can help a floundering government reconnect | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The return to the cabinet table of the only minister to be sacked in Sir Keir Starmer’s recent reshuffle should be treated as an opportunity to reset
articles.summary: Labour’s new deputy leader, Lucy Powell, reclaimed a seat at cabinet after being the sole casualty of Starmer’s reshuffle, her low-turnout election marking grassroots unease. As a soft-left former Miliband aide, she calls for a shift from technocratic, top-down control to a bolder social-democratic agenda on inequality, winter fuel allowances and disability benefits.
