Though lacking a formal portfolio, Powell’s presence in cabinet offers an opportunity to dial down ‘command & control’, challenge Reform UK on immigration, avoid policy missteps, and reconnect the government with voters ahead of crucial local elections.

articles.title: The Guardian view on global aid cuts: a malaria resurgence could be the canary in the coalmine | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The consequences of Donald Trump’s decision to scrap USAID, and other countries’ decisions to reduce funding, are playing out in deadly fashion
articles.summary: Malaria, killing 600,000—mostly African children and pregnant women—is resurging as western donors cut aid. Trump’s USAID termination and reduced funding threaten elimination goals. A report warns a resurgence could add 1 million deaths by 2030. The Global Fund provides 59% of financing, but recent pledges (Germany’s €1 billion, UK’s rumored 20% cut) risk 82,000–990,000 extra deaths and up to $83 billion GDP loss. Climate change and drug resistance compound risks. Meeting 2030 targets could save 1.86 million lives and boost African GDP by $231 billion.

articles.title: How the free speech debate stops us from stating the bleeding obvious | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The Sarah Pochin controversy has ignited another row over how nasty people are allowed to be before they get ‘cancelled’. It’s an insidious distraction, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams argues that the endless debate over free speech and ‘cancel culture’—exemplified by the Sarah Pochin affair—obscures our ability to plainly condemn racism. She criticizes how political figures dance around racist language without naming it, and how the free speech discourse fixates on provocation limits rather than substance. This obsession has eroded civility, crowded out generative dialogue, and blinded us to what should be obvious: racism is worthless and deserves unequivocal rejection.

articles.title: Milei’s win in Argentina had Trump’s fingerprints all over it. But just how long will their friendship last? | Jordana Timerman
articles.trailText: The Argentine president’s libertarian experiment is in tatters, and his hold on power seems increasingly dependent on volatile US support, says journalist Jordana Timerman
articles.summary: Javier Milei’s midterm victory in Argentina was propelled by Donald Trump’s ideological intervention: a $20 billion US currency swap line, direct peso purchases and public endorsements. Mirroring 1946’s Spruille Braden campaign against Perón, Washington aims to bolster an anti-Perónist ally and signal rewards for loyalty across Latin America. Milei’s radical austerity—steep subsidy cuts, surging inflation and real-wage declines—has already eroded public confidence, and US funding is only a temporary lifeline. With a slim congressional minority protecting his agenda, Milei now faces the daunting task of stabilizing the currency and restoring voter faith, all under volatile US influence.

articles.title: Should Californians vote to redistrict and fight Texas’s fire with fire? | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: A state referendum could give Democrats five more congressional seats. It faces two key critiques
articles.summary: Proposition 50, a California referendum slated for a special election, would allow mid-decade redistricting to gain five Democratic House seats as a direct response to Texas’s new Republican-drawn map. Supporters cast it as necessary counter-gerrymandering; critics warn of provoking GOP retaliation and creating permanently safe, uncompetitive districts that stifle democratic debate. Donegan rebuts the first critique—Republicans already gerrymander unilaterally—and concedes the second’s democratic costs but argues these trade-offs are essential to blunt Trump’s executive overreach. New Democratic members would still wield subpoena and investigative powers to check presidential power.

articles.title: Menopause getting you down? Don���t worry, the wellness industry has a very pricey solution for you | Viv Groskop
articles.trailText: Lion’s mane mushroom, maca root, collagen concoctions: there’s a menopause gold rush out on social media’s wild frontier, says comedian Viv Groskop
articles.summary: Comedian Viv Groskop warns of a “menopause gold rush” on social media as unregulated companies market costly supplements—lion’s mane, maca root, collagen, vitamin B6—and even lip balms branded for menopause relief to an estimated 13 million UK women. Algorithms amplify celebrity-backed ads, exploiting a one-size-fits-all narrative despite 100+ varied symptoms and one in ten sufferers facing suicidal thoughts. Academics call for a public information campaign on HRT, symptom management and realistic expectations. Groskop urges a balanced approach free from fear, hype and over-commercialisation.

articles.title: No shame, no opprobrium: racism is priced in now. Of all the right’s victories, this one has been critical | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: In this age of Tory nativism and Faragist populism, the question isn’t ‘is this person a bigot?’ Now it is ‘does that matter at all?’ says Guardian writer Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: Guardian writer Jason Okundaye argues that racism has been normalized and depoliticized within the UK right: explicit bigotry—from Robert Jenrick’s ‘no white faces’ remark to calls for deporting established families—now passes without penalty. Whereas Cameron and May at least acknowledged systemic racial injustice, today race debate is narrowed to personal insults and dog whistles around migration and culture. Ultra-conservatives have reframed racism as mere language, eroding focus on real outcomes in education, health, justice and integration.

articles.title: Geert Wilders failed in government, but the far right retains its grip on the Netherlands | Cas Mudde
articles.trailText: A media in thrall to Wilders’ party ensures its agenda is entrenched in Dutch politics and will dominate Wednesday’s election, says political scientist Cas Mudde
articles.summary: On October’s ninth Tweede Kamer vote, Dutch politics remain mired in fragmentation and far-right normalisation. Geert Wilders pulled his PVV-led coalition after under a year, yet core PVV policies (toughest asylum laws, burqa and antifa bans) persist—sanctioned by media sensationalism and mainstream parties. Wilders looms large despite scarce appearances; JA21 and FVD (under new leader Lidewij de Vos) gained disproportionate attention. Centre-right blocs shift: CDA surges on BBB/NSC collapse, VVD concedes voters to JA21, D66 and GL/PvdA adopt tougher immigration stances. The left stays marginal. With all parties excluding PVV but divided over partners, coalition talks promise a protracted deadlock and far-right hegemony.

articles.title: Spooky eucy! Let’s celebrate the haunting beauty of Australia’s gum trees this Halloween | Jess Harwood
articles.trailText: From skeletal spectres to portals to the underworld, eucalypts have the power to thrill and chill
articles.summary: Jess Harwood invites Aussies to spookify Halloween with native eucalypts: ghost gums (E. aparrerinja) glow under full moons in WA, NT and Qld; red tingles (E. jacksonii), rooted in 52-million-year-old Gondwana lineage, form hollow giants like underworld portals; Tasmania’s endangered Miena cider gum (E. gunnii divaricata) twists in witchy shapes, mourning climate decline; post-fire ‘zombie’ gums resprout from lignotubers; and warty yate (E. megacornuta) sports opercula like ghoulish fingers.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the budget: what a Labour chancellor should really say | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Rachel Reeves needs her address to restore confidence, rebuild capacity and bury the tired orthodoxy that has held Britain back
articles.summary: Guardian editorial outlines the speech a Labour chancellor should deliver: commit to balancing the economy by boosting demand and public investment rather than austerity; introduce a modest financial transactions levy; launch a National Reconstruction Plan to invest 1% of GDP annually in green energy, transport and advanced manufacturing under a new public balance-sheet rule; forge a Bank concordat to align monetary policy with growth objectives; pilot a regional job guarantee; create an Agency for Public Investment; implement a tiered-reserve system saving £20bn and a bank tax; and fully fund day-to-day spending without raising taxes, marking a clear break from Tory underinvestment.

articles.title: The Guardian view on electronic implants: a new way of seeing, not of being | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Electronic implants are helping people see again. Their promise is profound, but so are the risks. Progress must be guided by ethics and accessibility
articles.summary: Editorial highlights the progress and caveats of retinal microchip implants for age-related macular degeneration, where a 4mm×30μm Prima chip relays camera-captured images via infrared to the retina, enabling 84% of 38 trial participants to read, gaining five lines on an eye-chart after one year. It situates this among broader brain-computer interfaces—prosthetics with sensory feedback, Musk’s Neuralink—and warns of surgical complications (26 adverse events), high costs, regulatory hurdles, and the need for ethical, equitable deployment. AI decoding of visual signals underpinned the trials. Devices await FDA/CE approval and potential NHS rollout via public–private biotech partnerships, echoing £13k–£37k prosthetic costs and normalizing cyborg futures.

articles.title: Keir Starmer won’t be surprised Lucy Powell is his new deputy leader – but he should be very worried | Morgan Jones
articles.trailText: Labour members – and Caerphilly voters – have made their feelings clear. When will the PM realise that his strategy just isn’t working, asks Morgan Jones of Renewal
articles.summary: Lucy Powell won the Labour deputy leadership by 54% to 46% over Bridget Phillipson, reflecting deep discontent among rank-and-file left-liberal members with Keir Starmer’s government. A former Miliband aide and MP for Manchester Central, Powell—backed by Momentum—campaigned as a soft-left voice demanding bolder policies and a clearer Labour identity. Phillipson, the education secretary, drew support with teacher pay rises and a proposal to tax private school fees. Powell’s victory secures her a seat on the NEC and underscores anti-Starmer sentiment, presaging fresh pressure on the prime minister ahead of local elections after poor by-election results like Caerphilly.

articles.title: The ‘immoral, unthinkable’ political dispute rupturing a friendship requires a delicate therapeutic approach I Bianca Denny
articles.trailText: Disagreements between friends are as old as friendship itself, but the weight of a fractured world is pressing on many
articles.summary: Dr Bianca Denny examines how a protest-related political dispute nearly ended Sam and Chris’s decade-long friendship amid a climate of heightened global tensions. Employing “parts work” from internal family systems therapy, she treats Sam’s urge to sever ties as akin to cutting off internal self-parts, using their therapeutic relationship as a mirror for external conflicts. Through hypothetical questioning about her own protest stance and guiding Sam to list both positive and challenging aspects of his friend, Denny fosters curiosity over rigid judgment, tempering Sam’s initial impulse and allowing space for ambivalence and dialogue.

articles.title: Trump’s White House overhaul fits a global trend among far-right populists | Jan-Werner Müller
articles.trailText: The president’s move is less an example of American exceptionalism than part of a familiar pattern
articles.summary: Trump’s razing of the White House’s East Wing and push for neoclassical federal buildings mirror a global far-right playbook where leaders—from Erdoğan’s mosque palace in Ankara to Orbán’s medievalizing rebuilds and Modi’s temple projects—rewrite history in stone. His 2020 “Promoting Beautiful Federal Civic Architecture” executive order, linked to his 1776 commission, aimed to enshrine ‘real American’ identity via classical design and erase modernist or marginalized legacies. Like other populists, Trump wields monumental architecture to broadcast dominance, forge a mythic national narrative, and embed propaganda in everyday life, ensuring his legacy endures beyond his term.

articles.title: Catherine Connolly’s election as president has added a new dynamic to Irish politics | Justine McCarthy
articles.trailText: After a bizarre contest in which both government candidates blew their chances, the left has shown it can unite to win, says Irish Times columnist Justine McCarthy
articles.summary: Catherine Connolly, a left-wing independent TD, won a decisive victory to become Ireland’s 10th president, ending a chaotic contest in which Fianna Fáil’s Jim Gavin withdrew over an unpaid refund and Fine Gael’s Heather Humphreys lost traction despite negative smear ads. Backed by an unprecedented alliance of Sinn Féin, Labour, Social Democrats, People Before Profit and Greens, Connolly’s austere outsider profile, fluency in Irish, pro-reunification and disability rights advocacy appealed to younger and nonconformist voters. Record spoilt ballots amid Dublin riots underscore a restless electorate. Her triumph shatters the myth of an ungovernable left and lays groundwork for future cooperation ahead of the next general election.

articles.title: The tragic change a single year has made in America | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: As we approach the anniversary of the 2024 election, we awake to new horrors each day. But we must not give up hope
articles.summary: Margaret Sullivan warns that in the year since the 2024 election, America has slid toward authoritarianism under President Trump: immigrant roundups without due process, militarized policing, the White House gutted for a private ballroom, political rivals prosecuted, a Pentagon spending nearly $1 trillion in secrecy, and intimidation of universities, media and businesses. Yet hope remains in upcoming midterms, congressional probes, mass No Kings protests and a journalistic awakening against censorship. Sullivan urges citizens and reporters to hold power to account, preserve democracy and refuse to give up on the republic.

articles.title: Heard the one about the three vicars who went to the cinema – and were taught a lesson in tolerance? | Ravi Holy
articles.trailText: Watching the film I Swear, at first I was irked by the shouting and swearing from an audience member. But I ended up thanking him, says vicar and standup comedian Ravi Holy
articles.summary: Vicar and comedian Ravi Holy attended I Swear, a biopic about John Davidson MBE and Tourette syndrome, with two fellow vicars. A teenager with TS in the audience unintentionally disrupted the film with vocal tics, initially annoying Holy. Yet as the story unfolded, he realized that sharing the cinema with someone whose lived experience mirrored Davidson’s onscreen arc deepened his emotional engagement. By the end, Holy thanked the boy, Joe, and his father, Mark, and urged viewers to welcome neurodiverse audiences for a richer, more authentic experience.

articles.title: The war in Gaza is supposed to be over. But be warned: without truth and justice, it will never truly end  | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: A fragile ceasefire is in place, but what’s needed is an international tribunal for resolution and reparation. That’s the only route to lasting peace, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Despite a fragile 10 October ceasefire the Gaza war persists: killings continue, aid is restricted and occupation holds. Simon Tisdall argues that without addressing root causes—denial of Palestinian statehood—and enforcing accountability for alleged war crimes by Israeli leaders (Netanyahu, Gallant) and Hamas figures (Deif), the conflict risks reigniting. He demands an independent inquiry into the 7 October security failures, a UN-backed international tribunal complementing ICC and ICJ efforts to probe combatants, complicit states (US, Iran) and arms-supplying countries like the UK, ensure reparations, open Gaza to investigators, and secure lasting peace through justice, not impunity.

articles.title: Why is Trump demolishing the White House's East Wing? Because he wants to | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The president’s mega-project raises a lot of questions ��� including when he’s planning on leaving
articles.summary: President Donald Trump secretly bulldozed the 123-year-old White House East Wing—home to first ladies’ offices—for a $300 million, 90,000 sq ft ballroom. The demolition, executed without permits or National Capital Planning Commission approval, alarmed preservationists. Trump insists he’ll fund it “100%” with donations from tech giants (Apple, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft) and defense contractors (Lockheed Martin, Palantir). Critics cite ego and constitutional overreach, noting the project’s scope and timing fuel speculation he’s gearing up for a third presidential term.

articles.title: Trump was planning to send troops to San Francisco. Now he’s not. Here’s why | Joe Eskenazi
articles.trailText: The US president’s reversal was as capricious as his original plan. What if local billionaires had urged him to stick with it?
articles.summary: In October 2025, President Trump abruptly reversed his decision to deploy federal agents and troops to San Francisco after personally phoning Mayor Daniel Lurie. The about-face—driven, Trump admitted, by lobbying from local billionaire CEOs Jensen Huang and Marc Benioff and Lurie’s polite citing of record-low crime, rising retail and hotel bookings—highlights the capricious, personalized nature of federal intervention. Critics warn this deal hinges on billionaire “vibes” rather than policy, leaving long-term safety and federal assistance uncertain.

articles.title: Trump’s men come to Israel with plenty to say. But they’re silent on any real future for Gaza   | Roy Schwartz
articles.trailText: Kushner, Witkoff, Vance and Rubio – they’ve all been sent to keep the ceasefire in place. Now we need to hear about a concrete plan, says Haaretz journalist Roy Schwartz
articles.summary: Since Gaza’s fragile ceasefire, envoys from Trump—including Kushner, Witkoff, Vance and Rubio—have shuttled to Israel to deter renewed war, pressing Netanyahu’s government after Israeli retaliatory strikes killed dozens of Palestinians. Yet Washington has no clear plan for Gaza’s reconstruction, the composition or timeline of an international security force or the disarmament of Hamas. Israeli media largely omit civilian casualties, fueling hardline sentiment. Schwartz argues that beyond babysitting the truce, US emissaries must now present concrete governance, security and humanitarian strategies to avert another escalation.

articles.title: The Supremes, Marcus Garvey, Tupac Shakur: the cultural figures who inspired our Black History Month panel | Lenny Henry, Zeinab Badawi, Yolanda Brown and others
articles.trailText: At the end of Black History Month, our panel reveal the influences that helped them shape their beliefs and identities
articles.summary: A multi-generational panel—including Lenny Henry, Zeinab Badawi, YolanDa Brown, Nadine White, Gus Casely-Hayford, Simone Orefuwa and others—share the artists and movements that shaped their Black identities. From Percival Everett’s reimagined classics and pan-African unity under Nasser and Garvey, to Winifred Atwell’s genre-bending piano, Marvin Gaye’s stirring protest songs, Tupac’s poetic rap, The Supremes’ diva anthems, Black Panther’s pan-African soundtrack and reggae’s community anthem, each testimony spotlights art as a catalyst for pride, purpose and resistance.

articles.title: France has survived revolutions and wars: its crisis now is deep, but not terminal | David A Bell
articles.trailText: From the raid on the Louvre to the spectacle of Sarkozy in jail, it is tempting to think France is on a downward spiral. But history tells the tale of its resilience, says historian David A Bell
articles.summary: After a 2024 snap election produced a hung parliament, Emmanuel Macron’s government has cycled through five prime ministers, his popularity hovers at 20%, and two-thirds of French view politicians as corrupt. High-profile scandals—Sarkozy’s jailing, the Louvre heist, a shocking rape trial—and a 5.4% deficit fuel bleak public mood and a surge for Le Pen’s National Rally. Yet historian David Bell argues France’s chronic declinism dates to the 1760s and, despite deep divisions over exclusion and economic grievance, core republican consensus endures. Past crises—from 19th-century upheavals to 2005 riots—underscore France’s resilience, not terminal collapse.

articles.title: Australia fiddles with fossil gas while the country swelters in record heat. It doesn’t make sense | Bill Hare
articles.trailText: Australians have an obvious interest in action against global warming. Focusing on gas instead of renewables for the energy transition risks sabotaging our future
articles.summary: Bill Hare warns that Australia is enduring record October heat, marine heatwaves and reef bleaching as global warming nears 1.5C, risking 2.7C by century’s end. Despite renewables’ plummeting costs, the government backs new fossil gas projects and LNG exports to Asia through 2070, locking in emissions and relying on unproven CCS. The National Climate Risk Assessment highlights severe risks across health, ecosystems and infrastructure at 2C warming. Hare urges immediate phase-out of gas by 2050, scale-up of solar, wind, storage and green hydrogen, and seizing Australia’s renewable export potential.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Caerphilly byelection: Labour’s collapse in its Welsh heartland signals a wider loss | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Plaid Cymru’s win in Caerphilly marks more than a local upset. It exposes the exhaustion of Labour’s moral imagination – and a deeper British crisis of purpose
articles.summary: Labour’s loss of its Caerphilly stronghold to Plaid Cymru in the Welsh byelection signifies more than a local upset: it exposes the collapse of Labour’s century-long dominance in Wales, driven by infighting, a competence-over-conviction approach under Sir Keir Starmer and a lack of moral imagination. Plaid’s victory demonstrates that Welsh voters crave a politics rooted in ethics and local identity rather than managerial continuity or right-wing populism. Reform UK’s challenge was contained by decency, yet the result reflects a broader British crisis of purpose—where material insecurity and moral energy collide, defining the battleground for the left’s future revitalisation.

articles.title: The Guardian view on a bumper crop of horror: scary times call for even scarier films | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A new wave of socially engaged movies is storming the box office and changing how we think about the genre
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial argues that 2025 marks a ‘golden year’ for horror films, reflecting contemporary anxieties—from AI dystopia recast in Frankenstein adaptations by Guillermo del Toro, Luc Besson and Maggie Gyllenhaal, to capitalism’s ‘monsters’ in vampire and zombie sagas like Ryan Coogler’s Sinners and 28 Years Later. Tracing horror’s lineage from German expressionism and 1980s vampire booms to Jordan Peele’s Get Out, it shows how ‘elevated horror’—a cheaper, experimental medium—tackles race, class and gender, attracting women filmmakers. As Žižek observes, horror highlights how apocalyptic visions often outpace imagining economic alternatives. In pandemics, war and climate crisis, shared fear offers communal catharsis and confrontation with inner dread.

articles.title: Blue Lights is more than great TV. It might be the best chance Britons have of reckoning with the Troubles | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: The reaction to the Bloody Sunday trial makes it clear: those of us outside Northern Ireland just don’t understand the painful legacy of this brutal conflict, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland argues that the Bloody Sunday trial verdict—acquitting ‘Soldier F’ due to missing evidence and discredited witnesses—highlights how most Britons still ignore Northern Ireland’s ongoing trauma. Bereaved families felt betrayed, stoking “justice envy” between nationalist and unionist victims. Freedland says the Troubles’ legacy remains alive in daily policing and organised crime, and that the BBC drama Blue Lights, by embedding characters’ personal scars and post-conflict tensions into a police procedural, offers UK audiences a rare reckoning with the region’s living history and the fragile balance between justice and peace.

articles.title: Lily Allen’s West End Girl is funny, sexy, jawdropping – and forged in the fires of tabloid Britain | Jennifer Jasmine White
articles.trailText: The singer learned early how to navigate pop feminism and the public’s insatiable appetites. Her new album bumps up against the limits of both, says writer Jennifer Jasmine White
articles.summary: Lily Allen’s West End Girl dissects her high-profile divorce from actor David Harbour through 14 tracks that blend raw confessions of betrayal, family woes and sexual candor with sharp satire. Jennifer Jasmine White argues the album transcends mere revenge, embodying a pop-feminist therapy session forged by tabloid-fueled voyeurism. Allen exposes both her own neuroses and our cultural appetite for intimate secrets, challenging the confessional economy that demands female self-exposure. Funny, sexy and uncomfortably honest, West End Girl spotlights how market-driven feminism elicits compulsive self-revelation even as it confronts the audience’s invasive appetites.

articles.title: Donald Trump has built a regime of retribution and reward | Sidney Blumenthal
articles.trailText: The president’s purges and attacks on his enemies have developed into a system in which injustice is made routine
articles.summary: President Trump has institutionalized a system of punitive loyalty: purging DOJ and FBI officials—via firings of acting directors like Driscoll—and installing loyalists (Patel, Bondi) in senior posts. He demands $230m compensation, labels opponents “terrorists” under PNSM7, and relies on Supreme Court-granted immunity. His broad pardons—January 6 insurrectionists, George Santos, anti-abortion activists—reward fealty, while weaponized prosecutions target critics (Letitia James, Adam Schiff). This dual regime of retribution and reward transforms justice into a political tool.

articles.title: Reform swaggered into Caerphilly, ready for a coronation. An unpleasant surprise lay in store | Will Hayward
articles.trailText: Predictions of a Reform win were wide of the mark. But Labour’s crushing byelection defeat offers important lessons too, says Guardian columnist Will Hayward
articles.summary: Plaid Cymru won the Caerphilly Senedd byelection with nearly 50% of the vote, relegating Reform UK to 36% and Labour to a historic low of 11%. The shift exposes Labour’s complacency in its Welsh heartland and highlights risks under the new proportional system, which punishes parties below an 11% threshold. Reform’s immigration-focused strategy misread local concerns, while Plaid’s veteran candidate and clear anti–hard-right stance resonated. With the full Senedd election in May 2026 looming, UK parties must actively oppose far-right populism and deliver real policy gains to win back voters.

articles.title: Why we’re holding a teach-in about American history at the Smithsonian | Kellie Carter Jackson and Nicole Hemmer
articles.trailText: Podcasters, professors, journalists and ordinary citizens will gather in Washington as the Trump regime wages war on history
articles.summary: On October 26 podcasters, professors and citizens will hold a dawn-to-dusk teach-in at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History to confront the Trump administration's attempts to defund exhibits on the darker sides of US history and promote a whitewashed, MAGA-driven narrative. Organized by the hosts of "This Day" and "The Memory Palace" podcasts, it invokes the 1965 University of Michigan antiwar teach-in model, emphasizing in-depth, evidence-based learning over slogans. Jackson and Hemmer frame it as an act of defiance and solidarity, arguing that defending museums and truthful history is essential to safeguarding American democracy.

articles.title: What kind of country puts its pensioners ahead of children in poverty? | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: As long as a third of children are living below the poverty line, the government cannot justify keeping the pensions triple lock, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee highlights that with one-third of UK children in poverty and basic universal credit rising to just £98/week against a Joseph Rowntree Foundation basket costing £120/week, welfare falls short. Frozen housing allowances and a two-child cap worsen hardship, while pensioners enjoy a 4.8% triple lock and 11% pension credit boost. Toynbee urges ending the child limit, pegging state pensions to earnings only and redirecting savings to lift children out of poverty.

articles.title: Grooming gang survivors risk becoming pawns in a political game that is no place for vulnerable people | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: The chaos surrounding the inquiry stands as a warning: this is what happens when collapsing trust in public institutions, combined with point scoring, leads to paralysis, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Gaby Hinsliff argues that the national grooming-gang inquiry risks collapse as survivors like Fiona Goddard—failed in childhood by agencies in Bradford and elsewhere—quit a shaky panel distrustful of shortlisted chairs. Both Jim Gamble and Annie Hudson withdrew, citing political point-scoring, while a split among remaining panel members over Home Office minister Jess Phillips and liaison officer Sabah Kaiser deepens the crisis. Hinsliff warns this paralysis retraumatises victims and urges a cross-party effort to rebuild faith and deliver real accountability.

articles.title: The crimewave sweeping Britain? Illegal houses in multiple occupation | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: With private-sector villainy and public-sector complicity, what makes this HMO scandal so characteristic of modern Britain is how far the guilt spreads, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty exposes how illegal HMOs have proliferated across Britain’s rental market, focusing on Bowes Park tenant Eunice Osei, forced for three years into a windowless, damp micro-room despite £1,147 monthly rent. Landlord Andreas Stavrou Antoniades illegally subdivided homes into 11 HMO units, evaded licensing and paid nominal fines. Haringey council prosecuted him yet continued placing vulnerable tenants via Universal Credit. The scandal highlights private-sector greed, public-sector complicity, inadequate fines, legacy of underbuilt social housing and weak enforcement, underscoring systemic failures in modern Britain’s housing system.

articles.title: The Children’s Booker prize will tell kids that they matter
articles.trailText: As the number of children reading for pleasure hits a record low, the new award highlights its importance for wellbeing, and will give away thousands of books
articles.summary: Frank Cottrell-Boyce, Waterstones Children’s Laureate and inaugural chair of judges for the new Children’s Booker Prize (for 8–12-year-olds), argues the award can reverse a two-decade drop in children reading for pleasure by spotlighting bold new fiction, involving child judges and gifting thousands of books to underserved young readers. Launching alongside the government’s Year of Reading, the prize aims to widen horizons through imaginative titles—from Jamie Smart’s Bunny vs Monkeys to Katherine Rundell’s Impossible Creatures—while sending a powerful signal that every child matters, nurturing wellbeing, empathy and lifelong curiosity. Applications for junior judges open spring 2026.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Conservative immigration policy: the threat of mass expulsions is abhorrent | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Tory plans to revoke indefinite leave to remain in pursuit of greater ‘cultural coherence’ resemble the most extreme ambitions of far-right fringe parties
articles.summary: The Guardian lambasts Tory proposals to revoke indefinite leave to remain (ILR) from benefit claimants or earners below £38,700, warning this would uproot hundreds of thousands—potentially millions—of settled residents. It contrasts Keir Starmer’s ‘one in, one out’ deal with France, which acknowledges the necessity of EU collaboration and safe legal routes, with Kemi Badenoch and Nigel Farage’s hard-line stance that vilifies refugees and casts them as criminals. The editorial likens the ILR revocation to mass expulsions, exceeding even Idi Amin’s 1972 Ugandan Asian deportations, calling the plan abhorrent.

articles.title: The Guardian view on live music: a scheme to spread the sound around deserves support | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: More gigs would be a good thing, and a voluntary £1 levy for grassroots venues could help
articles.summary: An editorial in The Guardian warns that between 2019 and 2024 small UK music venues and festivals have sharply declined—125 grassroots venues lost in 2023 and 161 festivals closed—while arena tours and stadium shows pocket record revenues (£1.63 billion in 2023). Backed by the Music Venue Trust and MPs, a voluntary £1 ticket levy on major venues would redistribute funds to sustain local clubs, community-owned sites and nurture new talent. The scheme, complemented by public investment, addresses venue closures, reduced music education, ticket inflation and industry concentration in ticketing giants Live Nation and AEG, aiming to rebalance Britain’s live-music ecosystem.

articles.title: Silly inflatable costumes are taking over anti-Trump protests. What are they actually saying? | Julia Carrie Wong
articles.trailText: Whimsical frogs and unicorns have become mascots of the resistance – but it’s easy for tactical frivolity to devolve into entertainment
articles.summary: Beginning with a viral moment in Portland when a protester sprayed with chemical agent inside an inflatable frog suit, activists launched “Operation Inflation,” equipping No Kings anti-Trump marches nationwide with whimsical inflatable animals from frogs to unicorns. Embracing “tactical frivolity,” these costumes mock the administration’s violent “stern father” narrative and generate powerful imagery, yet risk devolving into commodified entertainment. Wong argues they work best strategically on the front lines—de-escalating state violence and creating symbolic spectacles—but are insufficient alone to build a serious, sustained opposition.

articles.title: Dogs bred for herding sheep shouldn’t be stuck in the city. I would know – years ago, I tearfully gave one up | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: Chasing a ball around for 20 minutes just isn’t going to give these beautiful, intelligent creatures the exercise and stimulation they need
articles.summary: Rebecca Shaw argues that herding breeds such as kelpies, blue heelers and border collies are ill-suited to city apartments and postage-stamp yards. She criticizes a bank advertisement that portrays moving from a 15th-floor flat to a 3×3m backyard as life-changing for a kelpie. Shaw recounts watching owners think a 20-minute ball-toss in a tiny park suffices, and shares her own heartbreak of rehoming her border collie, Jess, after moving off a farm. These intelligent, high-energy dogs require vast spaces and mental work to stay healthy. Prospective urban owners should consider more adaptable breeds or rescue dogs instead.

articles.title: New sanctions and weapons will not stop Russia. It’s time for Ukraine’s allies to change their flawed strategy | Christopher S Chivvis
articles.trailText: A negotiated settlement would be unfair and frustrating. But after nearly four years of fighting, it may be the best option, says Christopher S Chivvis of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace
articles.summary: Christopher S Chivvis of the Carnegie Endowment critiques the “cost-imposition” strategy of nearly four years of sanctions—now including Trump’s oil and gas measures and eased missile restrictions—and advanced arms like Abrams tanks and F-16s, which have slowed but not halted Russia’s gains. With the EU on its 19th sanctions package and China cushioning Moscow, incremental pressure won’t compel Putin to negotiate on Ukrainian terms. He urges a strategic shift: sustain deterrence while pursuing realistic talks—even if it means conceding regions like Donbas—to respect US power’s limits.

articles.title: Leading conservationists just decided that genetically engineering wild animals is OK – sometimes. They’re right | Helen Pilcher
articles.trailText: Humans have been selectively breeding animals for millennia. If we can help species survive by tweaking their DNA in a lab, I say bring it on, says science writer Helen Pilcher
articles.summary: At the IUCN’s 2025 World Conservation Congress, delegates rejected a moratorium on releasing gene-edited wildlife, opting instead for cautious, case-by-case approvals of CRISPR and gene-drive interventions to boost disease resistance, pollution tolerance and climate resilience. Pilcher argues that humans have long altered animal DNA through selective breeding and that modern techniques simply accelerate evolution amid human-driven extinction. Critics warn of uncontrollable novel traits and population-level risks, but proponents believe rigorous oversight could make genetic engineering vital for saving imperiled species.

articles.title: What we misunderstand in the debate over free speech | Avram Alpert
articles.trailText: Freedom of speech requires freedom of thought – and the American political climate poses a serious threat to it
articles.summary: Avram Alpert argues that authentic free speech hinges on free thought: a conscientious, critical, open-minded pursuit of truth inspired by Mill. He warns that cognitive biases, propaganda, attacks on education and science, media consolidation by billionaires, and ‘fear speech’ corrode this freedom. Rather than legal bans, we need new cultural norms—robust public discourse, strong educational and research systems, informed civic spaces, and a ‘call-in�� culture that listens to dissent. True defense of free speech demands nurturing the conditions for genuine free thought and discussion.

articles.title: The White House is getting renovated. Can we do the whole country while we’re at it? | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: Refurbishing the nation should be a collective effort – not the work of a single man with an unmatched taste for the gaudy
articles.summary: Dave Schilling critiques the Trump administration’s rapid, unapproved demolition of the White House East Wing to build a new ballroom—ostensibly funded personally by Trump—calling it a gaudy overreach that undermines the historic “people’s house.” He notes demolition proceeded without formal NCPC approval or vertical construction permits, sparking preservationists’ consternation. Schilling links this makeover to broader national decay—paralyzed government, eroded trust and elite enrichment—and invokes Jacksonian populism, urging a collective, democratic “renovation” of America rather than ceding control to one man’s taste.

articles.title: Could Zurich’s housing cooperatives be the solution to the rest of Europe’s housing crisis? | Peter Apps
articles.trailText: One in every five citizens in the city has bought a share in the company that built and owns their apartment block, says Inside Housing’s Peter Apps
articles.summary: Zurich’s cooperative housing sector now provides homes to one in five residents via resident-owned co-ops like Mehr als Wohnen, where members invest CHF 7,000–25,000 for a returnable share and pay cost-rent covering debt and upkeep. Backed by a century-old movement and boosted since 2011 by land leases, low-interest loans and zoning perks, co-ops deliver mixed-income, car-free developments with communal spaces, democratic governance and no speculative profit. Architect-designed, ecologically rated buildings exemplify high-quality standards. Despite rising costs, Zurich’s model sustains affordability and social integration, offering a scalable alternative to stalled social housing systems facing Europe’s crisis.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves is the face of this budget. But the really big decisions are not in Labour’s hands | Larry Elliott
articles.trailText: The UK’s economic policy isn’t decided by politicians, but by the OBR and the Bank of England. This is a system in dire need of a rethink, says Guardian columnist Larry Elliott
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Larry Elliott warns that while Chancellor Rachel Reeves will unveil an October 2025 budget heavy on tax rises, the big fiscal shape and interest-rate decisions lie with the technocratic OBR and Bank of England, not elected politicians. He argues their binding rules—multi-year spending forecasts and a rigid 2% inflation target—are flawed guesswork that hinders growth and ignores social goals. Elliott calls for reform: broaden the OBR’s remit to include poverty impact, adopt a flexible 1–4% inflation range or restore discretionary political control to better align fiscal and monetary policy with real-world needs.

articles.title: We must act now: without a written constitution, Reform UK will have carte blanche to toxify our nation | Goerge Monbiot
articles.trailText: It means breaking with hundreds of years of tradition, but it can’t wait. As hard-right figures spread division and laud autocrats, a fail-safe is vital, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Guardian columnist George Monbiot, recalling how Brazil’s clear 1988 constitution let citizens assert fundamental rights, warns that the UK’s uncodified, arcane framework—scattered across statutes, precedents and conventions—enables autocrats like Reform UK deputy leader Richard Tice to praise UAE-style authoritarianism. With parliament sovereign, no codified separation of powers and no effective limits, majorities could impose endless statutory instruments and extinguish rights in an 'elective dictatorship.' He urges Labour (with its two-thirds majority) to convene a citizens’ constitutional convention and codify a Bill of Rights to safeguard democracy against well-funded networks like Atlas before collapse.

articles.title: Poland’s birth rate is in freefall. The cause? A loneliness epidemic that state cash can’t solve | Anna Gromada
articles.trailText: Bonuses for families have done nothing to fix a baby bust caused by post-communist Europe’s relationships crisis, says sociologist Anna Gromada
articles.summary: Despite Poland’s booming economy, low unemployment and generous “800 Plus” child benefit, its fertility rate plunged from 1.3 in 2015 to 1.1 in 2024 and an estimated 1.05 this year. Anna Gromada argues the real cause is a loneliness epidemic and relationship crisis: nearly half of Poles under 30 are single, dating apps fuel hesitation, and gender polarization and post-communist social shifts hinder partnerships. Rapid economic change, fraying family ties, a surge in psychotherapy and educational and geographic imbalances between men and women have made sustained intimacy—and thus childbearing—rarer than any financial incentive can fix.

articles.title: Australian executives don’t deserve big bonuses. It’s time to end the cult of the CEO | John Quiggin
articles.trailText: Hardly anyone now believes in the neoliberal myth that giving more money to already highly paid executives leads to better companies
articles.summary: John Quiggin argues that lavish CEO bonuses at tax-free, loss-making firms such as CSL and Optus expose the neoliberal myth that high executive pay drives performance. Bonus schemes offer limited pay variation and no real downside, unlike risks borne by households. Privatisation, heralded to boost productivity, stalled after 2000; publicly born CSL and Optus now deliver little public benefit, fueling inequality. The "cult of the CEO" entrenched shareholder-value orthodoxy, widening pay gaps and souring consumer opinion. Yet pushback, from re-publicization efforts to worker resistance against return-to-office mandates, signals growing rejection of CEO supremacy and a potential shift toward the public interest.

articles.title: The Guardian view on campus discontent: listen to those on the frontline | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The government’s funding plans, announced in this week’s white paper, won’t do much to alleviate a deepening crisis of morale among university staff
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial argues that allowing UK tuition fees to rise with inflation from 2026, amid an eight-year freeze, and adding an international student surcharge, will exacerbate a higher education funding crisis. With 40% of English universities in deficit, institutions have shed over 12,000 jobs, staff pay is 20% down in real terms, and strikes loom as morale collapses under mounting workloads and insecurity. The piece urges policymakers to heed frontline staff and replace the fee-led model with stable public funding.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the cloud crash: an outage that showed who really runs the internet | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A failure at Amazon’s server centre paralysed global services for 15 hours. It was not just a glitch but a stark reminder of our digital dependency and fragility
articles.summary: An AWS outage in US-EAST-1 knocked offline Snapchat, Roblox, Signal, Duolingo and Amazon’s own operations for 15 hours, disrupting over 2,000 companies and underscoring how three cloud giants control 60 percent of global data flow. The repeated failures expose the fragility of digital infrastructure hinging on a narrow choke point and heighten calls—from UCL researchers—to build sovereign clouds, diversify supply chains and adopt open-source standards. Europe’s reliance risks digital colonialism as India, Brazil and Gaia-X push public alternatives.

articles.title: Big? Beautiful? Donald Trump is literally ripping apart the home of US democracy. Is anyone really surprised? | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: Demolition work has begun on part of the White House’s East Wing to make way for the president’s ballroom. Truly, these are post-satirical times, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Emma Brockes criticises Donald Trump’s demolition of the White House East Wing to build a 90,000 sq ft, $250 m ballroom seating 999, denouncing it as a post-satirical assault on a national symbol. Unlike the Obamas’ kitchen garden and Biden’s drape swap, Trump is bulldozing the 1942 facade, prompting diggers, torn-down walls and dust. Heritage bodies—the Society of Architectural Historians, AIA—and Hillary Clinton have condemned the plan. Privately funded, the new ballroom risks becoming a corporate event space, blurring state and personal business. Trump insists every president has 'dreamt' of a White House ballroom for state visits, while press secretary Karoline Leavitt calls the criticism 'fake outrage'.

articles.title: Poetry in motion: the most joyous four hours I’ve ever spent on a train | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: The plug sockets may not work and there isn’t a trolley service, but the Heart of Wales Line is a friendly, bustling, beautiful treat, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles recounts a four-hour trip on the Heart of Wales Line, boarding a two-carriage train at Swansea to Craven Arms. Despite broken sockets and no trolley service, he savors estuaries, viaducts and rolling hills while fellow passengers—retiree footpath volunteers and chatty locals—share wine and stories. Covering 121 miles and 25 stations such as Llandeilo and Llanwrtyd Wells, the community-maintained route cost £22. Chiles hails its scenic charm, camaraderie and unspoiled atmosphere as a bucket-list railway experience.

articles.title: I’ve seen courts hand children back to their abusers. Today that horror finally ends | Charlotte Proudman
articles.trailText: Ministers say a parent’s right to see their child no longer trumps a child’s right to safety. Now we need a public inquiry into years of needless suffering, says barrister Charlotte Proudman
articles.summary: Government will repeal the 10-year presumption in family courts that parental involvement trumped child safety, following the 2020 MoJ report exposing a pro-contact culture that forced rape survivors to return children under threat of prison. Barrister Charlotte Proudman, founder of Right to Equality, highlights cases like MP Kate Kniveton’s five-year battle and Claire Throssell’s sons Jack and Paul, killed after court-ordered access. She demands a public inquiry into decades of secret miscarriages, mandatory domestic abuse training for judges and transparency in family law reform, coining the change "Jack and Paul’s Law."

articles.title: It’s great to see pregnant women in the public eye – but must they all be so gorgeous? | Coco Khan
articles.trailText: Call me cynical, but I have a feeling Victoria’s Secret wouldn’t have sent a heavily pregnant model down the runway if she looked like most of us do at that stage, writes Coco Khan
articles.summary: Fashion giant Victoria’s Secret sparked debate by having veteran ‘angel’ Jasmine Tookes open its runway nine months pregnant, prompting Coco Khan to question the beauty-industrial complex. While visibility of pregnant bodies feels like progress, Khan argues that showcasing only glamorous, wealthy, thin mothers sidelines the everyday mental and physical realities most women face. She calls for more diverse, authentic representations of pregnant and postpartum bodies rather than slick marketing tokenism.

articles.title: There is a fascinating TV series to be made about a menopausal rock band – Riot Women isn’t it | Tiff Bakker
articles.trailText: Writer-director Sally Wainwright is a national treasure, but here she’s reduced the fury and passion of the riot grrrl movement to a minor plot device, says Tiff Bakker, a New York-based writer
articles.summary: Sally Wainwright’s Riot Women, centered on a menopausal punk band, flattens the riot grrrl movement’s radical feminist and queer roots into superficial set-dressing. Amid Rolling Stones covers and menopausal jokes, Wainwright offers no central queer figures, relegating trans and lesbian characters to marginal, violent subplots. The series reduces a DIY scene born of racism and homophobia resistance to suburban angst about ageing, failed marriages and sons. Unlike Wainwright’s past truths in Happy Valley or Gentleman Jack, Riot Women never captures the movement’s political edge or authenticity. Critic Tiff Bakker argues it feels like a 'punk fancy-dress party' devoid of the movement’s genuine fury.

articles.title: The politics of despair have engulfed Britain. But Zack Polanski is offering a way out | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: The leader of the Greens wants to focus on battles that unite – such as taxing wealth – without yielding an inch on minority rights, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Since Zack Polanski’s decisive election as Green leader on an unapologetically leftwing platform, membership has doubled to 130,000 and polls show 15%, rivaling Labour. Polanski’s revamped social media and confrontational style—championing wealth taxation, robust minority rights, public service expansion—seeks to shift debate from anti-immigrant scapegoating to economic justice. He argues Labour under Starmer can’t match this vision and urges cooperation with progressive parties to unite multicultural, economically disaffected voters. This Green surge offers a rare escape from Britain’s political despair.

articles.title: Nothing else has worked – so Starmer and Reeves are finally telling the truth about Brexit | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: It is the right way to go, but taking the long way round to such an obvious point has cost Labour precious time and credibility, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Labour’s Keir Starmer and Rachel Reeves have adopted a tougher tone on Brexit, branding its flawed implementation—alongside the pandemic and austerity—as drivers of Britain’s economic drag. Reeves told the IMF that Brexit has compounded a 4% productivity shortfall, per the OBR, and plans to blame a “bad deal” in her upcoming budget to justify tax rises. Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey warned its long-term growth impact will be negative. Politically, this late admission risks sounding like excuses amid the rise of Reform UK. Labour hopes linking Nigel Farage to mis-selling and amateur governance will energise voters, but critics say it’s overdue without a clear positive agenda.

articles.title: The EU was complicit in the war in Gaza.  Trump's plan can't be an excuse to dodge responsibility now | Nathalie Tocci
articles.trailText: Tiptoeing around Israel has cost Europe its credibility. It must exert meaningful pressure to ensure the horrors we have seen never happen again, says Guardian Europe columnist Nathalie Tocci
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nathalie Tocci argues that the EU’s inaction and continued political, economic and military ties have made it complicit in Israel’s Gaza war crimes. Deep divisions and policy paralysis prevented meaningful sanctions or conditionality despite widespread public outrage. The brief Trump-brokered ceasefire and hostage exchange are now used as an excuse for European leaders to avoid pressuring Israel, even as they line up humanitarian aid and reconstruction roles in Gaza. Tocci warns that without binding punitive measures, the US-backed roadmap will stall and violence will resume. To restore credibility and advance real peace, Europe must combine support for the plan with strong sanctions on Israel.

articles.title: Stop obsessing over what parents eat – we’re spinning too many plates to worry about what’s on our own | Sean Szeps
articles.trailText: Most parents aren’t able to eat like a wellness influencer when we’re chasing tiny humans who refuse to get dressed
articles.summary: Sean Szeps coins “parenting cuisine” to describe the half-eaten toast crusts, lukewarm lattes and reheated leftovers parents inhale amid morning chaos. When a nutritionist rebuked his Day-in-the-Life snapshot for low fibre and high caffeine, he argues that cultural obsession with parents’ diets—whether drive-through shame or smoothie perfection—is a privilege that ignores budgets, school runs and childcare logistics. Instead of moralizing macros, society should focus on context: supplying childcare that allows a proper sit-down meal, praising small wins like protein-packed peanut butter and shared hot chocolate, and reframing self-care as systemic support. Szeps, author of Not Like Other Dads, urges practical support—time, childcare and community structures—over diet policing.

articles.title: The Guardian view on post-16 education: colleges need attention, but the latest proposals are a mixed bag | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Another qualifications upheaval risks undermining the government’s good ideas
articles.summary: Following a decade of underinvestment, the government’s white paper seeks to elevate further education colleges. Yet past schemes—2017’s apprenticeship levy and new T-levels—have underperformed. The proposals spotlight defence, AI, green energy and construction, neglecting social care and creative industries. Devolving control to Skills England and regional bodies, plus levy flexibilities, could bridge the North/South “skills chasm,” and GCSE retake reforms are positive. However, axing existing BTEC courses before new V-levels are ready risks leaving 16-19-year-olds underqualified. Universities’ inclusion may undermine the focus on colleges. Ministers must fine-tune qualification reforms and heed college responses to avoid repeating past mistakes.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Sarkozy’s first day in prison: no citizen is above the law | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Attempts by the former French president and his supporters to discredit the legal process by which he was sentenced have been irresponsible and unjustified
articles.summary: As Nicolas Sarkozy began a five-year term at Paris’s La Santé prison for illicit Libyan campaign funds, The Guardian notes his defiant “innocent man” claim on X but underscores that no citizen, not even a former French president, is above the law. His conviction for criminal conspiracy—the first EU head of state jailed and the first French leader since Pétain—comes amid polls showing widespread political distrust. Attempts by his allies to brand the meticulous trial a judicial plot have spawned death threats against Judge Nathalie Gavarino yet failed to sway public opinion. The precedent will test the judiciary again in Marine Le Pen’s upcoming appeal.

articles.title: We were on the brink of a big bush revival - then Kim K released her pubic hair thong | Coco Khan
articles.trailText: The beauty industry has mastered selling us back an ersatz version of our own nature for enormous profit. Never has this been clearer than in the case of a sold-out modern-day merkin, says Coco Khan
articles.summary: Coco Khan had planned an essay celebrating a grassroots revival of natural pubic hair—fuelled by catwalk merkins, body-positive TikTok trends and calls to reject razor burns and the male gaze. But Kim Kardashian’s Skims upended it with the “Ultimate Bush,” a £34 faux-hair thong that sold out in 24 hours, turning genuine self-acceptance into another beauty accessory. Khan argues this stunt epitomises how the Kardashian empire has homogenised global standards, commodifying our bodies, and she urges a return to minimal effort and authentic “big bush energy,” ideally modelled by Kim herself.

articles.title: Trump is threatening Venezuela. But his own country looks a lot like it | Daniel Mendiola
articles.trailText: The US president’s efforts to consolidate power are strikingly similar to historical authoritarian moves in Caracas
articles.summary: Daniel Mendiola warns that Trump’s methods—expanding executive authority via a compliant Supreme Court, gerrymandering districts to entrench Republican majorities, deploying federal forces against opponents, demonising migrants and conducting extrajudicial strikes—mirror Hugo Chávez’s 1999–2013 playbook in Venezuela. He highlights US sanctions and coup support as contributing to Venezuela’s exodus, nearly 8 million fleeing hyperinflation and repression, while Trump contemplates intervention to depose Maduro. Just as Chávez used a constitutional assembly to suspend Congress and courts, Trump has effectively rewritten norms to create a unitary executive. The piece underscores the irony of US denouncing Venezuelan authoritarianism while adopting identical tactics at home.

articles.title: Guiding my mum through hospital showed me true patient-centred care takes more than paperwork | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: How many anxious people simply nod along, trusting the staff know what they are doing?
articles.summary: Oncologist Ranjana Srivastava recounts guiding her elderly, non-English-speaking, hard-of-hearing mother through hospital admission, exposing how jargon-filled checklists and rigid protocols can alienate patients. From omitted health cards and confused questions on pressure sores, cognitive impairment and dietary rules, to a priest miscalled for last rites and jelly labeled “allergy” over religious restrictions, Srivastava exposes absurd burdens on patients and carers. She argues true patient-centred care demands more than paperwork: it calls for empathetic dialogue, cultural sensitivity and practical flexibility. Despite Australia’s strong healthcare metrics, she warns against complacency and urges a shift from “always done” routines to genuine human connection.

articles.title: Dear Britain, do you worry that Team Farage is just a hot mess in power? Or is everyone too angry to care | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Footage of Reform councillors fighting is further proof that uselessness abounds, but that’s almost moot. To voters they are very useful idiots, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian-leaked footage shows Reform UK’s Kent councillors descending into chaos—bickering, muting colleagues and swearing—while pledging to cap council tax hikes at under 5% to prove competence. Yet Reform’s polling strength (367–445 seats in MRP models) suggests voters may embrace the ‘fuck-you’ revolt despite cack-handed governance, muted free-speech claims, bullying complaints and dashed austerity savings. Marina Hyde warns that tribal anger could propel Nigel Farage’s coalition into power, even as amateur theatrics undermine confidence.

articles.title: Nigel Farage has 1.3m followers on TikTok. Does this mean gen Z likes him? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: He is the most popular UK politician on one of the world’s most popular social media sites. Working out what that means is actually surprisingly difficult, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Nigel Farage, Reform UK leader, tops British politicians on TikTok with 1.3 million followers—far ahead of Zarah Sultana’s 489,000. But this popularity reflects catchy, bite-sized clips and viral familiarity rather than direct political endorsement. Gen Z viewers ‘like’ and share moments for entertainment, not necessarily because they agree. After years of writing off under-25s as apathetic, Farage’s online reach shows younger audiences engage with sharp, unfiltered content. We need to analyse what that engagement truly signals before assuming genuine support.

articles.title: Instagram keeps flubbing on teen safety. Will its new ‘PG-13’ guidelines make a difference? | Tayo Bero
articles.trailText: The content guardrails introduced this week feel like hollow posturing after the failure of past promises
articles.summary: Instagram’s latest automatic ‘PG-13’ feed for under-18s restricts content to US PG-13 standards, but critics say it’s hollow posturing. Meta’s past teen-safety measures—mandatory teen accounts and new filters—proved 64% ineffective; 47% of young users faced unsafe content monthly and 37% weekly, while 100,000 children reportedly endured online sexual harassment daily. Reuters found teens see 3× more eating-disorder content. Advocacy groups blame Meta’s profit-first culture and urge built-in safety, stronger regulation and parental education.

articles.title: Beef, pork, chicken: the world loves cheap meat. If people knew what really goes in it, that love affair would be over | Devi Sridhar
articles.trailText: Antibiotic use in farming is now rampant. How meat is produced in China may mean the drugs you need here won’t work, says Prof Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh
articles.summary: Demand for cheap meat in rising middle-income nations drives prophylactic and growth-promoting antibiotic use—73% of global antimicrobials—fueling colistin-resistant E. coli that spread via travel. Resistant infections threaten routine treatments and surgeries worldwide. The UK and EU cut livestock antibiotic use by ~50–59%, reducing resistance, but global action—balancing food security, cost pressures and environmental impacts—is essential to preserve antibiotic efficacy. Poultry demand is projected to grow 21% by 2034, intensifying antibiotic reliance.

articles.title: The Tories set a tax trap and Rachel Reeves walked straight into it. It may be her defining mistake | Chris Mullin
articles.trailText: By taking Jeremy Hunt’s NI cuts and ruling out other rises, Labour tried to out-Tory the Tories. And made a bad situation worse, says former Labour minister Chris Mullin
articles.summary: In January 2024 Jeremy Hunt cut employee national insurance by 2%, then from 10% to 8%, pledging more cuts. Reeves promised not to reverse these or raise income, VAT or NI, falling into a Tory trap. By ruling out tax rises, Labour ceded the tax debate, ignored the link between fair revenue and public services, and missed an electoral chance created by Tory overreach. Mullin argues this commitment doomed Labour, echoing past errors like Wilson’s delayed devaluation, and that an honest tax discussion is essential for sustainable funding.

articles.title: Standing with Maccabi’s football hooligans against local police – is that what patriotism looks like now? | Jonathan Liew
articles.trailText: Tommy Robinson is said to be going to Villa Park as a Maccabi Tel Aviv fan. Do the politicians jumping on this bandwagon care what they are doing, asks Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew critiques the uproar over West Midlands Police banning Maccabi Tel Aviv fans (including Tommy Robinson) ahead of a Europa League tie at Aston Villa. He traces Maccabi Fanatics’ history of anti-Arab banners (‘refugees not welcome’), racist threats to Israeli‐Arab player Maharan Radi and sectarian violence at home and abroad. Contrasting Israel’s politicised football culture with Britain’s apolitical stadia, Liew denounces rapid political grandstanding and warns that standing with foreign far-right hooligans against local police has become a distorted form of patriotism.

articles.title: Ed Miliband’s new green jobs will bring Britain hope. I dare Reform to denounce them  | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: While Nigel Farage promotes retro plans to reopen coalmines, will he really tell thousands of clean energy workers to leave their well-paid, local jobs, asks Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Labour’s climate minister Ed Miliband unveiled plans to create 400,000 green jobs by 2030 across 31 priority roles – from welders to production managers – supported by new academies in Lutterworth, Teesside decarbonisation hubs and clean-energy apprenticeships. With average wind-sector salaries at £51k versus £37k national, unions back project grants tied to enhanced recognition and fair-work charters. Miliband’s blueprint includes five technical excellence colleges, V-level reforms and a £300 energy-bill cut pledge, aiming to reengage nearly one million disengaged youth and counter Conservative and Reform UK’s anti-net-zero rhetoric. FE colleges like Crawley’s “green village” expect renewed investment in retraining and skills.

articles.title: Britain is suddenly pining for closer ties with the EU. It’s more likely to get the cold shoulder | Anand Menon
articles.trailText: Labour now wants to use the damage from Brexit to combat the threat of Nigel Farage, but the union has bigger fish to fry, says Anand Menon, director of UK in a Changing Europe
articles.summary: Labour’s government has shifted from cautious talk to an urgent push for an EU reset, touting Brexit’s economic damage to counter Nigel Farage and negotiating deals on fisheries, agrifoods, energy, defence and a new youth mobility scheme. Urgency is driven by upcoming budget forecasts, the EU’s carbon border tax from January 2026 and the need to join its new defence fund. But Brussels sees lower stakes, faces regulatory hurdles on alignment, numbers and fees, and resists doing Britain favours. UK enthusiasm risks collision with EU priorities, likely leading to frustration rather than quick wins.

articles.title: A 3,200km tour of small Australian libraries taught me just how vital they are | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: In the sleepiest towns I found bustling, light-filled places eager for conversations about books and writing
articles.summary: On a 3,200 km road-trip with crime novelist Michael Brissenden, Paul Daley found record-breaking engagement in regional and suburban Australian public libraries: 88 million in-person visits (up 10%), 119 million physical and 55 million digital loans, and 409,000 programs for over 7 million participants in 2023–24. Transformed into bright, conversation-friendly community hubs, libraries now host lively Q&As on writing craft, mentor aspiring authors, and provide free wifi and welcoming spaces—serving as an egalitarian social glue and lifeline for marginalised patrons.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the price of a prince: what Virginia Giuffre’s story says about palace accountability | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Jeffrey Epstein scandal has exposed a constitutional blind spot: royal privilege remains beyond democratic scrutiny. MPs must be able to question power
articles.summary: Virginia Giuffre’s allegations that Jeffrey Epstein trafficked her and forced her into sexual encounters with Prince Andrew—including at age 17—have reignited debate over royal immunity and accountability. Despite Andrew��s denials and a reported £12 million settlement funded by the late queen, parliamentary rules bar MPs from questioning the royals and only the crown can revoke titles—creating a self-referencing circle of deference. Since David Cameron’s 2011 funding overhaul tripled the sovereign grant and removed Commons oversight, Crown finances and roles escape democratic scrutiny. Lawmakers now press to restore parliamentary control over royal prerogatives and funding.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Ukraine peace talks: Europe must ensure Zelenskyy can resist Trump’s bullying | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The US president’s attempts to broker a deal fail to distinguish between the aggressor and the victim. No just agreement is possible on that basis
articles.summary: During Zelenskiy’s recent White House visit, Donald Trump alternated between offering Tomahawk missiles and pressuring Kyiv to cede territory, framing Russia’s invasion as a real-estate dispute. Ahead of a possible US-Russia summit in Budapest under Orbán’s patronage, Europe must shore up Ukraine’s financial resilience��e.g. Merz’s £122bn frozen-assets loan plan—and find workarounds to Viktor Orbán’s EU veto. EU leaders at the Brussels summit should counter Trump’s mercurial “mediator” role and ensure Ukraine resists any deal rewarding Putin’s aggression.

articles.title: The massive No Kings protests may mark a new American political posture | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The violence Republicans seemed to want did not materialize. Instead the event showcased liberal-democratic consensus
articles.summary: The week-long No Kings protests, organized by a global coalition of liberal groups, defied predictions of violence by Republican leaders—Mike Johnson, Tom Emmer, Roger Marshall—who branded demonstrators as antifa, Marxists and terrorists. Instead, millions rallied peacefully in cities from New York to San Francisco, employing humor and irreverent costumes to mock Trump’s authoritarianism. Diverse participants—from democratic socialists to libertarians—united under a common goal: restore liberal-democratic norms and rebuild constitutional protections. The movement’s capacious, joyous tone suggests a new left-liberal popular front, melding principle with irreverence in sustained opposition to the Trump regime.

articles.title: What do we learn from Epstein and Andrew? There’s a level of power at which right and wrong no longer exist | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Prince Andrew has finally decided to give up his titles – but we have known the shape of the allegations against him for years. Why was there a collective decision to look away, asks Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Facing fresh revelations in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir Nobody’s Girl, Prince Andrew announced he will relinquish his Duke of York title and Order of the Garter after decades of sex-trafficking allegations linked to Jeffrey Epstein. Despite denying all claims, his 2011 email to Epstein—signed “A, HRH the Duke of York, KG”—and Giuffre’s detailed account of underage sex have long undermined his credibility. Lawmakers now call for royal title removal powers. Critics argue society enabled his impunity, choosing to look away until public pressure mounted. Zoe Williams contends this saga exposes how extreme privilege can blur moral boundaries and shelter the powerful from accountability.

articles.title: What the menopause marketers won’t tell you: ageing is to be celebrated | Stella Duffy
articles.trailText: Advertisers exploit our misogynistic culture, making women feel as if their bodies are broken. But better information might just help, says writer Stella Duffy
articles.summary: Duffy argues advertisers exploit misogynistic, ageist and pronatalist fears in a “menopause gold rush,” leaving many unsure whom to trust. An Australian study of over 500 women aged 45–64 found widespread skepticism toward pharmaceutical motives. Recounting severe symptoms during chemo and IVF, she frames menopause as a physiological transition akin to puberty or parenthood. Marketing tactics fuel a divide between MHT and non-MHT camps; research shows no universal menopause: symptoms and attitudes vary by lifestyle, culture and bias. In cultures valuing older women, symptoms ease. Postmenopause, lasting a third of life, becomes a vibrant “third act” if guided by accurate information.

articles.title: When my kids wrote a song using AI, all I could think was: you missed the fun part | Myke Bartlett
articles.trailText: The arrival of AI is a chance to remind kids that the joy of creativity is not in what you made, but in the process of making it
articles.summary: When columnist Myke Bartlett’s preteens use ChatGPT to write a song, skipping the playful drafting stage, he realises they’ve lost the joyous pursuit of creativity. He warns that AI shortcuts reinforce a focus on outcomes over process, risking human redundancy in writing, art and beyond. Bartlett argues that true creative growth lies in experimentation, failure and craft, not instant results. He urges parents to help children value ‘endurance artistry’—the struggle and discovery that shape thinkers and makers—reminding us that the essence of creativity is in doing, not just having created.

articles.title: I never wash our bread knife – and I won’t let the internet shame me into changing my ways | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Apparently the mostly British habit of not cleaning your bread knife after use is ‘gross’ and unhygienic. If that’s true, then call me disgusting, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington rejects online shaming over her habit of not thoroughly washing her bread knife, arguing that a quick wipe and storage on a crumb-laden breadboard is harmless and reflects a common British shortcut. Her 2025 column highlights social media moral panics branding such practices “gross,” mocks contrived hygiene controversies—from knives and phone screens to sheets, towels, bras and sports kit—and celebrates her “robust medieval peasant microbiome.” She urges fellow self-described slatterns to resist disgust emojis and embrace relaxed cleaning routines, while still offering guests fresh sheets.

articles.title: Troops on the streets, Ice thuggery – and prices still climbing: welcome to Trump’s ‘golden age’ | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: The president has repeatedly proclaimed a shining moment. Meanwhile, he’s taking a wrecking ball to truth and democracy
articles.summary: Trump’s second term, billed as America’s 'golden age,' belies a federal shutdown, deep polarization and stalled job growth. He’s deployed the National Guard and ICE in cities, sparking teargas, arrests and accusations of thuggery. Polls show 58% disapproval and 62% say the nation is off track. Tariffs have fueled inflation and stalled manufacturing, while 10 million risk losing health coverage and 22 million face premium spikes. Science cuts and vaccine skepticism spurred a measles resurgence. Justice Dept politicization and plunging international approval (91% in Mexico) underscore a dark, not golden, age enriching gilders and billionaires.

articles.title: It’s still killing people, and the government has yet to act: Britain’s hidden asbestos epidemic | Tom White
articles.trailText: Asbestos was banned in 1999, but as materials left in our buildings deteriorate, thousands of lives are being lost every year, says writer and education worker Tom White
articles.summary: Despite a 1999 ban, Britain still records around 5,000 asbestos-related deaths annually (possibly up to 20,000), as ageing insulation in 78% of surveyed buildings continues to release deadly fibres. Mesothelioma’s long latency has spawned a third wave of cases, exemplified by 38-year-old Helen Bone’s fatal diagnosis. Current in-situ management rules let damaged crocidolite and amosite persist in schools, hospitals and homes—71% of materials are damaged, 30% high-risk—without coordinated removal. Unlike South Korea’s and Australia’s national eradication plans, the UK lacks a funded strategy. Campaigners demand a mass retrofit and removal programme backed by government and grassroots coalitions.

articles.title: A-level English, voluntary work, delayed citizenship: it’s Labour’s Orwellian Two Minutes Hate for immigrants  | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: It’s easier for politicians to blame others than to face the truth: Britain has been stripped of the spaces and opportunities that allow for true social integration, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik criticises Labour’s escalating immigration pledges—English A-level exams, mandatory volunteer work, and a ten-year route to citizenship—as punitive, symbolic gestures that scapegoat migrants for Britain’s erosion of social cohesion. She argues true integration depends on public services—libraries, community centres, youth clubs and adequately resourced schools and hospitals—hollowed out by austerity. By imposing arbitrary benchmarks on “skilled” and “high-potential” migrants, politicians evade addressing societal fragmentation and fuel nationalist sentiment. Malik calls for real investment in shared spaces and mockingly proposes a cricket Test match for migrants vying for citizenship.

articles.title: In Gaza, and now Ukraine, Donald Trump may be peace activists' greatest ally. That deserves our backing | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: It’s a fool’s game trying to understand the president’s true motives, but do our misgivings matter if the outcome is a speedy end to war, asks Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: By leveraging his recent Gaza ceasefire, Donald Trump is pressing for an immediate Ukraine ceasefire, rejecting Zelenskiy’s plea for more Tomahawks and urging both sides to halt fighting, return home and negotiate. Jenkins argues Trump’s unpredictability and minimal reliance on traditional diplomacy may open stalled conflicts to resolution. His approach prioritizes swift peace over ideology or consistency, promising guarantees along existing frontlines without US troop deployment. He contrasts this with Western inaction, Biden’s cautious limits on aid and NATO’s drift, suggesting Trump’s raw dealmaking can break stalemates where allies have failed. If successful, his personal charisma could end two bitter wars. We should support any outcome that stops the killing.
