Harris argues Conservatives once championed youth services; modern politicians must restore these community anchors to heal social divisions.

articles.title: Bari Weiss’s ascent at CBS News was 50 years in the making | David Sirota and Jared Jacang Maher
articles.trailText: A half-century ago, CBS’s own president was boasting of his support for an antidemocratic political project. Our new book uses never-before-reported documents to tell the story of a scheme to undermine accountability journalism
articles.summary: Bari Weiss’s appointment at CBS News epitomizes a five-decade corporate plot, documented in Sirota and Maher’s Master Plan, which began with Lewis Powell’s 1971 memo urging the Chamber of Commerce to co-opt national TV. Never-before-seen archives reveal CBS presidents, like Arthur Taylor, pressing editors to favor pro-business coverage and curb muckraking. Early collaborators—Roger Ailes, Metromedia and tobacco executives—engineered rightwing media, from repealing the fairness doctrine to modern tech-driven consolidation. Today Weiss shields oligarch interests amid algorithmic suppression, media mergers and defunding of public outlets. The authors argue this entrenched media monopoly endangers democracy by silencing accountability journalism.

articles.title: I spent years trying to avoid Vinted. It turns out I was right to be afraid | Carys Afoko
articles.trailText: I eventually signed up in the hope that buying and selling secondhand clothes would help me fight fast fashion. It just made me cheap, writes Carys Afoko
articles.summary: Carys Afoko resisted Vinted for years, equating secondhand with poverty, until she listed two unworn designer shirts. A quick first sale spurred her to buy and sell more, but she soon collided with Vinted’s pricing algorithm, endless notifications and gamified hooks that drive engagement. She learned to haggle for 5–10 percent discounts, got hooked on pings yet stressed by buyer–seller pressure. Shipping books vs local libraries, delivery-worker conditions and the environment complicated her "circular economy" ideal. After six months, she’s spent more than earned, petty from penny-pinching deals, and considers quitting.

articles.title: Democrats are captive to outdated etiquette. It’s endangering democracy | Ryan W Powers
articles.trailText: The establishment left’s attachment to rigid rules leaves the party out of touch and failing to meet the moment
articles.summary: Analyst Ryan W. Powers argues that the Democratic establishment’s rigid politeness and outdated etiquette are undermining its ability to counter right-wing assaults on democracy. He cites Texas lawmakers’ quorum-denying walkout and Governor Gavin Newsom’s dramatic bid to suspend California’s redistricting commission as examples of effective norm-breaking tactics. Drawing on his own viral dissent after a big law firm firing, Powers shows that strategic, nonviolent disruption can mobilize attention and safeguard institutions. He warns Democrats must abandon hollow courtesy in favor of bold, principled action or risk democratic backsliding.

articles.title: Parents who film their children crying for clicks should take a good look at themselves | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: Toddlers have big feelings. But sharing their tantrums and pain on social media is not a ‘teachable moment’. It’s cruel, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett warns that the viral trend of parents filming toddlers’ tantrums and tears for social media clicks exploits children’s vulnerability and breaches their privacy. While gentle-parenting advocates celebrate “big feelings” content as teachable moments, many videos—ranging from screaming fits to forced sinus-clearing or cheese-and-egg shocks—humiliate children without comfort. Branded educational, these posts prioritize parental performativity over genuine support, undermining a safe space for emotional expression. Cosslett argues that documenting rather than defusing distress is a dereliction of parental duty and sends a damaging message about natural emotions.

articles.title: France is not alone in its political crisis – belief in a democratic world is vanishing | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The populist right offers a solution in the form of turning back the clock. Macron and his counterparts need to find a different answer fast, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall argues that Emmanuel Macron’s warning of a ‘degeneration of democracy’ in France reflects a broader global breakdown: rising distrust, polarisation and populist extremes are eroding democratic debate across Europe, the US and other open societies. Young people, disillusioned by economic precarity, inequality, climate-linked migration and failed promises of progress, increasingly reject democratic systems. German scholar Andreas Reckwitz sees this as a crisis of ‘loss’ – the collapse of faith in continuous improvement. Unless governments forge new models of resilience and redistribution, populism will deepen democratic decay.

articles.title: My foolproof guide to living with a partner – and not falling out about home decor | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: After years of marriage, my husband thinks I’m still trying to find his hideous painting of Bobby Moore ‘the right frame’ so it can go on the wall. It’s these subtle interior design lies that keep a relationship going, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson offers a witty, practical guide to avoiding domestic decor clashes in long-term relationships by mastering subtle “compromises.” She shares personal and friend anecdotes—like stalling on framing a garish Bobby Moore painting or hinting a giant Lord of the Rings map needs “the right frame”—to illustrate stealth insertion or removal of unwanted items. Hudson contrasts blunt confrontation (insulting tastes) with secretive redecoration and suggests strategic sacrifices—bearing a hideous rug to win freedom elsewhere—emphasizing patience, tact and playful long-game techniques to harmonize shared living spaces.

articles.title: Why is this Fox News host speculating about AOC’s sex life? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Even his colleague has dubbed Jesse Watters’s claim about Ocasio-Cortez and Stephen Miller ‘creepy’
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi criticises Fox News host Jesse Watters for repeatedly lauding and sexualising Stephen Miller—calling him an “alpha” “sexual matador” with a younger wife—while bizarrely speculating that Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez secretly desires him. Even colleague Greg Gutfeld dubbed it “creepy.” Mahdawi contrasts this fluff with Miller’s hardline immigration record and family rebukes, and endorses AOC’s mocking tactic as a potent anti-authoritarian weapon. The piece also briefs on a French rape sentence increase; new genetics of women’s depression; Latvia eyeing Istanbul Convention exit; Gaza preschool malnutrition; UK universities spying for arms firms; and a runaway cat’s Virginia caper.

articles.title: Pity poor Trump, whose Nobel hopes were dashed by common sense | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: Maga supporters are upset the president didn’t receive the peace prize. One thing’s for sure: it’s all about him
articles.summary: Dave Schilling lampoons Donald Trump’s reaction to being passed over for the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize, which went to Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado. He notes Machado thanked Trump for backing democratic reform, then skewers MAGA supporters who call the award a ‘joke’ or rigged. Schilling ties this to a conservative reflex—denying legitimacy when they lose—and suggests Trump might console himself with a prospective Gaza peace deal looming next year. He then pivots to his own craving for accolades, mocking the self-absorption fueling modern political grievance culture.

articles.title: Do we need Imax? 70mm? VistaVision? All I need to watch movies at the cinema is darkness and quiet | Larry Ryan
articles.trailText: Cinema used to be an accessible and affordable mass pursuit. This debate about the ‘purest’ format to view certain films only risks putting off movie-goers, says freelance writer and editor Larry Ryan
articles.summary: Larry Ryan critiques the push towards premium cinema formats—70mm VistaVision, IMAX film and digital—arguing that claiming a single ‘pure’ version risks alienating regular moviegoers and undermining affordable mass cinema. He notes that exclusive screenings in rare VistaVision venues or sold-out IMAX hits have novelty and visual impact but cautions that a satisfying cinema experience simply requires darkness, quiet, a comfortable seat, and a screen ‘big enough.’ Drawing on his multiplex ‘XL’ screening of Paul Thomas Anderson’s One Battle After Another and childhood TV viewing of Rear Window, he insists love for film can flourish in any format.

articles.title: Don’t fall for the authoritarian hype – Reform and the hard right can be stopped in their tracks | Gordon Brown
articles.trailText: From the US to Europe and Asia, grievances are being exploited to gain power. But moderate voices are still in tune with the majority, says former prime minister Gordon Brown
articles.summary: Former PM Gordon Brown warns that Nigel Farage’s Reform UK is part of a global rise of hard-right, anti-immigrant, anti-globalisation parties seizing power from the US to Europe and Asia. He attributes this surge to exclusionary globalisation fueling ethnic nationalism that has replaced neoliberalism, undermining multilateralism and human rights. Yet surveys of 36,000 people show a clear majority supports inclusive, pragmatic multilateral cooperation—grouped as humanitarian, pragmatic or self-interested multilateralists—over exclusionary nationalism. Brown urges exposing Reform’s ‘Faragism’—deep cuts to public services—and argues for a positive, outward-looking patriotism appealing to public self-interest, compassion and community rebuilding.

articles.title: My kids gave me enough material to write TV comedy. Where will the jokes come from now they’ve left? | Helen Serafinowicz
articles.trailText: The inspirations for my BBC TV show have packed up and gone to uni, leaving me to rattle around on my own, says writer and television producer Helen Serafinowicz
articles.summary: Helen Serafinowicz reflects on how motherhood inspired her BBC sitcoms Motherland and its spin-off, mining anecdotes from daycare disasters, parental faux pas and school-trip chaos. With both children newly off to university in different cities, she recounts bittersweet farewells, empty rooms and the sudden hush of domestic life. Grappling with empty-nest syndrome, she replaces chronicling toddler dramas with Tuesday-Thursday netball and a home overhaul. Despite her sadness, she remains hopeful that this new chapter—and her children’s holiday returns—will restock the comedic well that fuels her writing career.

articles.title: Why should you be Labour’s next deputy leader? Guardian readers quiz the candidates
articles.trailText: As party members prepare to choose between Bridget Phillipson and Lucy Powell, the pair give their views on wealth taxes, Brexit, the climate crisis and the far right
articles.summary: Guardian readers questioned Labour deputy leadership contenders Bridget Phillipson and Lucy Powell on cost of living, wealth taxes, tackling the far right, Brexit, housing, customs union and climate. Phillipson touted reviving Sure Start, funded childcare from nine months, free school meals, ending the two-child benefit cap, progressive tax reforms and a £39bn social homes programme including new council houses. Powell championed lifting the benefit cap, public ownership of buses, GB Energy, renters’ rights, stronger anti-inequality messaging and just transition to net zero. Both stressed using the deputy role to amplify Labour values, reshape the economy and reconnect with working-class communities.

articles.title: Trump’s strong-arming of Netanyahu led to a deal. He must sustain that pressure | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: The US president long refused to use his influence over the prime minister. Last month, that appeared to change
articles.summary: After nine months of inaction, Trump leveraged US arms aid and veto power to force Netanyahu into a first-phase ceasefire deal with Hamas, brokered by Arab mediators. The agreement includes an Israeli hostages-for-prisoners swap and partial Gaza withdrawal, despite Netanyahu's last-minute amendments preserving Israeli troops and security perimeters. Hamas offered a conditional acceptance. Trump's direct pressure—culminating in blunt private rebukes—was pivotal. Sustained US leverage will be essential to prevent Israel from reneging, as it did after January's truce, and to advance later phases of the Gaza peace plan.

articles.title: The Guardian view on an AI bubble: capitalism still hasn’t evolved to protect itself | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Warnings about inflated tech stocks suggest investors never learn and central bankers learn too late
articles.summary: Global regulators warn AI stock valuations mirror dotcom bubble; concentrated gains risk crashing markets and dragging the wider economy, especially amid China’s proposed rare-earth export controls. Citing Kindleberger’s Manias, Panics and Crashes and Minsky’s financial instability hypothesis, the editorial argues that calm markets breed excess risk and require institutional redesign. Minsky’s prescription—a strong government safety net plus a central bank limiting risky credit and directing cash to productive uses—aims to tame speculative fads. With Sam Altman and Jeff Bezos calling AI valuations “insane,” the piece urges borrowing limits alongside fiscal and industrial policies to channel capital into socially useful technology and build a resilient capitalism.

articles.title: The Guardian view on AC Milan playing a ‘home’ game in Perth: the clue should be in the name | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Famous European football clubs should not be shunted around the globe in search of sports promoters with deep pockets
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns against turning clubs into global traveling brands by shunting home fixtures abroad, citing UEFA’s approval of Villarreal vs Barcelona in Miami and Milan vs Como in Perth. It argues that local identity, home advantage and league fairness suffer when clubs chase promoter profits overseas, urging investment in domestic competitions instead. With clubs pressured by promoters and Premier League rivals, it calls on UEFA to enforce rules protecting supporters, local communities and the integrity of domestic football.

articles.title: Trump wants a prize for the Gaza deal. But the real question is, why didn't he do it earlier? | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: The ceasefire in Gaza happened when the US president lost patience, but how much horror occurred, how many people were killed because he delayed, asks Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland argues that Donald Trump’s recent ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas, celebrated in Gaza and Israel alike, hinged on Trump finally leveraging US power to force Netanyahu’s hand after months of unchecked bombardment. While Trump’s arm-twisting yielded release of hostages and Palestinian prisoners, Freedland criticizes his delay, noting a similar truce existed in January and could have prevented further civilian slaughter and suffering. Netanyahu’s earlier refusal, Biden’s inaction, and Hamas���s missed opportunities compounded the toll.

articles.title: It’s Sam Altman: the man who stole the rights from copyright. If he’s the future, can we go backwards? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: His AI video generator Sora 2 has been reviled for pinching the work of others. One giant leap for Sam: for everyone else, not so much, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers OpenAI CEO Sam Altman’s launch of Sora 2, an AI video generator built on allegedly stolen copyrighted content, and his frenzied $1 trn in chip-maker deals with Nvidia and AMD. She lampoons Altman’s “post-rights” mindset, Trump-flattering politics and motto “we’ll do what we want,” warning of unchecked AI eroding creative ownership, user privacy and recapitulating the same hype-to-harm cycle as platforms like Meta. Hyde urges regulation to counter corporate hubris and protect artists’ rights.

articles.title: The fledgling UN tried to rein in mass-scale misinformation. The world turned its back and is now paying the price | Roland Burke
articles.trailText: The ruinous result of the US approach to freedom of information and media has made anti-democratic contagion impossible to ignore
articles.summary: Roland Burke chronicles the League of Nations’ 1930s radio censorship over “false news”, the early UN’s 1946–48 drafting of a Freedom of Information convention—later killed by US right-wing lobbying—and warns that decades of American opposition to global info regulation have enabled modern mass-scale misinformation. He highlights Australia’s pending age-verification and social network restrictions, the alliance of corporate media monopolies and far-right leaders, and argues that like the interwar radio age, fibre-optic amplification demands renewed democratic controls to curb anti-democratic contagion. He urges remaining democracies to reassess their long history of capitulation to unfettered “freedom of expression” that shields disinformation peddlers.

articles.title: Beware Netanyahu: he is a master of self-interest – and that’s why he signed the Hamas ceasefire deal | Ben Reiff
articles.trailText: The Israeli PM wants to bolster his position and ward off global pariah status. But he has shifted gears before and may do so again, says journalist Ben Reiff
articles.summary: Analyst Ben Reiff warns that Netanyahu’s embrace of the latest Gaza ceasefire deal is driven by self-interest: rescuing his battered approval, staving off global condemnation, and reviving his electoral fortunes ahead of an impending election and his ongoing corruption trial. Having broken a similar January truce and flirted with “Gaza Riviera” ethnic-cleansing schemes, Netanyahu now spins the agreement—divided into vague “phases”—as victory while preserving exit ramps to resume war. Reiff argues the international community must pressure Israel to enforce any deal, safeguard West Bank Palestinians from renewed displacement, and demand accountability for alleged genocide before meaningful Palestinian statehood or reconstruction can proceed.

articles.title: English democracy relies on local councillors. So why are so many facing the axe? | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Government plans to merge councils may not save money, and do nothing to solve the very real problems they face, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: White paper mandates merging district councils into large unitaries serving at least 500,000 residents, potentially cutting up to 90% of local councillors. Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee warns this top-down reorganisation—unannounced in the election manifesto and cheered by county councils—shrinks democratic engagement and undermines trusted local representatives. Evidence on cost savings is inconclusive, while mega-councils risk distant governance, complex contract unwinds and a reverse gerrymander favouring Conservatives. Cities like Portsmouth and Oxford are resisting. Toynbee calls for reforms: a national social care service, council tax overhaul and proportional representation to preserve local accountability and prevent minority takeovers, warning the public may finally wake up to losing their council.

articles.title: Stephen Miller is the most dangerous man in the Trump administration | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: In the White House deputy chief of staff, we see that Maga will not simply end with Trump. We must keep our eyes on Miller
articles.summary: Stephen Miller, as Trump’s deputy chief of staff, misrepresents Title 10 to claim ‘plenary power,’ implying the president’s absolute authority. In a CNN interview he dodged questions on defying federal court rulings and inadvertently revealed plans to federalize the National Guard. He peddles false legal arguments, twisting the US Code and Insurrection Act to undermine separation of powers. His speeches, echoing Goebbels with apocalyptic, white-supremacist rhetoric—‘We are the storm,’ vilifying domestic ‘enemies’—expose him as a resolute ideologue wielding real power behind an erratic president. Historians liken him to Stalin, warning that MAGA’s future depends on stopping Miller’s permanent authoritarian agenda.

articles.title: Who will run against Trump in 2028? Please step forward now – don’t wait | David Kirp
articles.trailText: A leading Democrat, backed by substantial funding, should enter the 2028 presidential race right now
articles.summary: UC Berkeley’s David Kirp urges Democrats to field a high-profile, well-funded challenger against Trump immediately rather than wait. He slams tired insiders like Schumer and Harris, praises Zohran Mamdani’s grassroots door-knocking and TikTok outreach, and calls for bold, non-wonky policies—millions of affordable homes, universal preschool, affordable healthcare and fair taxes—with a readiness to challenge party orthodoxies (e.g., Gaza). Potential early entrants include Whitmer, Buttigieg, Shapiro, Gallego or Beshear, backed by billionaire-grassroots coalitions.

articles.title: A book is being marketed with mayo-scented ink. Jealous? Me? | David Barnett
articles.trailText: With the rise of TikTok and two-tier marketing budgets, something’s off in the world of publishing (and it’s not just the aroma), says author David Barnett
articles.summary: David Barnett uses the garlic-infused ink edition of Jennifer L. Armentrout’s new romantasy The Primal of Blood and Bone—a Hellmann’s collaboration—to critique publishers’ reliance on TikTok gimmicks and uneven marketing budgets. He argues that big promotional spends target celebrity authors whose books would sell anyway, while midlist writers go unsupported, as shown by a publisher failing to send advance copies. Barnett also warns of viral hype’s downsides, referencing Audra Winter’s TikTok-fueled flop The Age of Scorpius, and jokes his next horror could be printed in real coal ink.

articles.title: We all know Brexit’s to blame for the crisis facing UK steel – it’s time for politicians to be honest and reverse it | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: With British industry faltering, the excuse that the public wants this is risible. Parliament must force Starmer to act, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins warns that Brexit is triggering a ‘terminal’ crisis in UK steel, with 80% of exports now facing slashed tariff-free EU quotas and a 50% levy on the remainder. He highlights parallel fallout in chemicals—60% of output sold to the EU, output down 35–40%—and a 27% drop in UK exports since 2021. Cambridge Econometrics projects a £300bn GDP shortfall over the next decade. With 61% now deeming Brexit a failure and 63% opposing looser EU ties, Jenkins urges cross-party leadership to admit the mistake and urgently rebuild trade links.

articles.title: I saw desperation at the Tory conference – but all traditional parties may be in this position soon | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: The feeling of crisis in Manchester also afflicts Labour and the Lib Dems. It leaves voters facing a dangerously unstable political order, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: Andy Beckett reports from the 2025 Conservative conference in Manchester, where half-empty halls, blue carpets and a frantic cascade of tax cuts, immigration crackdowns and law-and-order pledges underscore the Tories’ deepest crisis in decades. Delegates float leadership coups, discuss merging with Reform UK and lament lost seats as right-wing fringe meetings overflow. Yet Kemi Badenoch’s nostalgia-soaked reforms fail to halt decline. Similar attention-seeking by Labour and Lib Dems amid austerity fatigue, voter apathy and inequality signals a dangerously unstable British party landscape, leaving room for extremist and authoritarian alternatives.

articles.title: Walking the halls of the UN, I felt its power — and its distance from the people it was built to serve | Satara Uthayakumaran
articles.trailText: From the Tiwi Islands to Tasmania, from city classrooms to refugee programs, I have listened to thousands of young people. And now I carry those voices with me into the heart of the UN
articles.summary: At 22, Australia’s youth representative to the UN, Satara Uthayakumaran, contrasts the grandeur of the UN’s 80th anniversary with its distance from marginalized youth. After a year of face-to-face consultations across Australia—from the Tiwi Islands and remote detention centres to city classrooms—she brings thousands of letters describing child starvation in Palestine, poverty, forced marriage, modern slavery, police terror, detention trauma and refugee hardship. Uthayakumaran urges the UN to shift from symbolic speeches and photo-ops to truly amplifying the voices of the forgotten—Indigenous families, displaced refugees, survivors of slavery and climate-vulnerable nations—and reaffirm its role protecting those it was built to serve.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump and the ceasefire deal: hope at last, but the real work is just beginning | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: This is the best prospect of ending Israel’s war in Gaza since it began. But a long-term solution remains distant
articles.summary: Donald Trump brokered a temporary Gaza ceasefire as the first phase of a ‘durable peace’, pausing Israel-Hamas hostilities and enabling hostage releases and aid. His plan, supported by Tony Blair, would install a colonial-style Palestinian admin with only a vague future statehood promise, a proposal Netanyahu has rejected. By securing Qatari guarantees and rallying Egypt and Turkey, Trump compelled both sides to defer core disputes. With over 67,000 Palestinian deaths, dozens of hostages killed, and mass child malnutrition, risks of renewed fighting loom. Macron and regional powers heralded this window; now international actors must push toward a justice-based two-state solution.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the nationalist surge: the SNP and Plaid Cymru are making the political weather | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: In both Scotland and Wales, politics is marching to the beat of different drums from the rest of Britain. The UK-wide parties should watch out
articles.summary: Viewed through a Westminster lens, UK politics is a five-party battle, but in Scotland and Wales nationalist parties dominate. The SNP leads Scotland polls and could secure a fifth Holyrood term in May, reviving an independence referendum push via John Swinney’s new proposal amid 47% support. In Wales, Plaid Cymru, buoyed by economic malaise and Labour’s weaknesses, is neck-and-neck with Reform UK and eyeing a historic Senedd breakthrough after a key Caerphilly byelection on 23 October. Both parties face minority-government challenges in 2026.

articles.title: We know what the comedians got out of the Riyadh comedy festival. What about the Saudi regime? | Jonathan Liew
articles.trailText: The tawdry event was an ultimately doomed attempt by the Saudi government to buy the kind of authentic grassroots culture it is unwilling to countenance, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Liew critiques the inaugural Riyadh comedy festival, where Jim Jefferies was disinvited over downplaying Jamal Khashoggi’s murder; Jimmy Carr, Louis CK, Dave Chappelle and others drew seven-figure fees under strict censorship—no jokes on royals, religion or human rights. Liew contrasts this with an underground Saudi scene of Amy Roko, Hisham Fageeh and Bader Saleh using cafés, WhatsApp and irony, some risking execution, as did satirist Turki al-Jasser. He argues Riyadh’s £200 tickets and five-star shows expose a regime’s failed bid to buy “carnivalisation” without genuine artistic freedom.

articles.title: ‘It’s over! It’s over!’ they shout, but people here in Gaza still fear what the future may bring | Hassan Abo Qamar
articles.trailText: Phase one of Donald Trump’s peace plan has brought joy and relief, yet it’s hard to believe this fragile peace will last, says Palestinian writer and journalist Hassan Abo Qamar
articles.summary: After Trump announced that Israel and Hamas signed phase one of his peace plan – a prisoner exchange freeing 20 Israeli hostages and about 1,950 Palestinians – Gaza experienced a fragile ceasefire. Residents welcomed relief: gas, flour, medical supplies, 400 daily aid trucks, open Rafah crossing, warm meals. Yet half Gaza remains occupied, families live in tents, and Netanyahu’s far-right coalition denounces any truce as betrayal. With extremists threatening his government and international pressure mounting, Gazans fear this fragile peace may collapse, awaiting further phases amid ongoing displacement and humanitarian need.

articles.title: Why is the US House speaker refusing to seat an elected Democrat? | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Adelita Grijalva won a landslide election for her Arizona seat. But Mike Johnson is defying the will of the voters
articles.summary: Adelita Grijalva, who won a special election to Arizona’s 7th congressional district, remains unseated as Speaker Mike Johnson refuses to swear her in, leaving her without an office or voting rights. Johnson reneged on his promise to seat her, likely to block her from becoming the crucial 218th signer on a discharge petition to force a vote on releasing Jeffrey Epstein files, embarrassing Trump and other Republicans. Critics warn this unprecedented procedural power grab denies voter will and risks setting a dangerous precedent for future transfers of power.

articles.title: My girlfriend is supportive as a partner, but completely baffled by my love of sports | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: It’s very difficult to explain your sporting woes and joys to someone if they don’t understand the base level appeal
articles.summary: Rebecca Shaw, a long-time Brisbane Broncos and Lions supporter, explores how her girlfriend of five-and-a-half years, though supportive, remains baffled by the intensity of her emotional investment in NRL, AFLW and A-League finals. Shaw traces her passion to childhood cricket and football rituals with her family, coins the term “sports empathy” for those who grasp the emotional stakes, and contrasts her partner’s limited understanding with solace found in her family and male camaraderie. She jokes that only family and her NRL group chat fully empathize with her highs and lows, and anticipates increasing demands on her partner’s empathy as Queensland teams chase further premierships.

articles.title: I never thought I'd say this, but I now understand the appeal of home schooling | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: More and more parents in England are opting their kids out of the education system. I could never do it, but ‘wellbeing days’ do sound nice, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: In England homeschooling notifications doubled since 2020 to 66,000 in 2024 (total ~111,700 students). Once fringe and religious/health-driven, it now attracts parents seeking flexible timetables and well-being days. Families craft “concentrated learning” weeks, combining core lessons with extracurriculars, clubs and social meet-ups. Socialisation remains via orchestra, sports or youth theatre rather than classes. Self-motivated teens use textbooks, YouTube and tutors to excel, some returning to school for A-levels. Critics worry about curriculum gaps and family strain, but advocates highlight reduced stress, holidays in term time and better suit for children who “don’t fit the mould”.

articles.title: Democratic candidates can win Rust Belt voters by … attacking the Democratic party | Jared Abbott and Bhaskar Sunkara
articles.trailText: Voters support progressive economic populism, our survey shows. They just don’t trust Democrats to deliver it
articles.summary: In a randomized trial of 3,000 Rust Belt voters across Pennsylvania, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, researchers found an eight-point Democratic penalty on identical economic populist platforms—up to 16 points in Ohio, 13 in Michigan, 11 in Wisconsin. When prompted, 70% offered negative views of Democrats, citing incompetence, dishonesty and disconnect rather than “wokeness.” Only robust anti-corporate messaging—capping prescription drug prices, taxing super-wealthy and corporations, exempting Social Security income, and legalizing long-settled undocumented workers—boosts appeal. Authors urge Democrats to critique their own establishment, adopt stronger populist frames and refocus on fairness to win back working-class voters.

articles.title: Here’s the direct effect of our NHS blame culture: babies die. Tragedy after tragedy, it can’t go on | Jeremy Hunt
articles.trailText: Until staff are unafraid to be open about genuine mistakes, however devastating, nothing will be learned – and nothing will change, says former health secretary Jeremy Hunt
articles.summary: Former health secretary Jeremy Hunt warns that the NHS’s entrenched “blame culture” prevents staff from reporting mistakes, contributing to around 4,870 baby deaths annually in the UK. While perinatal mortality fell 20% between 2013–23, maternal deaths—disproportionately affecting Black and Asian mothers—have risen post-pandemic, and two-thirds of maternity units still need improvement. Inspired by no-fault systems in Sweden and Japan, Hunt proposes automatic compensation to foster openness, learning and safer care. He cites the Morecambe Bay tragedy and a reconciliatory encounter between a bereaved father and midwife as proof that honesty, not litigation, saves lives.

articles.title: We research AI election threats. Here’s what we need to prepare for | Samuel Woolley and Dean Jackson
articles.trailText: Artificial intelligence endangers democracy – but it’s less about specific deepfakes and more about a bigger transformation
articles.summary: Researchers Samuel Woolley and Dean Jackson warn that AI poses long-term democratic threats beyond low-quality deepfakes: it could supplant genuine constituent-politician dialogue through data-driven outreach; concentrate power among tech oligarchs who will erode participatory governance; and undermine fact-based journalism as LLMs redirect audiences to corporate platforms. While policy proposals exist, political will is lacking, distracted by debates over immediate catastrophic risks or unbridled innovation. To safeguard democracy, AI deployment must be regulated proactively, rejecting the notion that its societal impact is inevitable.

articles.title: I met Priscilla Presley this week – and couldn’t believe she was in the same building as me | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: My Saturday felt mind-bending, from interviewing the woman who was married to Elvis to watching my team endure a 3-0 defeat to Millwall. How can one day contain so much, asks Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles describes meeting 80-year-old Priscilla Presley at BBC Wales for an interview promoting her memoir Softly, As I Leave You: Life After Elvis. He recounts his memory of hearing about Elvis’s death at ten but holds back, letting her discuss teenage marriage anxiety and motherhood calmly. He then speeds by train and tube to London Bridge, fights through a posse of coked-up Millwall fans who once feigned stabbing him, and watches his side lose 3-0. This surreal juxtaposition of celebrity intimacy and football chaos underlines his reflections on nostalgia, public life and modern British absurdity.

articles.title: Dogs name toys while elephants name each other. Animal language is more complex than we imagine | Helen Pilcher
articles.trailText: If we really want to grasp what animals are ‘saying’, we need to understand their communication on their terms, not ours, says science writer Helen Pilcher
articles.summary: Science writer Helen Pilcher argues animal communication is far more sophisticated and diverse than human-centric views allow. Dogs not only learn human word-buttons and categorize toys, but elephants use unique vocal “names” for group members, dolphins emit signature whistles, songbirds exhibit regional dialects and sperm whales employ click-based phonetic patterns. Beyond sound—colour, smell, electric signals and gesture enrich their lexicons. Ethologists from Jane Goodall to Cat Hobaiter reveal chimpanzees’ purposeful gestures. To truly decipher animal “speech” we must study it on their terms, not ours.

articles.title: Thatcher was born 100 years ago and her reign feels a lifetime away. Why is her effect on the country still so huge? | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: Today’s politicians need to learn that she is not the answer to contemporary problems, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Martin Kettle marks Thatcher’s centenary to argue that although only older Britons recall her 1979–1990 premiership, her imprint remains pervasive: the primacy of business over state, low-tax orthodoxy, home-ownership, EU scepticism, climate policy and deregulation. Yet her radical reforms did not solve core issues of public-sector efficiency or social cohesion—challenges subsequent leaders from New Labour through the Coalition to Starmer still grapple with. Kettle warns against nostalgic invocations: Thatcherism is neither the cure for today’s crises nor a settled legacy, but part of the dilemmas modern Tory figures continue to invoke and battle with.

articles.title: Worried about rising bills and getting by? Keir Starmer has the answer: try chewing a flag! | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: The PM wants to talk about patriotism when the issue that is really affecting people is the cost of living. If he doesn’t wise up, that dissonance will sink him, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Aditya Chakrabortty argues that the UK cost-of-living crisis—inflation, rising food, energy and housing costs—remains voters’ top concern, yet Keir Starmer’s recent speech obsessed with patriotism and flags mentions bills only twice. Despite households facing steep price hikes and one million in arrears, Westminster and the media prioritise asylum rhetoric over living costs (542 vs 45 articles). Without urgent intervention to curb prices, living standards could stagnate or shrink—a first in modern history—threatening Labour’s electoral prospects and democratic stability. “Let them eat flags” risks alienating financially strapped families.

articles.title: The EU has a secret weapon to counter Trump’s economic bullying. It’s time to use it | Johnny Ryan
articles.trailText: The anti-coercion instrument, or ‘trade bazooka’, is designed to shield against foreign pressure, says civil liberties campaigner Johnny Ryan
articles.summary: Johnny Ryan warns that the EU’s anti-coercion instrument – the so-called ‘trade bazooka’ – remains unused despite Trump’s threats and a humiliating US deal locking in a 15% tariff on EU exports. This inaction, he argues, undermines Europe’s democratic sovereignty and risks vassalage to Washington and Silicon Valley. Ryan urges Brussels to activate the tool: impose reciprocal tariffs, block US investments, strip IP rights, enforce digital laws, and phase out non-EU tech platforms. Immediate, robust enforcement, algorithmic reform and homegrown alternatives are essential to preserve Europe’s autonomy and signal global democratic resolve.

articles.title: As I prepare for another bushfire season in NSW, I wonder: will triple zero be there if I need it? | Michael Burge
articles.trailText: It’s up to telcos like Optus to ensure our emergency system works, but so far the only word you could use to describe our mobile signal is ‘intermittent’
articles.summary: In rural NSW near Deepwater, journalist Michael Burge recounts repacking his bushfire evacuation bag after triple-zero outages left communities unreachable, highlighting intermittent Optus/Telstra mobile coverage that undermines the Hazards Near Me app and emergency calls. Recalling October 2023 fires and an eight-day Telstra tower failure in Uralla, he urges stronger telco reliability. After initially hesitating to report smoke, he joined the Rural Fire Service to bridge gaps between residents and responders. Burge calls on telcos to ensure consistent mobile signals and for locals to volunteer to bolster bushfire preparedness.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Kemi Badenoch’s speech: following the path of denial, delusion and defeat | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Conservative leader offers no insight into her party’s past failure and no original ideas that might make it relevant to Britain’s future
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s first conference as Conservative leader reveals no fresh analysis of last year’s defeat or genuine ideas for Britain’s future. Her keynote blamed a ‘bloated state’ and immigration for economic woes, proposing public spending cuts, a third of civil service layoffs, reversing Labour tax rises, treaty breaches for mass deportations and ditching carbon targets. This stale, post-Brexit Tory dogma ignores the damage of 14 years in power, skirts Nigel Farage’s xenophobia and leaves a demoralised, shrinking party with no path to relevance.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Cop30: Starmer must stop havering and announce that he’s going to Brazil | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: With global heating on a dangerous trajectory, it would be unforgivable for the prime minister to miss the summit in Belém
articles.summary: Editorial urges UK Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer to commit to attending Cop30 in Belém, Brazil, as UN scientists warn that current emissions pledges fail to limit warming to 1.5°C. It highlights President Lula’s outreach to key players, recalls the Paris 2015 precedent of leaders driving ambition, and underscores the UK’s strong climate record. Warning against Tory vows to repeal the Climate Change Act and Reform UK–inspired backbench fears, the piece frames attendance as a moral and diplomatic imperative, a test of leadership vital for multilateral cooperation and keeping the Paris goals alive.

articles.title: If we want a better, more equal society, we need more tax. But more tax only works if big business pays their fair share | Grogonomics
articles.trailText: Trust in both the tax and political system will falter if people feel they are being punished for not paying tax while large companies legally get away with paying nothing
articles.summary: ATO’s 2023-24 corporate tax disclosure shows 28% of firms with >$100m turnover, including Santos Ltd and Ichthys LNG, paid zero tax despite generating $90bn+ revenue. Australia’s low tax burden, lower than Canada’s, leaves $133bn annually unraised and contributes to poor aged-pension and high senior poverty rates. Profit shifting and loss-carryforwards mask true earnings at Netflix Australia and others, costing ~$23.7bn in foregone revenue. Although a 15% global minimum tax and country-by-country reporting aim to plug loopholes, US resistance under Trump and corporate lobbying threaten reforms. Without fair big-business contributions, calls for higher taxes risk eroding public trust.

articles.title: Why Tony Blair just can’t kick the habit of imperial interference in the Middle East | Oliver Eagleton
articles.trailText: The Blair-Trump fantasy for postwar Gaza shows the former PM still thinks that free enterprise can solve all the world’s ills, says associate editor at the New Left Review Oliver Eagleton
articles.summary: Former UK PM Tony Blair and Donald Trump’s 20-point postwar Gaza blueprint proposes turning the Strip into a colonial-style special economic zone overseen by an international board chaired by Trump, with Hamas disarmed and governance handed to a business-run authority led by Blair and foreign financiers. The plan’s faith in “public-private partnerships” echoes Blair’s failed market-led interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan and Palestine, raising conflicts of interest over his ties to JP Morgan, Oracle’s Larry Ellison, Gulf monarchies and oil investors. Critics say it lacks legitimacy, mandate or consent from Gaza��s population, embodying a fusion of imperialist ambition and Trumpian dealmaking.

articles.title: Bari Weiss is a weird and worrisome choice as top editor for CBS News | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: When Weiss was named editor-in-chief, it was the latest turn in the network’s confounding departure from its roots
articles.summary: CBS News has appointed Bari Weiss—ex-NYT opinion editor and Substack founder—as its new editor-in-chief, a move decried as undermining the network’s storied tradition of unbiased reporting. Lacking broadcast news experience, Weiss is a polarizing figure known for her staunch Zionism and critique of ‘woke’ DEI initiatives. Paramount���s $150 million purchase of her Free Press and an earlier lawsuit settlement with Trump fuel perceptions of corporate capitulation. Critics warn her ‘bothsiderist’ approach and direct reporting to owner David Ellison mark another step in CBS’s drift from editorial independence.

articles.title: The best gig I ever saw cost £4. Spiralling concert prices are a cultural disaster | John Harris
articles.trailText: Tickets for big tours have vastly outstripped inflation, while smaller artists and venues struggle. The magic is in danger of being snuffed out entirely, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris warns that spiralling gig prices threaten live music’s democratic spirit. Since 1996 average UK tickets jumped from £16.99 to £105.60 (a 521% rise), far beyond inflation. Arena and stadium shows now cost £100+ face value, topped by dynamic pricing and resellers; VIP packages can exceed £850. Major acts push prices while smaller venues struggle or close, squeezed by energy costs, Brexit touring bonanzas and Ticketmaster’s 60% market share. Exceptions like Paul Heaton (£35 cap) and The Cure (£77.50 core) offer relief, but grassroots gigs face cultural peril.

articles.title: If a four-year-old can pronounce a name correctly, so can a politician | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: When someone’s name is repeatedly botched, we shouldn’t give the perpetrators the benefit of the doubt. Just ask NYC mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi criticizes prominent US politicians—including Andrew Cuomo, Kathy Hochul and White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt—for repeatedly mispronouncing NYC mayoral candidate and democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani’s name despite his spelling it out during debates. She argues such persistent errors signal deliberate othering of ethnic names, echoing past mispronunciations of Kamala Harris by David Perdue and Donald Trump. Mahdawi notes young children effortlessly pronounce “Mahdawi” and “Mamdani,” underscoring politicians’ disrespect and the need to stop intentional mispronunciations.

articles.title: We fear what Israel will do to us if they seize our ship. But we are not turning back | Naoise Dolan
articles.trailText: Our captured flotilla colleagues have been subjected to violence and degrading conditions in an Israeli prison. This has only made us more determined, says Irish writer Naoise Dolan
articles.summary: Since departing on 27 September, Irish writer Naoise Dolan and six others aboard the second Global Sumud flotilla press toward Gaza despite Israel’s night-time seizure in international waters of the first flotilla’s ships and abduction of 341 activists, 138 still detained at Ktzi’ot prison amid reports of water and food denial and violent abuse. Living in cramped quarters, the crew carries medicine and baby formula destined to save lives. Dolan argues the mission rejects charity framing to affirm Palestinians’ right to freedom and self-determination.

articles.title: I know the real Handsworth – it’s a far better place than Robert Jenrick’s toxic vision of Britain | Nazia Parveen
articles.trailText: The shadow justice secretary complained of a lack of integration in an area that has shown, time and time again, that it is for everyone, says Nazia Parveen, an assistant managing editor at the Guardian
articles.summary: In her Guardian column, Nazia Parveen, a Handsworth native, rebuts shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick’s description of the diverse Birmingham ward as a “slum” lacking integration. She evokes Benjamin Zephaniah’s poem to highlight Handsworth’s mix of Pakistani (25%), Indian (23%), Bangladeshi (10%), Black African/Caribbean (16%), mixed/other (10%) and white (9%) residents. Parveen recalls interwoven community life—from cricket games and shared cotton-factory shifts to solidarity during austerity, bin strikes and hospital visits—and argues Jenrick’s comments ignore systemic neglect and stoke division.

articles.title: Badenoch’s ‘thoughtful Conservatism’ turns out to be just the slower road to Faragism | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: The Tory leader’s intellectual meanderings have shrunk her party into little more than a holding pen for future Reform party candidates, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Rafael Behr argues that Kemi Badenoch’s vaunted “thoughtful Conservatism” has reduced the Tory party to a holding pen for Reform UK talent. With aging loyalists and zero youth appeal, the Tories have lost agenda-setting power and are eclipsed by Nigel Farage’s immigration-obsessed populism. Badenoch’s initial pledge of rigour yielded abstruse ideological detours, then a desperate lurch into Faragist policies—£47bn cuts, mass civil-service layoffs, ICE-style deportations, ECHR withdrawal, Climate Act repeal. Her pseudo-intellectual posturing has accelerated the party’s identity crisis rather than reviving it.

articles.title: Unity is desperately needed, but the EU prefers turf wars to facing down Russia | Paul Taylor
articles.trailText: Failure to agree a common defence strategy risks emboldening Vladimir Putin. The squabbles have to stop, says Paul Taylor of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: At an informal EU summit in Copenhagen, leaders failed to agree on a unified defence strategy to deter Russia, squabbling over command structures, funding for Ukraine’s resistance and Kyiv’s EU bid. Ursula von der Leyen’s plan for a multilayered eastern drone wall and other flagship defence projects was rebuffed by France, Germany and Italy as a commission power grab. National rivalries, from competing fighter jet programmes to divergent threat perceptions, block efficient joint procurement. This discord risks emboldening Putin, prompting calls for a Franco–British coalition of the willing to lead rearmament.

articles.title: The Guardian view on calls to ban sunbeds: prevention in healthcare raises hard questions about risks | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Regulating unhealthy habits is difficult. But if ministers intend to reduce illness, clarity and courage will be required
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns ministers must decide whether to ban commercial sunbeds amidst rising skin cancer rates and widespread flouting of child-use restrictions. Cancer experts and BMJ authors advocate an Australia-style prohibition as cost-effective, highlighting risks to young women in deprived areas. The piece contrasts decisive tobacco bans with delayed junk food and alcohol regulations, noting government revenue from “sin taxes” and pro-business tensions. It argues that in a free NHS, individual risky choices impose shared costs, so true prevention demands clarity and courage to curb gambling, ultra-processed food, sunbeds and similar health hazards.

articles.title: The Guardian view on political chaos in France: the gift that keeps on giving to Marine Le Pen and the far right | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Influential abroad, Emmanuel Macron’s strategic errors at home are bringing mainstream French politics into disrepute at a crucial moment
articles.summary: Facing perpetual government turnover after a poorly judged snap election, President Macron’s centrist coalition is deadlocked: his third PM in a year, Sébastien Lecornu, resigned after 27 days amid right-wing backlash. Macron’s refusal to soften austerity, cut deficits without straining public services or wealthy households, has deepened discord, weakened mainstream parties and handed Marine Le Pen’s National Rally a polling advantage. He even threatens a second dissolution and snap legislative poll, but risks repeating gridlock. With bond markets uneasy and 2027 elections looming, France’s political paralysis threatens a far-right surge despite Macron’s strong foreign policy record.

articles.title: I was feeling a little smug at how much I had helped a cancer patient. Then came a devastating text | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: Misfortunes shouldn’t have to compete to be meaningful but a combination that fills me with dread is cancer and mental illness
articles.summary: Australian oncologist Ranjana Srivastava recounts treating a woman in her sixties with two incurable cancers and chronic depression. To maximize survival she recommended skipping surgery and prioritized urgent radiation and specialist nursing support. Hours later the patient texted to cancel all appointments, overwhelmed by the complexity and her mental health struggles. Srivastava reflects on the systemic gap in continuity for psychiatric care amid cancer treatment, noting the cognitive overload faced by dual-diagnosis patients. She argues for embedding counsellors within oncology teams to prevent avoidable crises and improve outcomes.

articles.title: Is growing racism causing Black Americans to rethink parenthood? | Jerel Ezell
articles.trailText: To the bewilderment of researchers like me, the historical racial fertility gap has shrunk. Conventional explanations for this come up short
articles.summary: Jerel Ezell argues that rising awareness of persistent racism is leading Black Americans to reconsider having children, shrinking the historical fertility gap. Polls show only 37% of Black adults prioritize parenthood vs 51% of whites. Conventional explanations (marriageable men) fall short; fears of racial animus—amplified by 24/7 news, Trump-era policies, and anti-DEI cuts—offer clearer insight. Drawing on historical precedents from slavery to modern “childfree” forums, Ezell links political climates to birth declines and adverse maternal outcomes. He warns of weakened Black political influence and elder-care gaps, urging depoliticization of racial equity and framing fertility as a social good.

articles.title: It’s Tory conference: Boris-wave goodbye to a deluded party on its way to electoral annihilation | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: When both Reform and the Liberal Democrats are eating your lunch, and even Nadine Dorries has abandoned ship, it might just be time to call it, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: At the Manchester conference, the Conservative party grapples with dismal 15% polling and warnings from John Curtice that they ‘cannot even see the Himalayas’ en route back to relevance. Kemi Badenoch’s leadership feels hollow; Robert Jenrick’s sock-puppet theatrics and leaked racial remarks deepen divisions as 20 councillors defect to Reform UK. Mel Stride pledges 2016-level civil service cuts amid policy incoherence. Meanwhile, Boris Johnson’s belated net zero mea culpa fails to stem defections—including Nadine Dorries to Reform—and Liberals and Reform are poised to outpace the Tories at the next election, spelling electoral annihilation.

articles.title: Taylor Swift's ode to Travis Kelce is cringe – but is it worse than these other terrible lyrics?| Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The singer-songwriter has proved herself a modern-day Shagspeare with Wood, a paean to the penis. When it comes to shocking lyrics, though, it faces strong competition, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi critiques Taylor Swift’s lyric “Wood” from The Life of a Showgirl, calling its explicit Kelce references (“key that opened my thighs,” “magic wand”) cringe-worthy amid her squeaky-clean brand. She then ranks other famously awful lyrics: Jake Paul’s “England is my city,” The Killers’ “Are we human, or are dancer?��, Des’ree’s toast-versus-ghost quatrain, Tinie Tempah boasting of clothes at his aunt’s house, and Snap!’s “serious as cancer” line. Mahdawi’s tone blends satire and personal taste, exploring the fine line between daring wordplay and lyrical embarrassment across pop music history.

articles.title: The Partiful app is a ‘vibey’ nightmare. Here’s my party-invitation solution | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: This year was the year of Partiful, a purple mess that won’t even let me be passive-aggressive without chastising me
articles.summary: Humorist Dave Schilling laments his exhaustion with Partiful, a purple, Y2K-styled party-invite app built by ex-Palantir staff that centralizes events but shames “maybe” RSVPs with nagging prompts. He decries its ‘vibey’ aesthetic—a candy-coated, violet-puke interface—and recalls nostalgia for Facebook’s now-defunct events tab amid social-media fragmentation. He bemoans how standalone tools from Evite to Instagram invites offer one feature poorly. As a remedy, he urges hosts to ditch apps and revive handwritten invites: the tedium of pen, paper, envelopes and stamps will discourage frivolous party-throwing.

articles.title: I didn’t realise how much I loved my home town until a terrorist attacked it. I pray unity prevails there | Simon Hattenstone
articles.trailText: Last week��s attack on the synagogue in Crumpsall, Manchester, was also an assault on a model and diverse community, says Guardian features writer Simon Hattenstone
articles.summary: After a lone attacker struck Heaton Park synagogue, Hattenstone rediscovers his affection for Crumpsall – the north Manchester suburb where childhood illness, schooling and synagogue visits shaped him. Once dismissive of its ‘parochial’ middle-class Jewish enclave, he grew to cherish its layered diversity: ultra-orthodox and secular Jews alongside Muslims in varying observance, thriving side by side amid socioeconomic contrasts. Crumpsall’s 18,000 residents form a peaceful microcosm of coexistence. He urges resistance to divisive narratives, reminding that unity and love, not hate, define this community’s strength.

articles.title: I’m ready to join the brave new world of women who are leaving their family at home – and holidaying alone | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Women are ditching their families to seek adventures on their own terms. What took us so long, asks Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams tracks the surge of solo female travellers aged 45–60 abandoning family holidays to satisfy adventure impulses. Tour operator Jules Verne reports 46% of bookings are solo travellers, 70% of whom are women drawn to hiking, cycling and kayaking—pursuits mismatched with partners or teens. After mistaking a press-trip invite meant for another, fitter Zoe Williams, she discovered the thrill of self-directed, unhurried travel. Williams critiques the lingering social stigma—embodied by her stepmother’s reluctance—and wonders why it’s taken women so long to embrace independent holidays.

articles.title: US universities must reject Trump’s ‘compact’. It is full of traps | Jan-Werner Müller
articles.trailText: The administration is trying to make nine universities an offer they seemingly cannot refuse
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s proposed ‘compact’ offers nine universities preferential funding and White House perks in return for ideological loyalty oaths and government-mandated policies—capping foreign students at 15%, requiring patriotic civics courses, policing ‘incitement’ and engineering a ‘broad spectrum of viewpoints.’ Jan-Werner Müller argues it exceeds presidential powers, threatens academic freedom, and uses vague criteria to entrap institutions. He urges all nine to reject the compact, expose its hidden traps, and defend higher education’s autonomy against autocratic overreach and politically driven bureaucracy.

articles.title: I preached levelling up as the key to Tory success – but Boris Johnson didn’t do it. Now look at us | Justine Greening
articles.trailText: Social mobility and equality of opportunity is crucial to Britain’s success. The party that embraces those things will prosper, says former Conservative minister Justine Greening
articles.summary: Former minister Justine Greening argues the Conservatives squandered levelling up by failing to transform her social mobility agenda—equality of opportunity and ‘talent is spread evenly’—into policy after 2019. Johnson’s government spent two years debating definitions, delivered only superficial town funds and scrapped her successful ‘opportunity areas’ that boosted youth optimism by up to 18 points. Voters punished them for broken promises. As Labour and Reform UK adopt new rhetoric, Greening warns that rhetoric alone won’t suffice: only a coherent, evidence-based social mobility strategy can restore hope and win public trust.

articles.title: Disappearing people, disappearing morals – how two years has changed Gaza and Israel | Orly Noy
articles.trailText: There can be no healing until the world stares into and acknowledges the void torn open by this conflict, says Israeli journalist Orly Noy
articles.summary: Two years after the 7 October massacre, Israeli journalist Orly Noy describes Gaza as a void of disappearance—hundreds of thousands of Palestinians erased without records, morality hollowed, decency and hope obliterated. She decries Israel’s embrace of “total victory,” starvation killing a classroom of children daily, media censorship, and the erasure of opposition under Netanyahu and Ben-Gvir. Normalized genocide, public apathy, and brutal silencing of dissent have severed personal bonds and shattered humanity. Noy warns that true healing requires confronting the abyss this conflict has carved into Gaza and Israeli society.

articles.title: I didn’t think I’d ever say this: let’s hope the Tory party can be saved | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Britain badly needs a grownup party of the centre right. It won’t come from Badenoch – it may come from a new generation of one-nationers, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee argues Britain needs a centrist, ‘one-nation’ Tory revival to counter Kemi Badenoch’s far-right drift. Badenoch’s mimicry of Farage—promising to leave the ECHR, scrap the Climate Change Act and create an ICE-style removals force—alienates moderate and younger Tories, risks deepening divisions and handing seats to Labour or Reform UK. Traditional conservatives like Heseltine, Grieve and new activists such as Cody Butler seek a pragmatic, pro-Europe, pro-business platform to restore competence and social liberalism. Without this, Toynbee warns, the Tory party faces self-destruction under populist extremism.

articles.title: This war of revenge has lasted two nightmare years. There’s only one hope for peace: Israel recognising Palestine | Raja Shehadeh
articles.trailText: Donald Trump’s proposals are in play, but here in the West Bank we live in fear that the devastation of Gaza is coming our way, says writer and lawyer Raja Shehadeh
articles.summary: Palestinian writer Raja Shehadeh reflects on two years of Israeli retaliation since Hamas’s 7 October attack, which killed over 65,000 Palestinians and reduced 92% of Gaza’s housing to rubble. He chronicles decades of dehumanizing walls, checkpoints, house demolitions, settler violence and olive-tree felling, warning that West Bank communities live in fear of similar devastation. Despite global protests and Donald Trump’s Gaza plan, Shehadeh argues that only Israel’s formal recognition of Palestinian self-determination can end the cycle of perpetual war.

articles.title: Two years after 7 October and the kidnap of my parents, hate is in fashion. For all our sakes, we need compassion | Sharone Lifschitz
articles.trailText: So many were killed – yet on her release, my mother said ‘shalom’ to her captors. Let’s learn from that moment of grace, says Sharone Lifschitz, London-based film-maker and academic
articles.summary: Sharone Lifschitz recounts the Oct 7, 2023 Hamas assault on Kibbutz Nir Oz that abducted her 85-year-old mother and 83-year-old father, killed 23 members and traumatized the community. Her mother was freed after 17 days, greeting captors with “shalom”; her father’s remains were returned 502 days later. Two years on, with 48 hostages still held and Gaza’s devastation visible from her destroyed kibbutz, she decries rising hate—from death chants at festivals to antisemitism in the UK—rejects revenge, and honors her parents’ peace activism by urging compassion, empathy, and bridge-building across divides to end the war.

articles.title: In Spain, what once seemed impossible is now widespread: the young are turning to the far right | María Ramírez
articles.trailText: Migration is barely mentioned – instead, failed policies on housing, wages and employment are driving young voters into the arms of Vox, says María Ramírez, deputy managing editor of elDiario.es
articles.summary: Polls show nearly 40% of Spanish men and 20% of women under 34 support Vox, driven less by migration than frustration over housing, wages, employment and the perceived incompetence of mainstream parties during floods and wildfires. Vox’s anti-establishment brand appeals to disillusioned youth, despite its push to expel immigrants, curtail abortion and trans rights and weaken EU institutions. Experts argue the Socialist and Popular parties must shift from partisan bickering to deliver affordable homes, higher wages and genuine crisis management if they hope to win back younger voters. Although Spain’s economy is among Europe’s fastest-growing, young adults struggle with high rents and stagnant incomes, heightening intergenerational tensions.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s Gaza plan: the bloodshed must end, but this proposal betrays Palestinians | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: An end to the annihilation, and the release of Israeli hostages, is urgently needed. But lasting peace cannot be built on the denial of basic rights
articles.summary: After two years of Gaza war since Hamas’s October 2023 attack that killed 1,200 Israelis and Israel’s Gaza campaign killing over 67,000 Palestinians, there is urgent need for ceasefire, hostage release and resumed aid. Donald Trump’s 20-point plan—immediate ceasefire, full hostage and Palestinian prisoner exchange, aid flow, and a vague “board of peace” led by Trump–Blair—gains traction but both Netanyahu and Hamas reject key clauses. The proposal sidelines Palestinian rights by treating statehood as an “aspiration,” risks entrenching occupation, and demands sustained external pressure to avert further betrayal.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Tory conference: history’s revenge on Conservatism | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Speeches from the conference floor reveal a party out of ideas. Its leadership team is mistaking slogans for policy and nostalgia for purpose
articles.summary: At the Tory conference, leader Kemi Badenoch and shadow chancellor Mel Stride delivered fervent but vacuous speeches—recycling austerity and Thatcherite slogans without viable strategies. Facing polls that place the Conservatives potentially fourth and enduring historic lows, the party confronts an existential crisis born of its centrism’s failure. Successive leaders—Cameron’s market-first Triangulation, May’s duty-based minimalism, Johnson’s theatrics, Truss’s ill-fated gambit, Sunak’s caution—have faltered. Badenoch now proposes a harsh 150,000-deportation “immigration hit squad” as drama over design. The editorial warns that declared “the end of history” has rebounded on modern Conservatism.

articles.title: It starts with Palestine protests. But where will the crackdown on Britain’s democratic freedoms end? | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: In making dissent a privilege, not a right, Labour is crafting a repressive toolkit. Imagine it in the hands of a Farage government, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: In Britain, Labour’s new rules would turn protest from a right into a privilege, giving police power to restrict pro-Palestinian demos or jail dissenters. Successive governments have eroded freedoms; now a Manchester synagogue attack is used to justify curbs on anti-Israel protests, conflating criticism of genocide and war-crimes with antisemitism. Non-violent groups like Palestine Action are banned, thousands arrested. Owen Jones warns this toolkit could be seized by a future Farage government, marking a dangerous slide towards authoritarianism and the destruction of democratic protest.

articles.title: It’s Badenoch’s Tory show, 2025: like Britain seeing an old flame and remembering why we blocked their number | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: The conference offers a flailing leader, Trumpite policies and rivals jockeying for position. It is comical, but also worrying, says Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s debut as Tory leader at the 2025 Manchester conference felt like watching Britain’s ex fling a tantrum. Her radical pledges include quitting the European Convention on Human Rights, scrapping the Climate Change Act, shredding treaties on immigration and human rights, and creating a £1.6bn “removals force” modelled on US ICE. Shadow chancellor Mel Stride proposed £23bn in benefit cuts for non-citizens. Meanwhile rivals such as Robert Jenrick and Katie Lam jostle for post-Badenoch succession. With MPs halved and Reform rising, the party’s Trumpite turn underscores the rightward pull and signals the progressive fight ahead.

articles.title: Enjoying the implosion of the Tories? That’s understandable – but completely wrong | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The world’s most successful democratic party is in a death spiral of its own making – leaving no moderate bulwark between the moderate and truly far right, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams argues the UK Conservative Party is in a self-inflicted ‘death spiral’ after Kemi Badenoch’s uninspiring conference address, reflecting a shift toward far-right rhetoric to counter Reform UK’s surge. Potential alternatives like Robert Jenrick or newcomer Katie Lam, who couples traditional Tory imagery with anti-migrant posts, underscore this radical drift. Williams warns that celebrating the Tories��� collapse misunderstands democracy’s need for a stable mainstream right – a lesson from Weimar Germany. By embracing xenophobic soundbites and nationalist pageantry, the party sacrifices moderation and weakens civil society’s bulwark against extremism.

articles.title: Cycle tracking isn’t woo-woo or a tradwife tool. It’s essential education for everyone – no matter the gender | Freya Bennett
articles.trailText: The 24-hour day might be perfectly synced to men’s hormonal cycle – but the menstrual cycle takes a longer view
articles.summary: Freya Bennett recounts monthly slumps in motivation aligned with her menstrual phases, illustrating how cycle tracking reveals clear hormonal patterns that shape mood, energy and productivity. Dismissing it as “woo-woo” in youth, she later used the fertility awareness method—daily temperature and cervical fluid charting—to predict ovulation and confirm early pregnancy. Bennett urges compulsory high-school menstrual education—not as contraception but as fundamental bodily literacy for all genders, enabling early detection of disorders like endometriosis or PCOS. She cautions against tradwife and anti-birth-control co-option, emphasizing cycle awareness should expand personal choice, gender equality and health empowerment.

articles.title: Good and bad news for Zack Polanski: the Green conference was a joy, but now hopes are stratospheric | Adam Ramsay
articles.trailText: Members loved hearing from a leader who boldly reflects their views and isn’t afraid of the rightwing press. How far can he take the party?, says journalist and Green party member Adam Ramsay
articles.summary: At Bournemouth’s Autumn conference, new Green leader Zack Polanski electrified members with bold messaging on nationalising utilities, taxing wealth, drug decriminalisation and anti-racism. Standing ovations replaced past caution as delegates cheered expansion from 58k to 86k members, polling above 10%, 900 councillors and four MPs. Deputies Millward and Ali united the party, endorsing LGBT inclusion and a toolkit against racism. Controversial motions to phase out landlords and proscribe the Israeli military passed. Greens now target Welsh Senedd seats, London elections and mayoralties in Hackney, Norfolk & Suffolk and Brighton, facing high expectations and media scrutiny.

articles.title: Why does the supreme court keep bending the knee to Trump? | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: As a new term begins, the justices have continually failed to provide a check on presidential power – with disastrous consequences
articles.summary: Despite life tenure and US checks and balances, the Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority has ruled overwhelmingly—over 90% of emergency docket cases—in Donald Trump’s favor, akin to judges in Hungary and Turkey under Orbán and Erdoğan. Since his return to office, conservatives have allowed Trump to gut agencies, fire independent regulators, cut foreign aid, deport immigrants, and shrink Congress’s spending power. Critics accuse Chief Justice Roberts and colleagues of appeasement, embracing a unitary executive theory to let Trump dismiss officials at will. With approval ratings at an all-time low, many legal scholars warn the court’s deference endangers American democracy.

articles.title: One Bladder After Another: why bros are finally having to queue for the loo | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: There are few things more irritating than waiting outside the Ladies while men sail in and out of their own facilities. A new, very long film has changed all that, writes Guardian columnist Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington explores the unexpected phenomenon of men queuing for bathroom breaks during Paul Thomas Anderson’s nearly three-hour film One Battle After Another. With predominantly male audiences, lengthy runtime prompts long lines at men’s lavatories, a rarity compared to the usual women’s loo queues. Social media and Reddit users strategize “pee breaks” around plot points. Beddington notes gender-neutral toilets could slash waiting times but remain unpopular. She invokes comparisons to hockey games, Oasis gigs and Reddit’s “One Pee Bottle After Another” tactics, joking she might bring earplugs to witness this men-only queue phenomenon.

articles.title: A united Labour party is making Britain work better for all. We cannot allow our mission to be disrupted | Bridget Phillipson
articles.trailText: I’ve delivered for tens of thousands of schoolchildren, lifting them out of poverty – as deputy leader I can deliver for all, says education secretary Bridget Phillipson
articles.summary: Education secretary and deputy leadership hopeful Bridget Phillipson argues that a united Labour has delivered free breakfast clubs, revived Sure Start, reinstated maintenance grants and expanded free school meals to lift 100,000 children from poverty. She urges members to back her bid for a stronger mandate to tackle child poverty and broaden youth opportunity, warning that internal division fuels Tory critics and risks Labour’s second term. Phillipson promises to champion achievements, challenge privately where needed and unite the party to deliver for working people.

articles.title: The fury at home left me terrified of anger. Until a teacher showed me how to use it as a force for good | Marisa Bate
articles.trailText: In an eye-opening drama class, Miss Smith taught me that rage didn’t only belong to men, says journalist Marisa Bate
articles.summary: Marisa Bate recounts how living under her stepfather’s terrifying rages made her fearful of anger until her A-level drama teacher, Miss Smith, used an improv exercise on homelessness to show her that anger can be a positive force. This safe context awakened a sense of injustice and permission to feel and harness rage constructively. Miss Smith’s parting advice—“stay angry”—empowered Bate to reclaim anger from its abusive associations and channel it into activism. Today, she uses that deliberate, considered anger in her journalism on women’s rights, donations, marches and organizing, while still fearing male aggression.

articles.title: The real goal of 'Make America Healthy Again'? Woo-woo treatments for the rich, shrinking healthcare for the poor | Alexander Avila
articles.trailText: A new coterie of advisers around Robert F Kennedy Jr is shaping the US’s already exclusionary health system for the worse, says video essayist Alexander Avila
articles.summary: Under Trump’s new ‘Make America Healthy Again’ (Maha) push, RFK Jr-backed advisers Calley and Casey Means have reshaped US health policy to favor unproven ‘root cause’ wellness solutions. They cancelled $500m in vaccine research, fired thousands of agency staff and spread conspiratorial mistrust of mainstream medicine. Through HSA expansions and their Truemed platform, they aim to redirect trillions in public funds into a $6.3 trn wellness marketplace—selling saunas, cold plunges and supplements—while slashing $1 trn from Medicaid and Medicare, deepening inequities and weakening care for the poor.

articles.title: Don’t despair, Tories: look upon Reform and see your rightful and fitting legacy | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: If Kemi Badenoch wonders why her party conference looks and feels like a sideshow, perhaps she should reflect on the Conservatives’ 14 years in power, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: As Tory conference opens in Manchester, Nesrine Malik argues the Conservative party’s 14 years of culture wars, Brexit-fuelled jingoism and punitive immigration policies laid the groundwork for Nigel Farage’s Reform UK. What remains of the Tories has morphed, not died: their normalisation of separatism, anti-immigrant rhetoric and spectacle politics created a more extreme heir free from traditional Tory constraints. Economic stagnation among younger voters drove Conservatives toward culture-war diversions, undermining their governing ideology. Kemi Badenoch’s provocative pledges on net zero, CRT and an ICE-style removals force exemplify this legacy. Rather than lament Reform’s rise, Badenoch should “rejoice” in her party’s inheritance of the Tories’ efforts.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Jaguar Land Rover cyber-attack: ministers must pay more attention to this growing risk | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Cybercriminals pose a seismic and increasingly sophisticated threat to businesses and national security. Yet Britain seems remarkably ill-prepared
